                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           September 9, 2010 Thursday

Online jihadist proposes terrorist attack on Spain's second city

LENGTH: 384 words


Text of report by Spanish newspaper La Vanguardia website on 9 September

[Report by Isabel Ramos Rioja: "Jihadist Forum Proposes Carrying Uut Terrorist
Attack on Barcelona on 24 September"]

Suggestion: Carrying out a terrorist attack on Barcelona's Villa Olimpica subway
station on 24 September. Why this subway station and that day? On an online
jihadist forum, an activist nicknamed Amin Al-Qa'idah answered: "Above that
subway station, there is the city's largest zoo, which will be packed with
visitors on that day." However, he did not explain why the zoo would be packed
on 24 September. Every Barcelonan knows why: The La Merce festival [held in
honour of Barcelona's patron, the Virgin of Mercy] is held in Barcelona on 24
September.

The idea of carrying out a terrorist attack in Barcelona appeared on an online
forum last night. The forum used to be administered by Faical Erradi, who was
arrested in Poble Nou de Benitatxell (Alicante [southeastern province]) on 27
August for moderating the Ansar al-Mujahidin online forums.

Last night, anti-terrorism sources told La Vanguardia that these kinds of
messages, which they see as wishful thinking rather than genuine threats, are
usually posted on other websites, which they monitor closely to verify their
threat level.

In any case, the views expressed on the forum showed anger over the arrest of
Erradi. That is why the already known threats against Spain were reiterated.

After uploading pictures of Spanish nuclear power stations as possible targets
for an attack, as well as some memorable slogans, such as "Terrorism is coming
for you, Spain," Amin Al-Qa'idah posed a question to his colleagues: "What do
you think about the city of Barcelona?" He answered this himself: "It is a
beautiful and seductive city. May God give the Muslims this city as easy booty."
According to the activist, an attack on Barcelona's transportation system,
especially the "Villa Olimpica" subway station, may succeed.

On a subway map, Amin Al-Qa'idah pinpointed the location of the subway station,
but failed to find the exact location of the closest hospital, which he placed
in Bellvitge. Amin Al-Qa'idah concluded by expressing this desire: "May God let
the lions of Al-Qa'idah succeed in their attack."

Source: La Vanguardia website, Barcelona, in Spanish 9 Sep 10

LOAD-DATE: September 9, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                                  The Express

                           September 9, 2010 Thursday
                                Scottish Edition

Jet passengers' terror at v iolent attacks by 'gangster '

BYLINE: By David Scott

SECTION: NEWS; 19

LENGTH: 406  words


HOLIDAYMAKERS watched in horror as a man was pinned down after assaulting
another passenger and a member of the air crew on an easyJet flight.

Colin Coats had been segregated at the rear of the plane after punching the
passenger in the face on a flight from Glasgow to Alicante.

When he learned police would board the aircraft on its arrival, he leaned
forward and whispered into a steward's face that if police came on board, he'd
kill him.

Minutes later, as officers entered the cabin, Coats, 40, kicked the steward
George Barron's legs and clawed at his face and neck.

As police pinned him down, he turned to a female passenger, Rosaleen O'Donnell,
39, told her she was a "specky bitch" and said he'd burn her house down, Paisley
Sheriff Court heard.

Ms O'Donnell said: "He said he knew gangsters, would find out where I lived and
would burn me and members of my family too.

He was angry and out of control. I was scared."

Steward Darren Donaldson intervened after the initial incident and saw the other
passenger with a lump on his face the size of an egg.

Coats' girlfriend, Angela, told him angrily: "You shouldn't have done that. He
was only speaking to me." Mr Donaldson said that Coats had been moved to the
rear of the plane for others' safety.

"He told me he had worked for Air Traffic Control, " he said, "and should have
known better.

"He seemed very angry. He was breathing deeply and shaking. He apologised then
started a tirade of abuse towards other passengers. It was extremely violent.

"He said to one he would 'throw acid your face' and said 'I'm Colin Coats. I'm a
gangster, Do you know who I am?'" At Paisley Sheriff Court, Coats, 40, of
Glasgow, denied conducting himself in a disorderly manner, uttering threats of
violence and committing a breach of the peace by placing others in a state of
fear and alarm, and assaulting George Barron.

He told the court he had no recollection of the flight and his first memory was
of waking up in his Spanish villa one or two days later and being told of media
reports. "It put me in a state of shock and disbelief, " he said.

Witness Amjed Khaliq, 42, said that, on the day of the flight, he and Coats had
been in a bar in Glasgow's west end with a group who were indulging in "high
jinks". He said Coats had been passed a glass of cola, which may have been
spiked with Acid.

Sheriff Neil Douglas described the claim as "incredible" and convicted Coats,
deferring sentence until October 5.

LOAD-DATE: October 4, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Colin Coats kicked air steward

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2010 EXPRESS NEWSPAPERS
                              All Rights Reserved

                                  The Express

                           September 9, 2010 Thursday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Scotland

Jet passengers' terror at violent attacks by 'gangster'

BYLINE: David Scott

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 407 words


HOLIDAYMAKERS watched in horror as a man was pinned down after assaulting
another passenger and a member of the air crew on an easyJet flight.

Colin Coats had been segregated at the rear of the plane after punching the
passenger in the face on a flight from Glasgow to Alicante.

When he learned police would board the aircraft on its arrival, he leaned
forward and whispered into a steward's face that if police came on board, he'd
kill him.

Minutes later, as officers entered the cabin, Coats, 40, kicked the steward
George Barron's legs and clawed at his face and neck.

Gangsters

As police pinned him down, he turned to a female passenger, Rosaleen O'Donnell,
39, told her she was a "specky bitch" and said he'd burn her house down, Paisley
Sheriff Court heard.

Ms O'Donnell said: "He said he knew gangsters, would find out where I lived and
would burn me and members of my family too. He was angry and out of control. I
was scared."

Steward Darren Donaldson intervened after the initial incident and saw the other
passenger with a lump on his face the size of an egg.

Coats' girlfriend, Angela, told him angrily: "You shouldn't have done that. He
was only speaking to me." Mr Donaldson said that Coats had been moved to the
rear of the plane for others' safety. "He told me he had worked for Air Traffic
Control," he said, "and should have known better.

"He seemed very angry. He was breathing deeply and shaking. He apologised then
started a tirade of abuse towards other passengers. It was extremely violent.

"He said to one he would 'throw acid your face' and said 'I'm Colin Coats. I'm a
gangster, Do you know who I am?'"

At Paisley Sheriff Court, Coats, 40, of Glasgow, denied conducting himself in a
disorderly manner, uttering threats of violence and committing a breach of the
peace by placing others in a state of fear and alarm, and assaulting George
Barron.

He told the court he had no recollection of the flight and his first memory was
of waking up in his Spanish villa one or two days later and being told of media
reports. "It put me in a state of shock and disbelief," he said.

Witness Amjed Khaliq, 42, said that, on the day of the flight, he and Coats had
been in a bar in Glasgow's west end with a group who were indulging in "high
jinks". He said Coats had been passed a glass of cola, which may have been
spiked with Acid.

Sheriff Neil Douglas described the claim as "incredible" and convicted Coats,
deferring sentence until October 5.

                               4 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                  Guardian.com

                           September 9, 2010 Thursday

Qur'an burning would increase risk of terror attacks - Interpol

BYLINE: Matthew Weaverguardian.co.uk

LENGTH: 690 words

ABSTRACT

Police agency warns of 'strong likelihood' of violent attacks if burning goes
ahead, as US pastor says he could cancel event if he is contacted by Barack
Obama

FULL TEXT

Interpol, the international police agency, has warned of an increased risk of
terror attacks if the planned burning of the Qur'an by extremist US pastor Terry
Jones takes place on Saturday.

"If the burning goes ahead as planned there is a strong likelihood that violent
attacks on innocent people would follow," Interpol, acting partly on a request
from Pakistan, said in a statement.

The warning came as Jones, a pentecostal preacher from Gainseville, Florida,
hinted he might be prepared to call off the burning - planned to mark the
anniversary of the 9/11 attacks - if he was contacted directly by Barack Obama,
the state department or the Pentagon.

"That would cause us to definitely think it over," Jones told USA Today. "That's
what we're doing now. I don't think a call from them is something we would
ignore." But he said that as things stood he was "not convinced that backing
down is the right thing".

The White House confirmed it was discussing whether to contact Jones - whose
church, The Dove World Outreach Centre, has a congregation of about 50 - to ask
him to call off his plans. Pentagon spokesman Geoffrey Morrell said: "That
possibility is currently under discussion within the administration. I don't
believe they've come to any resolution yet."

Barack Obama earlier joined mounting worldwide condemnation of the plan, saying
the event would be a "recruitment bonanza for al-Qaida".

The US president told ABC News: "If he's listening, I hope he understands that
what he's proposing to do is completely contrary to our values as Americans,"
Obama said.

Obama said the event was a stunt that would boost support for terrorism. "This
could increase the recruitment of individuals who would be willing to blow
themselves up in American cities or European cities," Obama said.

The president repeated a warning by General David Petraeus, the commander of US
and Nato forces in Afghanistan, that the burning would endanger US troops.

"And as a very practical matter I just want him [Jones] to understand that this
stunt could greatly endanger our young men and women who are in uniform," Obama
said.

David Cameron's spokesman said earlier that the prime minister strongly opposed
any attempt to offend members of a religious group.

Religious leaders of all faiths have warned against the event, with statements
of protest coming from both the Vatican and the Archbishop of Canterbury.

This week protests took place in the Afghanistan capital of Kabul where effigies
of Jones were burned alongside the American flag.

Anjem Choudary, the former leader of the banned Islamist organisation Islam4UK,
told Reuters he was calling on radical Muslim groups around the world to burn
American flags outside US embassies in retaliation.

Today about 200 lawyers and civilians marched and burned a US flag in the
central Pakistani city of Multan, demanding that Washington prevent the book
burning.

The foreign ministries of Pakistan and Bahrain issued some of the first official
denunciations in the Muslim world, with the latter calling it a "shameful act
which is incompatible with the principles of tolerance and co-existence".

The president of Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim nation, has written
to Obama asking him to stop the bonfire. Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono told Obama
that images of the Qur'an in flames could "threaten world peace", according to
his special adviser Heru Lelono.

India's home office has asked its country's media to exercise restraint in
reporting on the planned burning.

The rightwing US presidential hopeful Sarah Palin urged Jones and his supporters
to reconsider. Writing on her Facebook page she said: "People have a
constitutional right to burn a Qur'an if they want to but doing so is
insensitive and an unnecessary provocation - much like building a mosque at
Ground Zero."

In a statement on his faith foundation website, Britain's former prime minister
Tony Blair, said: "Rather than burn the Qur'an I would encourage people to read
it".

LOAD-DATE: September 10, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2010 Guardian Unlimited
                              All Rights Reserved

                       BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           September 10, 2010 Friday

AU, regional body condemn terrorist attacks on peacekeepers in Somalia

LENGTH: 247 words


Text of report in English by state-owned Ethiopian news agency ENA website

Addis Ababa, 10 September: Special representatives of the United Nation and
African Union and IGAD [Inter-Governmental Authority for Development]
facilitator for Somalia peace and national reconciliation have jointly condemned
the terrorist attack on AMISOM [African Union Mission in Somalia] troops in
Mogadishu, AU told ENA [Ethiopian News Agency] in a statement on Thursday [9
September].

The special representatives of the secretary-general, Dr Augustine P Mahiga, and
the chairperson of the African Union Commission for Somalia, Ambassador Boubacar
Diarra, and the IGAD facilitator for Somalia peace and national reconciliation,
Hon Kipruto arap Kirwa, have jointly condemned the deadly terrorist attack on
AMISOM troops.

It said the terrorist act resulted in the unfortunate and tragic loss of two
AMISOM soldiers, three others seriously wounded and the death of several
civilians.

The three envoys condemn, in the strongest terms possible, this "heinous act of
terrorism" occurring as it did on the eve of the holy feast of Id al-Fitr - a
solemn day of peace, compassion and mercy.

The three envoys express their heartfelt condolences to the people, the
government of Uganda and the members of the bereaved families.

The envoys also undertook a joint working visit to Somalia on 9 September for
consultations with President Shaykh Sharif Ahmed, it said.

Source: ENA website, Addis Ababa, in English 10 Sep 10

LOAD-DATE: September 10, 2010

                             Cambridge Evening News

                           September 10, 2010 Friday

â€˜Attack by terroristsâ€[TM] staged to teach staff

LENGTH: 326 words


Dozens of Cambridge security staff have been taught how to face a potential
terrorist attack on the city.

Guards from the Grand Arcade, Hyline Security and Bridgegate Security were
among 50 'pupils' put through a simulated terrorist attack.
The counter-terrorism event, Project Argus, was held at The Guildhall.


The annual free training session was organised by Cambac (Cambridge Business
Against Crime) with the police and Cambridgeshire County Council.
Tony Harold, Cambac chairman and general manager of Hyline Security, said: "It
is essential that Hyline Security, and other security companies working within
Cambridge, fully support Cambac in such initiatives as Project Argus.
"As a company operating extensively within the city centre, it is important that
our staff are able to react professionally to any terrorist attack to help to
prevent further injuries, and to offer a calming effect in what would be
difficult and uncertain circumstances."
Shamsu Choudhury, emergency management officer for the county council, was
delighted at the turnout.
He said: "It was really good to see businesses, emergency services and the local
authorities working together.
"The event was focused on a simulated terrorist attack. However, the key
messages of prevention, incident management and business continuity apply to all
sorts of situations."
Det Sgt Karen Boxall warned that the threat of a terror attack was a reality and
urged companies to get involved in training staff in how to cope with it.
She said: "The threat from terrorism is unfortunately both real and current."
The police were keen to help make crowded places safer and more resilient to
terrorist attack, she said.
"Through Project Argus we can all work together for the benefit of the people of
Cambridgeshire, as well as our visitors, enhancing their experiences of our
shopping centres and the night time economy," she added.
Businesses can email  to find out more.

LOAD-DATE: September 10, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: CambridgeNews

                               7 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                              DAILY MAIL (London)

                           September 10, 2010 Friday

KORAN BURNING 'WILL SPARK TERROR ATTACKS'

LENGTH: 457 words


OBAMA AND INTERPOL WARNING OVER PASTOR'S STUNT

BY SAM GREENHILL

TERROR attacks are 'likely' if a U.S. pastor goes ahead with his threat to burn
the Koran on the anniversary of 9/11, Interpol warned last night.

The international police agency said there was 'a strong likelihood that violent
attacks on innocent people would follow'.

Its alert to governments worldwide came amid widespread condemnation of Pastor
Terry Jones's plans, which have enraged many Muslims.

President Barack Obama warned: 'This is a recruitment bonanza for Al Qaeda. You
could have serious violence in places like Pakistan and Afghanistan.

'This could increase the recruitment of individuals who'd be willing to blow
themselves up in American cities or European cities.'

Pastor Jones and members of his Dove Outreach Church in Gainesville, Florida,
intend to throw 200 copies of the Islamic holy book on a bonfire tomorrow, the
ninth anniversary of the September 11 terror attacks on New York and Washington.

Mr Jones, 58, who now carries a gun after receiving more than 100 death threats,
said he wanted to send a message to radical Muslims that they could not impose
their beliefs on the U.S. So far he has refused to call off his International
Burn-A-Koran Day.

Demonstrations are already under way in Muslim countries against the stunt.

Protesters burned a U.S. flag in the Pakistani city of Multan. Their banners
included one that read: 'If Koran is burned, it would be beginning of
destruction of America.'

In Mahmud Raqi, capital of the Afghan province of Kapisa, hundreds of angry
protesters burned an American flag and chanted 'Death to the Christians'. In
Britain, Muslim extremist Anjem Choudary threatened to burn the American flag
outside the U.S. embassy in London tomorrow.

'Muslim blood is boiling with anger,' he said. 'I will not be surprised if there
are more terror attacks because of this.'

The secretary general of the Muslim Council of Britain, Farooq Murad, said:
'This proposed burning would be highly offensive.

'We call on those planning this malicious and mischievous act to refrain from
deliberate provocation.' At Westminster, David Cameron's spokesman said: 'We
would strongly oppose any attempt to offend any member of any religious or
ethnic group. We are committed to religious tolerance. We would not condone the
burning of any book.'

Foreign Secretary William Hague condemned the Koran-burning ceremony as 'selfish
and provocative in the extreme'. He said it 'would be offensive not just to
Muslims but to all supporters of religious freedom and tolerance worldwide'.

U.S. officials have said they are powerless to stop the Koran burning, as Mr
Jones is protected under the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, which
allows freedom of speech.

LOAD-DATE: September 9, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Papers


                   Copyright 2010 Associated Newspapers Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved

                          The Journal (Newcastle, UK)

Bollard plan to stop terror attack

SECTION: A; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 31 words


ONE of the main shopping streets in Newcastle city centre  is to have bollards
installed at every entrance as part of measures to stop a terror attack. The
move will cost £450,000. Page 15

                               9 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                               Belfast Telegraph

                               September 11, 2010
                                  Main Edition

It's hard to believe but it really is nine years since 9/11. And I bet you can
remember exactly what you were doing the moment you heard that two airplanes had
slammed into the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center as America suffered the
worst terrorist attack in its history.

SECTION: Pg. 2

LENGTH: 308 words


It's hard to believe but it really is nine years since 9/11. And I bet you can
remember exactly what you were doing the moment you heard that two airplanes had
slammed into the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center as America suffered the
worst terrorist attack in its history.

Even now the footage of those burning buildings -- and their rapid collapse --
still shocks. That afternoon, I was working in these newspaper offices where we
swiftly brought out a late edition of the Belfast Telegraph, its front page
capturing the full horror of the unfolding events.

At work and at home, everyone was horrified and frightened by the scenes that
had unfolded on TV.

How much worse, though, for those who had loved ones caught up in the attacks.
Perhaps most poignant of all were the last messages of those who knew they were
about to die and who phoned husbands, wives, mothers, fathers, sisters and
brothers to tell them how much they loved them and to say goodbye.

This week we talk to Deena Burnett, who was one of those who received just such
a call from her husband, Tom.

She'd seen the two planes hit the Twin Towers on the television news and was
desperately worried about her husband, who was catching a plane that morning.

Ironically, when she first heard his voice on the phone, she assumed he'd called
to tell her he was safe. Tragically, he'd called to tell her he was on a
hijacked plane, Flight 93 ...

Elsewhere, we talk to the gorgeous Sharon Corr about life with her Belfast
barrister husband Gavin Bonnar, being a mum and her plans to get back with her
sisters and brother to make more music.

Plus, we've got some great ideas for creating a nursery fit for the daughter of
a prime minister, delicious salads to keep you munching healthily through autumn
and a rundown on the jobs you need to do in your garden now.

See you next week,

Gail Walker

LOAD-DATE: September 11, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: UN


                Copyright 2010 Belfast Telegraph Newspapers Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved

                              10 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                           Express and Echo (Exeter)

                          September 11, 2010 Saturday

Biblical story of jonah has a lesson for pastor;
Well, i wonder if he will have done it. As I write this, an American
fundamentalist Christian minster from Florida was planning to burn publicly
copies of the Koran today in protest at the terrorist attacks on September 11
2001 - by Muslim fundamentalists.

SECTION: Pg. 16

LENGTH: 542 words


Perhaps it would be better to say: by misguided fanatics who claimed to be
acting in the name of Islam, the Muslim religion.  The truth is that the true
spirit of Islam would repudiate such acts of terrorism.  In the same way, the
true spirit of Christianity would repudiate the public burning of the Koran.

That's not to say that the two religions are the same as each other.  They are
not, though there are of course points of contact.  Nor is it to pretend that
there have not been plenty of times when people of both religions have made the
mistake of using violent force to establish or secure their own understanding of
the faith they belong to.  Undeniably, there have.

However, we should never make the mistake of confusing the wrong actions of some
of its adherents with the faith itself.  That, it seems to me, is what Pastor
Jones is doing.  I hope and pray he will have been persuaded not to go ahead.

The events of September 11,  2001, remain engraved on my mind.  I was in America
that week, and like many people have a story to tell.  It's too long to tell in
one week, but I will serialise it later in the autumn over a six-week period
when I will be away.  Meanwhile, I was reminded this week of a biblical story
which I think has something to say to Pastor Jones.

You probably remember there was one about a chap called Jonah who was rescued
from the stormy seas he had been thrown into by being swallowed into the belly
of a whale  - literal translation: a big fish - and then spewed out onto dry
land.  But do you remember the rest of the story?

As we have it, it is written by an unknown Jew sometime in the 5th, or possibly
4th, century BC.  But the story he tells has probably been around in legendary
form for several centuries before that.  Jonah was a real man, a prophet
advising a king in Northern Israel in the 9th century BC.

But in the story Jonah receives a call to go to a foreign city  - Nineveh,
capital of the big empire of the time -  and pronounce God's judgement and the
great calamity in store for them.

He is terrified and runs off to sea - as far away as he can get.  A storm blows
up and Jonah confesses to the non-Jewish sailors that he might be responsible.
Throw me over, he says, and the storm will stop.  The sailors try to avoid doing
so but eventually give up.  They are brought to faith as a result of all this.
Meanwhile Jonah is saved by the fish.

Then comes a second call to Nineveh.  This time he goes and to his amazement his
preaching works.  Everyone in Nineveh, including the king, responds and repents,
turning their lives around.  As a result the calamity is averted. But still
Jonah is not happy.  He now feels rather a fool and complains that God's
compassion makes him look stupid.  He goes into the desert to sulk, where God
works on him through a shady bush which comes up and then disappears: 'Should I
not be concerned for the people of Nineveh and its animals?' God asks.

We aren't told how Jonah responds in the end, but it is very clear what the
author is saying: there is no limit to the breadth of God's saving love, to his
desire to reach out in compassion to all.  We, like Jonah, are called to be part
of the process of extending that love and compassion.

Jonathan MeyrickDean of Exeter

LOAD-DATE: September 12, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: 63


                        Copyright 2010 Express and Echo
                              All Rights Reserved

                              11 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                               The Sun (England)

                          September 11, 2010 Saturday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Ireland

My sister's 9/11 death will haunt me forever;
FAMILY RELIVES TERROR ATTACK NIGHTMARE

BYLINE: NICK BRAMHILL

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 279 words


A HEARTBROKEN Irish man who lost his sister and niece in the 9/11 terror attacks
has told how he'll NEVER come to terms with their murder.

Tragic Ruth McCourt, 45, and her daughter Juliana, four, were on the second
United Airlines flight al-Qaeda villains crashed into New York's Twin Towers.

And today, on the nightmare's ninth anniversary, Juliana's distraught Cork
brother Mark, below, reveals his on-going torment since 2001.

Mark, 49, said: "I've moved on from it as best I can, but the scars still remain
and they always will.

"I think about what happened every single day. At times what happened doesn't
seem real. It almost seems like something out of a James Bond movie.

"I've tried to understand the motivation of those who carried out the attacks
and have travelled to the Middle East to try and get an understanding of the
radical fundamentalism."

Brave Mark added: "I'm very concerned 9/11 could happen again. Compassion and
diplomacy are the only way we're going to bridge the gap with extremists. I've
also learnt forgiveness, and often wonder if the terrorists really understood
the full repercussions of what they were doing.

"I have had to move on, because there is no point in being angry."

"The world has changed. The countless deaths of American and British soldiers
over in Iraq and now Afghanistan, most of whom are under 20, are as a
consequence of 9/11."

Mark and his family will gather to remember Ruth and Juliana, and other victims,
in Cork today.

It's believed one-sixth of the 2,973 people killed in the attacks were of Irish
heritage.

A website irishtribute.com has been set up for friends and family to pay tribute
to the victims.

irishsun@the-sun.ie

Scars

LOAD-DATE: September 13, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Aboard doomed jet ... Ruth & Juliana

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: SUN

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           September 13, 2010 Monday

Slovene daily says world is "divided" after terror attacks in USA

LENGTH: 216 words


Text of report in English by Slovene news agency STA

Maribor, 13 September (STA) - Daily Vecer sees a divided world nine years after
the terror attacks in the US. It suggests in its commentary on Monday that the
US has played its part in this with its actions in the aftermath of the attacks.

Nothing is as it was before September 11, writes Vecer. After the attacks the US
was perhaps as united as never before, but President George W. Bush and the
hawks in his administration abused this.

"The US, the cradle of democracy, legally tortured prisoners, abducted suspects
around the world, privatised the war effort with the help of security and
logistics corporations, and loosened the foundations of the global economy."

"The wars were started easily, but can be finished only seemingly - the one in
Iraq has apparently ended twice already...This Devil's work has not even eluded
President Obama, who is sending more troops to Afghanistan."

Vecer believes that Florida pastor Terry Jones's acting on his threat to burn
the Koran would only have additionally fuelled this clash of civilisations.

And although Rev Jones changed his mind, he will come away with more followers
of his Church, the paper writes under "Clash of Civilisations".

Source: STA news agency, Ljubljana, in English 0400 gmt 13 Sep 10

LOAD-DATE: September 13, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

* Terror attack man  stable

BYLINE: NO BYLINE

SECTION: NWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 68 words


A TEENAGER is today stable in hospital after being attacked by a man in
Renfrewshire at the weekend.

The 18-year-old was assaulted by a hooded thug as he walked in Huntersfield
Road, Johnstone, at around 9pm on Friday.

The attacker made off towards Cartside and the victim was taken to Royal
Alexandra Hospital, Paisley suffering from cuts.

Police say anyone with information on the attack should call 01505 404 000.

                              14 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                           September 13, 2010 Monday

Imam speaks out on Qur'an burning row: Act 'could have provoked fresh terrorist
attacks' Far-right UK group joins anti-Islam protests

BYLINE: Ewen MacAskill Washington Robert Booth

SECTION: GUARDIAN INTERNATIONAL PAGES; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 675 words


The New York imam at the centre of plans to build an Islamic centre near Ground
Zero said yesterday that disaster had been narrowly averted over the planned
burning of copies of the Qur'an by the Florida pastor Terry Jones.

In his first comments since the row escalated into a national and international
crisis, the imam, Feisal Abdul Rauf, said the act could have provoked fresh
terrorist attacks against the US.

After a series of conflicting and confusing statements over the previous 48
hours, Jones finally confirmed on Saturday that he was not going ahead with his
plan, "not today, not ever".

But some damage had been done by the pastor's threats and thousands of
protesters took to the streets in Afghanistan yesterday for the third day in a
row. Three were shot, with one seriously injured, amid threats to storm US
military bases.

While media attention focused on Jones, desecration of Qur'ans took place
elsewhere across the US on the ninth anniversary of the 9/11 attacks. Copies of
the Muslim holy book were torn up in New York and Washington, and burned in
Tennessee and Kansas.

Little publicity was given to these events, with the main US networks deciding
not to cover such stunts. Most said in advance that they would not have
broadcast Jones's book burning event.

With anti-Muslim sentiment reaching levels not witnessed in the US at any point
since the 2001 al-Qaida attacks on New York and Washington, rival rallies were
held in New York for and against Rauf's proposed cultural centre.

In an interview with the ABC network, Rauf said Jones's planned book burning
"would have strengthened the radicals, it would have enhanced the possibility of
terrorist acts against America and American interests".

He said he intended to go ahead with the cultural centre, and expressed concern
about a rise in anti-Muslim feeling across the US. "How else would you describe
the fact that mosques around the country are now being attacked?"

The imam did not meet Jones, who flew to New York from Florida on Friday. The
pastor, in an apparent face-saving exercise, claimed he had abandoned his
burning ceremony because Rauf had agreed to meet him and to move the location of
his centre. Rauf denied the claims.

Members of the far-right English Defence League flew to New York to join the
rally against the centre. The group's leader, who goes by the pseudonym Tommy
Robinson, was refused entry at JFK airport and put on a plane back to the UK,
according to the anti-Islam website Gates of Vienna. But others in the group
were allowed in.

Members of the EDL and other European rightwing organisations, including Geert
Wilders, the Dutch leader of the Party for Freedom, were pictured at the
demonstration holding banners with the slogans No Mosque at Ground Zero, The
more Islam, the Less Freedom, No Sharia, and No Surrender.

One of the US organisers of the campaign against the centre, Pamela Geller, has
in the past praised the EDL and said she has been in contact with the group.

Barack Obama, at a 9/11 ceremony at the Pentagon on Saturday, repeated his calls
for restraint, saying: "As Americans, we are not, and never will be, at war with
Islam." He said the US would stay true to its traditions as a diverse and
tolerant country.

But his pleas appeared to go unheeded at isolated ceremonies across the country.
Websites in Tennessee showed pictures of two pastors, Bob Old and Danny Allen,
burning copies of the Qur'an in Springfield. The Daily Beast website reported
that in Topeka, Kansas, members of the Westboro church burned a Qur'an in front
of the media.

A Christian group tore pages from the Qur'an outside the White House on
Saturday. In New York an unidentified man tore pages from the Qur'an and set
them alight outside the planned Islamic centre.

Captions:

Anna Sereno, from Brooklyn borough, holds a picture of her son Arturo, who was
killed in the 9/11 attacks aged 29, at a commemoration ceremony held near Ground
Zero in New York on Saturday Photograph: Jason DeCrow/AP

Members of the English Defence League demonstrate in New York at the weekend

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political

                           September 14, 2010 Tuesday

Terror group may have planned attack in west Indian city - official

LENGTH: 481 words


Text of report by Indian news agency PTI

Mumbai, 13 September: Three security establishments in Nashik city including
Indian Army's Deolali camp were recceed by arrested Lashkar-i-Toiba [LT] terror
suspect Shaikh Lalbaba Mohammed Hussain for a Lahore Police Academy-type attack,
Maharashtra Anti-Terrorist Squad (ATS) said on Monday [13 September].

A terror strike probably similar to that of the 2009 Lahore Police Academy
attack was planned on the three establishments as per instructions from LT
handlers in Pakistan, a senior ATS official said.

"The Deolali camp, Maharashtra Police Academy and Police Commissionerate in
Nashik were on the hit list of Shaikh alias Bilal," the official said.

"There may have been a plan of an attack similar to that of terror strike on
Lahore Police Academy," the official said on condition of anonymity.

On 30 May last year, heavily armed terrorists stormed a police academy near
Lahore in Pakistan, killing at least 27 policemen in an eight-hour siege that
ended with four terrorists being shot dead and six captured alive by security
forces.

Bilal, arrested for allegedly preparing for terror strikes in the western Indian
state of Maharashtra last week, was staying in Nashik with two fake identities
and conducted recce of these three locations since May as per the instructions
of his aide Mirza Himayat Baig, held in connection with Pune blast, the official
said.

"Baig was directed to select these targets by LT handlers in Pakistan," the
official said.

The fake identities assumed by 27-year-old Bilal were Amin Manik Parekh and
Sutar Iqbal. He was arrested under Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act from
Nashik.

During his stay in Nashik, Bilal was working as CNC lathe machine operator in
Satpur industrial area and used to work in shifts, the official said.

"Whenever Bilal had leisure time, he visited these places a number of times to
get details as what is the area of the targets, how many exit and entry points
they have etc," the official said.

They were in the 'early stage' of the terror plan, the official said, adding
photographs of these targets were also seized from them.

According to the ATS, Bilal had visited LT camps in Pakistan between January
2008 and early 2010 where he received advanced training in use of sophisticated
weapons and making bombs. He had sneaked into India thrice during the period
through the Bangladesh and Nepal borders.

In January, Baig along with Mohsin Choudhary and Mohammad Ahmed Zarar Siddibappa
alias Yasin, alleged Indian Mujahideen (IM) members, had held a conspiracy
meeting at his

Gold internet cafe in Udgir in Latur district to select their targets and German
bakery was chosen as it was frequented by foreigners.

Baig was also in contact with Zaibuddin Ansari, an alleged LT member wanted in
2006 Aurangabad arms haul case, the ATS said.

Source: PTI news agency, New Delhi, in English 1726gmt 13 Sep 10

Suspect in August terrorist attack found dead in Russia's south

LENGTH: 158 words


Excerpt from report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Stavropol, 15 September: The body of Aleksandr Kim, who was the main suspect in
the August terrorist act in Pyatigorsk, has been found in the Predgornyy
District of Stavropol Territory, a source in the law-enforcement agencies told
Interfax-South today.

"The body of 42-year-old Aleksandr Kim was found in Stavropol's Predgornyy
District with gunshot wounds," the source said.

The source said that Kim was the owner of the VAZ-2106 [Zhiguli model 6] car
which exploded outside a cafe in Pyatigorsk on 17 August.

Interfax has not yet received official confirmation of this information.

It was reported that on 17 August an explosion occurred near a cafe on Ulitsa
Kirova [street[ in Pyatigorsk, as a result of which more than 30 people were
injured. An explosive device left in a VAZ-2106 car went off. [Passage omitted]

                              17 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                          September 15, 2010 Wednesday

Front: Real IRA says it will target UK bankers: Exclusive Republican terror
group vows to resume mainland attacks

BYLINE: Henry McDonald Ireland correspondent

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 914 words


Banks and bankers are now potential targets for the Real IRA, leaders of the
dissident republican terror group have warned in an exclusive interview with the
Guardian. Despite having only 100 activists they also said that targets in
England remained a high priority.

In an attempt to tap into the intense hostility towards the banks on both sides
of the Irish border they branded bankers as "criminals" and said: "We have a
track record of attacking high-profile economic targets and financial
institutions such as the City of London. The role of bankers and the
institutions they serve in financing Britain's colonial and capitalist system
has not gone unnoticed.

"Let's not forget that the bankers are the next-door neighbours of the
politicians. Most people can see the picture: the bankers grease the
politicians' palms, the politicians bail out the bankers with public funds, the
bankers pay themselves fat bonuses and loan the money back to the public with
interest. It's essentially a crime spree that benefits a social elite at the
expense of many millions of victims."

But security sources in Northern Ireland say that the Real IRA lacks the
logistical resources of the Provisional IRA to prosecute a bombing campaign
similar to the ones that devastated the City of London in the early 1990s or the
Canary Wharf bomb in 1996. Although the Real IRA has access to explosives it has
yet to carry out large-scale bombings.

The terror group stressed in a series of written answers to the Guardian's
questions that future attacks would alternate between the "military, political
and economic targets". It is the first time the Real IRA has engaged in such
open

anti-capitalist rhetoric or focused on the role of the banking system.

The leaders also threatened to intensify the group's terror campaign on all
fronts.

"Realistically, it is important to acknowledge that we have regrouped and
reorganised and emerged from a turbulent period in republican history.

"We have already shown our capacity to launch attacks on the British military,
judicial, and policing infrastructure. As we rebuild, we are confident that we
will increase the volume and effectiveness of attacks," the organisation said.

One element in the Real IRA's recent activity has been a wave of so-called
"punishment" shootings and beatings of those they deem "antisocial elements" in
nationalist working class areas. In Derry alone the Real IRA and other aligned
groups have shot around two dozen men over the last 18 months.

The Real IRA's leadership was unapologetic over what its critics have described
as "rough justice". The group believes such attacks are popular and can garner
support in areas where the communities were previously alienated from the
police.

"These actions are taken as a last resort to protect the community. We are an
integral part of the community and the people in them are our eyes and ears. The
fact is that the British police force is rejected by republican communities and
people naturally turn to us for help.

"The vast majority of issues are resolved by negotiation, a small percentage
require more direct forms of intervention including punishment shootings and
expulsions," they said.

On the political front they dismissed Sinn Fein's claims that its electoral
strategy would ultimately yield a united Ireland despite the majority of
nationalists in Northern Ireland still voting for Sinn Fein and an overwhelming
majority backing the peace process.

The Real IRA insisted, however, that support for them was building and they had
turned away hundreds of young disaffected nationalists because they didn't have
the capacity to absorb so many members.

"From the point of view of republican communities, there is still a heavily
armed British police force that casually uses plastic baton rounds, CS gas and
Tasers, carry out house raids, stop and search operations and general
harassment.

"There's still a 5,000-strong British army garrison, a new MI5 HQ in Belfast,
and a British secretary of state. Republican communities are still subjected to
sectarian parades and the right to protest is being met with intimidation and
violence."

On the subject of recent reports of talks between dissident republicans and the
Dublin and London governments the Real IRA said: "There are no talks with either
the British government or the Free State Administration.

"The IRA is not unwilling to talk, in fact there needs to be talks . . .
however, talks need to deal with the root cause of the conflict, namely the
illegal British occupation of Ireland. We are mindful, though, that the history
of such approaches from the British has been characterised by a lack of
integrity, a lack of willingness to address the causes of conflict, and has been
motivated by a self-serving agenda." Northern Ireland's deputy first minister
and Sinn Fein MP, Martin McGuinness, also came in for strong criticism. The
former chief-of-staff of the IRA and key Sinn Fein negotiator recently claimed
that he had knowledge that dissidents were holding secret discussions with the
two governments.

"Martin McGuinness is a British Crown minister who has a vested interest in
causing mischief among republicans. His job is to administer the Queen of
England's writ in Ireland . . . However, if he has any evidence to back up his
claims, he should make it public," the Real IRA said.

Leader comment, page 32 >=

Captions:

The IRA bombed targets in the City during the 1990s. Now the Real IRA may use
the same tactic Photograph: Rex Features

                             Paisley Daily Express

                          September 16, 2010 Thursday
                                 First Edition

TRASHED;
Terror gang attacks house

BYLINE: JOHN LEES

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 413 words


A RAMPAGING gang of thugs armed with baseball bats and golf clubs brought terror
to a Paisley street early yesterday.

The yobs caused thousands of pounds worth of damage as they targeted a house in
Ferguslie Park, leaving a trail of destruction in their wake. Every window on
the ground floor of the house was smashed and two cars which were parked nearby
were also vandalised. It's understood a woman in her 50s was in the
semi-detached home in Tannahill Terrace when the gang struck in the early hours
of yesterday. morning. Neighbours in the street refused to talk about the
incident and some claimed they had heard nothing.

However, a resident in a neighbouring street, who was too scared to be
identified, told the Paisley Daily Express: "I could hear screams while all this
was going on. "Whoever did this was determined to cause as much damage as
possible and they certainly left a real mess behind them. "It looks like they
were out to terrify someone and I imagine they succeeded in doing that." The
Express understands that a gang of seven young men were responsible for the
frightening attack. As well as smashing several windows of the house in
Tannahill Terrace, both panes of glass on the front door were also holed.

The gang then turned their attention to a silver Mercedes which was sitting in
the driveway and a black Vauxhall Corsa which was parked in the street. Every
window of the Corsa was smashed and glass littered the inside of the car and the
roadside. Even a headlamp was smashed. There were also several dents on the
bonnet as it was struck by baseball bats or golf clubs. Two side windows on the
Mercedes were smashed and there had been attempts to break the windscreen. A
wooden fence in the front garden of the house was also damaged in several
places. The woman who was inside the house at the time was not injured but was
left badly shaken by the ordeal.

Two weeks ago, police were called to Tannahill Terrace in the early hours of the
morning to stop fighting in the street involving rival gangs. Two men were
injured in that incident but it is not clear if it is linked to yesterday.'s
attack. Last night, detectives appealed for anyone who has information about
this latest incident to come forward. One officer said: "We need the public's
help. If anyone saw or heard what happened in Tannahill Terrace, they should let
us know. "Whatever information you have, ring Paisley Police Office on 0141 532
5900 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111."

LOAD-DATE: September 16, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: pe

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           September 17, 2010 Friday

Turkey's president condemns "terrorist" attack; vows to take "necessary" steps

LENGTH: 260 words


Text of report in English by Turkish semi-official news agency Anatolia

Istanbul, 16 September: Turkish President Abdullah Gul condemned the terrorist
attack in southeastern part of the country on Thursday.

President Gul told reporters, "we are profoundly sorry about killing of nine
people in a terrorist attack in the southeastern province of Hakkari. Small
children are injured in the attack. This attack proved once again the brutality
and inhumanity of terror."

"I harshly condemn killing of civilians in acts of terror. Our state will never
leave its citizens alone against the terrorist organization. We will take all
necessary steps to eradicate the terrorist organization," he added.

Meanwhile, another condemnation came from France.

Bernard Valero, spokesman for French Foreign Ministry, strongly condemned the
bloody attack. He offered French people's condolences to those who lost their
beloved ones in the attack. Valero also extended France's support to Turkey in
its fight against terrorism.

Meanwhile, the death toll was corrected as nine. Earlier, it was reported that
ten people lost their lives in the attack.

The Governor's Office said in a statement that since one of victims had two
names and victims' bodies were smashed beyond recognition, there was a confusion
about death toll.

Nine people were killed and four others including a 3-year-old kid and a
15-month baby were injured when a land-mine went off in the province of Hakkari
while a minibus was passing earlier in the day.

Source: Anatolia news agency, Ankara, in English 1510 gmt 16 Sep 10

                              21 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                           September 17, 2010 Friday
                                   Edition 2;
                                National Edition

Terror attack risk is doubled;
Irish renegades and al-Qaeda are ready to strike, says M15 chief 100 Britons
training in camps run by al-Qaeda

BYLINE: Duncan Gardham

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1,2

LENGTH: 1026 words


BRITAIN is facing a wave of terrorist attacks on two fronts from a new
generation of al-Qaeda extremists and Irish Republican militants who could
strike on the mainland, the head of MI5 warns.

In his first public speech on the national security threat for three years,
Jonathan Evans will say today that his officers are engaged in an "intense
struggle" against Muslim radicals and Irish nationalists.

It is only "a matter of time" before Britain is the victim of an attack from
extremists based in Somalia, the director-general of the security service adds.

There has been a "persistent rise in terrorist activity and ambition" in
Northern Ireland over the past three years, says Mr Evans. Terrorists in Ulster
are using increasingly sophisticated weaponry to launch "reckless" attacks that
could kill civilians.

"While at present the dissidents' campaign is focused on Northern Ireland, we
cannot exclude the possibility that they might seek to extend their attacks to
Great Britain as violent Republican groups have traditionally done," he says.

Mr Evans, who has briefed David Cameron and Nick Clegg on the threats, says
there remains "a serious risk of a lethal attack taking place".

"I see no reason to believe that the position will signifi-cantly improve in the
immediate future," he adds.

He uses his speech to appeal to the Government not to abandon control orders,
the measure under which terrorist suspects are electronically tagged and put
under house arrest. There are nine suspects who are subject to the orders.

The Liberal Democrats had promised to scrap the measure and it is now being
considered under a wider review of counter-terrorism legislation.

Whitehall sources have told The Daily Telegraph that control orders are likely
to be retained in some form.

Mr Evans says MI5 is "committed to prosecutions wherever possible", but adds:
"It is a sad fact that for all sorts of good reasons terrorist threats can still
exist which the criminal justice system cannot reach. The Government cannot
absolve itself of the responsibility to protect its citizens just because the
criminal law cannot, in the particular circumstances, serve the purpose."

Mr Evans tells the Worshipful Company of Security Professionals in the City of
London that every day, hundreds of officers were fighting an "intense struggle"
to identify and investigate terrorists.

"The secret nature of this struggle makes it hard for those not directly
involved to understand some of the skirmishes," he adds. At any one time, MI5
had a "handful" of investigations that involved the "real possibility of a
terrorist attack being planned against the UK", he says. "Most turn out to be
the real thing."

The percentage of "priority" plots linked to al-Qaeda in the tribal areas of
Pakistan had dropped from 75 per cent two years ago to 50 per cent now. The
threat had increased from Somalia and Yemen.

Mr Evans says a "significant number" of British residents are training in camps
run by the al-Qaeda-linked group al- Shabaab. As many as 100 Britons of
Pakistani, Bangladeshi and West African backgrounds had travelled to Somalia.

The country "shows many of the characteristics that made Afghanistan so
dangerous as a seedbed for terrorism in the period before the fall of the
Taliban," he says. "I am concerned that it is only a matter of time before we
see terrorism on our streets inspired by those fighting alongside al- Shabaab."

Mr Evans says there has been a "surge in casework" related to Yemen and adds:
"There is a real risk that one of [preacher Anwar al-Awlaki's] adherents will
respond to his urging to violence and mount an attack in the UK."

In Northern Ireland, there were now thought to be about 600 hardline Republicans
involved in terrorist activity, around half the number during the peak of IRA
activity in the 1980s, sources said.

The director-general says there are "increasing signs of co-ordination and
co-operation between groups", resulting in 30 attacks or attempted attacks this
year. The terrorists were using a greater variety of techniques from shootings
to large vehicle bombs. They had improved their capability in the use of
explosives.

The vast majority of attacks had been directed at the security forces but Mr
Evans says the terrorists have been "reckless, often putting members of the
public at risk" with vague warnings of the type that resulted in the deaths of
29 civilians in Omagh in 1998.

MI5 is likely to face a budget cut of 10 per cent but sources said the agency
believed it could cope with that level.

Mr Evans says the idea that every attack is preventable is a "nonsensical way to
consider terrorist risk". "Risk can be managed and reduced but it cannot
realistically be abolished and if we delude ourselves that it can, we are
setting ourselves up for a nasty disappointment," he says.

Read Mr Evans's full speech at telegraph.co.uk/news

Lesson to be learnt from Ulster history

The security service has recently reinforced its presence in Northern Ireland
for the second time as it tries to cope with a network estimated at 600
dissidents.

Mr Evans, who worked on fighting Irish terrorism for MI5 in the 1980s and 1990s,
said that in the past few years "insufficient weight" had been given to studying
the pattern of history, in which hardliners had continued the "armed struggle"
whenever mainstream republicans had rejoined constitutional politics.

MI5 took over counterterrorism operations in Northern Ireland from the police in
2007, moving 400 officers to Belfast.

Growing threat in 'ungoverned areas'

As the threat from al-Qaeda's leadership - hemmed into the tribal areas of
Pakistan - has diminished, the threat has grown elsewhere.

MI5 is worried by the growth in so-called "ungoverned areas", particularly
Somalia and Yemen. Somalia is of greater concern because up to 100 Britons have
travelled to the country, where some have died fighting for the terrorist group
al-Shabaab. A student from west London blew himself up as a suicide bomber in
Somalia three years ago.

Al-Shabaab professes to global ambitions but its attacks have been mainly
limited to Somalia. It caused shock in Uganda in July by setting off bombs that
killed 74 people.

LOAD-DATE: September 17, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: DTL


                  Copyright 2010 Telegraph Media Group Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                              22 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                  Guardian.com

                           September 17, 2010 Friday

How much are we really under threat from terror attacks?

BYLINE: Richard Norton-Taylorguardian.co.uk

LENGTH: 524 words

ABSTRACT

Richard Norton-Taylor: The screaming headlines in today's papers show how hard
it is for the head of MI5 to make the case for its work

FULL TEXT

"Terror attack risk is doubled," shrieks the headline on the front page of the
Daily Telegraph. "Security services fighting terror on more fronts than ever,"
claims the Times on page three. He may not mind the headlines, he may even
welcome them, but it's not what Jonathan Evans, the head of MI5, said.

The security and intelligence agencies make their case like any other lobby. But
they have a particular problem. We know what the armed forces and the police are
up to because they are either in full view of the public (the police) or
fighting and dying for Queen and country (British troops in Afghanistan). MI5
and MI6, however, are involved in intelligence-gathering, by definition a covert
activity.

Yet from time to time they want to make their case in public, and indeed they
should. The trouble is they do it so rarely that when they do, their comments
are taken out of all proportion. Hence today's headlines, quoted above.

Evans, who  the  (one of the City's newest livery companies), said the threat
from dissident republican groups in Northern Ireland was growing, something that
is manifestly obvious, and that there was a serious potential threat from UK
nationals returning from jihadist training and fighting in Somalia, something
the spooks have been warning about for some time.

Evans correctly warned that the assumption that terrorism was 100% preventable,
which he said had been imported from the US media, was "nonsensical". Yet he
also said that while his agency's capabilities had improved in recent years,
"there remains a serious risk of a lethal attack taking place". He added: "I see
no reason to believe that the position will significantly improve in the
immediate future."

Intelligence-gathering and countering terrorism is, crucially, a question of
judgment, nuance, and managing risk. The security and intelligence agencies are
unlikely to minimise the threat, publicly at any rate. Yet exaggerating it can
lead to cynicism and the proverbial danger of crying wolf.

There can be no doubt that Evans has briefed David Cameron and Nick Clegg. MI5
will not escape the cuts completely but should be able to cope with the 10% or
so the Treasury may demand. Judging by Evans' speech, the security service is
concerned more by the  of the mass of anti-terror legislation introduced under
13 years of Labour. "The government cannot absolve itself of the responsibility
to protect its citizens just because the criminal law cannot, in particular
circumstances, serve the purposes," he said, in an apparent reference to control
orders.

"The secret nature of this struggle [investigating people suspected of being
involved in terrorism] makes it hard for those not directly involved to
understand some of the skirmishes that come into the public domain," he
continued. This sounds like special pleading. If it is, the question is: is it,
unlike those headlines, justified?

LOAD-DATE: September 17, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2010 Guardian Unlimited
                              All Rights Reserved

                              23 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                               The Sun (England)

                           September 17, 2010 Friday
                                   Edition 2;
                                    Scotland

Terror of M8 kids as bus is attacked;
TARGETED BY THUGS

BYLINE: PAUL DRURY

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 132 words


YOUNG kids screamed in terror as a bus full of pilgrims was attacked by thugs on
a motorway in the centre of Glasgow yesterday.

Dozens of adults and children were being ferried to Bellahouston Park on the M8
through Charing Cross when the rear window of their coach "exploded".

One nine-year-old girl was cut on the face by flying glass as the coach's entire
window blew in.

It is believed something was thrown from a bridge or a raised area of the
motorway.

One mum said: "Everyone was shaking and the kids were crying.

It is shocking that this should happen."

The pilgrims, from Our Lady of Lourdes Church in East Kilbride, were told to
stay on board until a replacement coach arrived, around 30 minutes later.

The attack came just hours before the Pope's motorcade passed along the stretch
of road.

                                  The Express

                          September 18, 2010 Saturday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Scotland

MUSLIM PLOT TO KILL POPE;
Bogus street cleaners held Police swoop to foil a 'terror attack' on Pope

BYLINE: John Twomey; David Pilditch; Nathan Rao

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1,4,5

LENGTH: 869 words


ISLAMIC terrorists disguised as street cleaners allegedly hatched an audacious
plot to blow up the Pope.

The threatened attack was foiled at the 11th hour after police raided a cleaning
depot in London as the suspects prepared to start their shift yesterday.

Last night six men - all believed to be North Africans aged between 26 and 50 -
were being questioned by detectives.

Five suspects were detained at the cleaning depot and the sixth was held at his
home yesterday afternoon.

Searches were being carried out at 10 addresses across the capital and police
seized computers, mobile phones and other items.

Pope Benedict XVI was said to have remained "totally calm" when he was informed
about the threat yesterday morning.

A £1.5million ring of steel has been put in place for the first official Papal
visit to Britain and security procedures were immediately reviewed but the
Pontiff's schedule continued as planned.

It is feared plotters with links to Al Qaeda planned "a double blow to the
infidel" by assassinating the head of the Roman Catholic church and slaughtering
hundreds of pilgrims and well-wishers.

The suspected plot was smashed after Scotland Yard officers swooped on the depot
in Marylebone, central London, at 5.45am after a tip-off just hours earlier.

A security source said last night: "We had to act and arrest them. We had
reasonable grounds to suspect they would carry out an attack.

"We could not take the risk that they would mount an attack on the Pope which
might lead to his death and the deaths of many others."

The suspects worked for Veolia Environmental Services, a contractor employing
650 staff to keep the streets of Westminster clean.

The depot was searched by officers from the Yard's Counter Terrorism Command. A
second business premises was also searched. Officers later carried out raids on
eight residential properties in north and east London, searching for  weapons,
bomb-making materials, maps and other suspicious items.

The five men detained are aged 26, 27, 36, 40 and 50. At least three are
believed to originate from Algeria while a fourth is thought to be a Tunisian
national. A sixth man, aged 29, was arrested at a house in north London.

The suspects were being detained last night at a central London police station
on suspicion  of the commission, preparation  or instigation of acts of
terrorism.

The depot where the men worked is less than a mile from Hyde Park where Pope
Benedict is due to hold a prayer vigil this evening. His wellpublicised route
takes him along The Mall past Buckingham Palace.

Up to 85,000 worshippers have been issued special "pilgrim's passes", with
ticket holders having to  arrive up to five hours before the Pope.

As street cleaners the men would have been able to move freely and
inconspicuously through the crowds.

An investigation is also under way to determine if the foreign nationals had
entered Britain legally and were entitled to work here.

Last night a Scotland Yard spokesman said: "As a result of the arrests policing
arrangements for the Papal visit were reviewed and we are satis- fied that our
policing plan remains appropriate. The itinerary has not changed and there is no
change to the threat level."

He added: "The initial searches have not uncovered any hazardous items."

Last night, Gian Paul, 31, owner of a restaurant near the cleaning depot, said:
"When I arrived this morning there were tons of police with dogs.

"The cops ran in and said they were from immigration. They made them all stand
up - the guy who told me said he felt like he was in a film.

Threat

"All the employees were made to put their hands on their heads. Then more police
came in and took some of the workers away.

"The man who told me about this didn't know the names of the people who were
arrested."

Dr Leith Penny, of Westminster City Council, said: "Security is of critical
importance and can never be taken for granted and so our congratulations must go
to the police authorities for their swift action."

The German-born Pontiff was alerted of the threat yesterday morning, the day
after his arrival in Britain for the historic four-day visit.

Vatican spokesman Father Federico Lombardi said: "We are totally confi- dent in
the work of the police and Scotland Yard.

"They have already said that the information that they have collected
demonstrates there is no need to change anything on the programme of the Pope
and the security measures." Last night a Vatican source said: "Publicly the
incident is being played down but privately the arrests verge towards the
serious side and came as a result of intelligence work."

Senior police officers said there was no information ahead of the visit to
suggest any "specific group" wanted to attack the Pope.

A spokesman for the Catholic Bishops' Conference of England and Wales said: "We
have absolute confidence in the security operation to protect both the Pope and
the public.

"The Pope is enjoying a wonderful visit, warmly welcomed wherever he goes."

The alleged plot is believed to be the second planned assassination on the Pope
recently. In April, Moroccan students Mohamed Hlal, 26, and Ahmed Errahmouni,
22, were deported from Italy, strengthening fears that Al Qaeda were seeking
recruits there.

                                   1 Edition

Terror police foil Pope attack plot;
Six held after suspects are arrested at gunpoint

BYLINE: Martin Williams

SECTION: HS - NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 324 words


SIX men working as street cleaners have been arrested by police officers
investigating a suspected terrorist plot to attack Pope Benedict XVI during his
state visit to the UK.

Five of the suspects, understood to be of Algerian origin, were arrested at
gunpoint in London by officers from the Metropolitan Police s Counter Terrorism
Command shortly before 6am yesterday, after information emerged overnight that
the pontiff could be in danger.

The sixth man was arrested elsewhere in the UK capital almost eight hours later.

The force has not ruled out a connection to a plot to assassinate the pontiff
involving North African students in Italy earlier this year.

All six men were working for Veolia Environmental Services, a contractor that
employs 650 on-street staff to keep Westminster s streets clean, Westminster
City Council said.

As the Pope and the Archbishop of Canterbury held an evening prayer service in
Westminster Abbey, Scotland Yard confirmed a sixth man, aged 29, had been
arrested under the Terrorism Act 2000 and was being questioned. He had been held
by officers at a residential property in north London shortly before 2pm.

The men were all taken to a central London police station to be questioned.

The first five men held   aged 26, 27, 36, 40 and 50   were arrested at Veolia s
Chiltern Street depot, when their shift was due to start, on suspicion of the
commission, preparation or instigation of acts of terrorism.

Their homes in north and east London were scoured for evidence. Police were
standing guard outside the Marylebone rubbish depot where the cleaners worked,
which is less than a mile from Hyde Park, where the Pope is due to hold a prayer
vigil this evening.

The depot remained cordoned off for several hours as officers scoured the
premises. As street cleaners, the men would have been able to move
inconspicuously through crowds.

Sources said no weapons, bomb materials, maps, planning materials or other
suspicious

                                    Ireland

Pope 'plot': six held;
Terror alert as pontiff makes strongest attack on secular society

BYLINE: David Brown ; Ruth Gledhill ; Adam Fresco

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 324 words


Police investigating an alleged plot to assassinate the Pope arrested six people
yesterday, less than 24 hours before a vigil by 100,000 Catholics in Central
London.

Five street cleaners were seized less than a mile from Hyde Park, where the
pontiff will lead prayers today. A sixth man was arrested in North London.

Details of the alleged plot emerged as the Pope laid out his strongest challenge
to secular society yet in an address to politicians and civic leaders at
Westminster.

"Some people even think that festivals such as Christmas should be discouraged,"
he said, "in the questionable belief that it might somehow offend those of other
religions or none." Attacking equality legislation, he said: "There are those
who argue... that Christians in public roles should be required at times to act
against their conscience." He spoke of "worrying signs of a failure to
appreciate not only the rights of believers to freedom of conscience and freedom
of religion but also the legitimate role of religion in the public square".

Scotland Yard ordered the raids at 5.45am after receiving a tip-off overnight
containing specific information about the suspects. Senior officers said that no
weapons, ammunition, maps, explosives or other "hazardous items" had been
discovered during initial searches. They said that the arrested men, some of
whom are from Algeria, were not known to the police or security services.

However, background checks led to the decision to arrest the cleaners
immediately at Westminster City Council's depot close to Baker Street. "It was
too much of a risk to let these men run," said a senior source. The cleaners,
aged 26, 27, 36, 40 and 50, were arrested on suspicion of the commission,
preparation or instigation of acts of terrorism.

Armed police also raided eight homes in North and East London and another
business premises in Central London. The arrested men were being questioned at a
Central London police station.

                               The Times (London)

                          September 18, 2010 Saturday
                                   Edition 2;
                                National Edition

Pope 'plot': six held;
Terror alert as Benedict makes strongest attack on secular society

BYLINE: David Brown ; Ruth Gledhill ; Adam Fresco

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 395 words


Police investigating an alleged plot to assassinate the Pope arrested six people
yesterday, less than 24 hours before a vigil by 100,000 Roman Catholics in
Central London.

Five street cleaners were seized within a mile of Hyde Park, where Benedict XVI
will lead prayers today. A sixth man was arrested later at his North London
home.

Details of the alleged plot emerged as the Pope laid out his strongest challenge
to secular society yet in an address to politicians and civic leaders at
Westminster. He said: "Some people even think that festivals such as Christmas
should be discouraged in the questionable belief that it might somehow offend
those of other religions or none." Attacking equality legislation in Britain, he
added: "There are those who argue - paradoxically with the intention of
eliminating discrimination - that Christians in public roles should be required
at times to act against their conscience."

The Pope spoke of "worrying signs of a failure to appreciate not only the rights
of believers to freedom of conscience and freedom of religion but also the
legitimate role of religion in the public square". Pleading with the assembled
parliamentarians, he said: "I would invite all of you therefore, within your
respective spheres of influence, to seek ways of promoting and encouraging
dialogue between faith and reason at every level of national life."

Scotland Yard ordered the raids at 5.45am after receiving a tip-off overnight
containing specific information about the suspects. Senior officers emphasised
that no weapons, ammunition, maps, explosives or other "hazardous items" had
been found during initial searches. They said that the arrested men, some of
whom are from Algeria, were not known to the police or security services.

But background checks led to the decision to arrest the cleaners immediately at
Westminster City Council's depot near Baker Street. They work for Veolia
Environment Services, a contract cleaning company. "It was too much of a risk to
let these men run," a senior source said. "We had to act". The cleaners, aged
26, 27, 36, 40 and 50, were arrested on suspicion of the commission, preparation
or instigation of acts of terrorism. Armed police also raided eight homes in
North and East London and another business premises in Central London. The
arrested men were being questioned at a Central London police station.

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           September 19, 2010 Sunday

Delhi police doubt role of terror group in tourist bus attack

LENGTH: 600 words


Text of report by Press Trust of India news agency

New Delhi, Sep 19 (PTI) In incidents apparently intended to cause terror ahead
of Commonwealth Games, two

unidentified motorcycle-borne attackers Sunday shot and injured two Taiwanese
nationals outside the Jama Masjid here

which was followed by a crude pressure cooker bomb blast in a car in the same
area.

Delhi Police appeared to be ruling out the role of any organized terror group
but intelligence experts said it could

be a handiwork of outlawed Indian Mujahideen, which was behind a series of
blasts in several cities, including Delhi and

Ahmedabad. The Indian Mujahideen claimed responsibility for theattack in an
e-mail sent to PTI and some other news

organizations and threatened terror strikes during the Games. [passage omitted]

Nearly two hours after the firing incident, a car went up in flames when a
"crudely-circuited" pressure cooker bomb

exploded about 50 metres away from the spot where the firing incident took
place.

"The car went up in flames due to a crudely-circuited pressure cooker bomb," a
senior police official said.

Investigators suspect the involvement of a "group of disgruntled youth or local
criminals" who wanted to create a

scare in the area. [passage omitted]

The e-mail sent by the Indian Mujahideen said, "in the name of Allah, the attack
is a tribute to Atif Amin and

Mohammed Sajid". Amin and Sajid were IM operatives killed by the police in the
Batla House encounter soon after the Delhi

serial blasts of September 2008.

"We are warning you. If you have the guts, then organize the Commonwealth
Games...We know that preparations

are on full swing. Be prepared...We are also making preparations...The
participants in the Games will be

responsible for the outcome," the e-mail said.

The modus operandi in the firing carries the signature of Indian Mujaheedin,
Home Ministry sources said.

Sources in security agencies said the incident could be an attempt to spread
scare ahead of the Games. They said

terror angle cannot be ruled out.

The Union Home Ministry is also closely monitoring the investigations into the
shooting incident and has sought a

report from the Delhi Police.

Asked if the security agencies have been able to find out the motive behind the
incident, senior Home Ministry

officials said it was too early to make an assessment and that the
investigations were underway.

Police said phone calls in the area are being scanned and armed personnel have
been deployed in the locality.

However, Delhi Police does not suspect the role of any organized terror group
behind the incidents but suspect the

involvement of disgruntled youths or a gang of local criminals.

The motive appears to be to scare people ahead of the Commonwealth Games, they
say, adding the attacks do not show

signs of the involvement of terrorist outfits like Indian Mujahideen.

The city police is also not giving much credence to the email sent to media
houses purportedly by outlawed Indian

Mujahideen as "its content and timing were not matching" with the incidents.

There were "no specific target or specific reasons" for the attacks and they do
not find any reason to believe

that an organized terror outfit was behind the incidents which left two
Taiwanese nationals injured, Delhi Police

spokesperson Rajan Bhagat said.

"The signatures of the attacks do not show that an organized terror organization
like Indian Mujahideen is

involved. If you see pressure cooker which was used to explode the car, it was
poorly circuited and crudely assembled," a

senior police official said. [passage omitted]

Source: PTI news agency, New Delhi, in English 1530 gmt 19 Sep 10
