Tajik ministry says 23 servicemen killed in terror attack in east

LENGTH: 328 words


Excerpt from report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Dushanbe, 20 September: Twenty three people, including several officers of the
Tajik Defence Ministry and National Guards, have been killed as result of a
terrorist attack on servicemen in Tajikistan's east, the head of the Tajik
Defence Ministry's press centre, Faridun Mahmadaliyev, has told Interfax.

"Service vehicles of the Tajik Defence Ministry were attacked by a terrorist
group at 1230 [local time - 0730 gmt] in Komarob gorge in Rasht District (185 km
east from Dushanbe). As a result, 23 servicemen, including several officers of
the Tajik Defence Ministry and National Guards, were killed," Mahmadaliyev said.

"This terror attack was committed by people related with former filed
commanders, Abdullo Rahimov (better known as Mullo Abdullo) and Alovuddin
Davlatov. These are hirelings from Pakistan, Afghanistan and Russia's Chechen
Republic, who are attempting to turn Tajikistan into an arena of international
wars, under the cover of the sacred religion Islam," the press centre head said.

Local media sources have reported about 40 killed servicemen, but the Defence
Ministry does not confirm this information.

"We have several people injured, including those with serious wounds. They all
have been taken to hospitals nearby. However, their exact number is not known
for now, as they were taken to various hospitals in chaos," Mahmadaliyev said.

He said that "law-enforcement officers have arrived at the scene of the terror
attack and are carrying out an operation to catch the criminal group".

"The Tajik Defence Ministry condemns the terror attack and is taking all the
necessary measures to detain and hold accountable those who committed the terror
attack," he noted.

[Passage omitted: covered details on the escape of 25 prisoners from the
Dushanbe remand centre in August 2010, they probably are hiding in the Rasht
Valley]

Tajik ministry says "foreign mercenaries" involved in terror attack

LENGTH: 439 words


Text of report by state-owned Tajik Television First Channel on 20 September

A statement by the Tajik Defence Ministry

A service vehicle of the Tajik Defence Ministry with servicemen on board came
under strong armed assault of terrorist groups while fulfilling their duties at
about 1230 [local time - 0730 gmt] in the country's east, in Rasht District's
Kamarob gorge on 19 September 2010. As a result of this terrorist act, 23
servicemen have been killed and several others have been injured.

It should be noted that groups of Abdullo Rahimov, who is known under a nickname
of Mullo Abdullo, and Alovuddin Davlatov, who is known under a nickname of Ali
Bedak, have a hand in this terrorist act.

According to specific information, these terrorist groups comprise mercenaries
from Pakistan, Afghanistan and Russia's Chechnya. Undoubtedly, their main
purpose is to worsen the atmosphere of peace, tranquility and unity of the
country and to turn the Republic of Tajikistan into an arena for the region's
extremist and conflict seeking groups to carry out their activities under the
guise of Islamic ideas.

When this terrorist act happened, rapid groups of the country's all security
services arrived at the scene and launched an operation to detain criminals. The
operation to search the criminals is continuing.

Servicemen, who received severe physical injuries, have been immediately
admitted to hospitals nearby. The Tajik Defence Ministry condemns this terrorist
act and will take every rapid and specific measures to detain and to bring to
account criminals who have committed this coward and disgraceful deed.

Dear viewers. With a feeling of great sorrow Tajik President Emomali Rahmon
received the news about the tragic incident of attack on a vehicle of servicemen
of the national army which occurred in the afternoon of 19 September 2010 in
Rasht District and which claimed lives of servicemen. The Tajik president is
expressing his sympathy and condolences to the kith and kin of those who were
killed as a result of this incident.

Tajik President Emomali Rahmon, who is currently in New York to attend the 65th
session of the UN General Assembly, gave strict instructions to the Interior
Ministry, Defence Ministry and the State National Security Committee of
Tajikistan to detain and hold accountable the criminal group which committed
this disgraceful act.

Currently, in line with this order of Tajik President Emomali Rahmon the
country's security services are taking every possible measures so that to fully
ensure peaceful life of the country's people.

Source: Tajik Television First Channel, Dushanbe, in Tajik 0300 gmt 20 Sep 10

                                    Scotland

Terrorists 'will attack' France after burka ban

BYLINE: Joel Taylor

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 223 words


IT IS only a matter of time before Islamic terrorists mount a successful attack
on France, the country's top spy believes.

The recent burka ban means all the 'red lights are now flashing' in regard to a
possible atrocity, domestic intelligence boss Bernard Squarcini said yesterday.

Speaking after the evacuation of the Eiffel Tower last week following a bomb
scare, Mr Squarcini warned: 'France's role in Afghanistan, its foreign policy
and the debate over the law banning the burka have all increased the risk.' He
said security services foiled an average of two planned attacks every year, but
added: 'One day or another, we're going to get hit.

'The risk of a terrorist attack on French soil has never been higher and,
objectively, there are reasons for worry.' Leaders of al-Qaeda's north African
network have vowed revenge on France if it outlawed the full Islamic face veil
from its streets. Muslim women have a six-month 'grace period' to adapt to the
new burka rules without facing prosecution.

Meanwhile, security has been stepped up around Jewish institutions in Paris
following the arrest of a suspected terrorist who planned to bomb an Israel
defence forces fundraising event in the capital.

There have been 47 attacks against synagogues, Jewish schools, creches and
association buildings in France so far this year, and 190 threats.

                           September 21, 2010 Tuesday

Ugandan court charges Kenyan Muslim activist over terror attacks

LENGTH: 279 words


Text of report by Cyrus Ombati "Activist charged over Uganda bombings" published
by Kenyan privately-owned daily newspaper The Standard website on 21 September

Human rights activist Al-Amin Kimathi has been charged in Uganda in connection
with the twin bomb blasts in Kampala, on 11 July.

Kimathi, alongside Omar Awadh, a 37-year-old Kenyan businessman, face 89 counts
including terrorism, murder and attempted murder.

The prosecution alleges that on 11 July, the suspects carried out terrorism
attacks at Kyadondo Rugby Grounds, Ethiopian Village and Makindye Village.

Nakawa Court Chief Magistrate Deo Ssejjemba did not allow them to enter plea
since their case could on only be tried at the High Court. He remanded them at
the Luzira Prison until 8 October.

Kimathi and co-accused were last week arrested together with lawyer Mbugua
Mureithi. According to Uganda police, they were arrested while meeting in a
hotel in Kampala. Mr Mureithi was, however, released after three days.

This brings the number of suspects held over the attacks that claimed more than
70 lives to 38.

Some human rights activists had condemned Uganda for holding Kimathi in an
ungazetted safe house without trial.

The Kenyans were arrested at Niagara Hotel in a Kampala suburb. Apart from the
two, the others were arrested on diverse dates over the bombing that killed
football fans.

Uganda police spokesman Vincent Ssekate said on Saturday that they wanted the
two to tell them what they know about the bombings.

The police also said they were studying a laptop that Kimathi had, which they
claim, has information that could help build their case.

Source: The Standard website, Nairobi, in English 21 Sep 10

Russian paper regrets subway terror attack militant's death

LENGTH: 480 words


Text of report by the website of pro-government Russian tabloid Komsomolskaya
Pravda on 14 September

[Report by Viktor Sokirko: "Militant Killed in Dagestan Will Not Say Anything
About Subway Blasts Now: In Interests of Investigation Live Shamil
Magomednabiyev Would Have Been Preferable to Dead One"]

In the opinion of investigators, Shamil Magomednabiyev was directly linked to
the terrorist attacks on the Moscow subway which took place 29 March this year.
It has been established that he had close ties with Magomedali Vagabov and
Magomed Isagadzhiyev, the direct organizers of the terrorist attacks - the
latter directly accompanied the suicide bombers to the subway stations.
Retribution was served - Vagabov and Isagadzhiyev were eliminated in August. Now
Magomednabiyev has also been killed - during a battle in the Dagestani village
of Komsomolskoye 12 September, in which siloviki eliminated three militants.

True, now none of them will give testimony on the subway terrorist attack itself
or the training of suicide bombers from the ranks of the so-called "black
widows." And it must be borne in mind that the main task of law enforcement
bodies is the punishment of criminals according to the law, not their
elimination during the process of detainment. With each new elimination of a
criminal a thread which could lead to the rebel leaders - the masterminds behind
the terrorist attacks - is cut short. You see, any captured militant can provide
investigators with a lot of useful information. For now all those who were
marked out have either been killed or are on the wanted list.

"All too often an order to arrest from above is premature (and there is no
avoiding resistance from the militants)," a special services agent in the North
Caucasus says. "A result is needed, shall we say, severed ears, which can be
presented as evidence. In this way a link which could have been used to work out
the major structure of the rebel underground resistance is lost. But there is a
certain elimination plan which everybody tries to fulfil. And then the search
for the criminals starts anew. Thus Magomednabiyev and all of his group were
bumped off. There will be awards and commendations, stock will rise, but the
valuable witnesses will not say anything now. And they would have talked! Any
captured militant can provide investigators with a lot of useful information."

Remember that a further 10 rebel group members were eliminated in Makhachkala 12
September. Expert laboratory employees identified the so-called "Sharia Judge"
of the Dagestani rebel underground resistance among those killed. It is likely
that these militants were involved in the murder of Gapal Gadzhiyev - head of
the North Caucasus antiextremism department. But they will not give any
information on crimes committed or future plans now.

Source: Komsomolskaya Pravda website, Moscow, in Russian 14 Sep 10

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                                National Edition

Paris terrorist attack 'imminent'

BYLINE: Henry Samuel

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 165 words


FRANCE raised its terrorism alert yesterday amid fears of suicide bomb plots
against the Paris transport network.

It followed a tip-off from a friendly intelligence agency - thought to be
Algeria's - warning of an imminent al-Qaeda threat.

Five French nationals have been kidnapped close to a French uranium mine in
Niger in the past week, while a bomb scare caused alarm at the Eiffel Tower.

In a separate development, armed guards were deployed to protect a prominent
Islamic moderate, Dalil Boubakeur, rector of the Paris mosque.

"The terrorist threat is real and our vigilance is reinforced," said Brice
Hortefeux, interior minister.

Last week the Senate voted in favour of a ban on full Islamic veils and it is
due to come into force next year if approved by constitutional judges.
Al-Qaeda's deputy leader Ayman al-Zawahiri has urged Muslim women to resist the
proposed ban.

A police source said security services had identified two separate Islamist
sleeper cells which had been activated.

LOAD-DATE: September 21, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: DTL

                                 Edinburgh News

                           September 21, 2010 Tuesday

World News: France braced for terrorist attack in wake of veils ban

LENGTH: 408 words



HIGHLIGHT: France is on alert for possible terrorism after intelligence
suggested that attackers might target a public gathering place, with one lead
pointing to a female suicide bomber, a counter-terrorism official said.


The official said authorities were bracing for a possible attack last Thursday.
Nothing unusual happened that day in France, but authorities are not letting
their guard down, the official said.

The scare came as five French workers and two African colleagues were kidnapped
in Niger, part of the African turf of al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb. On
September 14, there was a false bomb alert at the Eiffel Tower.

Last week, the Senate voted to ban burka-style Islamic veils in France. That
prompted warnings by al-Qaida's Maghreb group.

Interior minister Brice Hortefeux said: "The terrorist threat is real, and today
our vigilance, therefore, is reinforced."

Speaking during a visit to the Seine-et-Marne region, east of Paris, he did not
elaborate on the additional security measures being taken.

Despite the warnings, Mr Hortefeux said France had not raised its terror alert
level to the highest ranking.

Actress faces return to prison
Judges in the US have issued an arrest warrant for actress Lindsay Lohan, who
has admitted failing a drugs test just weeks after being freed from jail.

The 24-year-old star could be sent back to prison for 30 days if she is found to
have breached her probation.

N Korea set for new leader
North Korea's ruling party will hold its first conference in a generation on
September 28, state media reports say, amid speculation that leader Kim Jong-il
is about to name his successor.

Mr Kim's third son, Kim Jong-un, is widely expected to become the next leader.

Games head slams village
The head of the Commonwealth Games has expressed concerns over the living
conditions of the athletes in Delhi.Commonwealth Games Federation chief Michael
Fennell said the condition of the athletes village had "shocked the majority (of
delegates]".

Mr Fennell's comments came after a number of countries have reportedly objected
to the living conditions in the athletes village.

The Games are being held next month.

Antiques turn up in PM's office
More than 600 antiquities have been returned to the Iraqi National Museum after
they were found in boxes in Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki's office.

Antiquities minister Qahtan al-Jubouri blamed "inappropriate handover
procedures" for their disappearance.

Nine Nato members die in copter crash
Afghanistan: Nine members of the Nato-led International Security Assistance
Force have been killed in a helicopter crash in the south.

One Nato soldier, an Afghan soldier and a US civilian were also injured.

Passengers feared terror attack on Stansted flight

BYLINE: James Dwan

SECTION: GAZETTE NEWS (EV GAZETTE NEWS)

LENGTH: 152 words


PASSENGERS on a flight to Stansted feared they were being targeted by terrorists
when their plane filled up with smoke.

White smoke filled the cabin of the EasyJet plane 15 minutes into the flight
from Naples to Stansted.

One passenger said that passengers feared the flight had been tarted by
terrorists, which sparked panic.

The pilot was forced to turn the flight around and make an emergency landing.

A spokesman for Easyjet said the incident happened on September 17.

"EasyJet flight EZY3364 from Naples to London Stansted returned to Naples when a
smell of smoke was detected after departure from Naples," he said.

"The aircraft with 144 passengers and six cabin crew on board landed normally
and all passengers and crew disembarked safely.

"All passengers and crew were transferred to another aircraft to continue their
journey to Stansted.

"At no time was the safety and wellbeing of the passengers compromised."

With the games due to start in less than a fortnight, officials tried to

tourists.

The Taiwanese tourists were hurt by gunmen on a motorcycle who opened fire near
one of India's biggest mosques, the Jama Masjid.

across the Indian capital.

Games security stepped up after Delhi terror attack

BYLINE: JEFF WELLS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 365 words


Security for the Commonwealth Games was tightened after a random terrorist
attack wounded two tourists in Delhi.

With the games due to start in less than a fortnight officials tried to reassure
athletes and the public that they were safe.

Police increased patrols across the city and put more officers on the streets,
especially in areas frequented by tourists.

The tourists, from Taiwan, were hurt when gunmen on a motorcycle opened fire on
Sunday near one of India's biggest mosques, the Jama Masjid, in the heart of the
city.

Police launched a massive search for the gunmen and issued a security alert
across the Indian capital.

Hours later, the BBC's Hindi language service received an email from the Indian
Mujahideen, an Islamic militant group, threatening to attack the upcoming
Commonwealth Games which will draw vast crowds to watch 7,000 athletes perfor m.

The group, which has been linked to the banned Pakistan-based Islamist rebel
group Lashkar-e-Taiba, was outlawed in June after it was suspected of
involvement in an attack on a bakery in western India in which 10 people died.

New Delhi's top elected official, Chief Minister Sheila Dikshit, appealed for
calm, declaring the city was safe to host the October 3-14 games in which 71
teams are to take part. She said: "Please don't panic. An incident like this is
worrying, but nothing to panic about."

made elaborate arrangements to provide the Commonwealth Games athletes and
officials a safe and secure environment," he said.

The two Taiwanese men were stable in hospital after undergoing surgery, The area
around the mosque was cordoned off after the attack and police scoured the
densely populated alleys around it. Cars and other vehicles were checked at
barriers erected on major roads in the city.

Police said witnesses could give few details about the assailants.

"Eyewitnesses have told us the men were wearing raincoats and helmets. They
fired around seven rounds before they sped away," a spokesman said.

The secretary-general of the games organising committee, Lalit Bhanot, said the
shooting would have "no impact" on the event.

Indian authorities "have

'This is worrying, but nothing to panic about' Chief Minister Sheila Dikshit

                       BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                          September 22, 2010 Wednesday

Kenyan lawyer petitions US over probe into terror attacks in Uganda

LENGTH: 370 words


Text of report by Fred Mukinda headlined "Lawyer petitions US over Kampala
attacks" published by Kenyan privately-owned newspaper Daily Nation website on
22 September

A lawyer has petitioned the United States government over investigations into
the July twin bombings in Uganda.

In a letter to US ambassador Michael Ranneberger, Nairobi lawyer Mbugua Mureithi
complained that he was arrested illegally, held incommunicado and mistreated
under the supervision of FBI agents.

The FBI is assisting Ugandan detectives to investigate the blasts that killed 76
people in Kampala on 11 July.

The letter obtained by the Nation further claims that Muslim Human Rights Forum
executive coordinator Al-Amin Kimathi, who was arrested together with Mr
Mureithi, is facing trial on trumped up charges. He was charged with terrorism
and murder at a Ugandan court.

According to Ugandan police, the two were arrested in the company of an
Al-Shabab suspect at Niagara Hotel in Uganda.

The letter identifies the alleged suspect as Mr Omar Awadh Omar, but claims he
was arrested in Nairobi and not in Kampala.

"He was in fact arrested in Nairobi at around noon on 17 September - two days
after our arrest in Kampala. Habeas Corpus was filed in the High court in
Nairobi and is being heard today (yesterday)," read part of the letter.

Mr Mureithi was released on Saturday without charges and was flown back to
Nairobi, an act he describes as "deportation".

The letter recounts the arrest and interrogation.

"We were lured into a trap by members of Uganda's Rapid Response Unit. An
officer kept on calling Kimathi, posing as a good Samaritan waiting for us at
Niagara Hotel," the letter read.

It added: "On arrival at the hotel we were violently arrested, accused of being
terrorists, hooded and traumatised with endless high speed driving throughout
the night."

After interrogations, according to the lawyer, he was thrown into a cell where
three other Kenyan suspects who he had gone to represent in court, were being
held.

"They confided in me that the FBI had interrogated each of them and expressly
told them that they were the ones in effective charge of the investigations,"
the letter said.

Source: Daily Nation website, Nairobi, in English 22 Sep 10

Iran official says 11 killed in Mahabad "terrorist attack"

LENGTH: 291 words


Text of report by state-run Iranian radio on 22 September

[Presenter] In a terrorist attack this morning during the parade of the armed
forces in Mahabad, unfortunately 11 of our compatriots were martyred and 35
others were injured. Those martyred or injured in the incident were all women
and children. Isa Qanbari is the West Azarbayjan deputy governor-general for
security affairs.

[Qanbari - recording] The parade of the armed forces was under way in Mahabad on
31 Shahrivar [22 September, the 30th anniversary of the start of the Iraq-Iran
war] when at 1010 [local time; 0640 gmt] today, at a time when the forces were
passing through the Mother Boulevard in Mahabad, an explosion took place inside
the place where women were standing and watching the parade. As a result of the
explosion, 11 people, one of whom was a five-year old boy and the rest were
women, achieved martyrdom and 35 other were also injured. Some 12 of those
injured have been kept in hospital and the rest are being treated and are about
to leave the hospital.

[Correspondent] Mr Qanbari, do we know about those behind this terrorist attack?

[Qanbari] At the moment we do not know, but investigations are under way. We
will investigate the case and will announce the result in the near future, God
willing.

[Correspondent] Where was the bomb planted exactly?

[Qanbari] Among the needles of a pine tree inside the boulevard close to the
podium where a large number of women were present. The bomb was placed inside
the branches of the tree.

[Correspondent] Is it possible that the number of martyrs and those injured
would increase?

[Qanbari] No. The figures that I mentioned were the latest.

Source: Voice of the Islamic Republic of Iran, Tehran, in Persian 1030 gmt 22
Sep 10

Indonesia: Terrorism expert says police station attack "response" to arrests

LENGTH: 228 words


Text of report by Indonesian Metro TV on 22 September

Terrorism expert from Aceh, Al Chaidar, believes that the attack on a police
station in Hamparan Perak, Deli Serdang, North Sumatra early this morning was a
retaliation of terrorist group in North Sumatra following the arrests made by
the Special Detachment 88.

Terrorism expert Al Chaidar. (MetroTV, 22 Sep)

According to Al-Chaidar, the attack had been planned because the police, in
addition to US interests, are on their list of targets. The attack on the police
station also shows that terrorist group in North Sumatra is still strong in
terms of weaponry and number of members. This group is only short of funds.

To prevent similar incidents, the police must proactively increase security at
police stations, install CCTV's, and strengthen social relationships with the
surrounding communities. If needed, the police can also ask for help from the
Indonesian Military because terrorist groups are employing guerilla strategy.

[Begin Al-Chaidar recording] It is a response of terrorist group against the
arrests of their friends in Belawan and Tanjung Balai. This in fact was their
hands-on practice in the field to carry out attacks in the form of guerilla
warfare in accordance with the training they had received in Aceh Besar in [
2009]. [end recording]

                          September 22, 2010 Wednesday

Iran regional official says 11 killed in Mahabad "terrorist attack"

LENGTH: 611 words


Text of report by state-run Iranian TV channel one on 22 September

[Presenter] This morning, a bomb was detonated in Mahabad [a township in
northwest of Iran]. The exploded bomb had been placed among women and children
who were watching the [annual military] parades. According to the Central News
Unit form Mahabad, because of this terrorist explosion, at least 10 women and
children were killed and 35 other people were injured.

[Correspondent] In a terrorist attack during the parade of armed forces on the
occasion of Sacred Defence Week in Mahabad, a number of our citizens were
killed.

[An injured girl] We were standing when the bomb exploded. Everyone tried to
escape. When I tried to escape, I felt that I had lost the control of my foot.

[Injured woman - 1] Many people and children were killed and injured. The bomb
exploded near us.

[Injured woman - 2 speaking on the subject in Kurdish]

[Injured woman - 1] They are hypocrites [members of Mojahedin-e Khalq
Organization] and anti-Islam elements, those who do not like the Iranians.

[The injured girl] All of these are because of hypocrites and the
counterrevolutionaries.

[Presenter] For more information on the details of the terrorist attack, I will
interview the governor-general of West Azarbayjan Province in Mahabad Hamid
Jalalzadeh.

Mr Jalalzadeh can you explain the significance of the event to us and then
please confirm that the number of those killed and injured is the same as that
announced in the report.

[Jalalzadeh] In the name of God, I want to say hello to you and the respectable
audience of this news bulletin. I want to use this opportunity to congratulate
the start of Sacred Defence Week to people of Iran. The people of West
Azarbayjan Province participated in welcoming ceremonies for their powerful
armed forces similar to other provinces of Iran. And, with God's blessing, the
ceremonies were organized successfully in all cities of the province.

As you reported, on the sidelines of the parade of armed forces in Mahabad
Township, a bomb was exploded in front of the podium at 1010 local time [0640
gmt] and many women and children were killed. I send my condolences to all
respectable people of Iran on the occasion of this catastrophe.

As your report indicated, I have received news on the death of 10 residents and
injury of 35.

I came to Mahabad immediately and organized a meeting with the Security Council
in order to discuss the development.

We met injured people in hospitals and transferred the message of the interior
minister [Mostafa Mohammad Najjar] to injured people.

[Presenter] Mr Jalalzadeh, please give us some details on the explosion; was it
a bomb blast or was it a suicide-bombing? Have the perpetrators been identified?

[Jalalzadeh] As it was mentioned, the event happened only a few hours ago. From
the beginning of the event [changing tack], it is a good place to thank the
emergency groups for their timely presence and services to injured people and
transferring the bodies of people killed.

As the investigations indicate, the attempt has foreign backing.

Unfortunately, the Americans and their allies are in the region. From the first
day of their presence in the region and their slogan to establish security in
the region, we can see that the unrest has increased.

[Presenter] Thank you very much.

[Jalalzadeh] But, unfortunately their support for the counterrevolution,
hypocrites and terrorist groups in the region has been proven.

Today's event was surely one event which had the support of the foreigner powers
and global arrogance and [it was part of] their plots.

Source: Vision of the Islamic Republic of Iran Network 1, Tehran, in Persian
1103 gmt 22 Sep 10

                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                          September 22, 2010 Wednesday

USA split over terrorist attack commemorations - Russian commentary

LENGTH: 1072 words


Text of report by the website of liberal Russian newspaper Vremya Novostey on 13
September

Report by Pyotr Iskenderov and Boris Kaymakov: "Flaming Anniversary. The 11
September Commemoration Split American Society"

The commemorative solemnities on the latest anniversary of the terrorist acts of
11 September 2001 in the United States passed by without major excesses;
however, they did not reduce tension in relations with the Muslim world. While
the nearest and dearest of those who died at the hands of terrorists lit candles
and prayed, in Afghanistan, Iraq, and other states passions seethed.
Participants in mass demonstrations held the United States up to shame over the
intention of a number of American clergymen to mark the somber anniversary with
a public burning of the Koran. In Afghanistan casualties were not avoided -- in
Logar Province the security forces opened fire on demonstrators and shot dead at
least two Afghans.

And although organized actions involving the desecration of the Islamic holy
book were avoided in the United States, a spontaneous bonfire nevertheless
blazed in the State of Tennessee, where two pastors marked the ninth anniversary
by burning the Koran on a lawn in front of a house. And the intention of the New
York authorities to build a 13-story Islamic cultural center -- already dubbed
the "Obama mosque" -- on the site of the World Trade Center, which was blown up
by terrorists, continues to split American society.

Almost 3,000 people were killed as a result of the terrorist acts of 11
September 2001. The overwhelming majority (2,752) perished in the collapse of
the twin towers of New York's World Trade Center, which were hit by airplanes
controlled by terrorist suicide bombers. The names of the victims of this
tragedy were, as per tradition, read out by the organizers of the commemorative
ceremony in Manhattan's nearby Zuccotti Park. "We have returned to this holy
place in order to link our hearts with the names of those whom we loved and whom
we have lost," New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg stated. "No public tragedy has
wounded our city so deeply," he stressed. "No other place is so filled with our
compassion, our love, and our solidarity."

However, the area where the twin towers used to stand has this year become more
than just a place of remembrance. For the first time in the past nine years the
mourning solemnities were marked by serious tension and high feelings. At the
end of the official events spontaneous demonstrations arose in various districts
of New York both in support of the building of the Islamic cultural center, and
with a demand to cancel the project, which was approved by a city commission
already at the beginning of August. The overwhelming majority of Americans do
not doubt the responsibility of Al Qaida for the 11 September terrorist acts,
and hence, to many people, the idea of building an Islamic facility in what is
for them a holy place seems blasphemous. Their opponents, following US President
Barack Obama called for "religious tolerance" and awaited reports on acts
involving the burning of the Koran with trepidation.

This initiative was put forward back in August by Terry Jones, pastor of a
Protestant church in the city of Gainesville (State of Florida). He even called
for 11 September to be transformed into "international Koran-burning day."
Appeals were made to the pastor and his confederates to refrain from acts of
provocation in the last days by President Obama, US Secretary of State Hillary
Clinton, Attorney General Eric Holder, Defense Secretary Robert Gates, David
Petraeus, commander of US and NATO forces in Afghanistan, UN Secretary General
Ban-Ki Moon, Pope Benedict XVI, and many other figures. Barack Obama stated 10
September in an appeal to the nation that video footage of the consecration of
the Koran to the flames by a Christian clergyman would be "the most effective
recruiting tool imaginable for the Al Qaida terrorist group." He stressed that
the United States "is not at war with Islam." "We are fighting terrorist
organizations that distort Islam, or claim that they are standing under the
banner of Islam in order to justify their destructive actions."

"Anti-Islamic feelings are dangerous," Nina Mamedova, head of the Iran d
epartment of the Academy of Sciences Institute of Oriental Studies, stressed in
conversation with Vremya Novostey. "After all, Muslims not only constitute a
significant part of the world's population; they are also steadily increasing
their economic and military potential. In this respect, Muslim countries have
grown especially rapidly in the past decade." "The fact that blame for the 11
September terrorist acts is placed exclusively on Muslims just because they are
Muslims provokes from them hurt feelings and protest. And the roots of all this
should be sought in the world's political structure and in the relations between
the United States and the states of the Islamic world," the expert believes. In
her words, "hopes for the stabilization of relations with the Islamic world were
linked with Barack Obama, and there has been a certain progress." Our
interlocutor adds: "Obama himself to a certain extent belongs to the Islamic
world, and he understands that it is necessary to take into account the
mentality of Muslim peoples. However, doubts that the United States' policy with
regard to Islamic countries is undergoing positive changes still remain."

At the last moment Pastor Jones decided against his dangerous intention, stating
that he expected goodwill gestures from the initiators of building the Islamic
cultural center in New York too. However, desecration of the Koran was not
avoided after all. In the State of Tennessee, two pastors -- Danny Allen and Bob
Old -- publicly burned at least two copies of the book, at the same time
declaring Islam to be a false religion. In New York there was also an incident
involving the burning of several pages torn from the Koran.

"The events of 11 September attest that the developed countries must seek a
consensus in relations with the Islamic world," Nina Mamedova is convinced. In
her words, "the prejudiced critical attitude to all Muslims is unacceptable to
Russian Muslims too." "Pretexts arise on this basis for extremist oppositionist
movements, especially in view of the unequal economic development of Russia's
regions," the expert believes.

Source: Vremya Novostey website, Moscow, in Russian 13 Sep 10

LOAD-DATE: September 22, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2010 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved

                              49 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                          September 22, 2010 Wednesday

Over 50 terrorist attacks averted in Russia's Caucasus in 2010

LENGTH: 187 words


Russian security services have averted over 50 terrorist attacks, seized 140
explosive devices and killed 160 gunmen in the North Caucasus in 2010, RIA
Novosti news agency reported on 22 September.

"Russian Security Services, Interior Ministry and other law-enforcement agency
staff have averted over 50 terrorist attacks in the North Caucasus Federal
District since the beginning of the year," head of the regional directorate of
the Prosecutor General's Office Artem Melnikov has said, as reported by the
agency.

Since the beginning of 2010 the police confiscated over 800 kg of explosive
substances, 560 fire-arms and over 140 ready-to-use explosive devices, he said.
He also said that in Chechnya this kind of work was being done with particular
intensity; 197 individuals who aided and abetted militants were found there,
against 17 in Dagestan.

He went on to say that law-enforcement agencies should first of all focus on
preventative measures, as it is much cheaper to prevent a crime than to
investigate it and pay off compensations, the report said.

Source: RIA Novosti news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1009 gmt 22 Sep 10

LOAD-DATE: September 22, 2010

(Corr): Iran regional official says 10 killed in Mahabad "terrorist attack"

LENGTH: 630 words


[Correction: Altering the number of people killed in headline from 11 to 10; a
corrected version of the item follows]Text of report by state-run Iranian TV
channel one on 22 September

[Presenter] This morning, a bomb was detonated in Mahabad [a township in
northwest of Iran]. The exploded bomb had been placed among women and children
who were watching the [annual military] parades. According to the Central News
Unit form Mahabad, because of this terrorist explosion, at least 10 women and
children were killed and 35 other people were injured.

[Correspondent] In a terrorist attack during the parade of armed forces on the
occasion of Sacred Defence Week in Mahabad, a number of our citizens were
killed.

[An injured girl] We were standing when the bomb exploded. Everyone tried to
escape. When I tried to escape, I felt that I had lost the control of my foot.

[Injured woman - 1] Many people and children were killed and injured. The bomb
exploded near us.

[Injured woman - 2 speaking on the subject in Kurdish]

[Injured woman - 1] They are hypocrites [members of Mojahedin-e Khalq
Organization] and anti-Islam elements, those who do not like the Iranians.

[The injured girl] All of these are because of hypocrites and the
counterrevolutionaries.

interview the governor-general of West Azarbayjan Province in Mahabad Hamid
Jalalzadeh.

Mr Jalalzadeh can you explain the significance of the event to us and then
please confirm that the number of those killed and injured is the same as that
announced in the report.

[Jalalzadeh] In the name of God, I want to say hello to you and the respectable
audience of this news bulletin. I want to use this opportunity to congratulate
the start of Sacred Defence Week to people of Iran. The people of West
Azarbayjan Province participated in welcoming ceremonies for their powerful
armed forces similar to other provinces of Iran. And, with God's blessing, the
ceremonies were organized successfully in all cities of the province.

As you reported, on the sidelines of the parade of armed forces in Mahabad
Township, a bomb was exploded in front of the podium at 1010 local time [0640
gmt] and many women and children were killed. I send my condolences to all
respectable people of Iran on the occasion of this catastrophe.

As your report indicated, I have received news on the death of 10 residents and
injury of 35.

I came to Mahabad immediately and organized a meeting with the Security Council
in order to discuss the development.

We met injured people in hospitals and transferred the message of the interior
minister [Mostafa Mohammad Najjar] to injured people.

[Presenter] Mr Jalalzadeh, please give us some details on the explosion; was it
a bomb blast or was it a suicide-bombing? Have the perpetrators been identified?

[Jalalzadeh] As it was mentioned, the event happened only a few hours ago. From
the beginning of the event [changing tack], it is a good place to thank the
emergency groups for their timely presence and services to injured people and
transferring the bodies of people killed.

As the investigations indicate, the attempt has foreign backing.

Unfortunately, the Americans and their allies are in the region. From the first
day of their presence in the region and their slogan to establish security in
the region, we can see that the unrest has increased.

[Presenter] Thank you very much.

[Jalalzadeh] But, unfortunately their support for the counterrevolution,
hypocrites and terrorist groups in the region has been proven.

Today's event was surely one event which had the support of the foreigner powers
and global arrogance and [it was part of] their plots.

                                BreakingNews.ie

                   September 22, 2010 Wednesday 02:34 PM GMT

Terror attack threat hits peak in France

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 296 words


The threat of a terrorist attack on French soil is at its highest as authorities
suspect al-Qaida's North African affiliate may be plotting a conventional bomb
attack on a crowded target, the director of the country's national police said
today.

Frederic Pechenard told Europe-1 radio: "We have serious indications coming from
reliable intelligence saying that there's an important risk of an attack."

He said that al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb "is targeting us in particular.
That's for certain".

The group - which claimed responsibility for last week's abduction of five
French nationals and two Africans in northern Niger - is not thought to have the
means to launch a nuclear or biological attack, but is considered capable of
targeted assassinations and attacks using conventional explosives, he said.

"In order to do the maximum possible damage (such an attack) would be likely to
happen in a place where there are lots of people, which could be the public
transit system, a department store or a gathering," Pechenard said.

His comments came a day ahead of nationwide demonstrations against the
government's pension reform.

A previous round of protests earlier this month brought more than one million
people onto the streets of France, with hundreds of thousands taking part in
demonstrations in Paris.

"Unfortunately, potential targets abound," Pechenard said.

He said moderate Muslim figures could also be targets.

The rector of the main Paris mosque, prominent moderate Dalil Boubakeur, was
recently assigned armed guards.

Pechenard said that several prominent personalities have been placed under
increased security.

Last week, there was a false bomb alert at the Eiffel Tower, as well as the
kidnapping of the five French workers and their two African colleagues in Niger.

LOAD-DATE: September 22, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication


                    Copyright 2010 Thomas Crosbie Media Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved

                              52 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          Press Association Mediapoint

                    September 22, 2010 Wednesday 3:18 PM BST

FOUR POLICE IN COURT CHARGED WITH ATTACKING TERROR SUSPECT

BYLINE: Paula Fentiman, Press Association

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 241 words


Four police officers appeared in court today charged with attacking a terrorist
suspect almost seven years ago.

The officers - Pcs Nigel Cowley, 33, Roderick James-Bowen, 40, Mark Jones, 43,
and Detective Constable John Donohue, 36 - are accused of assault occasioning
actual bodily harm during the arrest of Babar Ahmad on December 2 2003.

The four, who were all members of the Metropolitan Police's territorial support
group (TSG) at the time, spoke only to confirm their names and ages at City of
Westminster Magistrates' Court.

Defence counsel Colin Reynolds said all four men intend to plead not guilty.

District Judge Daphne Wickham committed the case to Southwark Crown Court on
October 29.

The police officers, who did not enter the court via the main entrance amid high
security, were granted unconditional bail.

Ahmad, 36, who remains in custody awaiting a decision on whether he can be
extradited to the United States, was held on suspicion of supporting and helping
to recruit terrorists to fight in Afghanistan and Chechnya through email
accounts and websites.

He was arrested during a raid at his home in Tooting, south London.

The computer expert was never charged in Britain, but has been held in Long
Lartin prison since 2004 after the United States issued an extradition warrant.

In July, the European Court of Human Rights halted the move as it considers
whether it will breach his rights by exposing him to life imprisonment without
parole.

LOAD-DATE: September 23, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


                  Copyright 2010 The Press Association Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                              53 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                              Your Local Guardian

                               September 22, 2010

Officers to appear in court over terror suspect attack

BYLINE: Ian Mason

SECTION: UPLOAD NEWS ARTICLES

LENGTH: 210 words


Four police officers will appear in court this afternoon charged with assaulting
Tooting terror suspect Babar Ahmad.

They are to appear at City of Westminster Magistrates' Court accused of
attacking the 36-year-old as they arrested him during a raid on his home in
2003.

PCs Nigel Cowley, 32, Roderick James-Bowen, 39, and Mark Jones, 43, and
Detective Constable John Donohue, 36 - who were all members of the Metropolitan
Police's territorial support group at the time - face a joint charge of assault
occasioning actual bodily harm.

Mr Ahmad won a £60,000 payout from the Met in March 2009 after the force
admitted he had been attacked. He is currently in the low-secure Long Lartin
prison after being held without trial for nearly seven years - the longest
detained-without-charge British citizen in the modern history of the UK,
according to campaign group Free Babar Ahmad.

He has never been charged or convicted of any criminal offence.

After his imprisonment in 2004, the American Government issued a warrant for his
extradition, claiming he was involved in websites that allegedly supported
Chechen resistance fighters in the 1990s.

Judges at the European Court of Human Rights are due to announce next year
whether extradition would breach his human rights.

LOAD-DATE: September 22, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

UPDATE: Officers to stand trial over terror suspect attack

BYLINE: Ian Mason

SECTION: UPLOAD NEWS ARTICLES

LENGTH: 233 words


Four police officers will stand trial over accusations they assaulted Tooting
terror suspect Babar Ahmad.

At City of Westminster Magistrates' Court today, their defence counsel Colin
Reynolds said they intended to enter not guilty pleas in relation to allegations
they attacked the 36-year-old as they arrested him during a raid on his home in
2003.

The officers - PCs Nigel Cowley, 32, Roderick James-Bowen, 39, and Mark Jones,
43, and Detective Constable John Donohue, 36 - spoke only to confirm their name
and ages.

District Judge Daphne Wickham committed the case to Southwark Crown Court. The
men, who were all members of the Metropolitan Police's territorial support group
at the time, will stand trial charged with assault occasioning actual bodily
harm on October 29.

Mr Ahmad is currently in the low-secure Long Lartin prison after being held
without trial for nearly seven years - the longest detained-without-charge
British citizen in the modern history of the UK, according to campaign group
Free Babar Ahmad.

He has never been charged or convicted of any criminal offence.

After his imprisonment in 2004, the American Government issued a warrant for his
extradition, claiming he was involved in websites that allegedly supported
Chechen resistance fighters in the 1990s.

Judges at the European Court of Human Rights are due to announce next year
whether extradition would breach his human rights.

Terrorism expert Al Chaidar. (MetroTV, 22 Sep)

(www.kompas.com) on 23 September

[Unattributed article: 'Simbol Negara Diserang']

[On 22 September 2010,] North Sumatra Deputy Governor Gatot Pujo Nugroho
expressed concern over the attack on Hamparan Perak Sub-district Police Station
in Deli Serdang District, saying it was a direct attack on a symbol of the
state.

"It's as if the government has no authority," he said.

He called on the police to be professional and investigate the case thoroughly
without bias towards any group.

North Sumatra Governor Syamsul Arifin said that the incident would affect the
province as a whole.

"This will also have an economic effect. And North Sumatra, which always has
been known as a safe place, will be perceived as unsafe because of this
incident," he said.

Arifin said that the provincial government would soon hold a meeting with
district leaders about the current security situation in the province, adding
that he had asked all district heads and mayors to be more vigilant.

On 22 September, Coordinating Minister for Political, Legal and Security Affairs
Djoko Suyanto passed on President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono's instruction to the
Indonesian National Police (Polri) and the Indonesian Armed Forces (TNI) that
the state would not give in to terrorism.

The President made his comments in response to the attack on Hamparan Perak
Sub-district Police Station in North Sumatra, and called for the police to
immediately search for and arrest the perpetrators. Suyanto also said that Polri
must work together with TNI and the State Intelligence Agency (BIN), and other
groups in the community to immediately find the perpetrators of the attack.
Kompas -23 Sep: 'Negara Tidak Boleh Kalah'.]

Meanwhile, I/Bukit Barisan Military Area Command (Kodam I) Lieutenant Colonel
Spokesman Asren Nasution said that Kodam I was ready to help police [in their
investigations], but added that the police had not formally requested assistance
from TNI. He added that the commander of Kodam I had asked the units under his
authority to be more vigilant and report any suspicious activity.

Iran analyst questions US report on 9/11 terror attacks

LENGTH: 756 words


Excerpt of Commentary by Hanif Ghaffari headlined "A lie which is as tall as
twin towers" published by Iranian newspaper Resalat on 12 September

These days the American media is talking about the 11 September and the
officials of Bush's period are making statements about this event one after
another. Commentaries on the attack on the New York Twin Towers have dominated
the media. Some individuals, like Condoleezza Rice [former US Secretary of
State] and Dick Cheney [former US vice-president] are trying to analyze and
criticize the world after the 11 September and are trying to reveal some secret
issues [related to the incident].

The reality behind the incident is that radical neo-conservatives had designed
and implemented the 11 September events and used that self-made incident to
attack Afghanistan and Iraq. However, today the real elements behind this event
should be answerable for the 11 September incident.

We still remember that when Bush Junior and Tony Blair talked about the reasons
of their invasion on Iraq and Afghanistan in front of a group of reporters and
public opinion, they immediately referred to the address of the destroyed Twin
Towers in New York City.

Last year, in a signed letter, more than 1,000 experts and specialists
questioned the US government's official report on the 11 September events, and
demanded independent inquiry into the issue. Such independent investigation has
not been carried out yet because the US security institutions and intelligence
agencies have tried to prevent people and media sources to get access to the
confidential information about 11 September events. This year also these
ambiguities, along with the added ones, remain unanswered.

The interesting point here is that members of the Democratic Party have not said
anything about the 11 September events. 11 September is considered as a common
front for the pigeons and hawks of Washington. During the presidential election
campaign in 2004, the Democrat candidates John Kerry and John Edwards could have
easily cornered the two-member team of Bush-Cheney with a few simple questions
about the 11-September event. However, the silence of these two veteran US
politicians was an indicator of many behind-the-scene facts.

[passage omitted]

The experts, who have demanded to pursue the 11 September events, include
individuals like Dr David Ray Griffin, who has written immensely about 11
September events and Dr Steven Jones, a nuclear physicist and 11 September
researcher. However, any response was not given to these individuals yet.

It is believed that complicating the 11 September project is media machination
of a powerful lobby in Washington. The media outlets close to two main American
political parties are trying to project this issue as complicated, ambiguous and
mysterious. Meanwhile, the issue is completely clear and simple. The discussed
questions about 11 September events are clear to the extent, that even a simple
US citizens or just a viewer of news can also sense the existing ambiguities.

The passenger aircraft flying at a very low altitude, green light of the US
security forces to the perpetrators of attack and controlled collapse of the
World Trade buildings... [Ellipsis as published] are the codes [as published]
that lead us to unravel the facts about 11 September 2001.

The latest disclosures are based on the evidences of courts, video footages and
testimonies of eyewitnesses, which were not included in the official reports.
Among these issues, we can refer to the free collapse of the 47 floors of the
World Trade Centre building, which was completely controlled. However, the US
officials have no answer to these documents, but silence.

Nevertheless, the existing data that confirm that 11 September events were
carried out intentionally and were completely controlled do not end here. In
each sample taken from the dust after the collapse of the World Trade Centre,
prints of advanced "nano-thermite" explosive material were obtained, which is a
sort of a super-explosive material originating from a combination of thermites.
Was this explosive material was sprayed by the pilots of the aircrafts on the
Twin Towers' middle floors?

Finally, the time is ripe for uncovering the facts related to 11 September
events. Accordingly, the dark aspects of the 11 September events will be
discovered one after the other so that the international system could identify
the real face of the lobbying power in the United States.

Source: Resalat website, Tehran, in Persian, 12 Sep 10, p 21

                              58 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                                  Burton Mail

                          September 23, 2010 Thursday

Baseball bat attack terror for couple in farmhouse

BYLINE: PETER RICHARDSON

LENGTH: 460 words


A COUPLE were subjected to terrifying violence by raiders who targeted their
isolated farmhouse searching for cash, a court has heard.

David Elston was smashed across the head with a baseball bat when he was
attacked from behind as he loaded his pick-up truck on the paddock of his farm.

The jury at Lincoln Crown Court was told that Mr Elston collapsed unconscious
and was then tied up with his own belt before an intruder entered the property
and attacked his wife, Lorraine, 63.

Gordon Aspden, prosecuting, said that Mrs Elston was temporarily knocked out and
when she came round her attacker tied her ankles and wrists with cable ties
before demanding money.

Mrs Elston was then dragged into the kitchen of the property where a knife was
held to her face as she was told to reveal where the safe was.

"The intruder told her that unless she revealed the whereabouts of the safe he
would cut off her nose and then cut her throat," Mr Aspden said.

"He left the house and a few moments later returned with a second man. Mrs
Elston was convinced she was to be murdered. Neither man seemed concerned about
her being able to identify them later on as their faces were visible.

She pleaded with them for mercy."
   Lee Burton, 36, of Tower Road, Hartshorne, and Lee Watkins, 36, of Measham
Road, Moira, have admitted conspiracy to rob.

Andrew Waite, 38, of Cemetery Road, Bicker, Lincolnshire, denies the same
charge. A fourth man alleged to have been involved has yet to be traced by
police.

Mr Aspden said that after being told the safe keys were on Mr Elston's keyring
the intruders cut the telephone wires and left, taking a wallet - containing
just £200.

Mrs Elston, although still tied up, managed to hop around her house onto the
main road and her cries for help alerted neighbours who raised the alarm.

The couple were both taken to hospital, with Mr Elston in such a grave condition
he was immediately transferred to a specialist unit at the Queen's Medical
Centre, Nottingham.

His skull was fractured in three places and he later underwent an operation
which saved his life. His wife suffered two deep lacerations to her head and
other injuries.

A burned-out Jeep Cherokee used by the raiders was discovered later the same
evening and a VW Passat which had been parked nearby was also linked to the
robbery.

The Passat was traced later to Solihull. Forensic tests revealed the
fingerprints of both Watkins and Burton while a thumbprint of local man Waite
was on the internal mirror.

Mr Aspden said that the Elstons, who ran a bird sanctuary and earned a living
from selling eggs and logs, appeared to have been targeted because the robbers
believed they would find a large amount of cash at their home in Frithville,
near Boston, Lincolnshire.

The trial continues.

                       BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           September 24, 2010 Friday

"Secret" Kenyan police report details Al-Qa'idah's role in Uganda terror attack

LENGTH: 543 words


Text of unattributed report entitled "Secret report exposes terror network's
operations in Kampala attack" published by Kenyan privately-owned newspaper
Daily Nation website on 24 September

New details have emerged about what police and the intelligence services fear is
a network of terrorists who pose a threat to Kenyans.

In a report shown to the Nation on Thursday [23 September], the authorities also
revealed more information about how they believe the bombing attacks in Kampala
on 11 July were planned and carried.

But the purpose of leaking the declassified information appeared to be to warn
the country of the danger posed by elements of what they called Al-Qa'idah's
east African cell. Local Al-Qa'idah has merged with Al-Shabab, the Somali
extremist group which claimed responsibility for the Kampala bombings.

According to the report, the cell has 17 officials, and two liaison officers
based in Nairobi and Beirut, providing the link to Al-Qa'idah.

The cell leader in east Africa, the report claims, is Mr Fazul Harun, an
Afghanistan trained terrorist who has been involved in planning and executing
all terrorist attacks against Kenya and on whose head the US government has
placed a 5m-dollar bounty.

Anti-terror officials accuse Mr Abu Sahal of being Mr Harun's deputy. The Nation
could not reach Mr Sahal or independently verify the claims.

According to the report, terrorists in Somalia have been recruiting suicide
bombers, intelligence and surveillance officers from Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania
since 2007.

The recruitment was, with time, extended from North Eastern and Coast provinces
to Central, Western, Nyanza and Eastern.

Some of the recruits have been arrested in connection with the Kampala bombings
that claimed the lives of 76 people as they watched the World Cup finals on 11
July, it claimed.

A day later, plans to stage similar attacks in Nairobi and Mombasa were scuttled
after the suspects were arrested, according to the report.

The report also mentions a plan by Al-Qa'idah and Al-Shabab to disrupt the 2007
general election but does not disclose the motive or how it would have been
executed.

The explosives used in Uganda were assembled in Somalia, and possibly 10 vests
laden with explosives were delivered to Mombasa in February.

"It has not been determined who bought the vests, the actual number and how they
got into the country, but it's likely they were brought in by sea," it reads.

They were kept at a house in Mwembe Tanganyika by one of the Kenyans arraigned
in court in Uganda, the report claims.

The report does not say how the vests were brought to Nairobi but reveals that a
Land Cruiser was bought which transported them from Nairobi to Kampala on 8 May,
entering Uganda at Malaba. One of the vehicle's occupants, was arrested at the
border "because he had been watch listed," according to the report.

Two top lieutenants of Al-Qa'idah chief commander in East Africa organized his
release.

So far, 38 suspects, among them nine Kenyans, have been arrested and are facing
trial in Uganda.

Muslim leaders in Kenya have accused police and the intelligence services of
illegally transferring Kenyans to Uganda and are demanding that they be returned
and tried at home.

Source: Daily Nation website, Nairobi, in English 24 Sep 10

LOAD-DATE: September 24, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2010 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved

                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           September 24, 2010 Friday

Iran paper accuses top US official of hiding facts on 11 Sept terror attack

LENGTH: 534 words


Text of unattributed commentary by foreign political desk headlined "Rice does
not tell the truth!" published by Iranian newspaper Resalat on 18 September

Like other American officials involved in the 11 September 2001 event,
Condoleezza Rice prefers not to say anything regarding this so that the role of
the Washington government of that time in the destruction of the Twin Towers of
the World Trade Centre in New York is not disclosed.

Rice prefers to rely on the sidelines of this issue such as how she shouted at
Bush Junior after this event or what moves should the US political and security
organization should have made to tackle this issue. She escapes the main [point]
of the issue.

She is extremely afraid of speaking about herself as the US National Security
Advisor of that time and the neo-conservative government's direct interference
in the above-mentioned event. This fear is natural and the other members of Bush
government also suffer from it.

At the same time, the former US National Security Advisor cannot escape the
media. She appears in front of the media but tries to decrease the main load of
the story and add to its sidelines.

The most important headline that has been published about Rice with regard to
the 11 September 2001 event has been related to her dialogue with Bush Junior
after the event; the story that a few hours after the attack on 11 September
2001, she shouted at Bush and prevented him from returning to Washington.

Based on this, 30 minutes after the terrorists had flown the second kidnapped
plane towards the World Trade Centre and the two planes had hit these towers,
Condoleezza Rice, the US National Security Advisor of the time, had an argument
with the US President [of the time] George Bush.

This argument took place when Bush told Rice he intended to return to the White
House in order to take the control of the security crisis!

The reality is that the US National Security Advisor of the time has many unsaid
things with regard to the 11 September event. However, usually no criminals
confess about their crime in a natural situation. Rice, [Dick] Cheney, [US
vice-president under Bush administration], [John] Bolton [US envoy to the UN
under Bush administration] and [US Secretary of Defence under Bush
administration Donald] Rumsfeld are not exceptions to this rule.

Rice has tried to narrate the 11 September story like an interesting police
movie.

[She says:] "Many people came to this place from the White House. It went so far
that we could not even breathe. The members of the White House Secret Service
entered this place after some time, saying they had to take some people away
from this place..."

Rice stated that the government's communication systems were also unsuccessful
at the time of the 11 September attack and that even Bush spoke through
non-protected lines, which were easily obstructed. However, Rice knows very well
that in this story, the American intelligence and security services cooperated
with the agents of the event themselves and had information about the flight of
the planes at such a low level from the Earth. This event was preventable even
by a simple security structure!

Source: Resalat website, Tehran, in Persian 18 Sep 10

                                BreakingNews.ie

                     September 24, 2010 Friday 04:18 PM GMT

Irish terror attack on UK a 'strong possibility'

SECTION: IRISH NEWS

LENGTH: 322 words


The threat level to the UK from Irish-related terrorism has gone from moderate
to substantial, meaning an attack is a "strong possibility", British Home
Secretary Theresa May said today.

It is the first time that this threat level has been published, the British Home
Office said.

The threat from international terrorism remains severe.

Mrs May said: "The Director-General of the Security Service has informed me that
he has raised the threat to Great Britain from Irish-related terrorism from
moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility.

"Judgments are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups.

"This is the first time we have published the Irish-related threat assessment to
Great Britain. This is in the interests of transparency and to encourage people
to remain vigilant.

"The first and most important duty of government is the protection and security
of the British people.

"We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK from terrorism is
real and serious.

"The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed.

"I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and
security services in their continuing efforts to discover, track and disrupt
terrorist activity."

The threat assessment was being published for the first time "to encourage
people to be alert to the increased threat from Irish-related terrorism'', the
Home Office said.

But the threat is still lower than the overall threat level to the UK from
international terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre
(Jtac), which remains at severe, meaning an attack is highly likely.

"Measures taken to deal with the international terrorist threat will also
counter the threat from Irish dissident republican terrorism," a Home Office
spokeswoman said.

"In general the public should not expect any visible change in our security
measures."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication

                              64 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                 Edinburgh News

                           September 24, 2010 Friday

Omni centre attack victim tells of stiletto torture terror

BYLINE: IAN SWANSON

LENGTH: 414 words



HIGHLIGHT: A TEENAGE girl who was stripped, beaten and tortured by other
youngsters in a multi-storey car park has spoken for the first time of how she
thought she was going to die.


· One of the teenage girls involved in the attack is taken into Edinburgh Crown
Court after being sentenced

Emma Angus, 16, who waived her anonymity to tell of the ordeal, described how
her clothes were torn off and she was hit with stiletto heels and metal signs by
two girls as a boy filmed the violence and later posted it on the internet.

She and her two female attackers were just 14 when the sustained assault took
place in January last year in the car park of the Omni centre.

She said: "For a full 45 minutes I was subjected to the most horrific, brutal
torture. The worst bit was being stripped naked. They set my clothes on fire.

"By the end of it all I honestly thought I was going to die."

At the time of the attack, Emma was in foster care after her parents separated
and her mother turned to drink.

She had gone to a youth club in the Grassmarket and later with a girl gang to
the Omni centre, where the gang leader was thrown out for being abusive to
staff.

They ended up in the basement of the centre's car park. The violence began after
the gang leader accused Emma of kissing a boy she fancied.

Emma said: "It wasn't true. This girl just wanted to fight. They'd all been
drinking cider and she was looking for trouble.

"I could either run away or stay and take what was coming to me - but I knew
that if I ran I would get it even worse because I was in for it either way.

"At first the girl attacked me on her own, pulling me down by the hair and
punching me.

"I wanted to stay on my feet as long as possible but I soon ended up rolling on
the ground - and that's when the other two joined in.

"I was being hit with high-heeled shoes. They were ripping signs off the car
park to batter me with.

"At one point the boy said 'The f*****g little bitch has got blood on my shoes.
He then forced me to lick his shoes clean.

"And when I told them I needed the toilet they made me do it in front of them."

She said she had been slumped against a wall covered in blood and the boy, who
was 13, had said it was like ultra-violent film and computer game Resident Evil.
He also told her: "You're going six feet under".

The attack ended when some shoppers came into the car park. Although the adults
ignored Emma's cries for help, the gang ran off and Emma ran naked and bleeding
into the Omni centre.

She said: "I has tears streaming down my face and my hair was soaked in blood."

An ambulance took her to Edinburgh Royal Infirmary where she was kept in for
seven days.

"My head was like a basketball.

LOAD-DATE: March 14, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: EN

                           September 24, 2010 Friday
                                 Ulster Edition

ATTACK TERROR

BYLINE: MIRROR REPORTER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 36

LENGTH: 128 words


By MIRROR REPORTER A YOUNG woman fought off an attacker early yesterday amid
fears a prowler may be targeting female students.

Gardai in Letterkenny, Co Donegal, said the assault took place near the town's
IT college, where a similar incident took place on September 14.

Women attending nightclubs have now been warned to ensure taxis carrying them
home drop them right at their accommodation and not some distance away. The
attack at 1.40am was carried out on a 20-year-old woman after she got out of a
cab and was walking in the Ashlawn area of the town.

She bravely fought off her assailant who remained silent throughout as he tried
to drag her off.

Garda Inspector Pat O'Donnell said: "There is a distinct possibility that the
attacker could have been linked to the IT."

                              66 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                          Press Association Mediapoint

                     September 24, 2010 Friday 5:30 PM BST

IRISH-RELATED TERROR ATTACK 'STRONG POSSIBILITY'

BYLINE: Wesley Johnson, Press Association Home Affairs Correspondent

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 842 words


An attack on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a ``strong
possibility'', Home Secretary Theresa May said today as the country's threat
level was raised to substantial.

The threat assessment was increased after the head of the MI5 warned that
dissident Irish republicans could attempt to mount a new wave of terrorist
attacks on the British mainland.

But it was still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre (Jtac), which
remains at severe, meaning an attack is highly likely.

Mrs May said: ``The director-general of the Security Service has informed me
that he has raised the threat to Great Britain from Irish-related terrorism from
moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility.

``Judgments are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups.''

The assessment of the risk posed by Irish-related terrorism was published for
the first time ``to encourage people to remain vigilant'', she said.

Mrs May added: ``We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK
from terrorism is real and serious.

``The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed.

``I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and
security services in their continuing efforts to discover, track and disrupt
terrorist activity.''

The public should not expect any visible change in security measures as steps
taken to deal with the international threat will also counter the threat from
Irish dissident republican terrorism, the Home Office said.

Jonathan Evans, the director-general of the Security Service, said last week
there had been a ``persistent rise'' in ``activity and ambition'' by dissident
groups in Northern Ireland over the past three years.

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused
by the Provisional IRA at the height of the Troubles, he said they still
represented ``a real and rising security challenge''.

His warning came after one group, the Real IRA, publicly threatened to target
banks and other financial institutions in the City of London, accusing them of
``financing Britain's colonial and capitalist system''.

In a speech to the Worshipful Company of Security Professionals in the City, Mr
Evans said while MI5's ``main effort'' remained focused on international
terrorism, it had been necessary to reinforce its presence in Northern Ireland
to deal with the heightened threat.

He acknowledged that the recent rise in activity by dissident republicans had
not been foreseen, having been assumed just three years ago to be ``low and
likely to decline further''.

``Perhaps we were giving insufficient weight to the pattern of history over the
last hundred years, which shows that, whenever the main body of Irish
republicanism has reached a political accommodation and rejoined constitutional
politics, a hard-liner rejectionist group would fragment off and continue with
the so-called armed struggle,'' he said.

Since the start of the year there have been more than 30 attacks or attempted
attacks on national security targets by dissident republicans, compared with
just over 20 for the whole of last year, he said.

At the same time, there were increasing signs of co-operation and co-ordination
between the various groups, deploying a greater variety of attack techniques
with improved weapons capability - including Semtex explosives, associated in
the past with the Provisional IRA which is now on ceasefire.

``While at present the dissidents' campaign is focused on Northern Ireland, we
cannot exclude the possibility that they might seek to extend their attacks to
Great Britain as violent republican groups have traditionally done,'' he said.

But he said that, ultimately, the dissidents had done little to develop a
``credible political strategy'' the way the Provisionals and Sinn Fein did, and
many combined terrorism with organised crime, including trafficking drugs.

Asked about the Irish terrorist threat at New Scotland Yard yesterday,
Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Paul Stephenson said he was concerned.

The Scotland Yard boss said: ``Clearly we have got to be concerned by what
Jonathan Evans said.

``We have got to be concerned by the information that Jonathan Evans gave us.''

Earlier today, a Lithuanian judge postponed a hearing in the trial of a
suspected IRA dissident accused of trying to purchase weapons and explosives in
the Baltic country.

Michael Campbell, the brother of a senior Real IRA figure in Ireland, was
arrested in January 2008 in an international sting operation when he allegedly
handed cash to an undercover Lithuanian agent posing as a weapons supplier.

Campbell is the brother of Liam Campbell, who helped found the Real IRA and,
according to Irish police, is the faction's overall commander today.

Campbell could face up to 20 years in prison if convicted of seeking weapons for
terrorist purposes.

The hearing was postponed because Campbell's lawyer, Ingrida Botyriene, was ill.

LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


                  Copyright 2010 The Press Association Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

The threat level to Great Britain from Irish-related terrorism has gone from
moderate to substantial, meaning an attack is a ``strong possibility'', Home
Secretary Theresa May said today.

It is the first time that this threat level has been published, the Home Office
said.

The threat from international terrorism remains severe.

Alert raised for terror attacks on Britain by Irish dissidents

BYLINE: Mark Casci

LENGTH: 545 words



HIGHLIGHT: AN attack on Britain by Irish-related terrorists is said to be a

Home Secretary Theresa May announced the increase in the threat assessment after
the head of the MI5 warned that dissident Irish republicans could attempt to
mount a new wave of terrorist attacks on the British mainland.

But it was still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre (Jtac). This remains
at severe, meaning an attack is highly likely.

Mrs May said: "The director-general of the Security Service has informed me he
has raised the threat to Great Britain from Irish-related terrorism from
moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility.
Judgments are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups."

The assessment of the risk posed by Irish-related terrorism was published for

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused

represented "a real and rising security challenge".
