other financial institutions in the City of London, accusing them of "financing
Britain's colonial and capitalist system".

In a speech to the Worshipful Company of Security Professionals in the City, Mr
Evans said while MI5's "main effort" remained focused on international
terrorism, it had been necessary to reinforce its presence in Northern Ireland
to deal with the heightened threat.

He acknowledged the recent rise in activity by dissident republicans had not
been foreseen, having been assumed just three years ago to be "low and likely to
decline further".

Since the start of the year there had been more than 30 attacks or attempted
attacks on national security targets by dissident republicans, compared with
just over 20 for the whole of last year, he said.

Mr Evans added: "Perhaps we were giving insufficient weight to the pattern of
history over the last  hundred years, which shows that, whenever the main body
of Irish republicanism has reached a political accommodation and rejoined
constitutional politics, a hard-line rejectionist group would fragment off and
continue with the so-called armed struggle."

Yesterday, a judge in Lithuania  judge postponed a hearing in the trial of a
suspected IRA dissident accused of trying to purchase weapons and explosives in
the Baltic country.

Michael Campbell, the brother of a senior Real IRA figure in Ireland, was
arrested in January 2008 in an international sting operation when he allegedly
handed cash to an undercover Lithuanian agent posing as a weapons supplier.

                       BBC Monitoring Trans Caucasus Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday

Russia: Ingush leader on presumable aims of terrorist attack in Vladikavkaz

LENGTH: 556 words


Text of report by Ingush government website

Ingush leader Yunus-Bek Yevkurov has met residents of North Ossetia-Alania's
Prigorodnyy District at the Ingush presidential administration. The main issue
discussed at the meeting was the implementation of earlier agreements and the
development of interethnic relations between the Ossetian and Ingush peoples.

"I would like to speak about the uneasy situation that has taken shape after the
terrorist attack in Vladikavkaz [on 9 September], Yevkurov said.

"According to the operational information at our hand, the organizers of the
terrorist act pursued three main goals: destabilization of the situation in the
region, putting Ossetian and Ingush peoples at odds with each other, and
triggering a large-scale interethnic conflict, which would create conditions for
a complete closure [of the borders] of the republic, lead to the deployment of
troops, and a large-scale hunt for criminals," Yevkurov said at the meeting.

The Ingush leader said that "the identity of the suicide bomber has not been
established yet and the whole so-called 'Ingush trace' in the aforementioned
crime is that the car [that was blown up at the central market in Vladikavkaz]
had been sold by an Ingush, which is something any other person could have done.
Apart from this, so far it is still unclear whether [the terrorist attack]
involved a self-explosion or the car was blown up through a remote control".
Yevkurov urged residents not to sell or rent their immovable or movable property
to unknown persons.

Commenting on the situation around [North Ossetia's predominantly
Ingush-populated] village of Kartsa [which was approached by 300 irate
Ossetians] following the terrorist attack in Vladikavkaz, Yevkurov said that
"the North Ossetian leadership maintained contacts with the Ingush authorities
and that they took all necessary measures for stabilizing the situation. Now,
there will be a telephone in each regular bus and administration, to which it
will be possible to phone in the event of a slightest provocation".

"I believe it is important to inform you that the situation around Prigorodnyy
District is under special control by the country's leadership. If anybody thinks
that it is possible that the scenario of the year 1990 will be repeated these
days, they are deeply mistaken," Yevkurov said.

Commenting on the remarks by South Ossetian official [Konstantin] Pukhayev, [who
proposed closing the North Ossetian-Ingush border following the Vladikavkaz
blast], the president said that "appropriate conclusions have been drawn in
regard to those, who aggravated the situation through their remarks".

"We should avoid encouraging the ranting of those, who have never gone farther
than the Chermenskiy police checkpoint [on the administrative line between North
Ossetia and Ingushetia] and, having no idea about the current problems facing
the Prigorodnyy District residents, are making hasty and populist statements,
aimed at gaining cheap political dividends, as a result of which ordinary people
suffer. We have been preventing and will be preventing such actions," Yevkurov
said in response to a question about criticism voiced against him over his trip
to Moscow [as published; probably implying Yevkurov's recent visit to South
Ossetia].

Source: Respublika Ingushetia website, Magas, in Russian 23 Sep 10

LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                              70 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Scotland

Strong possibility of Irish terrorist attack, says MI5

BYLINE: Duncan Gardham

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 490 words


THE risk of an attack by dissident Irish terrorists on mainland Britain was now
a "strong possibility", MI5 said yesterday, as it published the threat level for
the first time.

The threat on the mainland had increased from "moderate", meaning an attack was
possible but not likely, to "substantial," meaning it was a strong possibility.
In Northern Ireland the threat of attack was "severe," meaning an attack was
highly likely.

The warning system is based on a combination of intelligence about terrorists'
plans and aspirations, along with assessments of their activity and
capabilities. The Real IRA has threatened to target financial institutions in
the City, accusing them of "financing Britain's colonial and capitalist system".

Theresa May, the Home Secretary, said yesterday the Government was publishing
the threat "in the interests of transparency and to encourage people to remain
vigilant". "We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK from
terrorism is real and serious," she said.

"The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed. I would
urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and security
services in their continuing efforts to discover and disrupt terrorist
activity."

A spokesman for the Home Office said measures taken to deal with the threat from
al-Qaeda would also counter the threat from Irish dissident republican
terrorism.

"In general the public should not expect any visible change in our security
measures," he said.

The warnings about Irish terrorism operate separately to the system for
international terrorism, where the level was raised to "severe" in the wake of
the failed plot to blow up a plane with explosives hidden in a bomber's
underwear on Christmas Day.

Jonathan Evans, the director general of MI5, warned in a speech last week that
Britain faced a dual threat from increased activity in Northern Ireland and a
new generation of Islamists. He said there was now a "real and increasing
security challenge in Northern Ireland" and it was possible that dissidents
might seek to "extend their attacks" to mainland Britain.

Mr Evans said that in the past few years "insufficient weight" had been given to
the "pattern of history" that showed that "whenever the main body of Irish
republicanism had reached a political accommodation, a hardliner rejectionist
group would fragment off and continue with the so-called armed struggle."

He said there were "increasing signs of co-ordination and co-operation between
the groups", which include the Real IRA, the Continuity IRA and Oglaigh na
hEireann.

The Security Service has recently reinforced its presence in Northern Ireland
for the second time as it tried to cope with a network estimated at 600
dissidents.

MI5 took over running counter-terrorism operations in Northern Ireland from the
police in 2007. There has been a number of unsuccessful attacks in recent months
largely aimed at security personnel.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                  Daily Record

                          September 25, 2010, Saturday

IRA ARE BACK;
'STRONG POSSIBILITY' OF TERROR ATTACK

BYLINE: Wesley Johnson

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 432 words


AN ATTACK on Britain by Irish-linked terrorists is a "strong possibility", Home
Secretary Theresa May warned yesterday.

She made the grim prediction as the threat level was raised to "substantial".

It's the first time the risk posed by terrorism connected to the Troubles has
been published.

Experts say the danger is from rebel former members of the Provisional IRA.

May's warning comes after intelligence chiefs revealed last week they feared
dissident Irish republicans could unleash a wave of attacks on the mainland. May
said: "Judgments are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups."

She said the assessment of the risk posed by Irish-related terrorism was
published for the first time "to encourage people to remain vigilant".

She added: "We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK from
terrorism is real and serious.

"The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed. I would
urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and security
services in their continuing efforts to discover, t rack and disrupt terrorist
activity."

Terrorism expert Professor Adrian Guelke, of Queen's University Belfast, said:
"Throughout 2009, there was seen to be an increase in recruitment.

"Their capacity is quite advanced, as they have recruited people who were former
provos. There is now concern that these groups have access to a team of
experts."

The Home Office said people should not expect any visible change in security
measures.

They explained that steps taken to deal with the international threat will also
counter the threat from Irish dissident republican terrorism.

MI5 director general Jonathan Evans said last week there had been a "persistent
rise" in "activity and ambition" by dissident groups in Northern Ireland over
the past three years.

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused
by the provos at the height of the troubles, he said they still represented "a
real and rising security challenge".

Hardline danger

REBEL republican groups are growing in size and expertise, experts warn.

The fringe hardliners are violent ly opposed to the peace process and have
focused on launching sporadic attacks, primarily on the police.

Key figures in Northern Ireland concede that it only takes a handful of
dangerous individuals to inflict major casualties.

The murder of three security force members last year has been followed by other
attacks, plus near-misses where many deaths could have been caused.

The fringe groups include the Real IRA and the Continuity IRA.

May: Irish terror attack is now 'a strong possibility'

BYLINE: By Dan Townend

SECTION: NEWS; 02

LENGTH: 552  words


AN attack on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a "strong

                                  The Express

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday
                                U.K. 1st Edition

May: Irish terror attack is now 'a strong possibility'

BYLINE: By Dan Townend

SECTION: NEWS; 02

LENGTH: 468  words


AN attack on Britain by Irish terrorists is a strong possibility, Home Secretary
Theresa May said last night as the country's threat level was raised to
"substantial".

The threat assessment was increased after the head of MI5 warned that dissident
Irish republicans could be planning to mount a new wave of terrorist attacks on
the British mainland.

The level is still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism which remains at "severe", meaning an attack is highly likely.

Mrs May said: "The director-general of the Security Service has informed me that
he has raised the threat to Great Britain from Irish related terrorism from
moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility."

She added that the assessment was published for the first time to encourage
people to remain vigilant.

"We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK from terrorism is
real and serious, " she said.

"The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed.

"I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and
security services in their continuing efforts to discover, track and disrupt
terrorist activity."

Jonathan Evans, the director-general of MI5, said last week that there had been
a "persistent rise" in "activity and ambition" by dissident groups in Northern
Ireland over the past three years.

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused
by the Provisional IRA at the height of the Troubles, he said they still
represented "a real and rising security challenge".

His warning came after one group, the Real IRA, publicly threatened to target
banks and other financial institutions in the City of London, accusing them of
"financing Britain's colonial and capitalist system".

Mr Evans said while MI5's "main effort" remained focused on international
terrorism, it had been necessary to reinforce its presence in Northern Ireland
to deal with the heightened threat.

Since the start of the year there have been more than 30 attacks or attempted
attacks on national security targets there by dissident republicans, compared
with just over 20 for the whole of last year, he said.

The last Real IRA bomb attack on London came in August 2001 when 45kg of
explosives were detonated in Ealing Broadway, west London, injuring seven
people.

Earlier that year a car bomb was detonated outside BBC Television Centre, also
in west London, injuring a Tube worker.

Irish terrorists last attacked a financial target in the capital in 1996 when
they exploded a bomb near South Quay station in London's Docklands. It killed
two people and caused GBP 85million worth of damage.

Three years earlier a massive bomb ripped through the City of London killing one
person, injuring 40, and causing GBP 350million worth of damage.

LOAD-DATE: October 4, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Warning by Theresa May
The 1996 attack on London's Docklands caused GBP 85m damage

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                                National Edition

May: Irish terror attack is now 'a strong possibility'

BYLINE: Dan Townend

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 468 words


AN attack on Britain by Irish terrorists is a strong possibility, Home Secretary
Theresa May said last night as the country's threat level was raised to
"substantial".

The threat assessment was increased after the head of MI5 warned that dissident
Irish republicans could be planning to mount a new wave of terrorist attacks on
the British mainland.

The level is still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism which remains at "severe", meaning an attack is highly likely.

Mrs May said: "The director- general of the Security Service has informed me
that he has raised the threat to Great Britain from Irishrelated terrorism from
moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility."

She added that the assessment was published for the fi rst time to encourage
people to remain vigilant.

"We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK from terrorism is
real and serious," she said.

"The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed.

"I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and
security services in their continuing efforts to discover, track and disrupt
terrorist activity."

Jonathan Evans, the director- general of MI5, said last week that there had been
a "persistent rise" in "activity and ambition" by dissident groups in Northern
Ireland over the past three years.

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused
by the Provisional IRA at the height of the Troubles, he said they still
represented "a real and rising security challenge".

His warning came after one group, the Real IRA, publicly threatened to target
banks and other fi nancial institutions in the City of London, accusing them of
"fi nancing Britain's colonial and capitalist system".

Mr Evans said while MI5's "main effort" remained focused on international

to deal with the heightened threat.

Since the start of the year there have been more than 30 attacks or attempted
attacks on national security targets there by dissident republicans, compared
with just over 20 for the whole of last year, he said.

The last Real IRA bomb attack on London came in August 2001 when 45kg of
explosives were detonated in Ealing Broadway, west London, injuring seven

Earlier that year a car bomb was detonated outside BBC Television Centre, also
in west London, injuring a Tube worker.

Irish terrorists last attacked a fi nancial target in the capital in 1996 when
they exploded a bomb near South Quay Station in London's Docklands. It killed
two people and caused £85million worth of damage.

Three years earlier a massive bomb ripped through the City of London killing one
person, injuring 40, and causing £350million worth of damage.

                                    Scotland

May: Irish terror attack is now 'a strong possibility'

BYLINE: Dan Townend

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 555 words


AN attack on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a "strong
possibility", Home Secretary Theresa May said last night as the country's threat
level was raised to substantial.

The threat assessment was increased after the head of the MI5 warned that
dissident Irish republicans could attempt to mount a new wave of terrorist
attacks on the British mainland.

But it was still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism which remains at severe, meaning an attack is highly likely.

Vigilant Mrs May said: "The director-general of the Security Service has
informed me that he has raised the threat to Great Britain from Irish-related
terrorism from moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong
possibility.

"Judgments are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups." The assessment of the risk posed by Irish
terrorism was published for the first time "to encourage people to remain
vigilant", she said.

Mrs May added: "We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK
from terrorism is real and serious.

The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed.

"I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and
security services in their continuing efforts to discover, track and disrupt
terrorist activity."

The public should not expect any visible change in security measures as steps
taken to deal with the international threat will also counter the threat from
Irish dissident republican terrorism, the Home Office said. Jonathan Evans, the
director-general of the Security Service, said last week there had been a
"persistent rise" in "activity and ambition" by dissident groups in Northern
Ireland over the past three years.

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused
by the Provisional IRA at the height of the Troubles, he said they still
represented "a real and rising security challenge".

His warning came after one group, the Real IRA, publicly threatened to target
banks and other financial institutions in the City of London, accusing them of
"financing Britain's colonial and capitalist system". In a speech to the
Worshipful Company of Security Professionals in the City, Mr Evans said while
MI5's "main effort" remained focused on international terrorism, it had been
necessary to reinforce its presence in Northern Ireland to deal with the
heightened threat.

He acknowledged that the recent rise in activity by dissident republicans had
not been foreseen, having been assumed just three years ago to be "low and
likely to decline further".

History "Perhaps we were giving insufficient weight to the pattern of history
over the last 100 years, which shows that, whenever the main body of Irish
republicanism has reached a political accommodation and rejoined constitutional
politics, a hard-liner rejectionist group would fragment off and continue with
the so-called armed struggle," he said.

Since the start of the year there have been more than 30 attacks or attempted
attacks on national security targets by dissident republicans, compared with
just over 20 for the whole of last year, he said.

Asked about the Irish terrorist threat at New Scotland Yard yesterday,
Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Paul Stephenson also said he was concerned.

LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Warning by Theresa May

JOURNAL-CODE: DXP

                              77 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday

Terror threat - or innocent joke? Airport attack tweet 'was just banter and
craic': Betjeman 'friendly bombs' line quoted in court appeal Conviction was for
causing a 'menace' via Twitter

BYLINE: Robert Booth

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 831 words


He was a courting lover who ended up with a criminal conviction after saying on
Twitter he would blow an airport "sky high" if it wasn't reopened to let him fly
to see his new girlfriend in Northern Ireland.

Paul Chambers, a 27-year old trainee accountant from South Yorkshire, yesterday
launched a fightback against what is thought to be the UK's first criminal
conviction for the content of a tweet on the microblogging site.

He landed a £1,000 fine after the snow closed Robin Hood airport near Doncaster
in January as he planned a trip to see "Crazycolours," a Northern Irish girl he
had just met online, and he tweeted to his 690 followers: "Crap! Robin Hood
airport is closed. You've got a week and a bit to get your shit together
otherwise I'm blowing the airport sky high!!"

A week later, he was arrested at work by five police officers, questioned for
eight hours, had his computers and phones seized and was subsequently charged
and convicted of causing a "menace" under the Communications Act 2003.

In an appeal at Doncaster crown court, his barrister, Stephen Ferguson, said
Chambers had been merely engaging in "banter and craic" and that far from having
menacing intent, his message was "a jest, a joke, a parody".

In an extraordinary day's evidence the court heard arguments ranging from the
fundamental right to the freedom of expression, to the emerging nuances of
Twitter etiquette and an often painstaking exposition of the basics of social
networking for the two magistrates and Judge Jacqueline Davies who were
presiding.

At one point the defence even appeared to ask the court if the criminal justice
system would treat Sir John Betjeman in the same way as Chambers if it was
considering his most famous verse. "Part of the importance of this case is that
if this tweet is somehow of menacing character, so would countless others from
the playground to Twitter users across society, day by day," said Ferguson. "To
misquote Betjeman: 'Come friendly bombs drop on Slough.' The point is an obvious
one."

The defence applied to the judge to rule out the prosecution case that the tweet
was "menacing" on the grounds it had not been sufficiently proved and there was
no intent on Chambers' part to cause menace. Throughout proceedings, Chambers
sat largely expressionless behind toughened glass panels with a security guard
beside him, only wincing slightly at the the continual repetition of his
offending tweet. He nodded when Ferguson told the judge simply: "The intention
was innocent."

On the other side of a glass barrier in the public gallery sat Crazycolours, the
pseudonym of the Northern Irish woman who only gave her name as Sarah, with whom
he had been planning to meet. "Young love did spring from these tweets and he is
now living in the same country as Crazycolours," the court was told.

Fresh evidence emerged which was not heard at the previous trial that the police
noted after Chambers was bailed "there is no evidence at this stage this is
anything other than a foolish comment posted on Twitter for only his close
friends to see". But the crown said the conviction should stand and presented
evidence that Chambers had sent direct messages to Crazycolours apparently on
the terrorist theme.

Caroline Wiggin, for the prosecution, said Chambers had earlier sent direct
messages to the woman in Northern Ireland as it appeared possible that the
airport might close. In one he wrote: "I was thinking if it does I have decided
to resort to terrorism." She argued that the context provided by such messages
strengthened the case that Chambers intended to cause menace.

Ferguson argued that Chambers's messages were obviously "hyperbolic banter" and
served to reinforce the fact that he was joking in the main message which he
sent to all his followers about blowing up the airport. "This (message) is
obviously facetious," he said. "There are at least three exclamation marks. The
first to add to the slightly naughty word 'crap'. The last two to the parody of
'to blow the airport sky high'." The court earlier heard that a senior airport
official had "determined (the message) was a non-credible threat" after it had
been found by Sean Duffield, an off-duty airport duty manager searching on-line
at home. Under cross-examination, Duffield, said the impact after he found
Chambers' message was "operationally nothing. It had no impact."

Chambers was not cross-examined, but the court heard extracts of his original
police interview. "Looking back it's daft now but that's my kind of humour,"
Chambers had said. "Not for one second did I think anyone would even look at it.
It was just a comment made on the back of the fact that the flight had been
grounded." The judge and magistrates retired to consider their ruling and said
the case would conclude a later date.

Captions:

Paul Chambers and Sarah or Crazycolours. Chambers was appealing against a £1,000
fine imposed for threatening on Twitter to blow Doncaster airport 'sky high'

Main photograph: Shaun Flannery/Alamy

LOAD-DATE: September 26, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                                  1ST Edition

Irish terrorism threat increases;
Attack is a 'strong possibility'

BYLINE: EXAMINER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 273 words


AN ATTACK on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a "strong
possibility", Home Secretary Theresa May claimed as the country's threat level
was raised to substantial.

The threat assessment was increased after the head of the MI5 warned that
dissident Irish republicans could attempt to mount a new wave of terrorist
attacks on the British mainland.

But it was still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre (Jtac), which
remains at severe, meaning an attack is highly likely. Mrs May said: "The
director-general of the Security Service has informed me that he has raised the
threat to G r e a t B r i t a i n f ro m Irish-related terrorism from moderate
to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility.

"Judgements are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups."

The assessment of the risk posed by Irish-related terrorism was published for
the first time "to encourage people to remain vigilant", she said.

Mrs May added: "We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK
from terrorism is real and serious.

"The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed.

"I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and
security services in their continuing efforts to discover, track and disrupt
terrorist activity."

The public should not expect any visible change in security measures as steps
taken to deal with the international threat will also counter the threat from
Irish dissident republican terrorism, the Home Office said.

An attack on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a "strong
possibility", the Home Secretary has said.

An attack on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a "strong
possibility", Home Secretary Theresa May said as the country's threat level was
raised to substantial.

The threat assessment was increased after the head of the MI5 warned that
dissident Irish republicans could attempt to mount a new wave of terrorist
attacks on the British mainland.

But it was still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre, which remains at

"Judgments are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups."

The assessment of the risk posed by Irish-related terrorism was published for
the first time "to encourage people to remain vigilant", she said.

                          The Journal (Newcastle, UK)

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday

May Warns Of Irish Terror Attack Threat

SECTION: A; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 410 words


Wesley Johnson

0191-201 6352

jnl.newsdesk@ncjmedia.co.uk

AN attack on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a "strong
possibility", Home Secretary Theresa May said last night as the country's threat
level was raised to substantial.

The threat assessment was increased after the head of the MI5 warned that
dissident Irish republicans could attempt to mount a new wave of terrorist
attacks on the British mainland.

But it was still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre, which remains at
severe, meaning an attack is highly likely.

Mrs May said: "The director-general of the Security Service has informed me that
he has raised the threat to Great Britain from Irish-related terrorism from
moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility.
Judgments are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups."

The assessment of the risk posed by Irish-related terrorism was published for
the first time "to encourage people to remain vigilant", she said.

Mrs May added: "We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK
from terrorism is real and serious.

"The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed.

"I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and
security services in their continuing efforts to discover, track and disrupt
terrorist activity."

The public should not expect any visible change in security measures as steps
taken to deal with the international threat will also counter the threat from
Irish dissident republican terrorism, the Home Office said. Jonathan Evans,
director-general of the Security Service, said last week there had been a
"persistent rise" in "activity and ambition" by dissident groups in Northern
Ireland over the past three years.

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused
by the Provisional IRA at the height of the Troubles, he said they still
represented "a real and rising security challenge".

His warning came after one group, the Real IRA, publicly threatened to target
banks and other financial institutions in the City of London, accusing them of
"financing Britain's colonial and capitalist system".

Mr Evans said while MI5's "main effort" remained focused on international
terrorism, it had been necessary to reinforce its presence in Northern Ireland
to deal with the threat.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               Leicester Mercury

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday

                                National Edition

Irish terrorist attack is now 'strong possibility';
WARNING: THREAT LEVEL NOW RAISED TO 'SUBSTANTIAL'

BYLINE: PA STAFF

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 377 words


An attack on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a "strong
possibility", Home Secretary Theresa May said yesterday as the country's threat
level was raised to substantial.

The threat assessment was increased after the head of the MI5 warned that
dissident Irish republicans could attempt to mount a new wave of terrorist
attacks on the British mainland.

But it was still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre, which remains at
severe, meaning an attack is highly likely.

Mrs May said: "The directorgeneral of the Security Service has informed me that
he has raised the threat to Great Britain from Irish-related terrorism from
moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility.

"Judgments are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups."

Mrs May added: "We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK
from terrorism is real and serious.

"The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed."

The public should not expect any visible change in security measures as steps
taken to deal with the international threat will also counter the threat from
Irish dissident republican terrorism, the Home Office said.

Jonathan Evans, the directorgeneral of the Security Service, said last week
there had been a "persistent rise" in "activity and ambition" by dissident
groups in Northern Ireland over the past three years.

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused
by the Provisional IRA at the height of the Troubles, he said they still
represented "a real and rising security challenge".

His warning came after one group, the Real IRA, publicly threatened to target
banks and other financial institutions in the City of London, accusing them of
"financing Britain's colonial and capitalist system". Mr Evans said it had been
necessary to reinforce its presence in Northern Ireland to deal with the
heightened threat.

"While at present the dissidents' campaign is focused on Northern Ireland, we
cannot exclude the possibility that they might seek to extend their attacks to
Great Britain as violent republican groups have traditionally done," he said.

                               Lincolnshire Echo

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Knife robber jailed for pharmacy terror attack;
Accused wore a long black and red wig, dark glasses and a 'tea-cosy'

BYLINE: Court Reporter

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 316 words


A MAN who carried out a bizarre knifepoint robbery at a Lincoln pharmacy was
jailed for two-and-a-half years.

Balding Joe Byrne donned a long black and red wig, dark glasses and a "tea-cosy"
hat when he walked into the pharmacy in Monks Road in the middle of the
afternoon.

Byrne, who also wore blue surgical gloves, produced a large kitchen knife during
the raid.

Christopher Lowe, prosecuting, told Lincoln Crown Court that Byrne, who had been
on a four-day drink and drugs binge, brandished the knife towards staff member
Gavin Gallimore and demanded the drug diazepam.

"Mr Gallimore directed him to where the diazepam was on the shelf. He took a
number of boxes of drugs from the shelf and put them in his bag.

"Before leaving he told the staff he didn't want to hurt them."

Byrne was traced after police identified him from CCTV footage.

Empty boxes of diazepam were found at his home, along with latex gloves and a
collection of wigs.

Although he denied he was responsible when he was interviewed by police, he
later confessed and wrote a letter of apology to staff at the store.

Mr Lowe said staff at the store were badly affected by the incident.

Byrne, 28, of Laceby Street, Lincoln, pleading guilty to robbery on June 24. He
stole drugs including Diazepam, Nitrazepam and Zopiclone.

Judge Ebraham Mooncey told Byrne he had no option but to send him to jail.

The judge said: "I have to bear in mind the fear you instilled in the staff. I
have to pass a sentence that will punish you."

Mark Watson, in mitigation, said Byrne had psychiatric problems and acted out of
desperation.

"This came off the back of a four-day binge of drugs and alcohol," he said.

He said that since being remanded into custody Byrne has been prescribed
methadone and is clean of illicit drugs.

Mr Watson said: "He is articulate and intelligent. He fully appreciates the
horror of what he did. The remorse he has shown is genuine."

LOAD-DATE: October 6, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: IN PRISON: Joe Byrne had been on a four-day drink and drugs binge when
he brandished a knife towards pharmacy staff and demanded the drug diazepam.

Irish terrorist attack warning;
World&National

AN attack on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a "strong
possibility", Home Secretary Theresa May warned last night.

The country's threat level was raised to substantial after the head of the MI5
warned that dissident Irish republicans could attempt to mount a new wave of

                              84 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          Press Association Mediapoint

                    September 25, 2010 Saturday 3:02 AM BST

'STRONG POSSIBILITY' OF IRISH-RELATED TERROR ATTACK

BYLINE: Wesley Johnson, Press Association Home Affairs Correspondent

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 2165 words


An attack on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a ``strong
possibility'', Home Secretary Theresa May said as the country's threat level was
raised to substantial.

The threat assessment was increased after the head of the MI5 warned that
dissident Irish republicans could attempt to mount a new wave of terrorist
attacks on the British mainland.

But it was still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre (Jtac), which
remains at severe, meaning an attack is highly likely.

Mrs May said: ``The director-general of the Security Service has informed me
that he has raised the threat to Great Britain from Irish-related terrorism from
moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility.

``Judgments are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups.''

The assessment of the risk posed by Irish-related terrorism was published for
the first time ``to encourage people to remain vigilant'', she said.

Mrs May added: ``We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK
from terrorism is real and serious.

``The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed.

``I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and
security services in their continuing efforts to discover, track and disrupt
terrorist activity.''

The public should not expect any visible change in security measures as steps
taken to deal with the international threat will also counter the threat from
Irish dissident republican terrorism, the Home Office said.

Jonathan Evans, the director-general of the Security Service, said last week
there had been a ``persistent rise'' in ``activity and ambition'' by dissident
groups in Northern Ireland over the past three years.

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused
by the Provisional IRA at the height of the Troubles, he said they still
represented ``a real and rising security challenge''.

His warning came after one group, the Real IRA, publicly threatened to target
banks and other financial institutions in the City of London, accusing them of
``financing Britain's colonial and capitalist system''.

In a speech to the Worshipful Company of Security Professionals in the City, Mr
Evans said while MI5's ``main effort'' remained focused on international
terrorism, it had been necessary to reinforce its presence in Northern Ireland
to deal with the heightened threat.

He acknowledged that the recent rise in activity by dissident republicans had
not been foreseen, having been assumed just three years ago to be ``low and
likely to decline further''.

``Perhaps we were giving insufficient weight to the pattern of history over the
last hundred years, which shows that, whenever the main body of Irish
republicanism has reached a political accommodation and rejoined constitutional
politics, a hard-liner rejectionist group would fragment off and continue with
the so-called armed struggle,'' he said.

Since the start of the year there have been more than 30 attacks or attempted
attacks on national security targets by dissident republicans, compared with
just over 20 for the whole of last year, he said.

At the same time, there were increasing signs of co-operation and co-ordination
between the various groups, deploying a greater variety of attack techniques
with improved weapons capability - including Semtex explosives, associated in
the past with the Provisional IRA which is now on ceasefire.

``While at present the dissidents' campaign is focused on Northern Ireland, we
cannot exclude the possibility that they might seek to extend their attacks to
Great Britain as violent republican groups have traditionally done,'' he said.

But he said that, ultimately, the dissidents had done little to develop a
``credible political strategy'' the way the Provisionals and Sinn Fein did, and
many combined terrorism with organised crime, including trafficking drugs.

Asked about the Irish terrorist threat at New Scotland Yard yesterday,
Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Paul Stephenson said he was concerned.

The Scotland Yard boss said: ``Clearly we have got to be concerned by what
Jonathan Evans said.

``We have got to be concerned by the information that Jonathan Evans gave us.''

Tory MP Patrick Mercer, a former Army officer who served in Northern Ireland,
told BBC2's Newsnight why he thought the threat level was raised.

He said: ``The security forces will have seen either the movement of personnel,
or the movement of equipment - weaponry, probably explosives in this case - the
hi-jacking of vehicles and the preparation of vehicles, or probably a
combination of two or more of those things. That will have caused them to change
the threat level.''

And he repeated claims the dissidents were seeking to attack political party
conferences, saying: ``For several months now it's become clear to me, from the
people I have been talking to who are comrades with whom I served in the past in
Northern Ireland, that the various dissident elements wanted to be active
particularly during August in order to have a platform during the party
political conference season which now is upon us.''

Shadow Northern Ireland secretary Shaun Woodward described yesterday's
announcement as a ``realistic assessment of the current security situation''.

He said: ``However serious the threat posed to Great Britain, we should
nonetheless recognise that the peace process has changed Northern Ireland
forever.

``Now our task is to ensure that those who wish to use violence to destroy not
only the politics, but the peace, will never succeed.''

Earlier yesterday, a Lithuanian judge postponed a hearing in the trial of a
suspected IRA dissident accused of trying to purchase weapons and explosives in
the Baltic country.

Michael Campbell, the brother of a senior Real IRA figure in Ireland, was
arrested in January 2008 in an international sting operation when he allegedly
handed cash to an undercover Lithuanian agent posing as a weapons supplier.

Campbell is the brother of Liam Campbell, who helped found the Real IRA and,
according to Irish police, is the faction's overall commander today.

Campbell could face up to 20 years in prison if convicted of seeking weapons for
terrorist purposes.

The hearing was postponed because Campbell's lawyer, Ingrida Botyriene, was ill.

Shadow Northern Ireland secretary Shaun Woodward said: ``Today's announcement is
a realistic assessment of the current security situation.

``However serious the threat posed to Great Britain, we should nonetheless
recognise that the peace process has changed Northern Ireland forever.

``Now our task is to ensure that those who wish to use violence to destroy not
only the politics, but the peace, will never succeed.''

Tory MP Patrick Mercer, a former Army officer who served in Northern Ireland,
told BBC2's Newsnight why he thought the threat level was raised.

He said: ``The security forces will have seen either the movement of personnel,
or the movement of equipment - weaponry, probably explosives in this case - the
hi-jacking of vehicles and the preparation of vehicles, or probably a
combination of two or more of those things. That will have caused them to change
the threat level.''

And he repeated claims the dissidents were seeking to attack political party
conferences, saying: ``For several months now it's become clear to me, from the
people I have been talking to who are comrades with whom I served in the past in
Northern Ireland, that the various dissident elements wanted to be active
particularly during August in order to have a platform during the party
political conference season which now is upon us.''

The head of MI5 warned last week that dissident Irish republicans could attempt
to mount a new wave of terrorist attacks on the British mainland.

Jonathan Evans, the director-general of the Security Service, said there had
been a ``persistent rise'' in ``activity and ambition'' by dissident groups in
Northern Ireland over the past three years.

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused
by the Provisional IRA at the height of the Troubles, he said they still
represented ``a real and rising security challenge''.

His warning came after one group, the Real IRA, publicly threatened to target
banks and other financial institutions in the City of London, accusing them of
``financing Britain's colonial and capitalist system''.

In a speech to the Worshipful Company of Security Professionals in the City, Mr
Evans said while MI5's ``main effort'' remained focused on international
terrorism, it had been necessary to reinforce its presence in Northern Ireland
to deal with the heightened threat.

Asked about the Irish terrorist threat at New Scotland Yard yesterday, Sir Paul
Stephenson said he was concerned.

The Scotland Yard boss said: ``Clearly we have got to be concerned by what
Jonathan Evans said.

``We have got to be concerned by the information that Jonathan Evans gave us.''

In his speech, Mr Evans acknowledged that the recent rise in activity by
dissident republicans had not been foreseen, having been assumed just three
years ago to be ``low and likely to decline further''.

``Perhaps we were giving insufficient weight to the pattern of history over the
last hundred years, which shows that, whenever the main body of Irish
republicanism has reached a political accommodation and rejoined constitutional
politics, a hard-liner rejectionist group would fragment off and continue with
the so- called 'armed struggle','' he said.

Since the start of the year, however, there had been more than 30 attacks or
attempted attacks on national security targets by dissident republicans,
compared with just over 20 for the whole of last year, he said.

At the same time, there were increasing signs of co-operation and co-ordination
between the various groups, deploying a greater variety of attack techniques
with improved weapons capability - including Semtex explosives associated in the
past with the Provisional IRA who are now on ceasefire.

``While at present the dissidents' campaign is focused on Northern Ireland, we
cannot exclude the possibility that they might seek to extend their attacks to
Great Britain as violent republican groups have traditionally done,'' he said.

But he said that, ultimately, the dissidents had done little to develop a
``credible political strategy'' the way the Provisionals and Sinn Fein did, and
many combined terrorism with organised crime, including trafficking drugs.

Earlier today, a Lithuanian judge postponed a hearing in the trial of a
suspected IRA dissident accused of trying to purchase weapons and explosives in
the Baltic country.

Michael Campbell, the brother of a senior Real IRA figure in Ireland, was
arrested in January 2008 in an international sting operation when he allegedly
handed cash to an undercover Lithuanian agent posing as a weapons supplier.

Campbell is the brother of Liam Campbell, who helped found the Real IRA and,
according to Irish police, is the faction's overall commander today.

Campbell could face up to 20 years in prison if convicted of seeking weapons for
terrorist purposes.

The hearing was postponed because Campbell's lawyer, Ingrida Botyriene, was ill.

A spokesman for the Police Federation in Northern Ireland said: ``It confirms
the predictions of the chairman, Terry Spence, that this threat would move
beyond Northern Ireland.

``The chairman is on the record as having pointed out that the terrorist threat
in Northern Ireland historically ends up going across to Great Britain to attack
the political, economic and infrastructural targets there because of the
political impact it can make.''

A series of attacks on members of the security forces in Northern Ireland have
failed in recent months. But two soldiers and a policeman have been shot dead
and there were attacks on police stations.

Northern Ireland First Minister Peter Robinson said dissident republicans had no
widespread support.

``The continued existence of such groups is in direct defiance of the wishes of
the people of Northern Ireland who have expressed clearly their desire for peace
and stability,'' he said.

``It is a worrying sign that the intelligence services have upgraded the threat
level, which underlines the need for adequate police resources to tackle this
threat and stamp it out completely.''

Nationalist SDLP leader Margaret Ritchie claimed MI5 was not on top of the
threat.

``The threat on this side of the Irish Sea is far too severe for us to leave it
to unaccountable agencies with a shady past in the north.

``Our representative, accountable policing service is not only the greatest
single success of the peace process, it is also our greatest asset in the fight
against violent groups.

``We have to mobilise the people of this island in support of their policing
services, supplying hard information which can be turned into evidence. That is
not a job which MI5 can do.''

LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


                  Copyright 2010 The Press Association Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                          Press Association Mediapoint

                    September 25, 2010 Saturday 3:02 AM BST

'STRONG POSSIBILITY' OF IRISH-RELATED TERROR ATTACK

BYLINE: Wesley Johnson, Press Association Home Affairs Correspondent

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 1066 words


An attack on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a ``strong
possibility'', Home Secretary Theresa May said as the country's threat level was
raised to substantial.

The threat assessment was increased after the head of the MI5 warned that
dissident Irish republicans could attempt to mount a new wave of terrorist
attacks on the British mainland.

But it was still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre (Jtac), which
remains at severe, meaning an attack is highly likely.

Mrs May said: ``The director-general of the Security Service has informed me
that he has raised the threat to Great Britain from Irish-related terrorism from
moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility.

``Judgments are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups.''

The assessment of the risk posed by Irish-related terrorism was published for
the first time ``to encourage people to remain vigilant'', she said.

Mrs May added: ``We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK
from terrorism is real and serious.

``The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed.

``I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and
security services in their continuing efforts to discover, track and disrupt
terrorist activity.''

The public should not expect any visible change in security measures as steps
taken to deal with the international threat will also counter the threat from
Irish dissident republican terrorism, the Home Office said.

Jonathan Evans, the director-general of the Security Service, said last week
there had been a ``persistent rise'' in ``activity and ambition'' by dissident
groups in Northern Ireland over the past three years.

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused
by the Provisional IRA at the height of the Troubles, he said they still
represented ``a real and rising security challenge''.

His warning came after one group, the Real IRA, publicly threatened to target
banks and other financial institutions in the City of London, accusing them of
``financing Britain's colonial and capitalist system''.

In a speech to the Worshipful Company of Security Professionals in the City, Mr
Evans said while MI5's ``main effort'' remained focused on international
terrorism, it had been necessary to reinforce its presence in Northern Ireland
to deal with the heightened threat.

He acknowledged that the recent rise in activity by dissident republicans had
not been foreseen, having been assumed just three years ago to be ``low and
likely to decline further''.

``Perhaps we were giving insufficient weight to the pattern of history over the
last hundred years, which shows that, whenever the main body of Irish
republicanism has reached a political accommodation and rejoined constitutional
politics, a hard-liner rejectionist group would fragment off and continue with
the so-called armed struggle,'' he said.

Since the start of the year there have been more than 30 attacks or attempted
attacks on national security targets by dissident republicans, compared with
just over 20 for the whole of last year, he said.

At the same time, there were increasing signs of co-operation and co-ordination
between the various groups, deploying a greater variety of attack techniques
with improved weapons capability - including Semtex explosives, associated in
the past with the Provisional IRA which is now on ceasefire.

``While at present the dissidents' campaign is focused on Northern Ireland, we
cannot exclude the possibility that they might seek to extend their attacks to
Great Britain as violent republican groups have traditionally done,'' he said.

But he said that, ultimately, the dissidents had done little to develop a
``credible political strategy'' the way the Provisionals and Sinn Fein did, and
many combined terrorism with organised crime, including trafficking drugs.

Asked about the Irish terrorist threat at New Scotland Yard yesterday,
Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Paul Stephenson said he was concerned.

The Scotland Yard boss said: ``Clearly we have got to be concerned by what
Jonathan Evans said.

``We have got to be concerned by the information that Jonathan Evans gave us.''

Tory MP Patrick Mercer, a former Army officer who served in Northern Ireland,
told BBC2's Newsnight why he thought the threat level was raised.

He said: ``The security forces will have seen either the movement of personnel,
or the movement of equipment - weaponry, probably explosives in this case - the
hi-jacking of vehicles and the preparation of vehicles, or probably a
combination of two or more of those things. That will have caused them to change
the threat level.''

And he repeated claims the dissidents were seeking to attack political party
conferences, saying: ``For several months now it's become clear to me, from the
people I have been talking to who are comrades with whom I served in the past in
Northern Ireland, that the various dissident elements wanted to be active
particularly during August in order to have a platform during the party
political conference season which now is upon us.''

Shadow Northern Ireland secretary Shaun Woodward described yesterday's
announcement as a ``realistic assessment of the current security situation''.

He said: ``However serious the threat posed to Great Britain, we should
nonetheless recognise that the peace process has changed Northern Ireland
forever.

``Now our task is to ensure that those who wish to use violence to destroy not
only the politics, but the peace, will never succeed.''

Earlier yesterday, a Lithuanian judge postponed a hearing in the trial of a
suspected IRA dissident accused of trying to purchase weapons and explosives in
the Baltic country.

Michael Campbell, the brother of a senior Real IRA figure in Ireland, was
arrested in January 2008 in an international sting operation when he allegedly
handed cash to an undercover Lithuanian agent posing as a weapons supplier.

Campbell is the brother of Liam Campbell, who helped found the Real IRA and,
according to Irish police, is the faction's overall commander today.

Campbell could face up to 20 years in prison if convicted of seeking weapons for
terrorist purposes.

The hearing was postponed because Campbell's lawyer, Ingrida Botyriene, was ill.

                              86 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                    Scotsman

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday

Home Office says Real IRA terror attack is now 'strong possibility'

BYLINE: Tom Peterkin

LENGTH: 401 words



HIGHLIGHT: The threat level to Britain from Irish-related terrorism has gone
from moderate to substantial, meaning an attack is a "strong possibility"', Home
Secretary Theresa May said last night.


It is the first time that this threat level has been published, the Home Office
said. The threat from international terrorism remains severe.

Mrs May said: "The Director-General of the Security Service has informed me that
he has raised the threat to Great Britain from Irish-related terrorism from
moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility.

"Judgments are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups.

"This is the first time we have published the Irish-related threat assessment to
Great Britain. This is in the interests of transparency and to encourage people
to remain vigilant.

"The first and most important duty of government is the protection and security
of the British people.

"We have been consistent in stating that the threat to the UK from terrorism is
real and serious.

"The balance we aim to strike is keeping people alert but not alarmed.

"I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police and
security services in their continuing efforts to discover, track and disrupt
terrorist activity."

The threat assessment was being published for the first time "to encourage
people to be alert to the increased threat from Irish-related terrorism", the
Home Office said.

But the threat is still lower than the overall threat level to the UK from
international terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre
(Jtac), which remains at severe, meaning an attack is highly likely.

"Measures taken to deal with the international terrorist threat will also
counter the threat from Irish dissident republican terrorism," a Home Office
spokeswoman said.

"In general the public should not expect any visible change in our security
measures."

Security experts believe that an IRA splinter group has access to explosives and
has members with experience of carrying out attacks such as the Canary Wharf
bomb in London in 1996.

The head of MI5 warned last week that dissident Irish republicans could attempt
to mount a new wave of terrorist attacks on the British mainland.

Yesterday a Lithuanian judge postponed a hearing in the trial of a suspected IRA
dissident accused of trying to purchase weapons and explosives in the Baltic
country.

Michael Campbell was arrested in January 2008 in an international sting
operation when he allegedly handed cash to an undercover Lithuanian agent posing
as a weapons supplier.

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday
                                 First Edition

An attack by Irish terrorists is 'strong possibility'

BYLINE: WESLEY JOHNSON

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 576 words


THEthreat level to Great Britain from Irish-related terrorism was raised last
night from moderate to substantial, meaning an attack is a "strong possibility".
It is the first time that this threat level has been published, the Home Office
said.

The threat from international terrorism remains severe.

Home Secretary Theresa May said: "The Director-General of the Security Service
has informed me that he has raised the threat to Great Britain from
Irish-related terrorism from moderate to substantial, meaning that an attack is
a strong possibility.

"Judgements are based on a broad range of factors, including the intent and
capabilities of terrorist groups.

"This is the first time we have published the Irish-related threat assessment to
Great Britain.

This is in the interests of transparency and to encourage people to remain
vigilant.

"I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police."

The threat is lower than the overall threat level to the UK from international
terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre (JTAC), which
remains at severe, meaning an attack is highly likely. "Measures taken to deal
with the international terrorist threat will also counter the threat from Irish
dissident republican terrorism," a Home Office spokeswoman said.

"In general the public should not expect any visible change in our security
measures."

The head of MI5 warned last week that dissident Irish republicans could attempt
to mount a new wave of terrorist attacks on the British mainland.

Jonathan Evans, the directorgeneral of the Security Service, said there had been
a "persistent rise" in "activity and ambition" by dissident groups in Northern
Ireland in the last three years.

While they did not have the capacity to return to the levels of violence caused
by the Provisional IRA at the height of the Troubles, he said they still
represented "a real and rising security challenge".

His warning came after one group, the Real IRA, publicly threatened to target
banks and other financial institutions in the City of London, accusing them of
"financing Britain's colonial and capitalist system". In a speech to the
Worshipful Company of Security Professionals in the City, Mr Evans said while
MI5's "main effort" remained focused on international terrorism, it had been
necessary to reinforce its presence in Northern Ireland to deal with the
heightened threat.

Asked about the Irish terrorist threat at New Scotland Yard, Sir Paul Stephenson
said he was concerned.

The Scotland Yard boss said: "Clearly we have got to be concerned by what
Jonathan Evans said. We have got to be concerned by the information that
Jonathan Evans gave us."

In his speech, Mr Evans acknowledged that the recent rise in activity by
dissident republicans had not been foreseen, having been assumed just three
years ago to be "low and likely to decline further".

"Perhaps we were giving insufficient weight to the pattern of history over the
last 100 years, which shows that, whenever the main body of Irish republicanism
has reached a political accommodation and rejoined constitutional politics, a
hard-liner rejectionist group would fragment off and continue with the so-called
'armed struggle'," he said.

Since the start of the year, however, there have been more than 30 attacks or
attempted attacks on national security targets by dissident republican groups,
compared with just above 20 for the whole of last year.

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           September 26, 2010 Sunday

Afghan observers urge USA to attack terrorist bases in Pakistan - TV

LENGTH: 293 words


Excerpt from report by privately-owned Noor TV on 25 September

[Presenter] US President Barack Obama has announced for the first time that
their [the USA's] negligence towards Afghanistan has prepared the ground for the
Taleban to revive and strengthen. He also emphasized that a strategy of
reduction and withdrawal would serve both countries. Meanwhile, a number of
observers believe that there are still a few opportunities for the USA to
correct its mistakes in Afghanistan.

[Correspondent] This is the first time the US president had acknowledged that
his country neglected Afghanistan and that the Taleban revived.

[Passage omitted: Obama's interview with BBC Persian]

Meanwhile, observers emphasized that the USA made a mistake when it trusted
Pakistan a great deal in dealing with Afghan issues instead of trusting the
Afghans. They also said that the USA should launch the war on terror in Pakistan
to rectify its mistakes.

[Ahmad Sayedi, captioned as political analyst, talking to camera] Now, if they
correct their mistakes and attack terrorist hotbeds and root out terrorists on
the other side of the border, it is good. However, fighting inside Afghanistan
has no meaning. The fight should be spread to where there are terrorist centres.

[Correspondent] Barack Obama made these remarks at a time when a new book
entitled "Obama's War" was due for publication next Monday. It is expected the
author of this book will disclose the details of how Obama tried to withdraw the
US forces from Afghanistan, because he is afraid the war may continue for years.

[Video shows Obama talking to a BBC Persian correspondent, US forces in
Afghanistan, an analyst talking to camera, a photo of the author of the book]

Source: Noor TV, Kabul, in Dari 1330 gmt 25 Sep 10

Irish-related terror attack 'is a strong possibility'

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 265 words


AN ATTACK on Great Britain by Irish-related terrorists is a "strong
possibility", Home Secretary Theresa May said as the country's threat level was
raised to substantial.

The threat assessment was increased after the head of the MI5 warned that
dissident Irish republicans could attempt to mount a new wave of terrorist
attacks on the British mainland.

But it was still lower than the overall threat to the UK from international
terrorism, published by the Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre (Jtac), which
remains at severe, meaning an attack is highly likely.

Mrs May said: "The director-general of the Security Service has informed me that

Al Qaida plots terror attacks in UK

BYLINE: Alan Mccabe

SECTION: NEWS; 999; Auto crime; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 47 words


TERRORISTS are planning commando-style raids in British cities, intelligence
sources claimed today.

The al Qaida plot involves teams seizing and murdering hostages - similar to the
attacks in Mumbai in 2008.

The group is also believed to be planning similar action in France and Germany.

Al Qaida plots terror attacks in UK

                              92 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                               Belfast Telegraph

                          September 29, 2010 Wednesday
                                  City Edition

Mumbai-style terrorist attack 'planned on UK'

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 322 words


Intelligence officials have intercepted a credible Islamist-linked terror plot
against Britain, it emerged today.

The threat is one of "a succession" of terror operations the country has been
dealing with over the past weeks, a government official said, although the UK's
terror alert status has not been raised from "severe".

The attack would have reportedly been similar to the deadly commando-style raids
in Mumbai, India, two years ago, with other European cities, in France and
Germany, also targeted.

Last night the Eiffel Tower in Paris was evacuated following a bomb threat
called in from a telephone booth. It was the second such alert at the monument
in two weeks.

One UK government official told the Associated Press news agency: "There have
been a succession of terror operations we've been dealing with over recent weeks
but one to two that have preoccupied us. Still, it hasn't been to the degree
that we have raised the threat level."

Another British official would not confirm the plot was "al-Qaida inspired" but
told AP there was an "Islamist connection" and that the plots were in an early
stage. No other details were given.

A Home Office spokesman said it was unable to comment on security matters, but
confirmed the country's terror threat was unchanged.

Yesterday French police closed off surroundings to the Eiffel Tower, France's
most visited monument. Officers pulled police tape across a bridge leading over
the Seine River, and stood guard.

Bomb experts combed through the tower and found nothing unusual, Paris police
headquarters said.

Tourists were let back inside about two hours after the structure was emptied.

German officials denied yesterday they had intercepted threats, saying there had
been no change to the country's threat level.

More than 170 people were killed during a 24-hour co-ordinated attack on Mumbai,
also known as Bombay, by 10 gunmen in November 2008. It has been blamed on
Pakistani militants.

LOAD-DATE: September 29, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: BT


                Copyright 2010 Belfast Telegraph Newspapers Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved

                              93 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                              DAILY MAIL (London)

                          September 29, 2010 Wednesday

SPECTRE OF TERROR HANGS OVER GAMES BRACED FOR TERRORIST ATTACKS

BYLINE: BY JONATHAN MCEVOY OLYMPICS CORRESPONDENT REPORTS FROM DELHI

LENGTH: 666 words


DELHI awoke to a heavenly blue sky yesterday. The grey smear on the city's
ceiling had been wiped away and the English archers came out to play.

A dozen of them, with their ancient weapons and stiff upper lips, practised at
the Yamuna Sports Complex. It was a civilised reminder of what the Commonwealth
Games should be all about.

Yet the 19th edition of this festival is still besieged on every side. It is not
now a question of whether the Games will go ahead on Sunday, but whether they
will be ambushed

a security or safety disaster.

It must be said in defence of the Indian organisers that there are a multitude
of guards , 80,000 police and 20,000 paramilitaries , protecting the venues and
the immediate city. We are repeatedly stopped: the taxi at every hotel gate,
every guest at the lobby entrance, each official and journalist on the Games
site, every underground passenger. At the hotel, guards and sniffer dogs roam
the corridors.

But as India's leading counter- terrorist expert told Sportsmail yesterday, it
may not be enough to thwart a left-field incursion

Islamic fundamentalists.

'I'm quite sure all the terrorist attacks that can be anticipated will be met
with sufficient counter measures,' said Ajit Doval, former director of India's
Intelligence Bureau. 'But I don't know whether the existing measures will
counter unanticipated or new or unusual threats. I have apprehensions about
saying what form the new threat could take. It might give the terrorists ideas.

'The sort of thing I have in mind will not require significant manpower or
weapon-power. It is unlikely to be at a big event such as the opening ceremony.
No, it would be carried out

one or two people. It will be surreptitious. I know how devilish the
Pakistani-based Islamic radicalists, who are the only real threat to the Games,
can be.'

England, who along with the home nations are natural targets given Britain's
prominent role in fighting terror, declared themselves happy with the security
provisions. Just as they did with the athletes' living quarters after the filthy
conditions delayed their moving in.

But what of the other buildings? Reports claim that 16 structures have yet to be
retested since the Central Vigilance Commission, India's foremost watchdog,
found two months back that safety certificates had been forged to cover up
corner-cutting and the use of substandard materials.

The venues for squash, hockey, diving, boxing, badminton and the practice rugby
stadium, as well as roads leading to the main Nehru stadium, are believed to be
vulnerable.

In light of the concerns, England last night spoke to other nations to gauge
their feelings before saying they would not seek further reassurances unless
evidence of more faulty buildings emerges.

The Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF) insist everything is in order, and the
teams appear to be taking them at their word.

Without wishing to be melodramatic, they will all look naive if a stadium, or a
road, gives way when full of spectators and athletes.

Read a newspaper or switch on the TV here and you see that the buck-passing over
these blighted Games is going on in Delhi faster than some athletes withdrew.
The misnomer that is the Organising Committee, under Suresh Kalmadi, and the
under-resourced CGF, under Mike Fennell, are to blame. The latter for not
imposing its will over the shoddiness of the former.

Talk to many an ordinary Indian and they feel let down

the government and

the corruption they know is rife. But as one newspaper columnist argued in the
Sunday Times of India this week: 'One thing is abundantly clear: we are nowhere
near being a developed country. The sooner we stop pretending to be a super
power, the better.

'There are many critical issues , poverty, hunger, literacy, drinking water , to
be addressed before we ever embark on an exercise like this.'

It was a thought at least worth pondering.

l South Africa's 800 metre world champion Caster Semenya, 19, will miss the
Games because of a back injury.

j.mcevoy@dailymail.co.uk

LOAD-DATE: September 28, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Papers

                            Nottingham Evening Post

                          September 29, 2010 Wednesday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Taxi driver's terror as attackers took his car

BYLINE: Rebecca Sherdley

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 386 words


TWO men took a taxi driver's car after one of them attacked him and yanked him
from his seat, a court heard.

Ashfaq Ahmed was answering a call to the Cross Keys pub, in Front Street,
Arnold, when two men came out of the nearby Horse and Jockey.

One of the men, Lee Ashton, opened the driver's door, told him to get out and
punched him in the head several times, Nottingham Crown Court was told. The
impact of one of the blows was so severe that Mr Ahmed, who works for city taxi
firm DG Cars, could not see out of his right eye.

Ashton then grabbed the terrified driver by his coat and pulled him out of the
car at 10.40pm on April 1. The Toyota Avensis was found abandoned in Arnside
Road, Bestwood, and had a flat tyre and damage to the front.

"The front of the meter was pulled off and found in the road some distance
away," said Jim Metcalf, for the prosecution.

Ashton had been with Lewis Chantler that evening. Both men were identified from
CCTV at the pub where they had been. Blood in the taxi was linked by DNA as
coming from 20-year-old Chantler, of Andover Road, Bestwood Estate. In court,
both men pleaded guilty to aggravated vehicle taking.

Ashton, 23, of Heddington Gardens, Bestwood Park, admitted a separate charge of
assault causing actual bodily har m.

Describing the attack after the men were sentenced, Mr Ahmed said it had all
happened so suddenly and left him feeling terrified.

"I thought they may have some weapons. They were so aggressive."

Recorder Peter Joyce QC jailed Ashton for six months for aggravated vehicle
taking and 12 months concurrently for the assault and gave him a two-year
driving ban.

"Taxi drivers are particularly vulnerable," he said. The court was told, in
mitigation, that Ashton had little recollection of what happened and his plan
was simply to go home.

Chantler received a 12-month community order, with supervision from the
Probation Service. He must attend a Thinking Skills Programme. He also received
a two-year driving disqualification.

"I accept that you were the lesser part," said the judge.

Chantler had pleaded guilty to the allegation at the earliest opportunity.

"He was out," said Simon Eckersley, in mitigation. "He was heavily intoxicated.
He was drinking to deal with the recent death of his mother."

Taxi drivers are particularly vulnerable. Recorder Peter Joyce

                               The Sun (England)

                          September 29, 2010 Wednesday

                                    Scotland

TERROR ATTACK PLOT UNCOVERED

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 175 words


SECURITY chiefs have uncovered a plot to mount a Mumbai-style terror attack in
Britain before Christmas. David Cameron has been warned the al-Qaeda plan was
under way but had not reached an advanced stage. It is also possible the
fanatics may target France or Ger- many. In 2008 a Pakistanbased al-Qaeda group
killed 165 people in more than ten coordinated gun and grenade attacks across
the Indian city of Mumbai. Nine attackers also died. The PM has been told US
spies picked up "internet chatter" suggesting another headline-grabbing outrage.
A British intelligence source said: "The Prime Minster has been made aware of a
possible Mumbai-style strike against the country. "Information was pinpointed
which gave rise to fears of a spectacular in the pipeline. "But it was unclear
whether the terrorists would definitely hit Britain or launch attacks in France
or Germany." One theory is that the terrorists may hit a number of European
cities simultaneously. Paris's Eiffel Tower was evacuated last night after a
terror alert.

s.hughes@the-sun.co.uk
