                    BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                          September 30, 2010 Thursday

Thailand: 467 sites in Bangkok under close watch for possible terror attacks

LENGTH: 639 words


Text of report in English by Thai newspaper The Nation website on 30 September

[Report by The Nation: "Police plan security operation in Bangkok"]

An intense 15-day security operation in Bangkok, beginning today, in response to
the frequent bomb-related incidents should be effective enough to prevent
further violence, police chief Pol General Wichean Potephosree said yesterday.

"There should be nothing serious for the public to worry about after police have
stepped up security measures. This will also mean police working harder and
staying one step ahead of the attackers," he said.

Police released a list of 467 locations that are under close watch for possible
terror attacks, including 164 under "special attention". The list mostly names
offices of the media, homes of important people and political figures on both
the government and opposition side, train terminals and fuel depots.

The ranking of media premises on the list was based on their stance towards
former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra. The Nation is 66th on the list while
Thai Rath, Daily News, and Naew Na rank 153, 154 and 155, respectively.

A joint security operation of the military and the Department of Special
Investigation has been launched after a series of analyses and forecasts by
intelligence agencies of regular bomb attacks and related incidents.

The DSI is now authorised to seek logistical support and help from troops in
situations that are beyond the hands of police, DSI secretary-general Tharit
Phengdit said yesterday.

Extra security has been posted around Parliament on a special request from
Speaker Chai Chidchob, who said the measures were in place despite his comment
that Parliament should not be a target for terror attacks.

Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva said the state of emergency could possibly be
lifted in certain provinces by tomorrow, following a recommendation by the
government's Centre for Resolution of the Emergency Situation.

Asked to comment on a police report that five to six politicians were behind the
bomb-related incidents, he said the Cabinet was not directly briefed about the
matter. He vowed to take action against anyone found involved and implicated by
evidence.

Deputy Prime Minister Suthep Thaugsuban said Defence Minister Prawit Wongsuwan
would take over the CRES director position from him while he was deactivated
temporarily to run in a by-election in his home province of Surat Thani. He also
declined to give interviews or speak publicly until after election day on
October 30, to avoid violating electoral laws.

Meanwhile, a hoax motorcycle bomb was found yesterday near a police box near
Khae Rai intersection in Nonthaburi province. The brown Yamaha RX-Z with an
Ayutthaya licence plate had a plastic bottle full of petrol as well as wiring
connected to a briefcase.

Bomb-disposal officers opened the briefcase and found it contained hand tools
and sparkplugs. The officers said it was a set-up meant to be a bomb scare. The
incident resulted in heavy traffic congestion after a few lanes of all nearby
roads were closed.

Meanwhile, after the surrender and confession of a suspect involved in the
weapons theft from an Army depot in Lop Buri, police found 13 rocket-propelled
grenades in a pond off a main highway in neighbouring Saraburi province.

Sgt-Major Prawit Cherngkheeree, who serves with the Army's Weapon Production
Centre based in Lop Buri, located the rockets for police divers to retrieve.
They have the same serial numbers as those reported stolen from the Army's
Ordnance Department storage.

Now, 29 of the 39 stolen rockets have been retrieved, with 10 still missing.
Yesterday's discovery of the 13 rockets contradicted earlier statements by the
government and security agencies that all 39 had been delivered to Burma's Wa
militants.

Source: The Nation website, Bangkok, in English 30 Sep 10

LOAD-DATE: September 30, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

Austrian Interior Ministry sees "no acute danger of terrorist attacks"

LENGTH: 157 words

[Report by Anna Gabriel: "Europe in Fear of Terrorist Attacks"]

It should have been a devastating series of attacks. Terrorists trained in
Pakistan planned simultaneous commando attacks in big cities in Germany, France,
and Great Britain. Intelligence services just managed to prevent the attacks.
This is reported by British and US media. [passage omitted]

The Austrian Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution and
Antiterrorism remains calm. There is "still no acute danger of terrorist
attacks" in Austria, there are "no indications pointing to attacks," Interior
Ministry spokesman Harald Noschiel assured Die Presse. Those responsible in the
countries in question must, however, sensitize and warn the people. Noschiel was
unable to assess what is behind the media reports on the prevented attacks.
[passage omitted]

                          September 30, 2010 Thursday

Terrorism: Irish dissident attack on UK likely, Garda warns

BYLINE: Henry McDonald, Ireland correspondent

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 94 words


A terrorist attack on mainland Britain by dissident Irish republicans remains a
strong possibility, Ireland's top police officer said yesterday, as the Guardian
learned that UK banks have stepped up security in Northern Ireland. The Garda
commissioner, Fachtna Murphy, said that the threat posed by dissident
republicans had gone from moderate to substantial. Murphy said the intent had
always been there, but the capability within dissident groups to carry out
bombings had increased, as was evident by recent bomb attacks such as that on
Newry courthouse in February.

                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             October 1, 2010 Friday

Police link Stavropol bombs to earlier terror attacks in southern Russia

LENGTH: 305 words


The two improvised explosive devices (IED) that were rendered safe in Russia's
southern town of Stavropol on 30 September may have been planted by the same
persons who staged a cafe blast in Pyatigorsk on 17 August, RIA-Novosti news
agency reported on 1 October.

"This is indicated by the fact that the explosive devices were similar in
construction and the modi operandi were similar," the agency quoted a
top-ranking source in the North Caucasus Federal District law-enforcement
agencies as saying.

The report said that the dead man found in the car that contained one of the two
Stavropol IEDs, earlier identified as local resident Gennadiy Tolboyev, was a
taxi driver.

Speaking of the recent spate of terrorist attacks in Russia's southern regions,
the source said: "There are reasons to believe that all these terrorist attacks
were planned and staged by one the same terrorist group."

In a separate report on the same day RIA Novosti said that rain had prevented
the detonation of the car bomb in Stavropol.

The report said that the dead man found in the car had several gunshot wounds at
the back of his skull. The car contained a radio-controlled IED consisting of
about 60 kg of explosive mixture of ammonium nitrate and aluminium powder, a
nine-volt battery, wires and components of a car alarm, the agency said. Forty
metres away, another radio-controlled IED was found disguised as a heap of
litter.

The report quoted Zhannett Karpel, acting prosecutor of Stavropol's
Promyshlennyy district, as saying: "If the explosive device had detonated the
consequences would have been dire, but the rain prevented this from happening by
dampening the nitrate and the ammonia [as received]." She said the IED had been
laced with iron bolts and ball bearings.

Sources: RIA Novosti news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0541 and 0301 gmt 1 Oct 10

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            October 2, 2010 Saturday

Rising terror attacks may lead US to abandon Pakistan-Afghan supply route- paper

LENGTH: 1078 words


Text of report by Amir Mir headlined "US may abandon Pak-Afghan supply route"
published by Pakistani newspaper The News website on 2 October

Lahore: Upset over mounting terror attacks targeting the Nato/ISAF supply trucks
travelling to Afghanistan via Pakistan, the high command of the US-led allied
forces stationed in Afghanistan has warned the decision makers in Islamabad that
their failure to prevent such assaults could force them to abandon Pakistan as
the major supply route to Afghanistan.

According to highly-informed diplomatic sources in Islamabad, the rising number
of terrorist attacks on the Nato-ISAF convoys, coupled with the sudden crisis
brought about by the recent floods in Pakistan, which have washed away several
key bridges and highways, have compelled the high ups of the US-led allied
forces to seek alternative supply routes for the international forces stationed
in Afghanistan.

Pakistan currently receives a huge reimbursement of economic and military
assistance from the United States for providing these logistical facilities to
the war-torn country. The Nato/ISAF convoys travelling through Pakistan are the
principal source of logistical support for the US-led allied forces in
Afghanistan. It being the shortest and most economical route, almost 75 per cent
of ammunition, vehicles, foodstuff and around 50 per cent of fuel for the
Nato-ISAF forces fighting against the Taliban militia in Afghanistan have been
transported via Pakistan for the last many years.

Pakistan has already blocked a key supply route for the US-led Nato force in
Afghanistan on September 30, 2010 after a cross-border helicopter attack in
which three Pakistani troops were killed. The move came a day after Pakistan
threatened to stop protecting the Nato/ISAF supply routes to Afghanistan after a
series of cross border aerial attacks by the Afghanistan based international
forces, killing several innocent Pakistanis, including three soldiers.

Around 100 Nato/ISAF vehicles have already been held up at Pakistan's border
with Afghanistan after these aerial attacks, following which 27 oil tankers
carrying fuel for the Nato/ISAF forces were set ablaze by Taliban-linked
militants in the Shikarpur district of the Sindh province on Thursday night. The
oil tankers have been torched a few weeks after Interior Minister Rehman Malik's
statement that the Nato/ISAF authorities were themselves responsible for the
safety of its supply lines, and that the Pakistan's federal and provincial
governments cannot provide security to the 4,000 trucks, which travel across
Pakistan daily.

Available figures show that in a short span of just one month (from 1 Sept to 30
Sept), as many as 22 Nato convoys were targeted by the militants, taking the
total tally of such assaults for the year 2010 to 55. The convoys that were
targeted included fuel tankers, each of which carries about 45,000 litres of
oil, as well as containers with unspecified quantities of logistic material for
the 120,000-strong Nato/ISAF forces, besides armoured transport for the allied
forces, which were either torched or looted by the militants.

Apart from tonnes of small commodities being transported everyday from Pakistan
to Afghanistan, choppers and Humvees were also transshipped via this route in
the past few years. However, diplomatic circles in the federal capital say,
having realized that the Pak-Afghan supply route was not safe now, the high
command of the allied forces has decided to warn Pakistan and accelerate efforts
to secure an agreement with some of the former Russian states to allow food and
military supplies to pass through the Central Asian Republics (CARs).

That the Americans have been trying to secure multiple supply routes for
transportation of food and military supplies to Afghanistan is not a secret.
Landlocked, mountainous, inundated by civil war and extreme underdeveloped
Afghanistan is surrounded by a clutch of hostile, apprehensive, barely
functioning sovereignties. But the allied forces stationed there require a
phenomenal mass of supplies from ammunition to toothbrushes, fuel, computers,
night-vision goggles, concertina wire et cetera, et cetera -- at the rate of
thousands of tons a day.

And the problem is that these trucks are 100 per cent civilian-operated, with no
military escorts, mainly because of the Pakistani sensitivities about its
sovereignty. Therefore, these trucks become an easy target of the militants,
prompting the Americans to seek alternative supply routes from countries, which
can also allow security men to guard them.

According to Islamabad-based diplomatic circles, the Americans are now trying to
secure three different alternative supply routes for Afghanistan. The first one
is the northern route, which starts in the Latvian port of Riga, the largest
all-weather harbour on the Baltic Sea, where container ships offload their cargo
onto Russian trains. The shipments roll south through Russia, then southeast
around the Caspian Sea through Kazakhstan and finally south through Uzbekistan
until they cross the frontier into north Afghanistan. The Russian train-lines
were built to supply Russia's own war in Afghanistan in the 1980s, and today
Moscow's cooperation is making them available for use by the US-led Nato/ISAF
forces in their own Afghan campaign.

The second one is the southern route, which transits the Caucuses, completely
bypassing Russia, from Georgia. Starting from the Black Sea port, Ponti, it
travels north to Azerbaijan and its port, Baku, where goods are loaded onto
ferries to cross the Caspian Sea. Landfall is Kazakhstan, where the goods are
carried by trucks to Uzbekistan and finally Afghanistan. While shorter than the
northern route, it is more expensive because of the on-and-off loading from
trucks to ferries and back onto trucks.

A third route, which is actually a spur of the northern route, bypasses
Uzbekistan and proceeds from Kazakhstan via Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan, which has
a northeast border with Afghanistan. But this route is hampered by bad road
conditions in Tajikistan.

However, there are those in the diplomatic circles who believe that it would be
hard for the Americans to induce any of the above former Russian states because
many of their leaders believe that the American plans to get military supplies
via their countries could draw the former Soviet colony into the battle as
Cambodia was dragged into the Vietnam war.

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 02 Oct 10

LOAD-DATE: October 2, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2010 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved

                                  Daily Record

                           October 2, 2010, Saturday

TANKER ATTACK TERROR

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 117 words


GUNMEN sparked a massive blaze yesterday when they attacked at least 27 tankers
carrying fuel for Nato troops in Afghanistan.

The trucks were targeted in southern Pakistan on the day the country shut a
major border crossing. The closure was in protest at a Nato incursion which saw
three Pakistani soldiers killed.

No one was thought to have been killed or wounded in the tanker attack.

Police said the tankers were parked at a terminal when gunmen opened fire,
forcing people to flee before the vehicles were set ablaze.

The trucks were still alight several hours later.

The closure of the Torkham border crossing means Nato vehicles must use Chaman,
creating a bottleneck which terrorists can easily exploit.

                              102 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                  Guardian.com

                            October 2, 2010 Saturday

Nigerian authorities 'were warned about terrorist attack on capital'

BYLINE: David Battyguardian.co.uk

LENGTH: 623 words

ABSTRACT

Government accused of failing to avert independence day bombing, despite
security warning from British intelligence

FULL TEXT

Questions have been raised about how much the Nigerian authorities knew about a
militant bomb attack that killed 12 people in the capital, Abuja.

It has emerged that British dignitaries pulled out of a parade yesterday,
marking the 50th anniversary of Nigeria's independence, after receiving a
warning of a security risk. The event was later hit by three car bombs.

The explosions late yesterday morning came an hour after the main militant group
in the oil-rich southern delta, the Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger
Delta (Mend), threatened in an email to attack the festivities and warned people
to evacuate the area.

Nigerian newspaper This Day, citing sources in the presidency, said the
government had failed to avert the attack despite receiving a warning from
British intelligence.

"We tried our best, working on several locations, but somehow we couldn't foil
the plot," an unnamed senior minister told the paper.

The Queen's representative, the Duke of Gloucester, was scheduled to attend the
parade but did not, while former prime minister Gordon Brown cancelled his visit
to the country altogether.

Two car bombs detonated outside the justice ministry in Abuja. A third, smaller
explosion hit a venue at nearby Eagle Square, where President Goodluck Jonathan
sat with hundreds of Nigerian and foreign dignitaries. Police spokesman Jimoh
Moshoo said the blasts killed 12 people and injured 17.

Jonathan, who faces an election next year, left in an armoured limousine without
making a scheduled address. The celebrations, with army bands, dancing children
and air force displays, continued without him.

Mend has been fighting for years for a greater share of oil revenues from the
Niger delta, home to Africa's biggest oil and gas industry. The delta, which is
also home to the president, is impoverished and polluted by oil spills.

In its warning email, Mend said: "For 50 years, the people of the Niger delta
have had their land and resources stolen from them." The group has previously
operated primarily in the delta, hundreds of miles from the capital, although it
has struck offshore oil installations and in the country's commercial capital,
Lagos. Yesterday's attacks, the first on Abuja and in defiance of tight security
surrounding the celebrations marking Nigeria's independence from the UK, are the
militants' boldest yet.

Mend's attacks subsided after an amnesty deal last year provided cash for
fighters and the promise of job training. However, many ex-fighters say the
government has failed to fulfil its promises.

Elizabeth Donnelly, Africa programme manager at the foreign policy thinktank
Chatham House, said: "This latest violence has broken the amnesty, but the
questions will be which part of Mend has perpetrated the violence - it could be
men from the lower ranks who did not benefit from the deal - and whether or not
this is part of a bigger, longer-term strategy."

She added that few ordinary Nigerians would have sympathy with the terrorists,
but neither did many have confidence in the government.

Nigeria's oil production has climbed from about 1.6m barrels a day before the
amnesty to about 2m now. A return to violence could have implications for
Nigeria's economic growth.

Alan Cameron, of Business Monitor International, said the attacks risked
reinforcing foreign perceptions that Nigeria was at risk of slipping into
violence, necessitating military intervention, or even a coup. But he added: "In
our view, these fears are still a little overdone, although today's incident
will create huge pressure on Jonathan to show that he can keep the situation
under control."

LOAD-DATE: October 4, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Israel condemns Abuja attack, backs Nigeria's fight against terror

                              104 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                                 Sunday Express

                             October 3, 2010 Sunday
                                U.K. 1st Edition

Bin Laden told UK terrorists to launch attack

BYLINE: By James Murray and Neil Doyle

SECTION: NEWS; 02

LENGTH: 522  words


AL QAEDA sleepers in Britain were ordered to attack cities in a manual of death
drawn up on the express instructions of Osama Bin Laden, it was revealed
yesterday.

Security services fear there may be attempts to storm overnment buildings as the
54-page document details how to attack well-protected offices.

They know two British brothers in Pakistan have been actively engaged in the
plot, which would also target hotels and tourist spots in London.

Fighters are urged to hurl hand grenades into the ground floor of buildings
before rushing in with machine guns and other weapons.

The document, shown to the Sunday Express, carries a picture of one of Bin
Laden's followers in Arab head dress reaching for a rocket propelled grenade and
is titled "Guidance for street fighters".

It is written in Arabic and was produced by a central coordinating unit called
the Office of Mujahideen Services acting on the orders of Bin Laden, mastermind
of the 9/11 attacks on New York's Twin Towers in 2001. In matter-of-fact
language, it chillingly states: "The success of operations within buildings,
whether the unit is attacking or defending, or in the process of withdrawing,
depends on the ability of the individual to direct his fire on the enemy and
silence them.

"Therefore, the individual must choose the appropriate shooting location which
does not expose him to danger.

Fighting in cities is one of the most violent and difficult forms of combat.

"When entering a building or room, take care to avoid using door handles. Fire
short busts into the door then kick it down."

The document was placed on Al Qaeda websites eight days ago. To stretch the
police and emergency services to the limit, Bin Laden also ordered a series of
car bomb attacks.

The onslaught on Britain is timed to coincide with similar attacks in France and
Germany and would be similar to the 2008 Mumbai terrorist attacks, when nine Al
Qaedalinked gunmen stormed the city and killed 175 people in a three-day rampage
that also left more than 300 injured.

Fighters selected for the task must possess a high degree of physical fitness
and be trained in self-defence, says the terror guide. They should move quickly
between buildings, using obstructions and smoke to avoid enemy fire.

US counter terrorism experts confirmed yesterday that Bin Laden was behind the
plot. He has also issued a new nine-minute recording in which he calls for aid
to help flood victims in Pakistan.

If legitimate, the tape shows that the terrorist leader is in apparent good
health as his voice sounds strong and clear.

One of the two British brothers was apparently killed in a drone attack in
Pakistan earlier this month but the whereabouts of the other is not known.

They have been working at terror training camps with eight German-speaking
accomplices, who are also being monitored. Two US drone attacks killed 22
militants in Pakistan yesterday. There were 21 similar attacks in September, the
highest number in a single month on record.

Leaders of the plot have been advised to follow the example of insurgents in Ira
q by using Skygrabber compute r software to detect the presence of drone
aircraft.

LOAD-DATE: October 4, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2010 EXPRESS NEWSPAPERS
                              All Rights Reserved

                              105 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                                 Sunday Express

                                October 3, 2010
                                   Edition 3;
                                National Edition

Bin Laden told UK terrorists to launch attack

BYLINE: James Murray, Neil Doyle

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 650 words


AL QAEDA sleepers in Britain were ordered to attack cities in a manual of death
drawn up on the express instructions of Osama Bin Laden, it was revealed
yesterday.

Security services fear there may be attempts to storm government buildings as
the 54-page document details how to attack well-protected offices.

They know two British brothers in Pakistan have been actively engaged in the
plot, which would also target hotels and tourist spots in London.

Fighters are urged to hurl hand grenades into the ground floor of buildings
before rushing in with machine guns and other weapons.

The document, shown to the Sunday Express, carries a picture of one of Bin
Laden's followers in Arab head dress reaching for a rocket propelled grenade and
is titled "Guidance for street fighters".

It is written in Arabic and was produced by a central coordinating unit called
the Office of Mujahideen Services acting on the orders of Bin Laden, mastermind
of the 9/11 attacks  on New York's Twin Towers in 2001.

In matter-of-fact language, it chillingly states: "The success of operations
within buildings, whether the unit is attacking or defending, or in the process
of withdrawing, depends on the ability of the individual to direct his f re on
the enemy and silence them.

"Therefore, the individual must choose the appropriate shooting location which
does not expose him to danger. Fighting in cities is one of the most violent and
difficult forms of combat.

"When entering a building or room, take care to avoid using door handles. Fire
short busts into the door then kick it down."

The document was placed on Al Qaeda websites eight days ago. To stretch the
police and emergency services to the limit, Bin Laden also ordered a series of
car bomb attacks.

The onslaught on Britain is timed to coincide with similar attacks in France and
Germany and would be similar to the 2008 Mumbai terrorist attacks, when nine Al
Qaedalinked gunmen stormed the city and killed 175 people in a three-day rampage
that also left more than 300 injured.

Fighters selected for the task must possess a high degree of physical fitness
and be trained in self-defence, says Moon, sun and tides the terror guide. They
should move quickly between buildings, using obstructions and smoke to avoid
enemy fire.

US counter terrorism experts confirmed yesterday that Bin Laden was behind the
plot. He has also issued a new nine-minute recording in which he calls for aid
to help flood victims in Pakistan.

If legitimate, the tape shows that the terrorist leader is in apparent good
health as his voice sounds strong and clear. Unsettled and windy and central
Spain east, some heavy thunder.

One of the two British brothers was apparently killed in a drone attack in
Pakistan earlier this month but the whereabouts of the other is not known.

They have been working at terror training camps with eight German-speaking
accomplices, who are also being monitored. Two US drone attacks killed 22
militants in Pakistan yesterday. There were 21 similar attacks in September, the
highest number in a single month on record.

Leaders of the plot have been advised to follow the example of insurgents in
Iraq by using Skygrabber computer software to detect the presence of drone
aircraft.

COMMENT: PAGE 36

Renewed fears may prompt US alert 13

US CITIZENS could be warned to stay away from high-profile sites in Europe, amid
renewed fears over terror attacks.

British and American officials are said to have been in contact over the
possibility of a broad alert.

Such a move could hit tourism because visitor sites and transport hubs are
likely to be highlighted as potential danger spots.

However, reports suggest any warning is likely to be vague. People will be urged
to exercise caution, rather than cancel travel plans altogether.

On Tuesday night the Eiffel Tower in Paris was evacuated after a bomb threat was
received. It was the second such alert at the tower in two weeks.

                              106 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                 Yorkshire Post

                             October 3, 2010 Sunday

Travellers in Europe given 'high risk' warning of terror attacks

BYLINE: Grace Hammond

LENGTH: 496 words



HIGHLIGHT: THE British and US governments upgraded their travel advice for
Europe yesterday following a series of terror alerts.


 The Foreign Office warned that there was a "high threat" of attacks in
countries including France and Germany, rather than the "general threat"
previously identified.

Meanwhile, the State Department issued guidance urging Americans to be vigilant
when visiting Europe, highlighting the "potential for terrorists to attack
public transportation systems and other tourist infrastructure".

The heightened warnings came after British intelligence officials intercepted a
credible plot linked to terror group al-Qaida last week.

The planned attack would reportedly have been similar to the deadly
commando-style raids in Mumbai, India, two years ago, with cities in France and
Germany also targeted at the same time.

Pakistani and Western intelligence officials also said last night that dozens of
Muslim militants with European citizenship are believed to be hiding out in the
lawless tribal area of north western Pakistan, training for missions that could
include terror attacks in European capitals,

A senior official of Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence agency said there
were believed to be "several dozen" people with European citizenship -many of
Pakistani origin - among the Islamic extremists operating in the lawless border
area.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said foreigners in the area
also include Chechens, Uzbeks, Arabs and Turks, one of whom was a former F-16
pilot in the Turkish air force.

On Tuesday night the Eiffel Tower in Paris was evacuated following a bomb threat
called in from a phone booth. It was the second such alert at the tower in two
weeks. A search by bomb experts found nothing unusual, and the tower was
reopened within hours.

On Friday, Sweden announced it has raised its threat alert to the highest level
ever because of an increased threat of terror attacks.

There has been speculation that terror leader Osama bin Laden could be
masterminding the latest plots personally.

The Foreign Office advice now states: "Like other large European countries, the
French/German authorities continue to consider that there is a high threat of
terrorism.

"Attacks could be indiscriminate, including in places frequented by expatriates
and foreign travellers."

Home Secretary Theresa May urged the British public to report any suspicious
activity to help police and security services disrupt the terrorists.

"The first and most important duty of this government is the protection and
security of the British people and visitors to the UK," Mrs May said.

She added that the UK was working closely with the US on counter-terrorism, and
its new guidance was "consistent with our assessment".

The US State Department stopped short of recommending that citizens stay away
from high-profile sites in Europe - as was thought to have been under
consideration before.

Instead the department said: "US citizens should take every precaution to be
aware of their surroundings and to adopt appropriate safety measures to protect
themselves when travelling."

LOAD-DATE: October 4, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: YPOS

                              All Rights Reserved

                             October 4, 2010 Monday

Japanese citizens alerted for possible terror attacks in Europe

LENGTH: 136 words


Text of report in English by Japan's largest news agency Kyodo

Tokyo, Oct. 4 Kyodo - The Foreign Ministry issued a travel alert Monday for
Japanese citizens living or travelling in Europe, warning them of possible
terrorist attacks by the al-Qaida network and other groups in the wake of
similar alerts issued by the US and British governments.

The alert called on Japanese nationals to exercise full caution at possible
terror attack targets, such as government facilities, public transport systems
and tourist spots.

According to the ministry, the United States has warned that al-Qaida and
affiliated organizations are planning terror attacks in Europe, while Britain
raised its four-stage terrorism threat alert to the highest level for France and
Germany.

Source: Kyodo News Service, Tokyo, in English 0711 gmt 4 Oct 10

Islamist party chief says army failed to prevent terror attacks in Pakistan

LENGTH: 221 words


Text of report headlined "Army failed to prevent terror attacks: JI" published
by Pakistani newspaper Dawn website on 4 October

Murree, 3 October: Jamaat-i-Islami (JI) chief Syed Munawar Hassan here on Sunday
[3 October] said during the last two years Pakistan Army could not prevent
terrorist attacks in the country due to its involvement in 'others' war.

Speaking at an 'Ittehad-i-Ummat' conference at Ausia near here, he said even the
GHQ in Rawalpindi and Data Darbar Lahore came under terror attacks.

The JI chief said drone attacks on Pakistani territory continued with the
alleged consent of the government in which hundreds of innocent Pakistanis had
been killed.

He said allies of the government were equally responsible for the killing of
innocent people at the hands of Nanto forces.

He said 57 Muslim countries remained dependent on America for their interests.
The US and its stooge countries are after the blood of Muslims in Afghanistan
and Iraq, he added.

Mr Hassan said a highly qualified Muslim woman has been sentenced to 86 years
imprisonment in the US where no male was ever handed down such a long jail term.

He welcomed suspension of supply to Nato forces and the condemnation by the
government of Pakistan and the army of the Nato incursions into our territory.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 04 Oct 10

                               Belfast Telegraph

                             October 4, 2010 Monday
                                 First Edition

'High threat' of imminent terror attacks in Europe

BYLINE: DAVID USBORNE

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 280 words


AMERICANS in Europe, and those with plans to visit, were given a warning by the
US State Department yesterday to "take every precaution" because of the elevated
threat of terrorist attacks that could be aimed at popular tourist spots as well
as transportation hubs.

After the alert was issued yesterday morning in Washington DC, British Home
Secretary Theresa May said it was consistent with the British view of the
threat. The Foreign Office warned of a "high threat" of attacks in countries
including France and Germany.

The warnings come after several days of media reports, partly confirmed by
government sources, of new intelligence suggesting that attacks in Europe may be
imminent and may resemble the 2008 commando-style assaults in Mumbai, India,
that left more than 170 people dead.

No individual countries were singled out in the American alert. Officials noted
also that there were still no plans last night for the US administration to
issue a more grave travel "warning", which would explicitly encourage Americans
to stay away from European destinations. The purpose of the alert, they said,
was to ensure vigilance.

"US citizens are reminded of the potential for terrorists to attack public
transportation systems as well as other tourist infrastructure," the State
Department said.

"Terrorists have targeted and attacked subway and rail systems, as well as
aviation and maritime services."

Almost simultaneously yesterday, the Foreign Office upgraded its travel advisory
about France and Germany, telling Britons that the threat of terrorist actions
in those countries was considered high. Previously, the risk in Germany and
France had been pegged as "general" by London.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: BT

                              110 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                               Belfast Telegraph

                             October 4, 2010 Monday
                                  City Edition

New terror attack warning for EuropeAppeal: Theresa May

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 323 words


TRAVELLERS faced a warning about possible terror attacks today after both the UK
and US governments issued new alerts.

The Foreign Office warned that there was a "high threat" of attacks in countries
including France and Germany, rather than the "general threat" previously
identified.

The US State Department urged Americans to be vigilant when visiting Europe,
highlighting the "potential for terrorists to attack public transportation
systems and other tourist infrastructure".

The heightened warnings came after British intelligence officials intercepted a
credible al Qaida-linked plot last week.

The planned attack would reportedly have been similar to the commando-style
raids in Mumbai, India, two years ago, with cities in France and Germany also
targeted at the same time.

Last Tuesday the Eiffel Tower in Paris was evacuated following a bomb threat
called in from a telephone booth -- the second such alert at the tower in two
weeks. A search by bomb experts found nothing unusual and it was reopened within
hours.

The Foreign Office advice now states: "Like other large European countries, the
French/German authorities continue to consider that there is a high threat of
terrorism.

"Attacks could be indiscriminate, including in places frequented by expatriates
and foreign travellers."

Home Secretary Theresa May urged the public to report any suspicious activity.

"We face a real and serious threat from terrorism. Our threat level remains at
severe -- meaning that an attack is highly likely. I would urge the public to
report any suspicious activity to the police in support of the efforts of our
security services to discover, track and disrupt terrorist activity," she said.

The State Department stopped short of recommending citizens stay away from
high-profile sites.

"US citizens should take every precaution to be aware of their surroundings and
to adopt appropriate safety measures to protect themselves when travelling," it
said.

                              111 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                BreakingNews.ie

                      October 4, 2010 Monday 12:36 PM GMT

Japan issues travel warning as fear of terror attack in EU grows

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 641 words


Japan issued a travel alert for Europe today, joining Britain and the US in
warning of a possible terrorist attack by al-Qaida or other groups, but tourists
appeared to be taking the mounting warnings in their stride.

The Foreign Ministry in Tokyo urged Japanese citizens to be cautious when using
public transport or visiting popular tourist sites - issuing another blow to
Europe's tourism industry, which is just starting to recover from the global
financial crisis.

European authorities - especially in Britain, France and Germany - tightened
efforts to keep the public safe in the wake of warnings by officials that the
terrorism threat is high and extra vigilance is warranted.

Last week, a Pakistani intelligence official said eight Germans and two British
brothers were at the heart of an al-Qaida-linked terror plot against European
cities, but the plan was still in its early stages, with the suspects calling
acquaintances in Europe to plan logistics.

The official said the suspects were hiding in North Waziristan, a Pakistani
tribal region where militancy is rife and where the US has increased its
drone-fired missile strikes in recent weeks.

Security officials say terrorists may be plotting attacks in Europe with assault
weapons on public places, similar to the deadly 2008 shooting spree in Mumbai,
India. European officials have provided no details about specific targets.

Earlier today, French police arrested a 53-year-old man suspected of links to
bomb threats including one on Friday at a Paris railway hub, an official with
knowledge of the investigation said.

The suspect, who was not identified, was detained south-west of the capital for
possible links to a phone-in threat at the Saint-Lazare train station.

French authorities recorded nine bomb alerts in the capital in September,
including two at the Eiffel Tower - a threefold increase from a year earlier. No
explosives were found.

The US State Department alert on Sunday advised the hundreds of thousands of
American citizens living or travelling in Europe to take more precaution about
their personal security.

Britain's Foreign Office warned travellers to France and Germany that the terror
threat in the countries was high.

Business travellers and tourists arriving today at Paris' Charles de Gaulle
airport from the US said they were aware of the new warnings but weren't
changing their plans.

"I'm very happy to be here in France. I think we're very safe, and I trust the
French government to keep us safe," said James O'Connell, a 59-year-old from
Pittsburgh, arriving in Paris for a seven-day holiday.

Karen Bilh, a 39-year-old traveller, arrived in Paris from Cincinnati.

"We'll pay extra caution and if there's terror threats, we'll listen to police
in the area. We're excited about the trip," she said.

Travellers taking the Eurostar trains between London and Paris were similarly
determined not to let the warnings disrupt their plans.

Jennifer D'Antoni, who owns a clothing shop in Britain, was in Paris to
celebrate her birthday.

"I had a wonderful time and I'll come back again. In fact, I wish I was here for
another day because I didn't get to see everything. We are just going to be a
bit more cautious getting on the train," she said.

Yet Germans - authorities and citizens alike - were not convinced of the need
for concern.

"I think it is quite exaggerated," said Marian Sutholt, 25, of Berlin. "If you
worry all the time, you actually live up exactly to what the terrorists want. So
you should take things as they come and not worry too much. Hopefully nothing
will happen."

But John Gooley, a tourist from Portland, Oregon, was more cautious.

"Berlin is an amazing city, it's a beautiful city, but I'd probably recommend
staying in smaller cities," he said. "I am still happy to travel all throughout
Europe, but for right now I might avoid Paris, Berlin, London."

LOAD-DATE: October 4, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication


                    Copyright 2010 Thomas Crosbie Media Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved

                              112 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                                  The Express

                             October 4, 2010 Monday
                                U.K. 3rd Edition

Britons 'at high risk of terrorist attacks'

BYLINE: By Padraic Flanagan

SECTION: NEWS; 02

LENGTH: 427  words


BRITONS who travel to France and Germany face a "high threat" of a terrorist
attack, it was revealed last night.

The Foreign Office raised its risk warning from a "general threat" alert after
the US upgraded travel advice to its own citizens.

The US State Department urged Americans in Europe to be vigilant, stressing the
"potential for terrorists to attack public transport and other tourist
infrastructure".

Last night it was claimed the risk of an attack on mainland Britain was also
higher, with intelligence officers fearing a commando-style attack, possibly on
a tourist location.

It is thought dozens of Al Qaeda operatives are being watched, according to
reports. One suggestion was that they may already have selected a target,
completed their surveillance and were waiting for the order to attack.

British intelligence officers at GCHQ, in Cheltenham, intercepted a credible Al
Qaeda-linked plot last week.

They picked up phone calls made by British citizens at terrorist training camps
in Pakistan and matched the voice prints to suspects in Rochdale and the
Midlands.

Security sources said the attack would be similar to commando-style raids in
Mumbai, India, two years ago with cities in France and Germany targeted.

Two brothers from Britain and eight German citizens were reported to be
involved, although Pakistani intelligence officials said the plan was still in
its early stages.

US intelligence officials believe Osama Bin Laden is the mastermind behind plots
to attack European cities.

On Tuesday, the Eiffel Tower in Paris was evacuated after a bomb threat was made
from a telephone booth. It was the second such alert in two weeks. A search
found nothing.

On Friday Sweden said it had raised its alert level to its highest-ever while in
Naples police arrested a 24-year-old French citizen of North African origin last
being an Al Qaeda member.

French defence minister Herve Morin said: "The terrorist threat exists and could
hit us any moment."

The Foreign Office advice now reads: "The French German authorities continue to
consider that there is a high threat of terrorism.

"Attacks could be indiscriminate, including in places frequented by expatriates
and foreign travellers."

Home Secretary Theresa May said: "We face a real and serious threat from
terrorism. Our threat level remains at severe, meaning that an attack is highly
likely.

"I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police."

Mrs May said Britain was working closely with the US on counter-terrorism
measures and its new guidance was "consistent with our assessment".

Britons 'at high risk of terrorist attacks'

BYLINE: By Padraic Flanagan

SECTION: NEWS; 02

LENGTH: 436  words


BRITONS who travel to France and Germany face a "high threat" of a terrorist
attack, it was revealed last night.

The Foreign Office raised its risk warning from a "general threat" alert after
the US upgraded travel advice to its own citizens.

The US State Department urged Americans in Europe to be vigilant, stressing the
"potential for terrorists to attack public transport and other tourist
infrastructure".

Both warnings came after British intelligence officers at GCHQ, in Cheltenham,
intercepted a credible Al Qaeda-linked plot last week.

They picked up phone calls made by British citizens at terrorist training camps
in Pakistan and matched the voice prints to suspects in Rochdale and the
Midlands.

Security sources said the planned attack would be similar to commando-style
raids in Mumbai, India, two years ago with cities in France and Germany also
targeted.

Two brothers from Britain and eight German citizens were reported to be
involved, although Pakistani intelligence officials said the plan was still in
its early stages.

US intelligence officials believe Osama Bin Laden is the mastermind behind plots
to attack European cities.

On Tuesday, the Eiffel Tower in Paris was evacuated after a bomb threat was made
from a telephone booth. It was the second such alert in two weeks. A search
found nothing and it was re-opened within hours.

On Friday Sweden said it had raised its alert level to its highest-ever while in
Naples police arrested a 24-year-old French citizen of North African origin last
month who is suspected of being an Al Qaeda member.

French defence minister Herve Morin said: "The terrorist threat exists and could
hit us any moment."

The Foreign Office advice now reads: "The French/ German authorities continue to
consider that there is a high threat of terrorism.

"Attacks could be indiscriminate, including in places frequented by expatriates
and foreign travellers."

Home Secretary Theresa May said: "We face a real and serious threat from
terrorism. Our threat level remains at severe, meaning that an attack is highly
likely.

"I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police."

Mrs May said Britain was working closely with the US on counter-terrorism
measures and its new guidance was "consistent with our assessment".

The US State Department stopped short of advising citizens to stay away from
high-profile sites in Europe.

"Current information suggests Al Qaeda and affiliated organisations continue to
plan terrorist attacks, " it said. "US citizens should take every precaution to
be aware of their surroundings and adopt appropriate safety measures when
travelling."

                              Gloucestershire Echo

                             October 4, 2010 Monday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

GCHQ team foils terror attack plan

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 221 words


WORKERS at GCHQ helped foil a UK terror attack, according to reports.

National news reports yesterday said the Cheltenham intelligence-gathering
centre prevented a Mumbai-style attack on London.

Telephone calls made by British jihadists at a training camp in the tribal
borders of Pakistan were intercepted to identify the suspects.

Terrorist camps were located and American forces launched drone attacks.

Some of the terrorists plotting the attack were identified when GCHQ matched
their voices against a secret database, according to the reports.

News of the foiled plot came on the day the Foreign Office updated its travel
advice for Europe, warning of a "high threat" of attacks in countries including
France and Germany.

Previously, it had advised only of a "general threat", but officials said the
safety of Britons abroad was of major concer n.

The US government had earlier warned its citizens to be vigilant when in Europe
because of the threat of an unspecific al-Qaeda attack.

The warnings came one week after GCHQ was said to have intercepted the
Islamist-linked terror plot.

The attack would reportedly have been similar to the deadly commando-style raids
in Mumbai, India, two years ago when 174 people died.

A GCHQ spokesman said he was unable to confirm or deny the reports because it
"would put people's lives at risk".

LOAD-DATE: October 6, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: GLE


                      Copyright 2010 Gloucestershire Echo
                              All Rights Reserved

Terrorist attack warnings

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 177 words


THE UK and US governments have upgraded their travel advice for Europe following
a series of terror alerts.

The Foreign Office warned that there was a "high threat" of attacks in countries
including France and Germany, rather than the "general threat" previously
identified.

Meanwhile, the State Department issued guidance urging Americans to be vigilant
when visiting Europe, highlighting the "potential for terrorists to attack
public transportation systems and other tourist infrastructure".

The heightened warnings came after British intelligence officials intercepted a
credible al Qaida-linked plot last week.

The planned attack would reportedly have been similar to the deadly
commando-style raids in Mumbai, India, two years ago, with cities in France and
Germany also targeted at the same time.

On Tuesday night the Eiffel Tower in Paris was evacuated following a bomb threat
called in from a telephone booth. It was the second such alert at the tower in
two weeks.

A search by bomb experts found nothing unusual, and it was reopened within
hours.

LOAD-DATE: October 4, 2010

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

following a series of terror alerts.

The Foreign Office warned there was a "high threat" of attacks in countries

Meanwhile, the State Department issued guidance urging Americans to be vigilant

Workers at GCHQ helped foil a UK terror attack, according to reports.

National news reports yesterday said the Cheltenham intelligence-gathering
centre prevented a Mumbai-style attack on London.

Calls made by British jihadists at a training camp in the tribal borders of

Some of the terrorists plotting the attack were identified when GCHQ matched

                              Western Daily Press

                             October 4, 2010 Monday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Home Secretary backs US alert over terrorist attack

BYLINE: EVA JONES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 402 words


Home Secretary Theresa May yesterday backed a US warning for its citizens to be
vigilant when visiting Europe in the wake of terrorism alerts.

Mrs May said the message was "consistent" with the UK's view of the threat that
currently exists.

She also urged the British public to report any suspicious activity as police
and security services try to disrupt terrorist activity. "The first and most
important duty of this Government is the protection and security of the British
people and visitors to the UK," Mrs May said.

"As we have consistently made clear, we face a real and serious threat from
terrorism.

Our threat level remains at severe - meaning that an attack is highly likely.

"We work closely with our international partners in countering terrorism and the
US advice is consistent with our assessment.

"I would urge the public to report any suspicious activity to the police in
support of the efforts of our security services to discover, track and disrupt
terrorist activity."

The advice issued by the State Department this afternoon stopped short of
recommending that citizens stay away from high-profile sites in Europe - as was
thought to have been under consideration before.

"Current information suggests that al-Qaeda and affiliated organisations
continue to plan terrorist attacks," the message said. "European governments
have taken action to guard against a terrorist attack and some have spoken
publicly about the heightened threat conditions."

It noted in particular "the potential for terrorists to attack public
transportation systems and other tourist infrastructure".

"US citizens should take every precaution to be aware of their surroundings and
to adopt appropriate safety measures to protect themselves when travelling," the
department said.

The warning comes after intelligence officials in Britain intercepted a credible
Islamist-linked terror plot last week. The planned attack would reportedly have
been similar to the deadly commando-style raids in Mumbai, India, two years ago,
with other European cities, in France and Germany, also targeted.

On Tuesday night the Eiffel Tower in Paris was evacuated following a bomb threat
called in from a telephone booth. It was the second such alert at the tower in
two weeks. A search by bomb experts found nothing unusual, and the tower was
reopened within hours.

'Threat level remains at severe - an attack is highly likely' Home Secretary
Theresa May

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                            October 5, 2010 Tuesday

Arsonists who attacked West Bank mosque are terrorists, says Barak

BYLINE: Harriet Sherwood Gaza City

SECTION: GUARDIAN INTERNATIONAL PAGES; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 510 words


The perpetrators of an arson attack on a West Bank mosque in which copies of the
Qur'an and prayer mats were burned were last night described as terrorists by
Israel's defence minister, Ehud Barak.

Settlers were widely blamed for torching the mosque in the early hours of
yesterday morning as part of a "price tag" campaign of revenge attacks on
Palestinians to mark their opposition to Israeli government policy on West Bank
settlement expansion. Graffiti sprayed on the mosque in the village of Beit
Fajar, between Bethlehem and Hebron, included the words "price tag" and "mosques
we burn" as well as a Star of David, according to witnesses. It is the fourth
attack on a West Bank mosque since December.

Ali Sawabta, the head of the village committee, said six settlers arrived in the
village at 2.40am. "Fifteen Qur'an books have been burnt and the building is
drenched in smoke," he told the Ynet website. "It is effectively out of
commission." Villagers, who claimed the attackers came from the nearby
settlement of Gush Etzion, rushed to defend the mosque and scuffles broke out
which were broken up by Israeli soldiers.

The attack came amid US efforts to persuade the Israeli government to prolong
the freeze on settlement construction, which expired just over a week ago, to
keep alive talks on a deal to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The
Palestinian leadership has said it will walk out of negotiations without an
extension.

Israel's prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, has so far refused US inducements.
His rightwing coalition government has a powerful pro-settler element.

Barak, who has been involved in negotiations with the US, was swift to condemn
the attack. "Whoever did this is a terrorist in every sense of the word, and
intended to hurt the chances for peace and dialogue with the Palestinians," he
said. "This was a shameful act that besmirched the state of Israel and its
values." He ordered the security forces to find and arrest the perpetrators.
Army spokeswoman Lt-Col Avital Liebowitz said the attack was "a very serious
incident which we view with the utmost gravity". The Israeli military has been
accused in the past of not pursuing settler attacks on Palestinians with
sufficient rigour.

"The settlers' message is: terrorise the Palestinian people," Mohammad Hussein,
the grand mufti of Jerusalem, who inspected the damage, told Reuters. "Such
attacks will only embolden the Palestinian people and increase our determination
to achieve all of our rights."

Almost 500,000 Jews live in settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem,
which are illegal under international law. Four settlers were killed last month
in a drive-by shooting near Hebron on the eve of direct peace talks. Hamas said
its militants carried out that attack. Hamas leader Mahmoud Zahar yesterday told
a meeting in Gaza City the negotiations were leading nowhere. "We believe in
resistance by all means to reach our goal," he said.

Captions:

A Palestinian with a burnt copy of the Qur'an after the attack on a West Bank
mosque Photograph: Abed al Hashlamoun/EPA

LOAD-DATE: October 5, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                  M2 PressWIRE

                            October 5, 2010 Tuesday

Security Council condemns deadly terrorist car bomb attacks in Nigeria

LENGTH: 271 words


October 4, 2010

The Security Council today condemned "in the strongest terms" Friday's deadly
terrorist car bombings in Abuja, Nigeria's capital, during celebrations marking
the 50th independence anniversary of Africa's most populous country."Terrorism
in all its forms and manifestations is criminal and unjustifiable, regardless of
its motivation, wherever, whenever and by whomsoever committed," the 15-member
body said in a press statement, reiterating its determination to combat all
forms of terrorism, in accordance with its responsibilities under the United
Nations Charter.



According to media reports, the Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta
(MEND) claimed responsibility for the attack which killed a dozen people and
injured three dozen more.

The Council underlined the need to bring perpetrators, organizers, financiers
and sponsors of "these reprehensible acts of terrorism to justice," and urged
all States, in accordance with their obligations under international law and
relevant Council resolutions, to cooperate actively with the Nigerian
authorities in this regard.

It reminded States that they must ensure that measures taken to combat terrorism
comply with all obligations under international law, particularly international
human rights, refugee and humanitarian law.

On Friday, Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon condemned the attacks, assuring Nigeria
of unflinching UN support and solidarity as the country seeks to address the
challenges confronting it, particularly to consolidate the significant gains
made in promoting democratic governance and improving the welfare of all
Nigerians.

ï»¿TERRIFIED betting shop staff were lucky to escape injury when masked robbers
hurled a paving slab through a security window.

Two masked men dressed in black burst into William Hill on Warrington Road,

site, two men dressed all in black with balaclavas and carrying a concrete
paving slab. We need to find the men responsible for this robbery, so if anyone
has any information, please call us.â

                           October 6, 2010 Wednesday

Iraqi Kurdistan security chief says Islamic militants plotting terror attacks

LENGTH: 274 words


Text of report in English by privately-owned Aswat al-Iraq news agency website

Sulaimaniyah/Aswat Al-Iraq: The Director of (Asayish) Security in northern
Iraq's Kurdistan Region on Wednesday [6 October] charged Ansar al-Islam with
"planning to undermine the region's security by carrying out terrorist
operations similar to those carried out last Wednesday in Qala Diza."

"The Asayish forces have uncovered information that the so-called Ansar al-Islam
group is planning to carry out terrorist acts aimed at undermining the security
of the Kurdistan Region, after the suicide operations carried out by one of its
members last week in Qala Diza, 131 km to the northwest of Sulaimaniyah
Province,"he said.

He urged citizens in the region to "be cautious and cooperate with the security
forces in Sulaimaniyah and other provinces of the region, in order to protect
the security and stability achieved in the region."

A suicide bomber had blown himself up on the main highway passing through Qala
Diza last Wednesday, Sept. 29, after being confronted by Asayish forces.

The blast left two Asayish men wounded.

Security forces in the Province said the suicide bomber was planning to blow
himself up among a Peshmerga (Kurdish armed forces), who were receiving their
salaries.

This suicide explosion is the first of its kind in Kurdistan in the past two
years, since a suicide bomber blew a car bomb in front of Sulaimaniyah Hotel in
Spring 2008, killing one of its guards and wounding several others.

Sulaimaniyah, the centre of the province carrying the same name, is 364 km to
the northeast of Baghdad.

Source: Aswat al-Iraq, Arbil, in English 0944 gmt 6 Oct 10

Foreign terrorist groups behind recent attacks in south Russia - official (more)

LENGTH: 288 words


Excerpt from report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Sochi, 6 October: International terrorist organizations were behind the recent
terrorist attacks in the south of Russia, [Russian] Security Council Secretary
Nikolay Patrushev has said.

"As far as Russia is concerned, no-one is denying now that the threat is coming
from abroad," Patrushev told journalists.

He said the threat of terrorism originated from Afghanistan, Pakistan and a
number of other countries.

Some time ago foreign colleagues denied that the threat came from abroad, he
said.

"You will remember that some time ago there was a denial, and now all agree that
one must counter jointly the threat of terrorism that exists, including in
Russia," Patrushev said.

He said that at the international conference [of high-ranking officials in
charge of security] in Sochi, the subject of terrorism was discussed in detail.
"We were given information about where terrorist training camps were located;
specific regions were named," Patrushev said.

He said that those taking part were of one opinion that these threats must be
countered jointly. "Unfortunately, not all countries are able to organize good
work, so international help is needed.

"Talking about the challenges of the 21st century, we should stress that
untraditional challenges are gaining strength, and so the current importance of
combating it is growing," he said.

Patrushev also said that "on the big issues, our views coincide (with foreign
partners - Interfax) about what threats and challenges exist". "On this basis, a
mechanism of how to fight it can be worked out, and that is very important,"
Patrushev said. [Passage omitted]

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1001 gmt 6 Oct 10

                         The Evening Standard (London)

                           October 6, 2010 Wednesday

FRANCE WARNS THAT TERRORIST ATTACK IN UK IS 'HIGHLY LIKELY'

LENGTH: 413 words


MARTIN BENTHAM

FRENCH citizens have been given their strongest warning for years about the
dangers of a terrorist attack in Britain in an official alert which will deal a
blow to London's tourist industry.

A notice posted on France's foreign ministry website said tourists should be
"extremely vigilant" on public transport and at busy tourist sites and that an
attack was "highly likely". The warning follows a similar alert issued by the US
State Department about the heightened risk of terrorism in Europe and reports
that an al Qaeda plot to carry out commando-style attacks in cities such as
London, Paris and Berlin had been disrupted.

One of those alleged to have been involved in the plot is understood to have
been a British national, Abdul Jabbar, who was killed by a US drone strike in
Pakistan last month.

A security source quoted in a BBC Newsnight report last night said he was being
groomed by Islamist extremists in Pakistan to lead a new terror group called "al
Qaeda in Great Britain" which would have tried to carry out the attacks.

In its warning, the French foreign ministry stops short of telling its citizens
not to travel to the UK, but suggests that they will face significant dangers if
they do so.

"The British authorities estimate that the level of terrorist threat is very
high in the UK and that the risk of a terrorist attack is highly likely," the
posting states. "It is recommended to be extremely vigilant on public transport
and the most popular tourist sites.'

The US government travel advice issued at the weekend warned that al Qaeda
"continues to plan terrorist attacks" and that "a variety of means and weapons"
might be used to "target both official and private interests".

It said that transport systems and tourist sites could be among potential
targets and "US citizens should take every precaution to be aware of their
surroundings and to adopt appropriate safety measures to protect themselves when
travelling" in Europe. The official threat level in Britain remains unchanged at
"severe" Ñ meaning that an attack is judged to be highly likely. The Foreign
Office has issued a travel alert to UK citizens about a heightened risk of a
terror attack in France and Germany.

Flight comparison website Skyscanner says the number of Americans carrying out
internet searches for trips to Britain has fallen by 35 per cent in the past
week. Searches about travel to Sweden were down 47 per cent, France down 42 per
cent and Germany down 40 per cent.

                            October 7, 2010 Thursday

Macedonian Interior Ministry rejects possibility of terrorist attacks

LENGTH: 295 words


Text of report by Macedonian newspaper Nova Makedonija on 6 October

[Report by "G.T.": "We Are Far From the Eiffel Tower"]

Neither is Macedonia threatened by a terrorist attack, nor is our state involved
in any way in the plots mentioned throughout Europe, Interior Ministry officials
say following the increasingly frequent world media reports that Al-Qa'idah has
been plotting attacks against civilians in European capitals, primarily Paris
(the Eiffel Tower and the Notre Dame Cathedral) and Berlin (the major railway
station and the Telecommunication Tower). The Macedonian citizens should have no
fears when at home, nor do they need to cancel their trips to Western Europe,
because the Foreign Ministry has not issued a travel advisory as the US and
Japanese ministries have.

"We have been monitoring the situation, and we have been gathering data from the
other Macedonian and foreign services. According to this, there are no serious
threats of terrorist attacks against our state yet. There is no information that
our territory is being used to prepare potential attacks, either, or that
citizens of this state have been involved in this. Still, we will resume
monitoring all future developments, although latest US news indicates that there
are no specific intelligence reports on this," Ivo Kotevski, the interior
minister's public relations assistant, says.

US Attorney General Eric Holder said that they had received enough data to send
out a warning against travelling to Europe, after which the Japanese Government
followed suit. Yet, our government still does not plan to do this.

"Should the need arise to issue a travel advisory, we will brief the public,"
MNR [Macedonian Foreign Ministry] officials say.

Source: Nova Makedonija, Skopje, in Macedonian 6 Oct 10

                    BBC Monitoring Latin America - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            October 7, 2010 Thursday

Barbados remembers the victims of Cubana terror attack in 1976

LENGTH: 477 words


Text of report by Caribbean Media Corporation news agency website on 6 October

Bridgetown, Barbados: Barbados Wednesday remembered the 73 victims of the Cubana
air disaster 34 years after what was then the most deadly terrorist attack in
the Western hemisphere.

Foreign Minister Maxine Mc Clean, Cuba's Ambassador Luisette Perez Perez, and
Dean of the Diplomatic Corp Juan Carlos Valdez Gonsalves laid wreaths at a
ceremony at the Monument erected in memory of the 48 passengers and 25 crew
members. The ill-fated Douglas DC-8 aircraft, Cubana flight 455, was blown up by
two bombs just off Barbados en route to Jamaica on October 6, 1976.

US Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) documents released in 2005 indicate that
the agency "had concrete advance intelligence, as early as June 1976, on plans
by Cuban exile terrorist groups to bomb a Cubana airliner."

Four men were arrested in connection with the bombing and a trial was held in
Venezuela. Two of the men, Freddy Lugo and Hernan Ricardo Lozano were sentenced
to 20-year prison terms, but Orlando Bosch was acquitted and now lives in Miami.

Posada Carriles was held for eight years while awaiting a final sentence, but
eventually fled. He later entered the United States, where he was held on
charges of entering the country illegally but released on April 19, 2007.

Cuba has been demanding his extradition.

Carriles has denied any involvement even though he has provided many details in
his book "Caminos del Guerrero (Way of the Warrior)".

Meanwhile, a number of Caribbean academics, politicians, journalists, women
organizations as well as musicians have penned a letter to President Barack
Obama calling on him to ensure that the "crime instigators and intellectual
authors" of the bombing of the aircraft are brought to justice and not given
protection by the US government.

They said that since the bombing, 34 years ago, "terrorist attacks in the
Caribbean,particularly against Cuba, have not ceased during all these years."

They said that Washington instead "decided to prosecute, condemn and sentence
the fighters against terrorism in Miami instead of arresting the authors of the
terrorist acts against our peoples.

"This injustice is a consequence of the blackmail the economic power groups and
lobbyists in the South of Florida exercise against the American Administration,
"they wrote urging that the five" anti-terrorists Cuban fighters" imprisoned now
in the United States be set free.

"There is absolutely no evidence that they received a fair trial. They were
eventually condemned as a result of an unfair trial. They are prisoners because
they were judged in Miami, where the decisive influence of law and order is in
the same hands of those who protect the authors of the crime of Barbados in
1976".

Source: Caribbean Media Corporation news agency website, Bridgetown, in English
2000 gmt 6 Oct 10

LOAD-DATE: October 8, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                            October 7, 2010 Thursday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

British diplomat escapes Yemeni terrorist attack

BYLINE: Oliver Holmes; Richard Spencer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 518 words


BRITAIN'S deputy ambassador to Yemen was the target of a rocket attack
yesterday. It was the second assassination attempt on a British diplomat in the
country's capital in six months.

Fionna Gibb escaped unhurt after two men disguised as street cleaners fired on
her car as she travelled to work at the embassy in Sana'a with four colleagues.

In what appeared to be a co-ordinated attack, a security guard at an Austrian
oil company in the city, opened fire on a French and British employee after
shouting Allahu akbar (God is Great). The Frenchman died and the Briton suffered
serious leg injuries. The incidents highlight the threat posed by al-Qaeda in
the Arabian Peninsula, a group re-formed only last year which has already
launched attacks in Yemen, neighbouring Saudi Arabia and across the world.

It claimed responsibility for the failed attack on the British ambassador,
Timothy Torlot, in April, when a suicide bomber detonated an explosive vest near
Mr Torlot's armoured car not far from where Miss Gibb escaped yesterday.

William Hague, the Foreign Secretary, said "This shameful attack on British
diplomats will only redouble Britain's determination to work with the government
of Yemen to help address the challenges that country faces."

Yemeni authorities had issued an alert about an imminent threat to Western
targets two days previously.

The British embassy in Sana'a lies in an exposed position on a hillside. It is
heavily defended, with sandbagged machinegun posts.

Armoured vehicles pick up staff members from their homes in the city every
morning, deliberately using different routes every day to shake off would-be
attackers. A spokesman said embassy security was "constantly under review".

Miss Gibb was being taken through a suburb east of the Old City at 8.15am when
the two men stepped forward with a rocket-propelled grenade launcher, witnesses
said.

"I saw two men dressed as street cleaners fire a grenade," Haitham al Dubani, a
student, said. The grenade missed but showered the car with shrapnel, shattering
the windscreen.

A Yemeni woman walking with a boy nearby was hit in the head by shrapnel and hit
by another car that veered off the road. She and the boy, who was also slightly
hurt, were taken to hospital, as was an embassy official, who was not seriously
injured.

Miss Gibb, who took up her post at the embassy two months ago, was said to be
back at work yesterday. She has previously worked as deputy consul general in
the southern Iraqi city of Basra.

Yemen is afflicted by numerous tribal, regional and religious divisions.

Last year, a group of Yemeni and Saudi militants, some former detainees of the
Guantánamo Bay internment camp, announced the formation of al-Qaeda in the
Arabian Peninsula. Inspired by the Yemeni-American radical preacher Anwar
al-Awlaki, they commissioned the attempt by a former student of University
College, London, to blow up an American airliner over Detroit on Christmas Day.

Britain is leading international attempts to form a plan to stabilise the
country. It is thought to have special forces operating at least in a training
capacity in Yemen.

LOAD-DATE: October 9, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Fionna Gibb: the target of a grenade attack by terrorists

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: DTL

                                  Daily Record

                           October 7, 2010, Thursday

MISSILES WIPE OUT 5 TERROR SUSPECTS;
ATTACK OVER RAID FEARS

BYLINE: Rebecca Evans

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 425 words


AT LEAST five suspected militants were killed yesterday in a drone strike in
north-west Pakistan, officials said.

The US have stepped up unmanned drone attacks in the last month, apparently to
disrupt an al-Qaeda plot to launch commando-style raids on European cities.

And France yesterday said the risk of terror attacks in Britain is "very high".

The Paris government urged French people to exercise "extreme vigilance" when
visiting the UK, especially London.

Britain and the US have already warned people travelling in Europe to be
careful.

But the French advice is the most extreme to date, saying that British
authorities believe "the risk of an attack is very likely".

In the latest drone attack, local officials said two missiles struck a militant
compound in Miranshah, the main town of the North Waziristan district.

Five German nationals were killed in another drone strike in Pakistan earlier
this week in an attack linked to the European threat.

There have been 27 drone strikes since early September.

European Union officials have renewed warnings that the threat from al-Qaeda is
real and ongoing.

EU anti-terrorism co-ordinator Gilles de Kerchove said: "Public officials would
not terrify the population without anything to back it up.

"The threat is in the context of a general threat that has not diminished in
recent times."

And former premier Tony Blair yesterday said Western nations are losing the
battle against violent Islamic extremists.

The UN peace envoy said the West is being "outspent, outmanoeuvred and
outstrategised" by fanatics presenting Muslims as oppressed victims.

Analysts have linked the alleged European plot with the disappearance of several
Muslim radicals from the German city of Hamburg last year.

It is thought that one of them was captured and gave US authorities information
on the European plot.

The US envoy to Pakistan yesterday apologised for a recent NATO helicopter
attack that killed at least two Pakistani soldiers near the Afghan border.

Rocket Anne Patterson said the US extended their "deepest apology to Pakistan
and the families of the Frontier Scouts who were killed and injured".

Tankers carrying fuel to NATO troops in Afghanistan yesterday came under attack
from gunmen in Pakistan.

At least 25 trucks were destroyed in the attack which bore the hallmarks of the
Pakistani Taliban.

Britain's deputy ambassador to Yemen survived a rocket attack in the capital
Sana yesterday.

It missed Fiona Gibb's car and she was unhurt but three bystanders and an
embassy employee are thought to have suffered minor injuries.

LOAD-DATE: October 7, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: BATTLE: Tony Blair AIR STRIKE: Missiles from a drone hit town
