                              DAILY MAIL (London)

                            October 7, 2010 Thursday

FRENCH WARN TERROR ATTACK ON BRITAIN IS 'VERY LIKELY'

BYLINE: FROM PETER ALLEN IN PARIS

LENGTH: 303 words


FRANCE has issued its most extreme warning in recent years about the dangers of
visiting Britain, saying a terrorist attack is 'very likely'.

A dramatic statement on the website of the Ministry for Foreign Affairs says
that visitors need to exercise 'extreme vigilance'.

President Nicolas Sarkozy ordered a crackdown on Islamic extremists this week,
with raids in Avignon, Bordeaux and Marseilles on Tuesday that led to 12
arrests.

Suspects were found with enough guns and ammunition to launch a 'Mumbai-style
attack' anywhere in Europe, with at least five airports highlighted as possible
targets. 'They were storing a lot of weapons, including Kalashnikov machine
guns,' said one detective.

The men were held after their phone numbers were found on the mobile phone of a
suspected terrorist arrested in Italy at the weekend.

Last week, security agents in France, Britain and Germany warned Al Qaeda
terrorists were planning a Mumbai-style atrocity in Europe.

The alert was sparked after Ahmad Sidiqi, an Afghan informant, told U.S.
interrogators of the plot. Sidiqi said Ilyas Kashmiri Z an Al Qaeda commander
linked to the attacks in Mumbai that left 174 people dead in 2008 Z had told him
teams had been sent to Europe to launch similar assaults.

The intelligence which led to France's warning about an attack in Britain being
'very likely' was provided

the Paris-based General Directorate for External Security.

It is known to operate undercover on British streets and has strong links with
MI6.

'The information was expertly attained in Britain, and this is the reason the
warning was issued,' said a French source.

Britain's deputy ambassador to Yemen survived a rocket-propelled grenade attack
on an embassy vehicle yesterday.

Fiona Gibb was unhurt but one of her colleagues was injured in the blast in the
capital Sana'a.

                               Lichfield Mercury

                                October 7, 2010

Terrorised resident cleared of attack on snowball teenager

BYLINE: Mercury Reporter

SECTION: Pg. 16

LENGTH: 256 words


A Householder who chased a schoolboy he caught throwing snowballs at his windows
was cleared of assault by jurors.

The 15 year-old claimed Mark James attacked him with a metal bar and beat him
with it more than a dozen times.

But James, who had cornered the boy following a pursuit across a snow-covered
field in Armitage, said he fell over on  ice when he grabbed the boy's jacket.

James, aged 50, of Shelley Close, Armitage had denied assaulting the boy, who
cannot be named, causing him actual bodily harm.

Stafford Crown Court heard  James and his family had suffered years of nuisance
behaviour from local youths, including water bombs, rubbish being thrown in to
their garden and nails put in car tyres.

He had repeatedly called out  police to try to tackle the situation and had been
put on a priority action list.

But James himself had also been cautioned by the police, in February last year,
for common assault on one youth following a snowballing incident.

The incident that landed him in the dock happened on January 7 this year, when,
he said, a gang of local youths were pelting his house with snowballs.

He was waiting for police to arrive over another incident two days earlier and
was hoping officers would catch them in the act.

But he decided to chase one "hoodie", who fled across a field at the rear of the
house and was cornered on a doorstep in a neighbouring street.

James said the boy took a swing at him, so he grabbed his jacket and the youth
fell on the ice.

He was cleared on Friday, October 1, following a five-day trial.

                              138 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                               The Times (London)

                            October 7, 2010 Thursday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Briton killed by CIA was 'senior terrorist';
Victim was linked to planned attacks in UK

BYLINE: Michael Evans ; Adam Fresco ; Alice Fordham

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 600 words


A Briton killed in a CIA drone attack in Pakistan last month was an up-andcoming
member of al-Qaeda, The Times has learnt.

Abdul Jabbar, who is believed to have lived in northwest England with a British
wife before travelling to Pakistan, was killed in one of an increasing number of
Predator drone strikes launched by the CIA to target terrorist leaders and
disrupt planned attacks in Western Europe.

The disclosure came as suspected al-Qaeda militants fired a rocket at a British
embassy car carrying the deputy head of the mission in Sanaa, the Yemeni capital
yesterday, injuring an embassy employee and several civilians.

While the Foreign and Commonwealth Office was still trying last night to get
more information from the Pakistani authorities on the nationality of the man
killed in the drone attack, a senior Western official told The Times: "This man
was a senior terrorist and he was British and he is dead. Abdul Jabbar was an
up-and-comer in the ranks of al-Qaeda."

It is suspected that Jabbar had been involved in "anti-coalition activities" in
Afghanistan and in attacks in Pakistan and was known to British security
services.

Although Pakistani intelligence sources are reported to have said that Jabbar
was linked to a plot to launch simultaneous "Mumbai-style" attacks in Britain,
France and Germany, the official said that there was no evidence.

Inquiries on both sides of the Atlantic are still continuing into Jabbar's
background and it is not thought that he had any connection with Faisal Shahzad,
the Times Square bomber who was jailed for life on Tuesday.

An unnamed Pakistani intelligence official has claimed that Jabbar had been
chosen as the leader of the Islamic Army of Great Britain, at a meeting in the
North Waziristan region of Pakistan three months ago, but security sources in
Britain warned against linking him with any al-Qaeda or Islamist group in
Britain.

The targeting of a Briton by an American drone attack is highly unusual. The
only other known killing of a Briton by a CIA drone attack involved another
senior terrorist, Rashid Rauf, who helped to plan the July 7 suicide bombings in
London in 2005.

Rauf, of Pakistani origin, lived in Birmingham before he fled to Pakistan in
2002 after his suspected involvement in the murder of an uncle. He was killed by
a Predator drone missile attack in November 2008.

Last month Jonathan Evans, the Director-General of MI5, said that four or five
"real plots" against Britain were regularly uncovered at any one time, which
showed that there was a persistent intent by al-Qaeda and its associates to
carry out an atrocity. MI5 had found increasing threats from different areas,
including Somalia, Pakistan and Yemen, he said.

An FCO spokeswoman said: "Following reports of a British national being killed
in Pakistan, the British High Commission in Islamabad have requested that the
Pakistan authorities urgently provide further details regarding the incident and
any British nationals involved."

Air Chief Marshal Sir Jock Stirrup, the Chief of the Defence Staff, confirmed
yesterday that Britain was on "a heightened state of alert" because of the
terrorist threat.

The threat posed to Britain was highlighted by yesterday's ambush in Sanaa.
Fionna Gibb, the deputy head of mission, was unhurt but said to be shaken by the
attack, which happened two miles from the British Embassy. A French national was
killed in a separate attack. William Hague, the Foreign Secretary, said that the
attacks would "only redouble Britain's determination to work with the Government
of Yemen to help address the challenges that country faces".

LOAD-DATE: October 7, 2010

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             October 8, 2010 Friday

Pakistan article urges media not to "sensationalize" terror attacks

LENGTH: 945 words


Text of article by Alam Rind headlined "Terrorism and media" published by
Pakistani newspaper The Frontier Post website on 8 October


Interestingly, terrorism is a term which doesn't have a globally agreed
definition. Jeffrey Record in his study published in 2003 had counted 109
definitions. Walter Lagueur, an expert on terrorism, had counted over 100
definitions, and concluded the violence and threat to use of violence are the
only constants in these definitions. Factually, an act of terrorism is never
committed in isolation.

It always has a political, philosophical, ideological, racial, ethnic, religious
or any other purpose attached to it. Moreover, terrorism is not confined to
small organizations struggling to impose their will on to the majority; rather,
there can be state-sponsored terrorism aimed at subjugating population seeking
their rights as is the case of Indian-held Kashmiris. Terrorism can take form of
agro-terrorism, bio-terrorism, insurgency, environmental terrorism, economic
terrorism etc. But its sole purpose remains to induce fear among the masses and
to instil a feeling of hopelessness. It is in this state of mind that
individuals, groups and nations submit themselves to the designs of the
perpetrators of terrorist acts as a fait accompli. Terrorism in Pakistan is
generally attributed to Islamization of Gen Zia-ul-Haq's era. An Islamization
that encouraged recruitment of jihadis to fight Soviet troops occupying
Afghanistan. Mostly, people from underdeveloped parts of the country, like
southern Punjab and tribal areas of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, joined jihadi
organizations predominantly for economic reasons. With the defeat of Soviet
forces in Afghanistan, these individuals and organizations were abandoned. No
effort was made to rehabilitate the members of these organizations and to bring
them in the mainstream society. A large number of religiously charged and
virtually illiterate individuals who knew nothing except how to fight became
available. That presented an opportunity to regional and global powers to
recruit them for pursuance of their aims. So the jihadis virtually turned into
mercenaries. They wear the robe of religious organizations and perpetrate
terrorist acts at the behest of their foreign masters. Indian sponsorship of
terrorism in Pakistan through her consulates in Afghanistan is an established
fact. American involvement in Jondollah is also well-known.

While terrorism is nurtured by major players, Pakistan is termed as its
epicentre and exporter. Obviously, all this is being done with a purpose.
Indians have not reconciled with the partition of the subcontinent and
US-Israeli lobby wants to undo Pakistan's nuclear capability. It appears that
the objectives of these foreign powers are being facilitated by our own media.
Pakistani electronic and print media in its newly found independence is all out
to project negative image of the country. On our television screens, horrific
scenes of bomb blasts are often beamed with total disregard to the fact that it
might have traumatic effects on the children and could be inexpressibly painful
for the members of the bereaved families. The best of channels are in the habit
of repeatedly telecasting dreadful scenes and their newscasts or the anchors
repeat the bad news so many times that one would be saturated. This technique
adopted by the television channels has serious psychological implications. A
person watching such news or programme grows indifferent to bad news and it also
induces hopelessness, a harbinger to accepting defeat. Our electronic media
seems to be in competition as to how best they can sensationalize otherwise
routine functioning of the state organs. Anyone watching programmes in
connection with NRO [National Reconciliation Ordinance, issued by then President
Pervez Musharaf in October 2007, under which certain politicians and bureaucrats
accused of corruption were granted amnesty] would feel that it is a matter of
hours or at best days that the government machinery will collapse. Creation of
uncertainty by the media is also proving to be one of the major reasons for the
flight of capital and slowing down of economic activities in the country.
Celebrated anchors of Pakistani channels have come up with stunning interviews
with the terrorist leaders like Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, Sirajuddin Haqqani,
Baitullah Mehsud, Hakimullah Mehsud etc. from time to time. The tone and texture
of the interviews would project terrorist leaders as heroes or at least as
glorified dignitaries. After watching the way bad news are repeated, uncertainty
is cultivated and terrorist leaders are glorified by the Pakistani electronic
media, one can only conclude that they are supporting terrorism rather than
helping government to combat the same. It is important for the media to
understand that terrorism thrives on inducing fear. For this purpose they commit
terrorist acts, which have localized effects, but it is through unbridled media
projection of their deeds that they get countrywide and global coverage. That
amounts to serving their cause. Most of the anchorpersons, to make their shows
captivating, extensively use superlatives in their conversation that converts a
mole into a mountain, painting a wrong picture. Moreover, the perception that
any and everything happening in the country has to be projected is also
incorrect. Media, being a state pillar, has to exhibit responsibility. It must
not play in the hands of those who want to damage Pakistan; rather, should
induce hope so that the people are able to face difficulty with courage and
persistence.

Source: The Frontier Post website, Peshawar, in English 08 Oct 10

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

main culprits behind the terrorist incident in Sanandaj [western Iran] were

In a cowardly attack on a Law Enforcement Force [police] station in the city of

                               Belfast Telegraph

                             October 8, 2010 Friday
                                 First Edition

Unions to lead Londonderry protest against the rising tide of terror attacks

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 276 words


TRADE unions are to lead a protest rally against the recent dissident republican
bombs in Londonderry, the Belfast Telegraph can reveal.

Unions in Derry last night voted unanimously to organise the rally in response
to people in the city calling for a public statement of protest against
dissident activity.

Today, church leaders, business people and the public will be asked to come to
the rally in the Guildhall Square next Friday at 1pm to hear speakers from the
trade unions and community organisations, and to voice their opposition to the
recent dissident republican activity.

The latest Real IRA bomb at the Ulster Bank on Tuesday was the catalyst for the
rally.

The car bomb followed other attacks carried out in Derry over the past few
months, including a 200lbs bomb at the Strand Road PSNI station in August, the
murder of Kieran Doherty in February and a hoax bomb that caused traffic chaos
on the Craigavon Bridge.

Secretary of Derry Trade Unions Liam Gallagher said: "We are hoping that people
from right across the the city will gather at the Guildhall to show in no
uncertain terms their opposition to the actions carried out by the dissident
republicans.

"People have a genuine fear that sooner or later we may see another Omagh.

"They are also brassed off about being held hostage in their own city time after
time because of the traffic chaos we witnessed this week and a few weeks ago
when there was a hoax bomb left on the lower deck of the Craigavon Bridge."

The rally has already received the backing of SDLP Youth, while other political
parties are now expected to join the union movement and back the protest.

CAPTION: Killed: Kieran Doherty

                                    Scotsman

                            October 9, 2010 Saturday

Europe terror alert 'link' to 9/11 attacker

BYLINE: JUERGEN BAETZ

LENGTH: 172 words



HIGHLIGHT: AN Islamic militant from Germany whose disclosures under US
interrogation in Afghanistan triggered Europe's recent terror alert is a friend
of a man convicted in the 11 September 2001 attacks, German intelligence
officials said.


Ahmad Wali Siddiqui, a 36-year-old German of Afghan descent arrested by the US
military in July in Afghanistan,  is the latest link between Germany and
al-Qaeda's terror campaign. Siddiqui is believed to have been part of the
Hamburg militant scene that included key 9/11 plotters.

Intelligence officials said he was a friend of Mounir el Motassadeq, who was
convicted by a German court in 2006 of being an accessory to the murder of the
246 passengers and crew on the four airliners used in the 2001 terrorist
attacks, and also frequented the al-Quds mosque in Hamburg, which the Germans
have now closed.

Motassadeq was found to have aided 9/11 suicide hijackers Mohamed Atta, Marwan
al-Shehhi and Ziad Jarrah by helping them keep up the appearance of being
regular university students - paying their tuition and rent - though it was
never established whether he knew of the planned timing, dimension or targets of
the attacks.

"Siddiqui is a long-term member who has been a friend of Motassadeq since 1997,"
said an intelligence official

                            October 11, 2010 Monday

Turkey "strongly" condemns terrorist attack in Afghanistan

LENGTH: 183 words


Text of report in English by Turkish semi-official news agency Anatolia on 11
October

Ankara: Turkey condemned the recent terrorist attack in northern Afghanistan.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement: "We strongly condemn the
terror attack in Takhar Province in which 15 people, including the provincial
governor, were killed and many others were injured. We also note that the attack
targeted a holy site and curse it as a crime against humanity."

"Any attempt that targets the efforts to ensure lasting peace and stability in
Afghanistan will not reach its goal. We sincerely believe that Afghan people
will reach peace, tranquillity and prosperity they deserve. Turkey will continue
extending full support to Afghanistan in its fight against terror and
extremism," the ministry added.

Fifteen people, including Mohammad Omar, governor of neighbouring Kunduz
Province, were killed and some 35 others were injured in a massive bomb blast
inside the Shirkat Mosque during Friday prayers in Takhar Province on October 8.

                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            October 11, 2010 Monday

Jordan to launch arrest campaign against terror attacks suspects - paper

LENGTH: 483 words


Text of report by Kuwaiti newspaper Al-Siyasah website on 10 October

[Unattributed Report: "Jordan Sets to Wage a Mass Arrest Campaign Against the
Involved Persons and Receives Important Information on Previous Terrorist
Operations."]

Well-informed Jordanian sources told Al-Siyasah that during the past few weeks,
the competent authorities in Jordan were able to get important information
through their investigations to reveal the sides responsible for carrying out
the two terrorist attacks in the country during the last nine months. The first
operation had targeted the convoy of the Israeli ambassador to Jordan on 14
January and the second targeted a bus transporting US trainers on their way to a
training base for the Jordanian Police in Amman's suburbs on 30 August.

The sources added on 8 October that the investigations of the Jordanian
authorities revealed that the two operations were almost identical, for they
were characterized by a high level of professionalism in gathering information
about the two convoys, their itinerary, and the time at which they leave. The
investigations further revealed that this contradicts the low level of
professionalism that characterized the Improvised Explosive Device [IED] that
targeted the two convoys, namely the small quantity of explosive materials in
the two IEDs and the fact that no side claimed responsibility for the two
attacks.

The sources further said that all these factors pushed the investigators towards
several possibilities, which significantly extended the period that the security
forces usually need to identify the perpetrators. Moreover, the investigation
took into account the two events of launching rocket-propelled grenades towards
Aqaba on 22 April and 2 August and the possibility that these two events are
related to the two terrorist attacks in a way or another.

The sources expected that the coming few weeks witness a mass arrest campaign in
Jordan against the people involved in the acts of sabotage, without referring to
their identities or affiliations, noting that some details must be received from
Arab intelligence services before continuing the investigation.

The sources added that "as shown in similar investigations, it is possible that
the cell that conducted the two attacks has organizational or funding ties with
sides in Egypt or Lebanon or within the Palestinian [National] Authority. It is
also probable that the arrest campaign, which will start in Jordan, includes
subversive elements from the above mentioned Arab countries and some European
countries." The sources further noted that these arrests will destroy one of the
most important subversive cells, adding that this cell became active in Jordan
in the last few years and is funded by sides from outside Jordan to carry out
subversive operations against foreign targets in the country.

Source: Al-Siyasah website, Kuwait, in Arabic 10 Oct 10

                                   Daily Star

                            October 12, 2010 Tuesday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Scotland

TERRORIST PUT OFF ATTACK;
Baby scare before ringleader sets off for London to kill 52, 1st day of inquest
told 7/7 attack was delayed to help pregnant wife

BYLINE: STEVE HUGHES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8,9

LENGTH: 435 words


THE 7/7 suicide bombers' leader delayed the attack so he could take his pregnant
wife to hospital, it was revealed yesterday.

Mohammad Sidique Khan sent fellow terrorist Shehzad Tanweer a text message
saying he "could not make it" because of a "major problem".

The next day Khan took wife Hasina to hospital in Dewsbury, West Yorks, then set
off for London on his evil mission.

She later had a miscarriage - on the day in July 2005 that her husband, Tanweer,
Jermaine Lindsay and Hasib Hussain murdered 52 innocent victims on London
Underground trains and a bus.

Relaxed

It means the attacks could have been planned for July 6, the day that London was
awarded the 2012 Olympics.

It was also revealed on the first day of the inquest into the deaths that the
gang had eight homemade grenades in the car they drove to Luton, Beds, which
they could have thrown at police if intercepted.

Fellow passengers said some bombers were "smiling and laughing, and generally
relaxed" as they travelled on to King's Cross station.

The Royal Courts of Justice in London was also told a piece of paper in
Lindsay's passport suggested Westminster, the heart of UK Government, may have
been a target. Emergency services and Tube officials were plunged into confusion
by the terror attacks.

Phone calls played in court showed staff still did not know if they were dealing
with a power surge or terrorism at least 44 minutes after the first blast.

A detective at Aldgate station told of "pandemonium".

Tormented

Relatives wept as Counsel to the inquest Hugo Keith QC outlined how apparent
blunders delayed emergency services.

Coroner Lady Justice Heather Hallett was told the gang wanted worldwide
publicity.

Tanweer, Khan and Lindsay detonated their bombs at Aldgate, Edgware Road and
Russell Square at around 8.50am and Hussain blew up a bus in Tavistock Square an
hour later.

Mr Keith said: "Just as the lives of 52 victims were callously and brutally
ended, the lives of many others have been and continue to be tormented."

The inquest is expected to last five months.

A special fund was set in memory of Scots accountant Helen Jones, 28, who died
in the explosion at Russell Square.

Helen grew up in Annan, Dumfries-shire, and was a school pupil in Lockerbie when
Pan Am 103 exploded in 1988.

The Helen Jones Appeal Fund gives financial assistance to pupils from the
Lockerbie area to study accountancy, finance or management courses at
university.

steve.hughes@dailystar.co.uk

YESTERDAY AT A GLANCE

* Attacks should have been 24 hours earlier

* Westminster was original target

* Car load of home-made 'grenades' found

* Delay in raising alarm slammed

Turrell at Edgware Road Tube station

                                   Daily Star

                            October 12, 2010 Tuesday
                                U.K. 1st Edition

TERRORIST PUT OFF ATTACK

BYLINE: by STEVE HUGHES

SECTION: NEWS; 08

LENGTH: 428 words


Baby scare before ringleader sets off for London to kill 52, 1st day of inquest
told

7/7 attack was delayed to help pregnant wife

THE 7/7 suicide bombers' leader delayed the attack so he could take his pregnant
wife to hospital, it was revealed yesterday.

Mohammad Sidique Khan sent fellow terrorist Shehzad Tanweer a text message
saying he "could not make it" because of a "major problem".

The next day Khan took wife Hasina to hospital in Dewsbury, West Yorks, then set
off for London on his evil mission.

She later had a miscarriage - on the day in July 2005 that her husband, Tanweer,
Jermaine Lindsay and Hasib Hussain murdered 52 innocent victims on Tube trains
and a bus.

It means the attacks could have been planned for July 6, the day that London was
awarded the 2012 Olympics.

It was also revealed on the first day of the inquest into the deaths that the
gang had eight homemade grenades in the car they drove to Luton, Beds, which
they could have thrown at police if intercepted.

Fellow passengers said some bombers were "smiling and laughing, and generally
relaxed" as they travelled on to King's Cross station.

The Royal Courts of Justice in London was also told a piece of paper in
Lindsay's passport suggested Westminster, the heart of Government, may have been
a target. Emergency services and Tube officials were plunged into confusion by
the terror attacks.

Phone calls played in court showed staff still did not know if they were dealing
with a power surge or terrorism at least 44 minutes after the first blast.
Meanwhile, police were reporting explosions and deaths as the walking wounded
staggered out of stations.

A detective at Aldgate station told of "pandemonium" as Tube operators elsewhere
denied there had been explosions.

Relatives wept in court as Counsel to the inquest Hugo Keith QC outlined how
apparent blunders delayed emergency services in getting to the scenes.

That possibly meant the injured did not get the urgent medical attention they
needed.

He said: "These calls reveal considerable difficulties in assimilating
information that is coming in as clearly a very confused incident presented
itself."

Coroner Lady Justice Heather Hallett was told the gang wanted worldwide
publicity.

Tanweer, Khan and Lindsay detonated their bombs at Aldgate, Edgware Road and
Russell Square at around 8.50am and Hussain blew up a bus in Tavistock Square an
hour later.

Mr Keith said: "Just as the lives of 52 victims were callously and brutally
ended, the lives of many others have been and continue to be tormented."

The inquest is expected to last five months.

                                   Daily Star

                            October 12, 2010 Tuesday
                                Scottish Edition

TERRORIST PUT OFF ATTACK

BYLINE: by STEVE HUGHES

SECTION: NEWS; 08

LENGTH: 420 words


Baby scare before ringleader sets off for London to kill 52, 1st day of inquest
told

7/7 attack was delayed to help pregnant wife

THE 7/7 suicide bombers' leader delayed the attack so he could take his pregnant
wife to hospital, it was revealed yesterday.

Mohammad Sidique Khan sent fellow terrorist Shehzad Tanweer a text message
saying he "could not make it" because of a "major problem".

The next day Khan took wife Hasina to hospital in Dewsbury, West Yorks, then set
off for London on his evil mission.

She later had a miscarriage - on the day in July 2005 that her husband, Tanweer,
Jermaine Lindsay and Hasib Hussain murdered 52 innocent victims on London
Underground trains and a bus.

It means the attacks could have been planned for July 6, the day that London was
awarded the 2012 Olympics.

It was also revealed on the first day of the inquest into the deaths that the
gang had eight homemade grenades in the car they drove to Luton, Beds, which
they could have thrown at police if intercepted.

Fellow passengers said some bombers were "smiling and laughing, and generally
relaxed" as they travelled on to King's Cross station.

The Royal Courts of Justice in London was also told a piece of paper in
Lindsay's passport suggested Westminster, the heart of UK Government, may have
been a target. Emergency services and Tube officials were plunged into confusion
by the terror attacks.

Phone calls played in court showed staff still did not know if they were dealing
with a power surge or terrorism at least 44 minutes after the first blast.

A detective at Aldgate station told of "pandemonium".

Relatives wept as Counsel to the inquest Hugo Keith QC outlined how apparent
blunders delayed emergency services.

Coroner Lady Justice Heather Hallett was told the gang wanted worldwide
publicity.

Tanweer, Khan and Lindsay detonated their bombs at Aldgate, Edgware Road and
Russell Square at around 8.50am and Hussain blew up a bus in Tavistock Square an
hour later.

Mr Keith said: "Just as the lives of 52 victims were callously and brutally
ended, the lives of many others have been and continue to be tormented."

The inquest is expected to last five months.

A special fund was set in memory of Scots accountant Helen Jones, 28, who died
in the explosion at Russell Square.

Helen grew up in Annan, Dumfries-shire, and was a school pupil in Lockerbie when
Pan Am 103 exploded in 1988.

The Helen Jones Appeal Fund gives financial assistance to pupils from the
Lockerbie area to study accountancy, finance or management courses at
university.

CORONER: Hallett
CARNAGE: Wreckage of the bus and, below, hero Paul Dadge helps victim Davinia
Turrell at Edgware Road Tube station

                              148 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                               The Times (London)

                            October 12, 2010 Tuesday
                                   Edition 2;
                                National Edition

Calls to emergency operators reveal chaos as terror attacks were initially
discounted

BYLINE: Fiona Hamilton

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 649 words


484 witnesses contacted by the inquest team 240 witnesses expected to give oral
evidence A picture of chaos and panic in the wake of the July 7 attacks emerged
yesterday as previously unheard calls to emergency operators revealed how they
were plunged into confusion.

Despite numerous reports about a series of explosions on the London Underground,
it took its control room staff almost an hour to accept that they might be
terror-related.

Black smoke seeping out of tunnels was initially attributed to a power failure,
while there were varying reports of a train crashing at Edgware Road.

As emergency services struggled to cope with the attacks, there was uncertainty
about which carriages had been affected and in which direction the damaged
trains were travelling.

Meanwhile, in a series of panicked phone calls, police and other key staff were
describing scenes as "pandemonium" and warning of casualties as people came out
of tunnels with blood on their faces.

Hugo Keith, QC, lead counsel for the inquests, said: "A considerable amount of
time had elapsed, you will have seen, from the moment of the explosion of the
bombs to the acceptance by the staff of the NCC [the network control centre at
London Underground] that in fact they were bomb-related." He said that the
inquests would investigate whether any of the 52 people who died could have
survived if they had received immediate medical attention.

There were delays to treat victims at the Edgware Road blast, despite reports of
"multiple casualties", because ambulances were sent to an incorrect address at
nearby Praed Street. There were further delays because of fears of secondary
bomb blasts and concerns that the power was still on.

The three trains exploded almost simultaneously at 8.49am but operators
initially ruled out a terror attack. One operator initially showed a reluctance
to dispatch rescue workers, saying "we are not looking at an act of aggression
at the moment".

However, the calls became increasingly panicked, with several reports of a
"bang", walking wounded and passengers in the tunnels.

Detective Inspector Ian Baker, of British Transport Police (BTP), called
operators from Aldgate at 9.02am and said: "The building shook and we thought,
'what the f**k was that'.

"We've got pandemonium here." Control operators described the situation as
"mayhem". Inspector Robert Munn, of BTP, told an operator shortly after the
blasts: "There are people on those trains who will die if they do not get
immediate care. We need ambulances to Aldgate urgently."

About 20 minutes later one Underground worker reported: "There are people
walking out of Aldgate with blackened faces and God knows what."

However, at 9.28am controllers at London Underground were still ruling out a
terror attack.

Andrew Barr, network co-ordination manager, told a caller: "We don't put out
that it's an explosion. We think that train [at Edgware Road] has allegedly hit
the tunnel wall." He said it was thought that cable outages were responsible for
the other explosions.

At 9.32am, a worried train supervisor from Morden was assured that "it is not
believed to be terrorist-related".

However, at the same time, another operator told an official from the Railway
Inspectorate: "There are definitely walking injured, possibly fatalities. The
decision we can't make is whether it is a terror incident or whether it is a
[power] cable. We are leaning towards terror at the moment but I can't tell you
that." Mr Keith told the coroner that a "very confused picture" clearly
presented itself.

Graham Foulkes, father of 22-yearold David, who was killed at Edgware Road, said
the response to the attack was "clearly shambolic". He added: "They were clearly
unprepared and had clearly not been trained to deal with any major event
whatsoever."

The aftermath 52 people died as a result of the 7/7 attacks 20,000 CCTV tapes of
the scenes have since been studied

LOAD-DATE: October 12, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                           October 13, 2010 Wednesday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Scotland

Terrorist cyber attacks are a growing threat to the nation, says GCHQ chief;
Online tax systems 'at risk of attack'

BYLINE: James Kirkup

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1,2

LENGTH: 415 words


CYBER attacks pose a threat that "goes to the heart of our economic well-being
and national interest," the head of GCHQ said last night.

In an unprecedented public speech, Iain Lobban, the chief of the Government's
secret surveillance centre, warned of the threat from terrorists, criminals and
hostile states using the internet.

Government systems are being hit by email-borne attacks 1,000 times a month, he
disclosed. Mr Lobban, who has never before given a public speech, spoke at a
London think tank as ministers prepare to increase government spending on
Britain's defences against electronic attack.

In the defence and security review next week, the Government will announce an
increase in funding for precautions against cyber attacks. Mr Lobban said such
increases could not come soon enough, and disclosed details of attacks already
being sustained by Britain.

GCHQ, which monitors millions of emails and telephone calls every day, is
detecting more than 20,000 malicious emails on government networks each month,
Mr Lobban said. Of those, 1,000 are "deliberately targeting" the state, he said.
The cyber threat to Britain's "critical national infrastructure" of power,
communications, transport and financial networks is a "real and credible one,"
he added. Mr Lobban also warned of the growing use of cyber techniques "by one
nation on another to bring diplomatic or economic pressure to bear" on others.

The British economy is also facing the threat of "theft of intellectual property
on a massive scale," he said. Mr Lobban warned that government business will
become vulnerable as more transactions are conducted online. He pointed out that
online tax and benefit payment systems could be soon processing more than £100
billion. Individuals are at risk from a "disturbing" growth in electronic
crimes, he added. Thousands of stolen British credit card details are available
for sale online for less than £2 each, he said.

A single computernet.work is believed to have stolen online banking details
^from more than 12 million § people worldwide, he added. i Mr Lobban's words to
the fc International Institute for y Strategic Studies are the most 5 explicit
warning to date from § Britain's intelligence chiefs £about the threat of
internet.- 5 based attacks. Jonathan Evans, i the head of MIS, has warned iithat
Britain faces "unrecon- Sstructed attempts by Russia, China and others" who were
using "sophisticated technical attacks" to try to steal technology on military
projects.

                          Press Association Mediapoint

                     October 13, 2010 Wednesday 3:34 PM BST

BOMBERS 'LAUGHING' ON WAY TO TERROR ATTACK

BYLINE: Chris Greenwood, Sam Marsden and Katie Hodge, Press Association

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 214 words


The July 7 bombers were ``sharing a joke, laughing, smiling and generally
relaxed'' as they made their final journey, a commuter said today.

Barrister Ben Leech said he watched the four men with suspicion after joining
their train at St Albans on his way to work in Temple, central London.

He said they stuck out from other commuters because they were carrying rucksacks
and wearing dark-coloured casual clothing that would not be suitable for the
office.

The inquests into the deaths of the 52 people killed in the 2005 atrocities
heard Mr Leech told police he suspected they were military cadets or going on
holiday together.

Speaking at the Royal Courts of Justice today, Mr Leech said the men ``seemed to
be in fairly good spirits''.

He said: ``They were fairly young and looked like they were going away, simply
because they had rucksacks, quite large backpack-type rucksacks.

``But they did not look like they were going on a casual holiday because they
were not wearing casual relaxed clothing, something a little bit more formal.''

The inquest heard Mr Leech told police in a statement they were ``sharing a
joke, laughing, smiling and generally relaxed''.

Under cross examination by Gareth Patterson, who represents four of the bereaved
families, he added: ``They were not subdued.''

                              151 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                   vnunet.com

                           13 October 2010 Wednesday

UK facing increased threat of cyber terrorist attack

BYLINE: David Neal

LENGTH: 466 words



HIGHLIGHT: Critical infrastructure at very real risk, warns GCHQ director


The director of GCHQ has warned that the UK is facing the very real threat of a
cyber terrorist attack.

Iain Lobban said during a speech at the International Institute for Strategic
Studies that the UK's economic future relies on its ability to fend off cyber
attacks on the country's critical infrastructure.

Lobban explained that GCHQ has a role to play in all areas of UK security, and
had its roots in the code breakers at Bletchley Park.

"Through the intervening years our achievements have remained at that high level
of technological expertise. Our people, of whom I am immensely proud, remain one
of this country's great unsung assets," he said.

Securing the UK's critical infrastructure and protecting against malware is a
constantly evolving task, Lobban added.

"We have seen worms cause significant disruption to government systems, both
targeted deliberately against us and picked up from the internet accidentally,"
he said.

"There are over 20,000 malicious emails on government networks each month. Cyber
space lowers the bar for entry to the espionage game for states and criminals."

Lobban explained that the risks in all these areas are growing in line with the
growth of the internet.

"Cyber space is contested every day, every hour, every minute, every second. I
can vouch for that from the displays in our own operations centre of
minute-by-minute cyber attempts to penetrate systems around the world," he said.

Government use of technology is well documented, from self-service portals to
plans for ID cards, medical and police databases and the systems it uses to
operate.

Lobban said that the government will continue to put services online, but that
it has to be done without putting citizens' data at risk, and without opening up
payment systems to fraud. "This is a big challenge," he warned.

Lobban called the growth of electronic crime "disturbing", adding that when
thousands of credit card details are stolen they are sold for a handful of
pounds. Yet the implications go much deeper than financial loss.

"E-crime begins to look like a low-risk, but potentially high-profit,
opportunity for the creative criminal. So we need to change that," he said.

Likely solutions include better reporting mechanisms, increased use of
intelligence, improved law enforcement and better control at the supplier end.

"The owners of vulnerable services can help by adhering to good information
assurance practices," he said.

Lobban promised that the UK is committed to working with other countries and law
enforcement agencies to deal with the most advanced attacks, and that such
co-operation is critical.

"Where there is a deliberate or an unintended spread of a worm that threatens
critical systems, countermeasures will need to be co-ordinated internationally
in order to be effective," he said.

LOAD-DATE: 14 October 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication

                           October 14, 2010 Thursday

US security firm, Indian agency behind terror attacks in Pakistan - article

LENGTH: 993 words


Text of article by Naveed Masud Hashmi headlined "What are US Blackwater
terrorists doing?" published by Pakistani newspaper Ausaf on 12 October

Whether or not anyone accepts it, the reality is that attempts to ignite the
fire of sectarianism in Karachi have reached their peak. On the very next day of
the killing of Maulana Muhammad Amin, a Jamia Banoria al-Alamia [Islamic
seminary] teacher of the Hadith and renowned religious scholar, two bomb
explosions occurred at the shrine of famous sufi saint Syed Abdullah Shah Ghazi
in Karachi. The government termed the explosions suicide attacks and claimed to
identify one of the bombers as 14-year-old Naseebullah. But, Naseebullah reached
home safe and sound the next morning. After finding one of the suicide attackers
alive, police authorities had to free Naseebullah's father. Therefore, our
security agencies can claim tomorrow that bomb explosions, and not suicide
attacks, had taken place at the shrine of the saint.

If one meets ulema, religious and political workers, and ordinary people of
Karachi, he will face no difficulty in knowing that residents of the Sind
metropolis have been completely disappointed with the role of the Sind
Government and police. Addressing a gathering on the occasion of Maulana
Muhammad Amin Shaheed's funerals, Maulana Mufti Muhammad Naeem and Maulana
Aurangzeb Farooqui demanded Supreme Court Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad
Chaudhry to take suo moto notice of targeted killings [preceding two words in
English] of ulema and religious workers in Karachi. They said that approximately
40 of their colleague ulema and workers had fallen prey to targeted killing in
Karachi in two moths, but the administration and police did not arrest murderers
of anyone of them. As they had no expectation of justice from police and other
law enforcement agencies; therefore, the chief justice should provide justice to
them, they added.

The explosions at Syed Abdullah Shah Ghazi shrine had killed 10 innocent people.
Addressing a condolence meeting, Sunni Tehreek Chief Sarwat Ejaz Qadiri and
other ulema also demanded the chief justice to take suo moto notice of attacks
on shrines of sufi saints in the country. It is a reality that after the
targeted killing of ulema and religious workers in Karachi and recent attacks on
Data Darbar [one of the most revered shrines in Pakistan] in Lahore, two bomb
explosions at Shah Ghazi's shrine have created an environment of severe
restlessness among the countrymen. Whatever opinions different sectarian
organizations form about these incidents, it is their right. But the reality is
that the Pakistani people are not at all prepared to believe that these attacks
have any link with sectarianism.

Pakistan came into being 64 years ago and people belonging to Brelvi, Deobandi,
Ahl-e Hadith, and Shiite communities have been living in the country with each
other. The sacred shrines of sufi saints are also present in the country for
centuries. The question is: "What has happened during the past three or four
years that sacred shrines have started coming under attacks?" If anyone says
that curriculum taught in madrasahs belonging to a certain school of thought
incites for attacks on shrines, he is telling a lie. Had madrasahs curriculum
been producing such attackers, the followers of Deobandi, Brelvi, and Ahl-e
Hadith schools of thought would have been eliminated by now by fighting each
other.

And if anyone claims that shrines are being attacked because of "jihad," he has
been making such claims because of his ignorance or shallow knowledge. Jihad has
not started just one, two or three years ago; rather, a group of Pakistani
mujahidin had for the first time participated in the Afghan jihad in 1979.
During the war against former Soviet Union; students and teachers of the
Pakistani madrasahs and colleges, ulema, and people have been going to
Afghanistan to take part in jihad. A jihadist movement has been going on for the
past 20 years in Occupied Kashmir [India-administered Kashmir] as well and
thousands of Pakistan mujahidin have embraced martyrdom, fighting the Indian
forces there. But during this entire period no shrine was ever attacks in
Pakistan.

It clearly means that any true mujahid does not consider attacking shrines or
innocent people jihad. Had those conducting the attacks on shrines been
representing any particular sect, this evil had started half a century ago. The
attacks on shrines should be seen in the backdrop of the US so-called "war on
terror." No individual, group, or organization can pit followers of different
schools of thought against each other in Pakistan unless it enjoys support of
any foreign power.

Our media has been raising hue and cry about present of Blackwater in Pakistan
for the past several years. The question is: "What the hundreds of Blackwater
terrorists are doing in Pakistan?" And it is not hidden from any sensible
Pakistani that the United States and India want to pit two main Pakistani sects
-- Brelvi and Deobandi -- against each other. When Maulana Dr Sarfaraz Naeemi, a
renowned scholar of Brelvi school of thought, came to know about the US
conspiracy to pit these sects against each other, he was ruthlessly martyred.
But the country was saved from major sectarian riots because of sane reaction
expressed by the Brelvi school of thought.

What is the demand of the situation today is that renowned religious scholars of
both schools of thought, shrine leaders, and madrasahs elders sit together and
find a unanimous solution to this issue. Thousands of terrorists belonging to
Indian intelligence agency -- RAW [Research and Analysis Wing] and US Blackwater
are not visible to anyone in spite of being present in Pakistan. They are
engaged in their heinous activities on the Pakistani soil, but no one is aware
of this situation. If our ulema and leaders did not infuse unity in the country,
we will be annihilated.

Source: Ausaf, Islamabad in Urdu, 12 Oct 10, p 10

Failed terror attack suspect sacks legal team

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 105 words


Failed airline bomber Umar Farouk Abdulmutalla has dismissed his legal team and
will represent himself in court in Detroit today.

The 24-year-old Nigerian, who tried to blow up a flight from Amsterdam to the
city last Christmas Day, is due for a pre-trial hearing.

He will be accompanied by a standby lawyer who can give advice.

Last month Abdulmutalla suggested he wanted to plead guilty to some charges.

He is charged with attempting to use a weapon of mass destruction to blow up
Northwest Airlines Flight 253 by trying to fire to explosives hidden in his
underwear.

He has been held at a federal prison in Michigan since his arrest.

                     October 14, 2010 Thursday 01:09 PM GMT

US still wary of European terror attack

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 112 words


The US still believes that Europe is at grave risk from a terrorist attack, a
government official warned today.

US State Department counter-terrorism co-ordinator Daniel Benjamin said the
terror plot remained active and a travel alert will stay in force.

Earlier this month the department advised American citizens living or travelling
in Europe to take more precautions for their personal security, following
reports that terrorists may be plotting attacks.

Concerns have centred around a plot using assault weapons on public places
similar to the 2008 Mumbai massacre.

Mr Benjamin said in London: "We don't view the conditions as warranting us
rescinding the (travel) alert."

Film explores terror attacks

LENGTH: 142 words


Thanet Film Society

The Palace, Broadstairs

London River Tuesday, October 19, 8pm Cert 15

»Ramsgate actress Brenda Blethyn stars as hard-working protestant Guernsey
farmer Elisabeth.

She is devoted to her daughter Jane, who lives in London and after the July 7
bus and tube bombings she stops answering her phone.

Concerned for her safety, Elisabeth travels to London, where she is contacted by
French-speaking African Muslim Ousmane, who has come to the UK in search of his
missing son, who appears to have been romantically involved with Jane.

French director Rachid Bouchareb uses a true incident to explore the emotional
turmoil of those  affected by it, and the racial and religious prejudice that
arose in its aftermath.

A subtly powerful and moving film, it benefits greatly from two excellent
central performances from Brenda Blethyn and Sotigui Kouyate.

                                  Sunday Life

                                  Main Edition

TA soldiers put on terror attack alert ...

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 315 words


TA soldiers put on terror attack alert

PART-TIME soldiers in Co Antrim have been advised to increase their personal
security, Sunday Life has learned.

It follows a threat by dissident republicans hell-bent on cranking up their
bloody campaign to smash the peace process.

And it is Territorial Army members living in Newtownabby who are specifically on
the renegades' radar.

The heightened security threat centres on four areas of the borough --
Glengormley, Carnmoney, Mallusk and Hightown.

TA members living in these areas were warned in emails from Army headquarters
last week: "All personnel to increase security drills and vehicle checks."

The threat has emerged just two months after a high-ranking soldier was targeted
in a booby-trap car bomb in Bangor, Co Down.

TA soldiers train at barracks across Northern Ireland and also serve on
operations either with TA units or as individuals attached to regular Army
units.

More than 1,000 TA soldiers are deployed in war zones like Afghanistan each
year.

One source told us: "The dissidents have obviously been spotted carrying out
surveillance on soldiers in Newtownabbey.

"Some of the men in a couple of the areas mentioned probably feel safe because
by and large they would be loyalist districts, but it just goes to show the
danger dissidents continue to pose."

Leading Newtownabbey councillor Nigel Hamilton condemned the threat and urged
the Chief Constable Matt Baggott to review the protection of TA members.

He said: "It is a serious step up in activity to target part-time soldiers who
live and work openly in our community.

"It is not enough that TA members risk their lives in Afghanistan but to be
constantly under threat at home can only put them and their loved ones on
constant alert.

"The Chief Constable must respond to this threat and I will be seeking an urgent
meeting to ask for that response."

Pakistan religious outfits to hold long march against shrine terror attacks

LENGTH: 323 words


Text of unattributed report headlined "Sunni Ittehad Council to stage long march
from Bari Imam to Data Mazar" published by The News website on 18 October

Islamabad: Sunni Ittehad Council on Sunday [17 October] announced to hold long
march on 27 November from Islamabad to Lahore to highlight the importance of
Nizam-i-Mustafa (Peace Be Upon Him) in ensuring peace and stability in the
country.

Chairman of the Council Sahibzada Fazl Karim made this announcement while
addressing the Ulema and Mashaikh Convention held here under the aegis of Sunni
Ittehad Council. A large number of Ulema and religious scholars belonging to
Sunni school of thought and their followers attended the conference.

The march would start from the shrine of Hazrat Bari Imam (RA) and culminate at
the shrine of Hazrat Data Ali Hajveri (RA) in Lahore, he said. Fazl Karim, who
is also MNA, announced that he and like-minded people would contest the next
general elections from the platform of the Sunni Ittehad Council, urging Ulema
and Mashaikh to get them united to play an active role in national politics.

Today, he said Pakistan is facing the biggest challenge of terrorism for which
an effective strategy is required to uproot the menace from the society.

He appreciated the efforts of security forces in flushing out the militants from
the tribal areas. The Ulema convention passed a number of resolutions on various
issues like poverty, terrorism, price hike, unemployment, national sovereignty
and publishing of hatred literature, asking the government to resolve these
problems in an appropriate manner.

Among others, Pir Mazhar Saeed Kazmi, Haji Haneef Tayyab, Pir Afzal Qadri,
Sarwat Ejaz Qadri, Qari Munir Ahmed Jeelani, Abdul Hameed Saifi, Syed Riaz
Hussain Shah, Rana Muhammad Iqbal and Abdul Rehman attended the convention and
expressed their views to ensure peace and stability in the country.

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 18 Oct 10

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            October 18, 2010 Monday

India: Government counsel terms Mumbai attack "act of state-sponsored terrorism"

LENGTH: 507 words


Text of report by Indian news agency PTI

Mumbai, 18 October: Ajmal Kasab, the lone surviving Pakistani terrorist involved
in the 26/11 [26 November 2008] attacks, smiled, yawned and scratched his head
showing no signs of remorse as India opened arguments in the Bombay High Court
Monday [18 October] on confirmation of his death sentence.

Government Counsel Ujjwal Nikam, while giving details about the barbaric acts of
Kasab and nine others who came from Pakistan to strike terror in Mumbai, said:
"The 26/11 attack was an act of state-sponsored terrorism and was executed by
Lashkar-i-Toiba [LT] with the aid of security apparatus of that country".

The arguments began in Court 49 before Justice Ranjana Desai and Justice R.V.
More through video conference to enable Kasab hear the proceedings from the
Central Jail, where he is imprisoned in the high security bomb-and-bulletproof
cell.

23-year-old Kasab, who appeared on a big screen sharp at 11 a.m. [local time],
seemed to be uninterested in the proceedings as most of the time he was seen
smiling and yawning. At times, he scratched his head, played with the button of
his prison uniform and stretched his arms.

During the first half of the hearing, Kasab sought permission to go to the
washroom. He gestured at jail staff who informed the court which allowed him.

This is for the first time that arguments on confirmation of death sentence are
being heard through video conference in the Bombay High Court, legal sources
told PTI.

The entire high court building was converted into a fortress, with deployment of
armed policemen at all the four entrances. Lawyers, media persons and court
staff were issued special passes to enter Court 49 to hear the 26/11 case.

Although Kasab was not brought to the court, security was tight in view of the
sensitive nature of the case.

On 6 May, the trial court had awarded death sentence to Kasab. In accordance
with law, death penalty was referred to the High Court for confirmation.

Nikam said a heinous conspiracy was hatched in Pakistan by LT to destabilize
India, wage war against India and cause financial losses by organizing terror
attacks in Mumbai in November, 2008, in which 166 persons from India, UK, USA,
Israel and other countries were killed.

He said the ten terrorists were trained in Pakistan and left Karachi for Mumbai
by boat Al-husseini. Midway, they hijacked M.V. Kuber and killed Captain
Amarsinh Solanki. They landed at Badhwar Park in south Mumbai and went to
different places in separate batches to execute the terror attacks.

Kasab and Abu Ismael took a taxi and planted a bomb before getting down at CST,
where they fired indiscriminately at people, killing several. The taxi bomb
exploded at Vile Parle, in which the driver and a lawyer were killed.

The duo then entered nearby Cama Hospital and killed a police officer and a
constable, while injuring few others. Outside the hospital, they shot dead top
police officers, Hemant Karkare, Ashok Kamate and Vijay Salaskar.

Source: PTI news agency, New Delhi, in English 1141gmt 18 Oct 10

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                            October 18, 2010 Monday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Terrorism and cyber attacks are key threats to Britain, says report

BYLINE: Duncan Gardham

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 528 words


BRITAIN faces an increased threat from terrorism, cyber attack and small-scale
wars, a National Security Strategy published today will say.

The security and intelligence services and counter-terrorism police are to
escape major cuts in this week's public spending review due to the threats.

The strategy is a key precursor for the Strategic Defence and Security Review,
to be published tomorrow, which will explain how Britain will defend itself
against such attacks.

It will also form the basis for spending decisions to be announced this week,
including a £500million boost to cyber defence, sources told The Daily
Telegraph.

"The security strategy will look at the issues we are going to face in coming
years and the spending review will look at how to deliver that," one source
said. The security strategy is expected to outline four key threats to Britain.

The primary threat remains al-Qaeda in Pakistan and its associates in Somalia,
Yemen and North Africa, who continue to plan attacks against targets in Britain,
the security strategy will say.

That is likely to mean that MI5, MI6, GCHQ and the Metropolitan Police
counterterrorism command will escape the worst of the cuts. But the document
will also highlight the threat from cyber attacks on government infrastructure.

While not naming individual states, GCHQ, which is responsible for cyber
defence, has been concerned for some time that states such as China and Russia
are unlikely to use conventional or nuclear weapons in an attack on Britain and
are more likely to attempt to shut down essential systems used to run the
country.

Similar attacks have been seen when Russia has been in disputes with Estonia and
Georgia, leading to problems with their internet and even cash machines.

A third risk that will be highlighted is the threat of small-scale wars in
foreign countries that may escalate out of control, drawing in neighbouring
countries and creating havens for terrorists.

That threat is likely to have a major bearing on the defence review tomorrow,
which is likely to emphasise the need for mobile forces involving a combination
of aircraft carriers and special forces.

The fourth element will be the risk from natural disasters such as pandemic flu,
where strategies have been developed over recent years.

Iain Lobban, the head of GCHQ, said in a speech last week that the Government
was receiving 20,000 malicious emails a month, of which 1,000 were deliberate
attacks.

Security Lack of strategy 'puts UK at risk'

The UK's national interest is threatened by a lack of strategic thinking at the
heart of government, MPs have warned.

The public administration select committee identified a tendency for Whitehall
to "muddle through'' and pointed to the Iraq and Afghanistan wars as examples
where there had been a lack of overarching strategy.

They called for the remit of Sir Peter Ricketts, the National Security Adviser,
to be expanded to include a central co-ordinating role on national strategy. The
report said Britain's capacity to think strategically had been undermined by
assumptions that national interests were best served by the special relationship
with the US and economic links within the EU.

LOAD-DATE: October 18, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: DTL


                  Copyright 2010 Telegraph Media Group Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                                  Daily Record

                            October 18, 2010, Monday

SUPER MIKE CALLS IT A DAY AFTER 41 YEARS;
COP HAS HANDLED CASUALS, TERROR ATTACKS, NEDS AND STARS

BYLINE: Paul O'Hare

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 1085 words


STRATHCLYDE'S longest serving police officer made his final arrest in front of
the Pope.

And Superintendent Mike Dean's epic career ended in the Hampden tunnel as
Scotland took on world champions Spain.

The dad-of-two officially retires on Friday after nearly 41 years of service.

Over the years, he's man-marked Maradona, drank with Inter Milan's Ultras, dealt
with the grim aftermath of the Lockerbie bombing and crossed Europe with the
Olympic flame.

Mike, 59, was on duty in Bellahouston Park, Glasgow, last month - just as he was
for Pope John Paul II's historic visit in 1982.

And he was called into action to make the solitary arrest of the day.

He recalled: "During the Mass there was a call put out, 'Chief inspector
requiring assistance in Zone 4' "I was first in and Kenny Graham, my chief
inspector colleague who is ages with me, was on the deck.

"He had a guy pinned down and the guy was trying to bite and kick him.

"I landed on top of the guy and Kenny looked round and said, 'Oh, no. Not you.'

"I never thought me and Kenny would have been rolling about in front of the Pope
but I don't think he saw us!"

Colleagues later joked that the two officers were just like Jack and Victor from
the hit BBC comedy Still Game.

Christopher McGill, 30, admitted breach of the peace, resisting arrest and
police assault last Friday and was given a 100-day curfew.

Mike's final duty was as ground commander at Hampden for Tuesday's Euro 2012
qualifier.

He said: "I specifically asked to be in the tunnel for Scotland versus the world
champions for my last working day.

"It was a great night - pity about the result!

"After the game my three-year old grandson got his picture taken with Allan
McGregor.

"And as I handed him over I said, 'Don't drop him!' "

Stalking

Mike was also on duty when Scotland played Argentina in a friendly in 2008. And
he shadowed the South American side's legendary star-turnedmanager in the
tunnel.

Yesterday, he laughed as he recalled his brother phoning from Hong Kong after
watching the match on TV.

Mike said "I was actually told I was stalking Diego Maradona."

His role as a police adviser has taken him to places such as Barcelona, Milan,
Amsterdam, Prague and Belgrade.

One game that sticks out was the behind closed doors Champions League match
between Inter Milan and Rangers in 2005.

Mike revealed: "Before the match, the chief of police took me to a pub to meet
the Ultras.

"There is an uneasy relationship between the chief and the head of the Ultras
but he was a really nice guy.

"I gave him a Strathclyde Police lapel badge and he went scurrying away and came
back with an Inter Milan lapel badge for me.

"He told me: 'I'll be coming to Glasgow.' I said: 'I hope you are not going to
cause any trouble.'

"But he replied, 'No. I'm bringing my wife and children and there will be no
trouble from the Ultras.'

"It was surreal to see the chief of police and the head of the Ultras having a
beer together."

Another highlight was a European tour in 2005 after Strathclyde Police were
tasked with taking the Olympic flame on foot from Athens to Glasgow for the
Special Olympics.

Mike, who acted as a media officer, said: "We went through almost every capital
in Europe and it took over six weeks. And we kept the flame lit the whole way.

Mike, whose daughter is also a cop, has policed dozens of concerts ranging from
Bruce Springsteen and AC/DC at Hampden to Snow Patrol and Coldplay at
Bellahouston.

He revealed that even in the tensest times there were a few lighthearted moments
- including one in Glasgow's Gorbals.

Mike revealed: "A few years ago, we did an ambush in Norfolk Street. The day
before, the suspect threatened to kill his social worker.

"My star witness, the only one who could identify this guy, was in my command
vehicle.

"It was a busy area we were watching and the guy said: 'I think that might be
him'.

"I said, 'Thinking's not good enough, you need to be sure.'

"This happened two or three times and I said, 'Are you okay doing this? Is there
anything wrong with your eyes?'

"He then told me: 'I'm going in for an eye operation next week'.

"I asked him how bad his eyes were and he said, 'I was at a game at Parkhead
last week and I could not tell the difference between Evander Sno and Neil
Lennon.'

Thankfully. minutes later the suspect was spotted, identified, surrounded by 10
armed cops and arrested.

A career spanning more than four decades has also had its share of dark days.

In his role as a media spokesman for the force, Mike was dispatched to Dumfries
to assist the country's smallest force in the wake of the 1988 Lockerbie
bombing.

He said: "I went down on day two and at that time, nothing had been removed and
there were still bodies lying around. It was absolutely horrific."

And Mike's first helicopter trip was to accompany a TV crew as the famous aerial
footage of the crater was filmed.

The officer's childhood dream was to join the RAF as a pilot.

Freak

But after a change of heart, aged 17, he sat his police entrance exam in Elgin.

In March 1970, Mike joined the then Dunbartonshire Constabulary.

And he recalled how Sir William Kerr, the first of eight chief constables he has
served under, was almost killed in a freak accident.

Mike said: "The force was looking at buying or hiring a helicopter and the chief
went for a shot in one of them.

"It landed beside the current headquarters in Dumbarton and as he got out he
walked into the tail rotor of the helicopter.

"He lost his eye and part of his shoulder.

"The detective sergeant who was dealing with it came into the office with a
piece of the chief's collar bone."

Mike learned an early lesson - "always watch your prisoners" - when he was
headbutted by a ned in Dumbarton town centre.

And he recalled being hit on the head with a bottle and kicked in the privates
by a female on his first Saturday night shift in Drumchapel.

Since then he has served in all three Glasgow divisions. He also played a vital
role in community relations in the wake of the Kriss Donald and Moira Jones
murders.

His final appointment was as deputy divisional commander and earlier this year
he was presented with a lifetime achievement award.

The force he leaves is a world away from the one he joined thanks to advances
such as DNA and CCTV. But with budget cuts looming he fears for the future.

Mike said: "If certain organisations can get bailed out with public money then
why can't the public sector?

"If you spoke to someone on the street and said 'Would you rather have police on
the street or a bank on the street?' "I know what they would say."

LOAD-DATE: October 18, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: CRAZY CAREER: Mike has dealt with Ultra casuals, left, the Lockerbie
disaster and Diego Maradona, right VISIT: Mike's last arrest was in front of the
Pope

                                  Guardian.com

                            October 18, 2010 Monday

Terrorism and cyber attacks are main threats to UK, national security strategy
finds

BYLINE: Helene Mulhollandguardian.co.uk

LENGTH: 747 words

ABSTRACT

New report also highlights risk of terrorism linked to Northern Ireland

FULL TEXT

Britain is under a "potent threat" of attack from al-Qaida, the government said
today, publishing a report that also highlighted terrorism linked to Northern
Ireland as a serious risk.

In a joint statement, David Cameron and Nick Clegg said there needed to be a
"radical transformation" in the way Britain thinks about and organises its
national security.

The Tory-Lib Dem coalition government's first  says terrorism and cyber attacks
are currently the main threats facing the UK. It identifies four "tier one"
risks that, it says, must be the government's highest priority.

The other major threats are a large-scale accident or natural hazard such as
pandemic flu and an international military crisis that could draw in the UK and
its allies.

A second series of "tier two" priorities include an attack by another state or
its proxy using weapons of mass destruction, a civil war or other instability
that terrorists could exploit to threaten the UK, and a significant increase in
the level of organised crime.

Also listed as a "tier two" priority is the threat of severe disruption to
information received or transmitted by satellites, possibly as the result of a
deliberate attack by another state.

A large-scale conventional military attack on the UK is rated only as a "tier
three" priority alongside disruption to oil and gas supplies and a large-scale
radioactive release from a civil nuclear site.

Other "tier three" risks include a significant increase in the numbers of
terrorists, organised criminals or illegal immigrants trying to enter the UK, an
attack on another Nato or EU member or a UK overseas territory, and the
disruption of essential supplies such as food or minerals.

The publication of the strategy comes ahead of the release tomorrow of the
strategic defence and security review, which will set out the future shape of
the armed forces.

In a joint foreword to the strategy, Cameron and Clegg said: "We are entering an
age of uncertainty. This strategy is about gearing Britain up for this new age
of uncertainty - weighing up the threats we face and preparing to deal with
them," they said.

"As g Government, we have inherited a defence and security structure that is
woefully unsuitable for the world we live in today. We are determined to learn
from those mistakes and make the changes needed."

In a written ministerial statement, Cameron said the UK faced a "complex array
of threats from a myriad of sources".

The prime minister said: "Our objectives are ensuring a secure and resilient
United Kingdom, and shaping a stable world.

"In pursuit of these goals, our highest priorities are tackling terrorism, cyber
security, international military crises and natural disasters such as floods and
pandemics.

"We will draw together and use all the instruments of national power to tackle
these risks, including the armed forces, diplomats, intelligence and development
professionals, the police, the private sector and the British people
themselves."

Speaking earlier today, May said that 51% of malicious software threats that
have ever been identified occurred in 2009.

The home secretary said: "It's a threat to government, it's a threat to
businesses and indeed to personal security. We have identified this as a new and
growing threat in the UK."

Iain Lobban, the director of GCHQ, the government's eavesdropping and encrypting
agency, last week used his first public speech to call for an aggressive
approach to cyber attacks, and warned of the dangers of adopting the sort of
defensive strategy famously symbolised by France's Maginot line, which was meant
to repel the Germans and failed.

On international terrorism, May said Britain now faced a "very serious threat".
"That is why we have a threat level that is at 'severe', which means an attack
is highly likely," she said. "We must all be vigilant."

Yvette Cooper, the shadow home secretary, said ahead of today's statement: "The
government seem to be producing a reheated security strategy to provide cover
for a rushed defence spending review, rather than producing a renewed and
careful consideration of the UK's defence and security priorities.

"The government should show renewed vigour in the process towards a political
settlement in Afghanistan, led by the Afghans, while supporting our 10,000
troops with the resources they need in creating the conditions on the ground for
a more stable country."

LOAD-DATE: October 18, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            October 19, 2010 Tuesday

Police say Pakistan Taleban financed failed Time Square terror attack

LENGTH: 422 words


Text of report by Mudassir Raja headlined "TTP men financed botched New York
attack" published by Pakistani newspaper Dawn website on 19 October

Rawalpindi, 18 October: The capital police on Monday [18 October] said
Tehrik-i-Taleban Pakistan (TTP) men had extended financial support to Faisal
Shahzad in planning the botched terrorist attack in New York's Time Square.

This was stated by Sihala police in its investigation report about the arrest of
three men, Hunbal Akhtar and Mohammad Shoaib Mughal of Rawalpindi and Mohammad
Shahid Hussain of Islamabad. The report was submitted to Anti-Terrorism Court
(ATC) Special Judge Malik Mohammad Akram Awan. The court put off the hearing in
the case till 26 October. They said it had been established that the three men
had links with the man in the US.

The investigators in their report, under Section 179 of Pakistan criminal
procedure code, said the three men used to visit Hakimullah Mehsud of TTP, and
Shoaib allegedly allowed Faisal Shahzad and three other suicide bombers to stay
at his home for one week. In their investigation report, the police said the
name of one of the bombers was Qaiser Mehmood and another was identified as
brother of Qari Hussain, while the third one was unknown. Later, the men who
stayed at the house of Shoaib carried out suicide attacks in Muzaffarabad. On
the disappearance of Humbal, Shoaib and Shahid, the police believed that they
had been kidnapped and registered cases with different police stations of the
twin cities. But on 5 September, they received information that they had gone
underground and had never been abducted. Police arrested them from Islamabad
Highway when they were travelling in a car (LXL-8485), while their two other
accomplices, Faisal and Faheem, escaped. The investigators got the registration
number checked from Lahore and found it fake, as the number was issued to a
motorcycle and its owner was not known. Police said a laptop and maps of
important buildings of Islamabad, including Parliament House, were also
recovered from the vehicle. They said the accused in their statement, under
Section 164 of criminal procedure code before a judicial magistrate, confessed
that they had provided 43, 000 dollars to Faisal Shahzad for the attacks. Police
had obtained the recording data of conversation between the accused and Faisal.
The investigators prayed to the court to convict the men for abetting and
carrying out terrorist activities within and outside the country.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 19 Oct 10
