                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            October 19, 2010 Tuesday

Politicians blame Chechen attack on international terrorism

LENGTH: 697 words


This morning rebels attacked the Chechen parliament, Gazprom-owned
editorially-independent radio "Ekho Moskvy" reported on 19 October. As a result,
three people died and at least 17 were wounded. One of the rebels blew himself
up while two others penetrated the building. A shoot-out started.

The report said that the Chechen attack was discussed at the State Duma. A
detailed investigation is needed to understand what the goal of the terrorists
was and how they managed to penetrate the parliament, Vladimir Vasilyev, head of
the State Duma Committee on Security, said.

"After initial reports, contradictions and uncertainties always abound. Now we
already have certain theories. We should wait, and I'm sure these questions will
be answered, especially as we have taken this problem under control, and we will
learn more within our sections, naturally. Since the group of rebels was small,
their goal was limited, I think," Vasilyev said.

Vasilyev confirmed that a number of parliament employees had died in the
accident, the radio added.

There are no safe zones in the North Caucasus today, Gennadiy Gudkov, deputy
head of the State Duma Committee on Security, believes. He told the radio
station that this is a systemic problem.

"In spite of the efforts taken by the federal government and the president, the
desirable result is eluding us. This fact, it seems, indicates the existence of
some serious systemic flaws in the overall mechanism of power in the Russian
Federation. We cannot single out individual areas and clear them of corruption
and bureaucratic arbitrariness which, certainly, create favourable breeding
grounds for the viruses of terrorism in this region. We cannot achieve this.
Consequently, it seems that the measures taken are correct and that the
government understands that socioeconomic policy should be put in order in the
first place but these measures are too late. They are coming against the above
mentioned problems of the Russian authorities have, the problems which,
unfortunately, reduce to nothing these efforts to normalize the situation in the
North Caucasus," Gudkov said.

The attack of rebels on the Chechen parliament will be discussed at a meeting of
the Caucasus commission under the upper chamber of the Russian parliament,
Aleksandr Torshin, member of the Federation Council, head of the Caucasus
commission and member of the National Antiterrorist Committee, has told
Interfax. The meeting is scheduled for next Tuesday [26 October].

Torshin said that it seems the terrorists had found a new target. "Whereas
before the terrorists attacked only the executive, now they carry out attacks
against the representative authorities too," Torshin said. He believes that the
event warrants special attention because in this case "we are dealing with a
certain show of force. This must not be left without response".

Aleksandr Torshin doesn't rule out that the attack was timed to coincide with
head of the Interior Ministry Rashid Nurgaliyev's working trip to Chechnya.
"This was a public-relations stint for the fighters," the senator thinks.

The Interfax agency quoted head of the Chechen parliament Dukuvakh Abdurakhmanov
as saying that, in his view, the attack on Chechen parliament was coordinated
from abroad.

This view was echoed by head of the Russian Federation Council, currently in
China. According to an ITAR-TASS report from Beijing, Federation Council speaker
Sergey Mironov believes that the terrorist act in Groznyy was funded by
international terrorism. "This was an attempt to destabilize one of the Caucasus
republics and to justify the money the terrorist underground receives from
abroad, "Sergey Mironov told Chinese journalists. Mironov is convinced that the
existing legislation makes the efficient struggle against terrorism possible.
The Federation Council speaker is convinced, at the same time, that in this case
"we are dealing with international terrorism" which can be countered efficiently
only by joint international efforts.

Source: Ekho Moskvy radio, Moscow, in Russian 0900 gmt 19 Oct 10; Interfax news
agency, Moscow, in Russian 0846, 0856 gmt 19 Oct 10; ITAR-TASS news agency,
Moscow, in Russian 1047 gmt 19 Oct 10

Crime ring busted in southern Russia planned terror attacks - committee

LENGTH: 399 words


Excerpt from report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Moscow, 19 October: The activities of a criminal group that planned terrorist
attacks in Astrakhan Region have been stopped, the National Antiterrorist
Committee (NAC) has told Interfax on Tuesday [19 October].

"The activities of a criminal group that planned to carry out terrorist acts and
bandit raids in Astrakhan Region have been stopped in a timely manner," the
committee said.

"Getting information in advance, competent actions of field officers, the
effective work of the operational headquarters and investigators made it
possible to prevent crimes and ensure the safety of our citizens," the committee
said.

According to NAC, Gayni Zhumagaziyev, who was on the wanted list, was killed in
Astrakhan. He had offered armed resistance and was killed in the ensuing gun
battle.

"The criminal was found in possession of a belt with two grenades, a knife,
loaded magazines for automatic weapons, and an assault rifle and two pistols
stolen from a police employee," NAC said.

The committee also said that in the process of ending the activities of the
militant group, special services found other ammunition, a cardboard box with
ammonium nitrate weighing about 1kg, and aluminium powder packed in plastic
bags.

"The bandits were also found in possession of documentary and video materials on
religious and extremist topics, a notebook with notes on tactical combat
training, a sheet of paper depicting sectors of fire for shooting at a motor
vehicle," NAC said.

The committee noted that the special services got on the trail of the criminals
while investigating three armed attacks on police employees committed during the
summer in Astrakhan. Two policemen were killed and six were wounded in the
attacks. The attackers stole service weapons and radio stations.

According to NAC, it has been established that a weapon seized from the
militants was used in the commission of crimes: on 27 August, a young woman was
killed using the weapon, and on 5 October it was used in the attack on the imam
of a mosque in the city.

"The criminal cases opened on these facts have been consolidated to form one
case. Eight people have been detained in the course of subsequent search
operations. Two other suspected accomplices are still wanted," NAC said.

[Passage omitted: background]

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                            October 19, 2010 Tuesday

Cyberwar and terror attacks rated as worst security threats in review: National
security strategy lists four 'tier one' risks: Non-state groups most likely
perpetrators

BYLINE: Richard Norton-Taylor, Security editor

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 484 words


The government yesterday unveiled its national security strategy, emphasising
new threats facing Britain from cyberspace, non-state groups and hostile forces
that are unlikely to be deterred by conventional weaponry.

Coming before today's defence review on military spending, the national security
strategy white paper identified four "tier one" threats to Britain - terrorism,
attacks in cyberspace, a large accident or hazard, and lastly, a military
crisis, the only one relating to a conventional emergency that would involve
other states.

The defence review will confirm that the navy will get two aircraft carriers at
a total cost of £5bn, by far the most expensive single item in the armed forces'
inventory. The RAF's ageing Tornado jets will be reprieved, at least in the
medium term.

The review will also allow extra resources for countering cyber attacks,
amounting to about £500m. GCHQ, the codebreaking and eavesdropping centre, is
likely to benefit.

Officials did not say whether the government would develop an offensive cyber
warfare capability, as the US has done. But they made clear MI5 and MI6, which
have enjoyed budget increases in recent years, would not escape an austerity
package in tomorrow's spending review.

The "tier two" list of threats includes potential attacks on the UK by other
states employing chemical, biological, radiological or nuclear weapons;
insurgency overseas; and attacks on satellites.

"Tier three" threats include disruption to gas and oil supplies, a rise in the
"level of terrorists, organised criminals, illegal immigrants, and illicit goods
trying to cross the UK border to enter the UK", and attacks on a UK overseas
territory "as the result of a sovereignty dispute".

The white paper was based on risk assessments taking into account the impact of
a potential attack and its likelihood, said senior British officials.

The paper states: "At present only al-Qaida represents a major ideologically
driven threat to the national security of the UK and our allies. But . . . some
regionally based ideologies could affect us through our role as an international
hub, through the engagement of some (in) diaspora populations, or through
driving conflict which impacts on our interests. It is a realistic possibility
that in the next 10 years, extremists . . . could cross the line between
advocacy and terrorism."

The white paper was welcomed by anti-nuclear groups, including Greenpeace, which
claimed the MoD had wasted money "equipping itself to fight the last war rather
than the next". It added: "Yet that doesn't seem to be deterring the government
from . . . plans to waste £97bn on Trident's replacement, a cold war weapon
entirely irrelevant to the key threats."

The shadow foreign secretary, Yvette Cooper, said: "Our concern is, this (was)
produced to provide cover for what the defence secretary admits has been a
rushed defence review, not strategic at all."

LOAD-DATE: October 20, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                   Irish News

                            October 19, 2010 Tuesday

Terrorism and cyber attacks the main threats

BYLINE: Gavin Cordon

SECTION: Pg. 19

LENGTH: 254 words


Terrorism and cyber-attacks are the main threats facing Britain and Northern
Ireland, the British government said yesterday.

The new National Security Strategy identifies four "tier one" risks which, it
says, must be the government's highest priority.

The other major threats are a large scale accident or natural hazard such as
pandemic flu and an international military crisis which could draw in Britain
and its allies.

A second series of "tier two" priorities include an attack by another state or
its proxy using weapons of mass destruction, a civil war or other instability
which terrorists could exploit and a significant increase in the level of
organised crime.

Also listed as a "tier two" priority is the threat of severe disruption to
information received or transmitted by satellites, possibly as the result of a
deliberate attack by another state.

A large-scale conventional military attack is rated only as a "tier three"
priority alongside disruption to oil and gas supplies and a large-scale
radioactive release from a civil nuclear site.

Other "tier three" risks include a significant increase in the numbers of
terrorists, organised criminals or illegal immigrants trying to enter Britain or
Northern Ireland, an attack on another Nato or EU member or an overseas
territory and the disruption of essential supplies such as food or minerals.

The publication of the strategy comes ahead of the release today of the
Strategic Defence and Security Review, which will set out the future shape of
the British armed forces.

                              171 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                telegraph.co.uk

                      October 19, 2010 Tuesday 2:07 PM GMT

After a brazen suicide attack by Islamist terrorists, how can Russia's top brass
claim Chechnya is 'stable'?

BYLINE: By Andrew Osborn

SECTION: BLOG

LENGTH: 442 words


Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, has been struck by Islamist terrorists in a
brazen suicide attack. The assault has punctured the Kremlin's far-fetched
claims that the restive region is "safe and stable". Three extremists drove into
the internal Russian republic's parliamentary compound on Tuesday morning,
killed three people, and then blew themselves up with explosives. Witnesses said
the trio shouted "Allahu Akhbar", and engaged in a fierce gun battle with
Special Forces.

The parliament building was left badly scarred and seventeen people seriously
wounded. If that is what Russia's interior minister Rashid Nurgaliyev calls
stability (a statement he made hours after the attack) then I think someone
needs to hand the man a dictionary. Chechnya is not stable. It is more stable
than it used to be, yes, but when suicide bombers can drive into the centre of
Grozny and wreak mayhem, a serious problem remains.

I have lost count of the number of times I have heard Russian military top brass
claim to have defeated the insurgents. I have lost count of the number of times
that Ramzan Kadyrov, the Kremlin-backed Chechen leader, has claimed the same.
But still the attacks continue.

Nor is the Islamist insurgency confined to just Chechnya anymore. Russia's
entire mainly Muslim southern flank - the North Caucasus - is seething. It is an
undeclared guerrilla war. Every now and then the militants pull off "a
spectacular" like the double suicide bombing of the Moscow metro in March that
left forty people dead.

Such appalling atrocities briefly capture the world's attention. But not for
long. Russia's two brutal wars in Chechnya in the 1990s did grip the world but
what is happening there now is far less tangible. Suicide car bombings,
shoot-outs, and targeted assassinations take place across the North Caucasus
every week. But they are often in places and affect people that few Westerners
have ever heard of.

The militants say they want to create an Islamic caliphate, while experts in the
region say crushing poverty across the region makes it easy for them to
replenish their ranks. In the meantime, the Kremlin is blithely endorsing
grandiose plans to build a series of luxury ski resorts across the North
Caucasus. It is a nice idea albeit one that seems decades ahead of its time. Yet
if the Kremlin is serious about bringing peace and prosperity to this troubled
part of the world, it needs a new strategy that goes well beyond its tried and
failed heavy-handed response of merely meeting fire with fire. Building a ski
resort or two before the insurgency has been properly and definitively
extinguished isn't going to do the trick either.

LOAD-DATE: November 8, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication

                           October 20, 2010 Wednesday

Simulated terror attack rebuffed in Russian-Indian drill - agency

LENGTH: 229 words


Text of report in English by corporate-owned Russian military news agency
Interfax-AVN

Chaubattia, India, 20 October: Contingents participating in the Indra-2010
Russian-Indian anti-terror drill at the foot of the Himalayan mountains are
practicing operations to spot and neutralize terrorists, spokesman for the
Southern Military District Lt-Col Andrey Bobrun told Interfax-AVN on Wednesday
[20 October].

"In accordance with the scenario, a Russian checkpoint has been attacked by
terrorists. The terrorists were fully defeated," Bobrun said

"The Russian mountain riflemen also practiced search operations with the use of
sapper dogs. They searched 'pilgrims', discovering a grenade. The pilgrims,
dramatized by Hindus, were dispersed, immobilized and detained," the spokesman
said.

The Russian riflemen also searched a populated area, where they discovered and
defused bombs, and detained another terrorist group.

The Russian contingent's professional performance was praised by the commanders
of the exercise, including Maj-Gen Glinin and Commander of the 99th Brigade,
Brigadier General Gopal.

The Indra-2010 anti-terror drill started in Chaubattia in northern India on
Saturday [16 October].

The exercise is proceeding on densely populated terrain with great elevation
differences and forested areas.

                              173 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                           October 20, 2010 Wednesday

Suicide bombers kill three in attack on Chechen parliament: Islamist terrorists
fail to breach politicians' refuge: President Kadyrov blames Britain for tumult

BYLINE: Luke Harding, Moscow and Agencies, Grozny

SECTION: GUARDIAN INTERNATIONAL PAGES; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 655 words


Gunmen stormed Chechnya's parliament building in Grozny yesterday, killing three
people and injuring 17, in the latest audacious military operation by the
region's Islamist underground.

One insurgent detonated a bomb outside the gates at 8.45am local time, killing
himself and wounding others. Two gunmen then ran into the building shouting,
"Allahu Akbar!" ("God is great" in Arabic) and opening fire, Chechen officials
said.

The militants reportedly tried to enter the main parliamentary hall, where
several deputies were meeting. Unable to do so, the gunmen barricaded themselves
in the building's ground floor and eventually blew themselves up, officials
said.

All the attackers were killed. Two police officers and a civilian also died.
There was a grim scene around the building, with body parts and the decapitated
corpse of a terrorist lying amid shattered glass.

Russian interior minister Rashid Nurgaliyev, who was in Grozny at the time,
described the assault as "extremely rare". "Here there is stability and
security," he said, repeating Kremlin claims that Chechnya, run by the
pro-Moscow president, Ramzan Kadyrov, was firmly under government control.

The attack can been seen as further evidence of the insurgents' growing capacity
to strike at high-profile targets linked to Kadyrov and his regime.

The insurgency by Islamist rebels has grown over the past three years, with
daily bombings and shootouts between militants and security forces.

The rebels are fighting to establish an Islamic emirate across Russia's northern
Caucasus. The centre of the violence has shifted to the neighbouring Muslim
republics of Dagestan and Ingushetia. But the situation in Chechnya remains
highly volatile, despite assertions that the country is now peaceful after
brutal wars in 1994-1996 and 1999-2005.

"The timing and target of this latest attack is very interesting," said Dr
Cerwyn Moore, an expert in north Caucasus politics at Birmingham University. "It
really underlines the weakness of Kadyrov. We are seeing well co-ordinated
assaults on the symbols of power inside Chechnya."

Moore said a schism this summer in the insurgents' hierarchy may have
contributed to the recent escalation in violence.

Last week the rebel leader Doku Umarov ordered a number of commanders to renew
their oath of allegiance to him. "One (anti-Umarov) faction could be
demonstrating its ability to carry out attacks in Chechnya proper," Moore said
of yesterday's assault.

In recent months the rebels have staged a number of spectacular attacks. In
March, two female suicide bombers from Dagestan attacked the Moscow metro,
killing 40 people. In August, rebels stormed the home village of Kadyrov,
seizing several buildings. Last month 17 people were killed when a suicide car
bomb exploded in Vladikavkaz, capital of predominantly Christian North Ossetia.

Speaking at a parliamentary session after yesterday's attack, Kadyrov blamed the
UK and other European countries for the ongoing violence. He lambasted Britain
for failing to extradite Akhmed Zakayev, the Chechen separatist leader who has
political asylum in London.

Zakayev was briefly arrested last month in Warsaw while meeting other Chechen
exiles. Russia yesterday renewed an Interpol warrant for his arrest.

"The authorities and special services of London and Warsaw are protecting
bandits who killed people and committed crimes on the territory of Chechnya.
Where's democracy?" Kadyrov asked.

He also suggested Zakayev would be punished, regardless of whether Russia's
attempts to extradite him succeed. "If they don't respect us, we will make them
do so. They are barring me, a politician and a law-abiding citizen, from Europe,
but they are at the same time covering Zakayev, who is suspected of terrorism."

Captions:

Chechen special forces examine bomb damage outside the parliament in Grozny
Photograph: Musa Sadulayev/AP

Chechen forces gather on an armoured personnel carrier after the incursion

                                  M2 PressWIRE

                           October 20, 2010 Wednesday

Infosecurity Europe says IT industry is ready to meet the challenge of terrorism
and cyber-attacks identified as major threat to UK PLC

LENGTH: 568 words


October 20, 2010









Responding to the government's newly-unveiled security strategy, the organisers
of the InfoSecurity Europe event, held each spring in the UK, says that the UK's
IT industry is ready to take on the challenges that the new decade of cybercrime
will create. Infosecurity Europe's will be held at Earls Court, London 19-21
April 2011 www.infosec.co.uk

Claire Sellick, Infosecurity Europe's Event Director, said that the current -
and ongoing - convergence of technologies in the IT sector means that business
life can be made significantly easier, with information available on a 24-7
basis, even when out and about, using a mobile Internet-enabled device.



"Even without access to a laptop and mobile broadband dongle, business
professionals can still hold a lot of computing power in the palm of their hand,
in the shape of a smartphone. But just as these mobile Internet-enabled devices
are threatened by cyber-crminals, our research suggests that, with the right
technology in place, the Internet users of UK PLC are more than ready for the
security threats that hackers and criminals throw at them," she said.

"The government has committed half a billion pounds to help defend the UK
national infrastructure which, when viewed against a backdrop of budget cuts
elsewhere in Whitehall, is a very positive move, for which the cross-party
review team are to be applauded," she added.

According to Sellick, the conclusions of the cross-party Strategic Defence
Review lays the foundations for a new period of UK defences, with the battle
lines of the future being drawn in both the traditional physical landscape, as
well as the equally important cyber landscape.

We are seeing, she said, a growing number of terrorists that eschew their
traditional tools for the electronic weaponry that the Internet now offers them.


The UK IT security industry, she explained, has been supplying its clients with
the latest computer defences for several years, creating an electronic ring of
steel around business IT systems that few people truly understand, and even
fewer can attack effectively.

"The rapid pace of electronic hackery and espionage, however, is such that
crackers will develop new attacks and methodologies that can be employed for
fraudulent, and well as terrorist means," she said.

"We're confident that, with the latest technology at their fingertips, today's
British businesses can better defend themselves against the coming wave of
security threats," she added.

For more on the government's national security strategy: http://bit.ly/aByYrL

About Infosecurity Europe

Infosecurity Europe, celebrating 16 years at the heart of the industry in 2011,
is Europe's number one Information Security event. Featuring over 300
exhibitors, the most diverse range of new products and services, an unrivalled
education programme and visitors from every segment of the industry, it is the
most important date in the calendar for Information Security professionals
across Europe. Organised by Reed Exhibitions, the world's largest tradeshow
organiser, Infosecurity Europe is one of five Infosecurity events around the
world with events also running in Belgium, Netherlands and Russia. Infosecurity
Europe runs from the 19th - 21st April 2011, in Earls Court, London.

                                    Scotsman

                           October 20, 2010 Wednesday

Pakistan spy agency 'helped terrorists to plan Mumbai attack'

BYLINE: RAVI NESSMAN

LENGTH: 324 words



HIGHLIGHT: A US citizen convicted in the 2008 Mumbai attacks has claimed
Pakistan's main spy agency was deeply involved in planning the strike,
monitoring preparations and providing funding and advice to the attackers,
according to an Indian government summary of his interrogation.


The report gives the strongest indication of the involvement of Pakistani
authorities in the attack, which killed 166 people, paralysed India's business
capital and froze peace efforts between Pakistan and India.

Under questioning by Indian officials, David Headley told how intertwined
Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence agency was with the Lashkar-e-Taiba group
accused of carrying out the attack,  according to the report.

Headley, 50, from Chicago, was born Daood Gilani to a  Pakistani father and an
American mother. In March, he pleaded guilty in US federal court to laying the
groundwork for the Mumbai attack as well as preparing for an attack in Denmark.

According to the report, Headley said the Pakistani spy agency provided
individual handlers - many of them senior officers - for all the top members of
Lashkar and gave them direction and money to carry out their reconnaissance of
prospective targets.

The group's chief military commander, Zaki-ur-Rahman Lakhvi, was close to the
director general of the spy agency, Lieutenant General Ahmed Shuja Pasha, the
report states.

"According to Headley, every big action of LeT is done in close coordination
with ISI," the report said, using a common abbreviation for Lashkar-e-Taiba.

The ISI has long been suspected of links to terror groups. The spy agency is
thought to have nurtured Lashkar to attack Indian security forces in disputed
Kashmir.

Western officials have accused the ISI of working with the Taleban to
co-ordinate attacks on Nato forces in Afghanistan.

According to the report on the interrogation, Headley said the spy agency was
having problems with militant groups in Pakistan, as fighters based in Kashmir
were beginning to join Taleban groups fighting along the Pakistan-Afghanistan
border.

Launching a huge attack on India would prevent further defections from these
groups by raising their morale and move the "theatre of violence" from Pakistan
to India, the report said.

                           October 21, 2010 Thursday

India says US terror inputs before Mumbai attacks were "not specific"

LENGTH: 282 words


Text of report by Indian news agency PTI

New Delhi, 20 October: India on Wednesday [20 October] said terror-related
inputs provided to it by the US prior to the Mumbai attack in 2008 were
"general" in nature and "not specific".

The remarks by India's External Affairs Minister S M Krishna came days after
reports that two estranged wives of Pakistani-American LT [Lashkar-i-Toiba]
operative David Coleman Headley had before the Mumbai carnage told US officials
about his "radical connections".

"We had some general and not specific information which we had received from the
US prior to the heinous attack on Mumbai. But it was not specific and very
general," External Affairs Minister S M Krishna told reporters in reply to a
question on the subject.

He emphasized on the strategic ties between US and India and how they were
further strengthened in the recent years.

"We share a common outlook on a host of issues including on combating
terrorism," Krishna said.

According to media reports, two estranged wives of Headley had met US officials
and informed them about his terrorist links. However, the US has maintained that
these inputs were of a general nature.

Headley had made startling revelations about his activities in India to the
National Investigation Agency (NIA) officials who interrogated him in Chicago in
the US recently.

This includes terror attack plots on targets including the National Defence
College here.

US ambassador to India Timothy Roemer said in a statement last Saturday that
Washington had shared with New Delhi terror-related inputs it deemed were
"potentially credible" to this country's national security.

Afghan Defence Ministry taking measures to prevent terror attacks

LENGTH: 427 words


Text of report by Afghan independent Tolo TV on 20 October

[Presenter] The National Defence Ministry of Afghanistan reports about taking
necessary measures to prevent new attacks of Al-Qa'idah network in Afghanistan.
Although this ministry views such information as part of Al-Qa'idah network's
false propaganda, but it says the ministry is very serious about such reports.
On the other hand, the Afghan National Defence Ministry also reports about the
readiness of Afghan forces to take over security responsibility.

[Correspondent] Although an ISAF high official in Afghanistan has recently said
that quite a few number of members of Al-Qa'idah network from Pakistan have come
to eastern parts of Afghanistan. They are returning to Afghanistan to carry out
new attacks. However, the National Defence Ministry of Afghanistan says it has
taken the necessary measures in this regard.

[Gen Zahir Azimi, spokesman for the National Defence Ministry, captioned] The
National Defence Ministry in cooperation with the international community and
Afghan forces take measures regarding every expressed opinion or movement. We
are not indifferent towards such information. At the same time, though we
consider such information more false propaganda rather than practical, we take
such information seriously.

[Correspondent] The National Defence Ministry of Afghanistan sees Al-Qa'idah as
the most important element in the increase of insecurity in northern
Afghanistan. However, the ministry also insists on focusing attention on
providing security in these areas. The National Defence Ministry of Afghanistan
also reports about the readiness of the Afghan security forces to take the
security responsibility.

[Gen Zahir Azimi] The readiness of the Afghan forces is seen based on evaluation
and analysis. The Afghan forces have the capacity to take on the security
responsibility and at the same time there are potentials in different parts of
Afghanistan to start this process tomorrow. However, I do not want to start it
from secure places. If it is not too difficult it must at least places where the
[security] situation is in average state.

[Correspondent] These ideas are expressed at a time when the process of American
forces' gradual withdrawal will start next summer. However, the government of
Afghanistan insists on enhancing the capacity of Afghan security forces.

                            Manchester Evening News

                           October 21, 2010 Thursday

Mum-to-be's terror in pub firework attack

BYLINE: Paul Britton

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 483 words


A HEAVILY-pregnant woman has told of the

horror moment a masked yob hurled a bundle of exploding

display fireworks into a crowded pub.

The makeshift bomb' of 20 fireworks taped together landed near Amy Royle, who
was with partner Jon Flood and dad

Raymond at the Melville Hotel, Barton Road, Stretford.

Customers ran for cover as scorching red missiles showered the bar area. Amy,
who is 41 weeks pregnant, was bundled into the ladies' toilets.

Customer Viv St Paul was hit in the face by an exploding shell before she ran to
safety. Both women escaped serious injury.

Police are now investigating the reckless and stupid' attack, which was captured
on the pub's CCTV system. The graphic footage shows the thug lighting the
fireworks outside before throwing them inside and running off. The explosion is
also caught on camera.

Amy, 28, who works at a doctors' surgery, is originally from Canada but has been
living in Stretford for six years. She said: The shots from the fireworks were
firing everywhere. People were just running about the place. It was awful.

Jon and my dad pushed me into the ladies toilets because that was the nearest
room away from the bar. I am 41 weeks pregnant and even after this it still
didn't trigger anything. I was really shook up but I was more concerned about
the bump. The midwife came out to see me later but I was okay. The baby seems
quite content.

Viv, 41, a hairdresser at New Reflections on Barton Road, was enjoying a drink
with friends and suffered a cut nose. She said: Me and two others ran into the
toilet. I didn't realise I'd been hit until one of the girls saw my nose
bleeding. I couldn't see anyone the room was just full of smoke. I was so
terrified. They weren't normal fireworks, they looked like an explosive. I was
still in shock most of the night. It's been playing on my mind what could have
happened.

Viv's partner Phil Cumpsty, 41, added: It was like a firework display indoors. I
just think about what could have happened we had some friends with small
children in earlier.

Thirty customers were inside at the time. Landlord David Brown was having a meal
in Manchester when he got a call from his son and raced back. He said: When I
got there the pub was just covered in smoke. You couldn't see the person in
front of you. This is a proper boozer. There are never any arguments and it is
always peaceful. This is very much out of character and I cannot understand why
this has happened.

The CCTV is very dramatic. It shows the thing exploding and about 45 minutes of
smoke-filled rooms afterwards.

It landed on the carpet and was almost like a bomb. Apparently it was just boom
after boom. We are all just glad that no one was hurt and hope the police catch
this person soon.

The CCTV footage is being studied by detectives. Call police with information on
0161 856 7655 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

â   Women's pregnancies normally last up to 40 weeks.

                              Liverpool Daily Echo

                            October 22, 2010 Friday
                                  1ST Edition

ULTRAS TERROR IN STAB ATTACKS;
Fan tells of how gang threw bottles at them

BYLINE: LAURA JONES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 832 words


A LIVERPOOL fan today spoke of his fear as he ran through the streets of Naples
chased by a mob of violent moped riding "Ultra" hooligans.

Tage Herstad, of Anfield, was one of many fans caught up in a night of trouble
on the city's streets which saw three men treated in hospital for stab wounds
and a family group of four supporters from Bedfordshire hurt.

Ian Friar, 44, from Huyton, Philip Alexander Phillips, 53, from Netherton, and
Luke Watson, 27, were slashed by knife wielding yobs in Naples old town and
treated in hospital.

Meanwhile Gary Brown, from Bedfordshire, and his two sons Daniel, 23, and Adam,
17, and their friend Ross Hazeldene, 23, needed hospital treatment after a
separate attack.

Mr Herstad told the ECHO that Reds supporters were met with a violent welcome in
the notoriously dangerous port city ahead of last night's Europa League fixture.

"We went out for a drink (on Wednesday) and at about 11pm we went to get a pizza
when we heard a big group getting together behind us," he said.

"They were smashing sticks and baseball bats on the floor making a noise, so we
just started walking.

"We started walking quickly, but we walked the wrong way and into a blind alley
way and had to go back towards them.

"Then they came chasing us on scooters, there was a big crowd of them - about 30
after us.

"They followed us into a big square and then there was a big group in front of
us too, about 20 or 25.

"So we just went into the pub." In a bid to calm the situation Mr Herstad left
his 10 friends in the bar to try to reason with the scooter riding yobs.

"I went out to them and they said 'can't you just come out and fight?' "I told
them no and so they just said OK and left. The first gang respected that and
walked away.

"But then minutes after that the young lads in the second group wearing
balaclavas came in and went ballistic with bottles flying.

"They were hitting us and throwing bottles. I got hit once or twice with bottles
in the elbows and some of my mates got hit."

TARGETED: Life-long Liverpool fan Tage Herstad pictured in Naples the morning
after he was attacked along with a group of Liverpool fans by local hooligans
Picture: GARETH JONES After trouble flared the police arrived to help victims,
but too late to stop an innocent local man being hit in the head twice by flying
bottle.

"He was injured just outside and was bleeding to the head.

"There were loads of police around they came just a bit too late. They were with
five or six cars."

The shaken Reds fans were then escorted back to their hotel by three police
cars.

Italian police yesterday convened a press conference to warn Liverpool
supporters to follow their strict safety procedures after admitting Napoli''s
Ultras were out on the streets targeting visiting fans in random attacks.

Three men known to the Italian authorities - Lucio Gerrado, Fiorentino Mirko and
Marco Mazzano - were arrested in connection with the attack on Mr Brown and his
family.

Police also seized a number of weapons, including six-foot planks of wood with
protruding screws, a baseball bat, knuckle dusters and iron bars.

Reds'' fans were told to stick to certain designated areas near the port before
kick-off at Estadio San Paulo, amid fears of further attacks in the build up to
the game.

However, there were unconfirmed reports of running battles between police and a
group of Napoli fans after they tried to ambush Liverpool supporters outside the
stadium before the start of the game.

Filippo Bonfiligo, head of Digos - the Italian anti-terror unit - said: "The
city is so great (vast) that it is impossible to prevent everything occurring.

"We will be searching everyone going in to the stadium but (visiting) supporters
are obliged to follow the special route to the stadium. That area will be safe.

"We hope that the English supporters coming here will follow the strict meeting
points so they can be escorted safely to the stadium."

He added: "We know groups of 'Ultras' are seeking English fans. There have been
investigations into the violence that has taken place and we have made three
arrests."

NAPOLI FAN APOLOGISES FOR VIOLENT ATTACKS ONE apologetic Napoli supporter logged
on to the ECHO website to apologise to LFC fans for the violence. Giovanni
wrote; "I''m a SSC Napoli supporter, a real supporter, I think, not like stupid
people who did stupid things yesterday night. "As a Neapolitan citizen I''m
ashamed about what happened last night and all I want to let you know is that
according to most of supporter of my team, fans of Liverpool are one of the best
in the world. "Our teams (Liverpool and Naples) never have played against each
other and for us playing against Liverpool was like a dream [to] meet fans of
Liverpool to drink a beer together and to exchange our scarves." He added: "I
think that something is already broke. "I''m so sorry (like the most of
neapolitan supporters and citizens); there isn''t any other words to express
this feeling."

                              Liverpool Daily Echo

                            October 22, 2010 Friday
                                  2ND Edition

ULTRAS TERROR IN STAB ATTACKS;
Fans targeted by big gangs of 'Ultra' thugs

BYLINE: LAURA JONES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 522 words


LIVERPOOL FC fans enjoyed a trouble-free night after their team's draw with
Napoli - but their trip was overshadowed by violence in which three fans were
slashed by knife-wielding thugs.

Merseyside police stationed in Naples said intelligence suggested there was no
repeat of Wednesday night's bloodshed at the hands of Italian "Ultra" yobs.

Violence errupted after articles published in the daily Il Mattino newspaper
used the word "hooligans" to describe Reds fans journeying to the game.

Merseyside police chief inspector Dave Lewis said: "They actually used the word
'hooligan', which I think is probably irresponsible because there was no
foundation for that description."

Liverpool fans spoke of their horror as they were chased through the streets by
moped-riding thugs in the run-up to the game.

Tage Herstad, of Anfield, was one of many fans caught up in a night of trouble
on the city's streets which saw three men treated in hospital for stab wounds
and a family group from Bedfordshire hurt.

Ian Friar, 44, of Huyton; Philip Alexander Phillips, 53, of Netherton; and Luke
Watson, 27, were slashed by knife-wielding yobs in Naples old town and treated
in hospital.

Gary Brown, of Bedfordshire, and his two sons Daniel, 23, and Adam, 17, and
their friend Ross Hazeldene, 23, needed hospital treatment after a separate
attack.

Mr Herstad told the ECHO Reds supporters were met with a violent welcome in the
notoriously dangerous port city ahead of last night's Europa League fixture.

He said: "We went out for a drink [on Wednesday] and at about 11pm we went to
get a pizza when we heard a big group getting together behind us.

"They were smashing sticks and baseball bats on the floor making a noise, so we
just started walking.

"We started walking quickly, but we walked the wrong way into a blind alley and
had to go back to them.

"Then they came chasing us on scooters. There was a big crowd of them - about 30
after us.

"They followed us into a big square and then there was a big group in front of
us too, about 20 or 25, so we just went into a pub."

In a bid to calm the situation, Mr Herstad left his 10 friends in the bar to try
to reason with the yobs.

He said: "I went to them and they said 'can't you just come out and fight?' I
told them 'no' and so they just said 'OK' and left. The first gang respected
that and walked away.

"But then minutes after that, the young lads in the second group wearing
balaclavas came in and went ballistic with bottles flying.

"They were hitting us and throwing bottles. I got hit once or twice with bottles
in the elbows and some of my mates got hit."

Police arrived to help victims, but an innocent local man was hit in the head
twice by flying bottles.

Mr Herstad said: "He was injured just outside and was bleeding to the head.
There were loads of police around but they came just too late."

The shaken Reds fans were then escorted back to their hotel.

Filippo Bonfiligo, head of Digos - the Italian anti-terror unit - said: "We know
groups of 'Ultras' are seeking English fans. There were investigations into the
violence and we have made three arrests."

LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2010

flares during the game Picture: GARETH JONES

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                           October 23, 2010 Saturday

US offers Pakistan $2bn arms deal to fight Taliban and al-Qaida: Clinton
announces 30% rise in arms funding Focus on terror havens for attacks in
Afghanistan

BYLINE: Ewen MacAskill Washington Declan Walsh Islamabad

SECTION: GUARDIAN INTERNATIONAL PAGES; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 465 words


The US announced a $2bn (£1.3bn) arms sales deal with Pakistan yesterday to help
boost the fight against Taliban and al-Qaida groups using the country as a safe
haven for attacks inside Afghanistan.

The deal, to be spread out over the next five years, amounts to about a 30%
increase in US funding for weapons sales to Pakistan.

US-Pakistan relations are turbulent, constantly switching between Washington
criticising Pakistan for a lack of commitment to fighting extremism to insisting
it one of its most important allies.

The planned increase in spending was announced by the US secretary of state,
Hillary Clinton, at the end of a three-day US-Pakistan summit in Washington
attended by senior military, diplomatic and political representatives of both
countries.

Clinton sought to appease the Pakistani government and public opinion bruised by
recent criticism from the US. "I want to say publicly what many of us have said
privately: the United States has no stronger partner when it comes to
counter-terrorism efforts against the extremists who threaten us both than
Pakistan," she said.

The Pakistani foreign minister, Shah Mehmood Qureshi, standing beside Clinton,
said: "There are still tongue-in-cheek comments, even in this capital, about
Pakistan's heart not really being in this fight," he said. "We do not know what
greater evidence to offer than the blood of our people. Madam secretary, we are
determined to win this fight."

US congressional approval is likely to be forthcoming, but sceptical members
will raise awkward questions, especially after reports last year that earlier
military aid to Pakistan had gone missing or was diverted from counter-terrorism
to bolstering defences against India.

Congress has also expressed concerns about human rights abuses by the Pakistani
military, in particular over its offensive in the Swat valley last year. Under
US law, the Obama administration is planning to withhold military aid going to
any units involved in alleged human rights abuses.

"If there is going to be progress against al-Qaida, we need the support of the
Pakistani army," the Democratic senator, Patrick Leahy, said yesterday.

"But there is a lot of concern with extrajudicial killings by the army that
remain unpunished, and this will be a factor when we consider a request for more
aid. Respect for our law and the laws of war is fundamental."

The military aid comes on top of $7.5bn in civilian assistance already promised
for the next five years.

The US hopes that Pakistani military offensives against Taliban and al-Qaida
bases along the Afghanistan border will help reduce violence in Afghanistan. But
the aid is also aimed at stabilising Pakistan at a time when Washington is
fearful of the country, and its nuclear weapons, falling into the hands of
Islamist extremists.

LOAD-DATE: October 23, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2010 Guardian Newspapers Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political

                            October 25, 2010 Monday

Pakistan: Intelligence report says many shrines at risk of terror attacks

LENGTH: 251 words


Text of report by Asad Kharal headlined "Shrines at risk of terrorist attacks"
published by Pakistani newspaper Daily Times website on 25 October

Lahore: Only 58, out of a total 319 shrines (darbars) across the province, have
security arrangements, that too inadequate, revealed a survey report prepared by
a provincial intelligence agency. The remaining 261 shrines have no security at
all and are at risk of terrorist attacks, it said. The Punjab Home Department
had directed a provincial intelligence agency to conduct a secret survey of all
shrines in the province after series of attacks on shrines in Lahore and
Karachi. Sources told Daily Times that the purpose of this exercise was to
prepare a strategy and ensure foolproof arrangements at shrines to avert any
untoward incident in the future. According to the report, 22 shrines are
situated in Lahore region, 15 in Gujranwala, 22 in Sheikhupura, 85 in
Rawalpindi, 25 in Multan, 30 in Bahawalpur, 33 in Sargodha while 21 shrines are
located in Dera Ghazi Khan region. The survey officials found no security
arrangements at 261 shrines, but the security at 58 others was also not
satisfactory. Through a circular, the home department has directed the inspector
general of Punjab Police, all divisional commissioners, regional police
officers, city police officers and district police officers to personally visit
shrines and ensure preventive measures to foil nefarious designs of terrorists.

Source: Daily Times website, Lahore, in English 25 Oct 10

                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            October 25, 2010 Monday

Algerian police chief says "safe" from terrorist attacks

LENGTH: 429 words


Text of report by Fateh Agoune headlined: "Algiers Is Safe from the Terrorist
Threat, According to the Director General for National Security," published by
Algerian electronic daily Tout sur l'Algerie website on 24 October

On Sunday, 24 October, Major General Abdelghani Hamel, the Director General of
National Security [DGSN], indicated that Algiers was safe from terrorist
attacks. He said he thought the potential for a new attack by the armed groups
in the capital city was "very low."

Major General Hamel, who was speaking at his first press conference since
assuming office this past 7 July, defended the increase in the number of the
road blocks and the check points by the security agencies in and around Algiers.
"These roadblocks have been studied. Some are part of the mechanism for fighting
terrorism, others are designed to fight the drug trafficking," he explained.
These roadblocks, which create traffic jams, particularly at the eastern entry
into the capital city, have been decried by motorists.

Mr Hamel indicated that the country's security coverage had now hit 70 per cent.
The DGNS also mentioned the national police's internal situation. He announced
that the managers in that institution should have university degrees. "I do not
want middle and primary levels," he said. The major general also wants to lower
the age of police management staffing. "A commissioner's age should not exceed
50 and that of the principal commissioner should not exceed 52," he added during
this meeting with the press, which was held at the Graduate Police School in
Algiers.

Mr Hamel added that 23 police officials have been promoted to the rank of chief
of province security, eight security chiefs had been transferred to other
provinces, and the other 17 kept in their posts. The major general ruled out
creating a special commission to punish police managers who had been prosecuted
within the justice system. "We already have a disciplinary commission," Mr Hamel
said, who told of his opposition to the establishment of a police union in the
immediate future.

Last, Major General Hamel denied having issued a massive appeal to National
Gendarmerie managers to occupy posts in the police. "I appealed to two
Gendarmerie non-commissioned officers [NCOs]. That was all," he added.

Major General Hamel, 55, officially assumed his duties this past 7 July. He
replaced Colonel Ali Tounsi, who was assassinated this past 25 February in his
office. A Tlemcen native, Major General Hamel had been chief of the Republican
Guard.

Source: Tout sur l'Algerie website, in French 24 Oct 10

LENGTH: 130 words


Excerpt from report in English by Russian state news agency ITAR-TASS

Moscow, 25 October: The terrorist attack committed by militants at the
Baksanskaya hydroelectric power plant in Kabarda-Balkaria has been solved,
Deputy Russian Prosecutor-General for the North Caucasus and Southern Federal
Districts Ivan Sydoruk said on Monday [25 October] at an extended meeting of the
Russian Federation Council Committee on Legal and Judicial Issues.

"The terrorist attack at the Baksanskaya hydroelectric power plant was solved
last week," he said. "Two attackers were killed, two were detained and are
actively giving evidence. Another two have been put on the wanted list," he
added.

                            October 26, 2010 Tuesday

Pakistan paper flays government's "dismal failure" to prevent terror attacks

LENGTH: 233 words


Text of editorial headlined "Shattered peace" published by Pakistani newspaper
The News website on 26 October

Another shrine has been struck - this time in the city of Pakpattan. The target
this time was the mausoleum of Baba Farid, which stands as one of the most
significant Sufi places of worship and devotion in the country. By detonating a
bomb placed, according to official reports, in a milk container, the extremists
have demonstrated their desire to drive people away from shrines. People are to
be denied even the comfort of seeking solace in prayer or merely benefitting
from the sense of peace many say they feel when present at these shrines -
temporarily detached from the many sorrows that fill their lives.

Six have died in the latest attack, more than twice that number is injured. The
blast ripping through the quiet dawn air has also caused a deep sense of trauma.
Its effects were visible on the panic-filled faces of those gathered at the
shrine. But with panic, there is also growing anger. People ask why those behind
the blasts have not been apprehended, why there has been only limited movement
in this respect and who stands accountable for the dismal failure of our police
and other units which back them to go after the terrorists and, by doing so,
give the people back some of the peace they have so tragically lost.

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 26 Oct 10

                               Belfast Telegraph

                            October 26, 2010 Tuesday
                                  City Edition

Police train to fight terror attacks

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 162 words


Police are being given more powerful guns and extra training to prepare for a
possible Mumbai-style terror attack in the UK, it was reported today.

Security chiefs are staging a series of counter-terrorism exercises with police
sharpshooters training alongside units of the elite SAS under the plans, the BBC
said.

The development follows the interception last month by British intelligence
officials of a credible al Qaida-linked plot.

That would have reportedly been similar to the deadly commando-style raids in
Mumbai, India, two years ago, which left 166 people dead and several hundred
injured after attacks by Islamic militants.

Cities in France and Germany were also targeted as part of the plot.

Ex-security minister Lord West told the BBC that police officers needed to be
properly trained to deal with similar terror attacks.

The UK's terror threat rating remains at "severe", the second highest rating,
where it has been since increasing from "substantial" in January.

Police  get SAS training for terror attacks

BYLINE: NO BYLINE

SECTION: UKP; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 208 words


Police are being given more powerful guns and extra training to prepare for a
possible Mumbai-style terror attack, it has been reported.

UK security chiefs  are staging a series  of counter-terrorism exercises with
police sharpshooters training alongside units of the elite SAS under the plans,
the BBC said.

The development follows the interception last month by British intelligence
officials of a credible al Qaida-linked plot.

That would have reportedly been similar to the deadl raids in India two years
ago, which left 166 people dead and  hundreds more injured.

Cities in France and Germany were also targeted as part of the plot.

Former security minister Lord West told the BBC police needed to be properly
trained to deal with similar attacks.

He said:  These people like the Mumbai terrorists, are a bit like soldiers, they
do fire and support, move forward, all they want to do is kill as many people as
possible, with heavier weapons than our police.

Therefore you have to give heavy weapons to the police and train them how to do
it.

There is no way, except at immense cost, you could have SAS-level troops in
every part of the country to be able to respond in the timescale you d need. The
police are there and have to do that first response.

POLICE GIVEN BETTER GUNS;
Officers train for terror attacks

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 249 words


POLICE are being given more powerful guns and extra training to prepare for a
possible Mumbai-style terror attack in the UK, it was reported today.

Security chiefs are staging a series of counter-terrorism exercises with police
sharpshooters training alongside units of the elite SAS under the plans,
according to reports.

The development follows the interception last month by British intelligence
officials of a credible al Qaida-linked plot.

That would have reportedly been similar to the deadly commando-style raids in
Mumbai, India, two years ago, which left 166 people dead and several hundred
injured.

Cities in France and Germany were also targeted as part of the plot.

Former security minister Lord West said police officers needed to be properly
trained to deal with similar terror attacks.

He said: ''These people like the Mumbai terrorists are a bit like soldiers, they
do fire and support, move forward, all they want to do is kill as many people as
possible, with slightly heavier weapons than our police have.

''And therefore you have to give heavy weapons to the police and train them how
to do it.

''There is no way, except at immense cost, you could have SAS-level trained
troops in every part of the country to be able to respond in the timescale you'd
need. The police are there and have to do that first response.'' The UK's terror
threat rating remains at ''severe'' -the second highest rating -where it has
been since increasing from ''substantial'' in January.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Cops ready for terror attacks

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 101 words


POLICE are to be armed with superguns and given SAS training to help them
prepare for a potential Mumbai-style terror attack on home soil, it has been
revealed.

Security bosses want Britain to be prepared for large scale attacks like the
killing spree in India two years ago.

They plan to make bigger guns available to more officers as well as using
training techniques usually reserved for elite forces like the SAS.

Paul Davis, of the Police Federation, said the plans would mean the wider use of
"super" weapons.

He said: "It is in our interests to make sure our officers have the best
training and equipment."

                            East Anglian Daily Times

                           October 27, 2010 Wednesday

Terrorist attack advice for firms

BYLINE: Sarah Chambers

SECTION: BIZZ

LENGTH: 435 words


A COUNTER terrorism security adviser will be showing managers what they can do
to protect organisations, staff and members of the public from an attack when he
addresses a talk next week. Douglas Paine, the adviser for Suffolk, will be
explaining the nature of the terrorist threat at a Chartered Management
Institute (CMI) event at the Astral Centre, St Peter's Street, Lowestoft, at
6.30pm on Monday, November 1. Those attending will learn about Project ARGUS, a
National Counter Terrorism Security Office initiative which explores ways to
help businesses in preventing, preparing for, handling or recovering from a
terrorist attack. Entry is free to CMI members and non-members. To book a place,
contact Tony Tibbenham at ttibbenham@ssdm.co.uk or phone 01502 527009. East
Anglian firms are being urged to prepare for the VAT rate increase on January 4.
Business adviser Grant Thornton said firms should make ready for the rise, from
17.5% to 20%, which will affect any business that sells or purchases goods or
services and are subject to the standard rate.

"The VAT rate increase means potential accounting and record-keeping
difficulties for businesses," said Grant Thornton's VAT director for the region,
Anne Holt. "It is more important than ever to ensure you have the correct
systems and procedures in place before the New Year. Businesses failing to take
due care in establishing appropriate systems and procedures could suffer from a
reduction in profits or even penalties." East Anglian chartered accountancy firm
Ensors has joined CPA Associates International (CPAAI), a worldwide association
of independent accounting and business consulting firms. Ensors managing partner
Danny Clifford said: "We are delighted to have joined CPA Associates
International and be able to offer our clients in the UK access to worldwide
expertise and advice. As the world gets smaller and advances in technology
encourage businesses to expand their cross-border activities, it is essential to
be on hand with up-to-date, quality advice to support clients." Builders'
merchant Kent Blaxill urged the Coalition Government to support a plan to
renovate and insulate existing homes as Colchester LibDem MP Bob Russell paid
the firm a visit on Friday. The Builders' Merchants Federation's (BMF) Plan B,
drawn up before last week's public spending announcement, was explained to Mr
Russell by the firm's managing director Simon Blaxill, who outlined how the firm
was coping with the downturn and by BMF policy manager Brett Amphlett. Mr
Amphlett said: "Construction equals real, purposeful jobs and enduring economic
growth."

                              Gloucestershire Echo

                           October 27, 2010 Wednesday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

County police training for Mumbai-style terror attack

BYLINE: NADIA STONE

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 379 words


POLICE in Gloucestershire will be given SAS-style training to prepare for a
potential terrorist attack.

Former security minister Lord Alan West says officers need to be trained to deal
with terror attacks similar to one in Mumbai two years ago - and Gloucestershire
police say the county is a prime target because it houses the Government's GCHQ
intelligence headquarters.

Derek Jones, chief inspector of operations at Gloucestershire police, said: "Our
officers will be updating their skills in line with developments nationally and
internationally. "The police service has a good track record for gathering
intelligence in order to prevent incidents from occurring and are much better
placed than ever before with dedicated counter terrorism units based in each
region.

"Officers across the country continue to train so that they are able to deal
with such eventualities, should they arise.

"As with all operational issues we are always looking at ways of improving our
response and the police service is working in partnership with other agencies to
enhance our capacity and capabilities."

Councillor Rob Garnham, chairman of Gloucestershire Police Authority, said he
welcomed any move that could help prepare the county for an attack.

He said: "Terrorist incidents are extremely rare, but we must ensure that when
they do occur we are fully capable of dealing with these incidents. We don't
know what might happen in the future and training to enhance the capability of
our officers is to be welcomed."

Gloucestershire defence expert Air Vice Marshall Tony Mason said he was aware,
from personal experience, of the importance of intelligence and the need to have
forces in readiness to respond to possible terrorist attacks.

He said he suspected that Government agencies, such as Cheltenham-based GCHQ,
would already be well prepared.

Instead, he felt security officials would be considering how to protect softer
targets in Gloucestershire.

He said: "Mumbai was an attack against the general public.

Therefore, in this county, of particular concern would be major events where
there are large numbers of people."

Earlier this month workers at GCHQ helped foil a UK terror attack.

Terrorists plotting the attack were identified when GCHQ matched their voices
against a secret database.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: GLE

Algeria's "terrorists" film "made-up attacks" - paper

LENGTH: 312 words


Text of report by Sounia Q, headlined "Terrorists carry out made-up attacks;
they film them to satisfy the emirs" published by privately-owned Algerian
newspaper Echourouk El Youmi website on 28 October

Echourouk learnt from well-informed sources that a repentant terrorist who
recently surrendered to the authorities in Sidi Ali Bounab revealed many false
truths about the Salafi Group in the Kabylie region.

This group tries to use all the deceptive methods to delude the public opinion
into believing that they are still strong. This comes despite the fact that only
the extremist members of this group survived, because they are strongly attached
to emir Abdelmalek Droudkal, who is known as Mousab Abdelouadoud.

The repentant said in an interesting statement that terrorists working in
"Ennour brigade" had faked their control over an area by filming imaginary
murders and editing the material professionally. Then they send the material to
the emirs to delude them into believing that they are carrying out criminal
attacks against the citizens and the security forces. This happens in order to
obtain the satisfaction of the emirs, and especially the financial award in
return for their attacks.

The repentant terrorist confessed that three terrorists were liquidated last
August after they were tortured, because they refused to appear in one of the
videos that were about to be sent to the group officials. They did this for fear
of the exposure of their psychological defeat and that they are not carrying out
any armed acts.

On the other hand, Echourouk learned that the army search operation in Sidi Ali
Bounab forests - between Tizi Ouzou and Boumerdes provinces - are still ongoing
for the sixth consecutive day. The joint forces are in control of the area,
where around 40 terrorists are besieged.

                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political

                           October 28, 2010 Thursday

Russian chief investigator notes sharp rise in terrorist attacks in 2010

LENGTH: 147 words


Text of report by Russian state news agency RIA Novosti

Moscow, 28 October: The number of terrorist acts in Russia in January-September
this year was more than double that in the same period last year, Investigations
Committee Head Aleksandr Bastrykin said at an open meeting of the committee's
board on Thursday [28 October].

"For several years now, the number of registered crimes in Russia has been going
down. At the same time we are worried by the high share of grave and gravest
crimes: they account for over one quarter of the overall number of crimes (27
per cent)," Bastrykin said.

Thus, he said, the number of terrorist acts increased by 150 per cent in the
past nine months compared with the same period last year (from 11 to 27).

"The number of extremist crimes rose by 19 per cent," the committee head noted.

Source: RIA Novosti news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0926 gmt 28 Oct 10

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

US 'failure' in terrorist attack

India accused the United States yesterday of failing to warn it about the
terrorist connections of a key figure in the 2008 Mumbai attacks.

It believes David Headley, who has admitted carrying out reconnaissance missions
for the attacks, could have been arrested had the United States passed on two
warnings they received from his two wives.

"We were disappointed that the name of David Headley was not provided," said GK
Pillai, the home secretary.

Had the information been shared, India could have "nabbed him", he added.

Text of report in English by Turkish semi-official news agency Anatolia

Ankara, 31 October: The Turkish ministry of foreign affairs condemned Saturday
[30 October] the recent terrorist attack waged in Iraq's Diyala province.

problems Iraqis faced in the political process leading to a national consensus
in the country.

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            October 31, 2010 Sunday

Turkey: Istanbul governor says suicide blast appears to be terrorist attack

LENGTH: 301 words


Text of report in English by Turkish semi-official news agency Anatolia

Istanbul, 31 October: Istanbul Governor Huseyin Avni Mutlu said about Sunday [31
October] morning's explosion in the central Taksim Square, "it appears to be a
terror act" Mutlu told reporters, "I strongly condemn those who are responsible
for this heinous act. A male bomber detonated the explosive close to a spot in
Taksim square where riot police were stationed. Twelve people including ten
police officers were injured. None of them are in life-threatening condition.
Four of them are hospitalized."

He said that no one claimed responsibility for the attack yet.

Taksim Square takes place at the heart of Turkey's biggest city Istanbul and it
is a major tourist attraction and transport hub, surrounded by restaurants,
shops and hotels

A number of avenues and streets around Istanbul's central Taksim Square have
been closed to traffic after Sunday morning's explosion.

Police cordoned off the scene of the attack and took tight measures after a
suspected suicide bomber detonated a device, injuring 22 people including 10
police officers. The attack caused major damage in a police bus stationed in the
square.

The blast also shattered windows of nearby buildings and vehicles.

The body, believed to be that of the suicide bomber, was still lying near the
site of the explosion, covered over with newspapers.

It was the third suicide bombing targeting police officers in Taksim Square in
the last eleven years.

On March 27, 1999, a suicide bomber blew himself up in the square injuring ten
people including three police officers.

The second attack occurred on September 10, 2001. Two policemen were killed
while 20 people including 13 policemen and 7 civilians were injured.

Source: Anatolia news agency, Ankara, in English 1051 gmt 31 Oct 10

LOAD-DATE: October 31, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                                  Sunday Life

                                October 31, 2010
                                  Main Edition

TERRORIST ATTACK ON PLANE ...

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 266 words


TERRORIST ATTACK ON PLANE

THE target for a bomb found on a cargo plane in England may have been the
aircraft itself, Home Secretary Theresa May said today.

Speaking after a Cobra meeting, the UK Government's emergency planning committee
to discuss the security situation, Ms May told reporters the device found on a
cargo plane at East Midlands Airport could have blown the airliner out of the
sky.

She said: "The target may have been an aircraft and had it detonated the
aircraft could have been brought down.

"I can confirm that the device was viable and could have exploded.

"We do not believe that the perpetrators of the attack would have known the
location of the device when it was planned to explode.

"Our investigation remains sensitive. We are working closely with international
partners to increase our understanding of this case and of course to bring those
responsible to justice.

"At this stage there is no information to indicate another attack is imminent."

The Home Secretary said the threat level was at "severe", meaning a terrorist
attack in the UK is "highly likely" and there was no plan to change the level at
this stage.

But she said: "We must take further precautionary measures. I have agreed with
the Transport Secretary (Philip Hammond) that we will take immediate action to
stop the movement of all unaccompanied air freight originating from Yemen into
or through the UK.

"Direct cargo and passenger flights from the Yemen were suspended in January
this year for security reasons following an earlier attempt to bomb an aircraft
destined for Detroit."

CAPTION: VIGILANT: Theresa May

Obama commemorates 2008 Mumbai terror attacks at Taj Hotel on first day of Asia

India: U.S. President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama begin 8-day
trip to Asia with a four-day visit to India beginning in Mumbai, where he
delivers a speech at the restored Taj Mahal Palace hotel to commemorate the 31
people who died during the Nov 2008 terrorist attacks on the city. His entourage

opportunities of doing business in India, and then delivers a centerpiece speech
to delegates. U.S. Secretary of Commerce Gary Locke also participates.
 President Obama will travel on to Jakarta in Indonesia on 9 Nov, then to Seoul

October 31, 2010

Washington, DC --The United States condemns today's terrorist attack in
