                            November 15, 2010 Monday

Pakistan TV show discusses Karachi terror attack, tax reforms

LENGTH: 879 words


Karachi Geo News television in Urdu at 1700 gmt on 12 November relays live
regularly scheduled "Today With Kamran Khan" programme. Noted Pakistani
journalist Kamran Khan reviews, discusses, and analyzes major day-to-day
developments with government ministers and officials, opposition leaders, and
prominent analysts in Geo TV's flagship programme. Words within double slant
lines are in English

Programme: "Today With Kamran Khan"

Reception: Good

Duration: 60 minutes

Segment I

Khan begins the programme by saying that the TTP [Tehrik-i-Taleban Pakistan] has
claimed the responsibility for the attack on the CID [Criminal Investigation
Department] building, Karachi; although police hold the Lashkar-i-Jhangvi [LJ]
responsible. Khan says: "The LJ, Al-Qa'idah, and the TTP are working together
along with other banned extremist organizations of Pakistan." Khan says that the
TTP has threatened to attack President Asif Ali Zardari. Khan says that 17
persons lost their lives to 11 November attack in Karachi. Khan says that
according to police, 500-kg of explosive material was used in the attack.

Khan plays a video report on 11 November attack. The report says that according
to the FIA [Federal Investigation Agency] personnel, the attack on CID building
was almost of the same intensity as Marriot, Islamabad. The CID, Sindh was
created to control sectarian violence and terrorism in 2002. The report says:
"This attack is speculated to have carried out by the LJ whose intention was to
free six of its members from CID police's custody." The six terrorists from the
LJ were arrested by the anti-terrorist wing of CID.

Khan establishes video link with Geo News correspondent Afzal Nadeem Dogar and
asks him to update about the findings of initial investigation. Dogar says that,
although investigation is underway, the police are not in a position to name any
organization clearly. Dogar says that police cannot collect evidence through
CCTV [close circuit television] cameras since the building got collapsed by the
explosion, and the entire camera system as well. Dogar says that according to
eye witnesses, "the number of terrorists was 10"

Segment II

Khan says that the government has decided to impose the RGST [Reformed General
Sales Tax] on disgruntled poor Pakistanis. Khan says that these taxes are to be
paid by those who are already paying taxes and tax defaulters are not being
heaved into the tax net. Khan says that rich and powerful land lords are out of
the tax net. Khan says that the government presented the RGST bill in parliament
on 12 November. Khan says that all political parties are offering stiff
resistance to the government's plan to get the RGST endorsed by parliament. Khan
says: "Apparently, the government will have to surrender before the majority of
parliament." Khan quotes Nawaz Sharif, chief of the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz
[PML-N], as saying that his party will never allow the RGST bill to be endorsed
by parliament. Khan says that the JI [Jamaat-i-Islami], JUI-F [Jamiat
Ulema-i-Islam-Fazlur Rehman], ANP [Awami National Party], PML-Q [Pakistan Muslim
League-Qaid-i -Azam], and the MQM [Muttahida Qaumi Movement] have also rejected
the idea of the RGST and FT [Flood Tax] on poor people. Khan quotes Prime
Minister Yusuf Raza Gillani as claiming that Punjab Chief Minister Shahbaz
Sharif was in favour of the RGST and totally on board the decision.

Khan establishes telephone link with Shahbaz Sharif and asks him to clear his
position in this regard. Shahbaz Sharif says: "The original idea of the federal
government was to impose VAT [Value added tax], which his party has never been
in favour of." Sharif says that the idea of the RGST was created in lieu of VAT.
Sharif says that instead of imposing the RGST; the government should control
//mismanagement// and corruption, and improve governance. Shahbaz Sharif says
that the RGST is being imposed to fulfil the IMF's conditions. Shahbaz Sharif
says that in addition to the RGST, the government has increased the price of
oil. Sharif says that the government's extravagant lifestyle and corruption
leave no moral ground for the RGST. Shahbaz Sharif says: "The RGST is not
acceptable to the PML-N in the given circumstances."

Khan says that the government is not interested in taking measures for curbing
of corruption. Khan says: "The public sector corporations inflict a total loss
of 500bn rupees on the economy every year."

Segment III

Khan says that the NIC [National Insurance Corporation] has suffered a loss of
10bn because of its Managing Director Muhammad Ayyaz Niazi who used to be a
manager of a night club in Dubai before taking charge of the NIC. Khan says that
similarly, chairman of the NHA [National Highway Authority] was in prison on
charges of corruption.

Khan establishes a video link with Senator Haroon Akhtar and asks him to comment
on unmerited appointments. Akhtar says that the Supreme Court has taken notice
of all four major real estate deals that revolve around these two corrupt
persons. Akhtar says that the FIA investigation is underway and one out of four
cases has been completed. Akhtar says that Niazi and company made 65m dollars
unlawfully through four real estate deals. Khan concludes the programme.

Source: Geo TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1700gmt 12 Nov 10

LOAD-DATE: November 15, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2010 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved

                              230 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            November 15, 2010 Monday

Pakistan analyst sees Al-Qa'idah role in Karachi terror attack

LENGTH: 800 words


Text of report by Cyril Almeida headlined "New strands of militancy descend on
Karachi" published by Pakistani newspaper Dawn website on 14 November

Interior Minister Rehman Malik's claim the Lashkar-i-Jhangvi (LJ) is responsible
for the fidayeen-cum-suicide attack on the CID [Central Investigation
Department] centre in Karachi has been met with scepticism by analysts and
officials.

"Malik's statement is neither here nor there because LJ, like TTP, has become a
generic name for urban terrorist groups," according to a senior security
analyst.

Since the death of Riaz Basra in a police encounter and the arrest of his
second-in-command, Akram Lahori, in the early 2000s, the LJ is known to have
split into several factions.

According to Amir Rana, director of the Pakistan Institute for Peace Studies, a
think tank which tracks militancy, there are at least six factions of LJ: "Some
are directed against sectarian targets, others against the state and yet others
have an 'internationalist' focus."

"Some of these groups have come up with their own names, but many haven't and
they get put under the LJ label," Rana added.

Another analyst claimed: "There are at least three known factions (of LJ). Some
say perhaps five groups. The reasons for splits range from financial disputes
over money looted from banks to personality clash and ideological conflict.

"Basra, and to some extent Akram Lahori, raised LJ purely on anti-Shia lines.
Their only difference with SSP (the parent organisation of LJ) was they thought
Sipah-i-Sahaba had become soft on the anti-Shi'i issue after going into
mainstream politics."

The main suspect in Thursday's attack is one Qari Abid, believed to be the head
of the Lashkar-i-Jhangvi Al Alami. The 'Al Alami' nomenclature is usually
associated with Al Qaeda.

"The Marriott bombing (in Islamabad) was similar to what happened in Karachi,"
according to Amir Rana, "and so that has instantly raised the possibility of a
Qari Abid-Al Qaeda connection."

Added another official, "Qari Abid's faction is part of the bigger TTP
conglomerate, and he is believed to be hiding in South Waziristan, although some
officials believe he has been to Karachi a number of times.

"(Abid) or members of his group are the prime suspects as, despite having a
strong anti-Shia bias, they concentrate more on security-related targets."

But, as with all things in the world of militancy, little can be said with
certainty. Another suspect in the Karachi attack is Malik Tassaduq, member of
what was once known as the Harkatul Mujahideen Al Alami and a former associate
of Ramzi Yusuf.

According to an official, "The Harkat has either merged with the TTP or is using
its name to carry out attacks against the security establishment."

There is also a third major suspect: Attaur Rehman aka Qari Rehman aka Naeem
Bokhari. Arrested several years ago in connection with the killings of Shias,
Rehman was released on bail after the prosecution's case faltered.

"Though some argue he has found refuge in South Waziristan, others believe he is
in Karachi these days and that his men are behind some of the recent attacks on
Shias and even the shrine of Abdullah Shah Ghazi," a security analyst claimed.

Given these complexities, long-time analysts of militancy in Pakistan are
dismissive of Rehman Malik's suggestion a monolith 'Lashkar-i-Jhangvi' was the
most likely culprit in the latest Karachi attack.

"All these groups use different names for their propaganda campaigns. Depending
on the kind of action, or political need, they can identify themselves as TTP,
LJ, Punjabi Taliban, etc," an analyst claimed.

The one commonality is sanctuary in Fata: "Although there are serious
differences on how this battle against those perceived to be 'heretics' or US
agents or un-Islamic is be fought, the TTP leadership has provided all of them
refuge in the tribal areas," a senior Karachi-based editor claimed.

"It's a loose conglomerate of anti-US, anti-army, anti-Shia, and
anti-Barelvi/Sufi Muslims, as the main leadership of the TTP believes all these
elem ents service each other's needs."

For Karachi, which like the rest of the country will soon be preparing for
Muharram, most worrying is the crossover in the aims and intentions of the
various militant groups.

An official said: "Until recently the authorities were of the view that only the
anti-Shia group was active in Karachi, and was also targeting soft Sunni-Sufi
shrines or Barelvi leaders.

"But with the CID attack, the fear is that the other, rival, 'LJ' faction has
descended on Karachi. This other group not only wants to target vulnerable
police/paramilitary installations, but also to prove to their rivals that they
have roots in Karachi and are capable of playing havoc in the city."

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 14 Nov 10

LOAD-DATE: November 15, 2010

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            November 15, 2010 Monday

Pakistan writer says continuing terror attacks anti-Islamic in nature

LENGTH: 1147 words


Text of article by A. R. Jerral headlined "Is Islam being maligned?" published
by Pakistani newspaper The Nation website on 14 November

Someone transmitted a pertinent question on cell phones: "Why do the Talebans
target mosques, places of worship, shrines and religious processions and not
cinemas, clubs and other places of pleasure?" Is there a deliberate move to
tarnish the image of Islam? Viewed in the perspective of contemporary events one
tends to become suspicious of the philosophy upheld and propagated by these
militants; they are acting in a manner that raises many doubts. They appear to
be following an anti-Islam agenda.

Islam, as a religious ideology, advocates strict respect and safety of life and
property. Even in the time of war it prohibits killing of unarmed civilians,
children, women and the old. These people, who target the civilian gatherings,
show total disregard of these principles of Islam, yet they claim to fight for
it. By killing innocent people, they hardly serve the cause of Islam. I recall a
documentary prepared by BBC, which traced the rise of Muslim militancy in North
African Muslin nations. One scene in it has remained embedded in my memory - a
man carrying the dead body of child killed in a bomb attack claimed by Ikwan
militants in Tunisia asks bluntly: "Is this Islam?"

The message is loud and clear; such bombings and killings create hatred for
those who cause such miseries. Islam is not an extremist ideology; it preaches
balance and justice. Even waging war is guided by strict rules of restraint. The
face of Islam projected by these so-called exponents of the faith is a gross
distortion. Irony is that some of our Islamic scholars neither show courage to
condemn them, nor make the effort to preach the true ideology of Islam. Islam
believes in a strong, legal and central political system where all affairs of
the state are exercised by a legal authority. It does not permit a parallel
authority. The way punishments and reprisals were meted out in Swat and
elsewhere by these so-called Islamists have no justification in Islam; these are
state functions.

People, who have endured their excesses, tell harrowing tales of atrocities
committed. One wonders whether it is a deliberate scheme to veer people away
from the Islamic system. In this era, there is a constant struggle between two
parallel and opposing ideologies -secularism and Islam. Secularism is being
projected as the culmination of man's social, economic and political progress.
It makes religion man's personal affair with no or very little influence on his
worldly activities in all fields of life. It sets man free of any personal
accountability as long it relates to social conduct. It is a soft and easy-going
image of life. Islam, on the contrary, demands a strict code of social conduct
where wrongs and rights are strictly defined. However, there is a conscious
effort in place to project Islam as a backward and repressive system competing
with secularism. And the best way it can be done is by bringing operatives on
centrestage, who depicts Islam as a rigid and harsh ideology. These 'extremists'
penetrate in the legitimate Islamic movements and then act in a cruel and
callous manner.

Ikhwan-ul-Muslimeen of Egypt under Syed Qutb was a legitimate politico-social
movement seeking political change on the basis of Islamic principles. True that
the ruling elite of Egypt was opposed to it and dealt with the movement harshly.
Syed Qutb was executed on cooked-up anti-state charges, yet the Ikwans acted and
conducted themselves within bounds. Despite the government's strict opposition,
the popularity and membership grew. Then the movement was penetrated by elements
that preached and adopted violence from its platform. The face of Islam
projected by this 'extremist' element had the desired effect; the movement
suffered in popularity and is almost non-functional now. Islam, the religion of
peace and accommodation, suffered.

The dilemma facing Muslims all over the world is that we individually and
collectively are ignorant of the true teachings of Islam. We have let it become
the domain of a specific group, who are taken as authority to interpret it.
Majority recite the Holy Book as a ritual for blessings only. Our understanding
of what is written is at best rudimentary with emphasis on visible rituals.
Thus, the majority follows what the so-called clergy teaches and advocates. The
masses are divided in sects, cults and groups, who are rigid in beliefs and
conducts. This ignorance makes the task of extremists easy. All they need to do
is adopt an outward Islamic look and garb, do visible rituals and preach
violence - for establishment of an Islamic order. A cursory look at what has
happened in Pakistan in the past confirms this observation.

Pakistan has had a fair share of such element. We had our Mullahs like
Fazalullahs of Swat, the Mehsud Talibans and now the Pakistani Talibans; all
claiming to be the pious Muslims struggling for an Islamic society and
politico-social order. Yet, they proudly claim responsibility for the slaughter
of worshipers at the mosques. They murdered eminent religious scholars and
claimed responsibility without any regret or remorse. Even if attacks on police
posts and security installations will be regarded as acts of legitimate
retaliation, attacking places of worship and shrines; and killing innocent women
and children cannot be accepted or condoned as acts in service of Islam.

The Muslim society as a whole has become a target for subjugation. The
approaches adopted against it are multifaceted; direct military attacks as
witnessed on Iraq and Afghanistan are one dimension of this onslaught. The
perpetrators of this new 'crusade' against Islam are intelligent and wise. They
know that military victories can be overturned and are not permanent. Changing
and subverting ideology is lasting and permanent. Islam provides the motive
force and an ideology for the establishment of a society-based social justice,
distribution of wealth, equality and accountability for actions and deeds. This
is opposed to a social order where wealth is accumulated in a few hands that
wield power, can manipulate justice and are answerable to rules made by them.
One example of this inequality is the veto power that the mighty hold in the
world body - the UN which claims to be the guardian of peace and justice. These
so-called Muslim extremists are the field operatives of this modern day crusader
deployed to malign Islam and what it stands for. The question narrated in the
beginning of this write-up is pertinent and needs a comprehensive answer. Our
religious scholars must project Islam in its true spirit in thought, deeds and
actions. If we cannot do that its fate will not be different that of the
Christian faith as it stands today.

Source: The Nation website, Islamabad, in English 14 Nov 10

LOAD-DATE: November 15, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                              All Rights Reserved

                              232 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          Press Association Mediapoint

                      November 15, 2010 Monday 7:02 PM BST

FREEZING ASSETS OF TERRORISTS 'STOPS ATTACKS EARLY'

BYLINE: David Hughes and Ben Padley, Press Association Political Staff

SECTION: PARLIAMENTARY NEWS

LENGTH: 1298 words


Cutting off the supply of finance can stop terror attacks in their early stages,
a Treasury minister said tonight.

As legislation to freeze bank accounts linked to terrorists reached the Commons,
Financial Secretary Mark Hoban said relatively small sums were needed for acts
such as the July 7 attacks or the foiled air cargo bomb plot.

The legislation to make the UK's regime for freezing the assets of terrorist
suspects more permanent has already cleared the House of Lords.

With the terror threat rated as ``severe'', Mr Hoban said: ``Just a few weeks
ago intelligence agencies encountered another plot designed to cause death and
destruction to innocent people.

``Those involved in the air cargo bomb plot ... were well connected and part of
an international network of extremists.

``It would seem that the terrorist threat we face is developing. We see the
continued emergence of a more diverse and evolved terrorist threat.''

He added: ``Small networks or even individuals acting alone are able to use
technology to their advantage, giving them the ability to wreak havoc
potentially worse than their size might indicate.

``It is clear that those who wish to do us harm operate on an increasingly
global scale and are devising ever more sophisticated methods of avoiding
detection.

``This is why we must ensure that the tools we deploy to combat terrorism remain
effective.''

One of those tools was the asset-freezing regime which ``we can use to take
preventative action to disrupt suspected terrorists''.

Mr Hoban said: ``By cutting off access to finance and preventing money from
reaching terrorist networks, we can stop individual acts in their early stages.

``Currently, around £140,000 is frozen in the UK under our domestic terrorist
asset freezing regime.

``Whilst this may not seem a large amount ... it only takes a relatively modest
amount of money to carry out a deadly attack.

``The dreadful attacks of July 7, 2005 cost less than £10,000 to carry out while
the air cargo bomb plot is also likely to have cost a comparably small amount.''

The Terrorist Asset-Freezing etc Bill will introduce a new regime following the
Supreme Court's decision earlier this year that earlier powers were defective.

The court ruled that the previous regime, dating from 2006 and which was
separate from rules affecting al Qaida and the Taliban, was defective in that it
had been implemented by order of the Privy Council rather than parliamentary
legislation.

That defect was remedied by emergency legislation passed earlier this year, but
ministers pledged at the time to introduce a permanent regime.

Mr Hoban said the new Bill included ``significant safeguards'' governing the use
of the powers and the regime would be subjected to regular reviews.

Assets will only be allowed to be frozen for more than 30 days if there was a
``reasonable belief'' that the money would be used to fund terrorists instead of
the previous ``reasonable suspicion''.

Shadow Treasury minister David Hanson said Labour supported the ``aims and
objectives'' of the Bill.

But he said Parliament's Joint Committee on Human Rights had raised a number of
concerns about the Bill including ``the need for a higher standard of proof, for
transparency on the use of closed material and on the proposed reviewer to be
appointed by Parliament rather than the Government''.

The committee's recommendations ``don't necessarily have the support of the
Opposition'', Mr Hanson said, ``but I do think it is important that they are
considered''.

Tory Matthew Hancock (W Suffolk) said: ``Far from being rushed through, this
Bill is timely. Far from it being too soon, given that there is a review of it
going on at the moment, it is very important that we get this Bill through.''

He said he wanted to see what the extent of cross-party support was in regards
to proposed changes to the standard of proof.

``As somebody who has argued that the balance in this country between civil
liberties and protection against terrorism has in the past swung too far in
favour of autocracy and away from civil liberties, I am pleased to see the new
threshold over 30 days of reasonable belief rather than reasonable suspicion,''
he said.

Keith Vaz, Labour chairman of the Home Affairs Select Committee, warned of the
need to look carefully at the legislation and not act in haste.

He added: ``One of the problems that we have had in the past is that we have not
thought carefully enough about counter-terrorism legislation until some great
event occurs.''

Liberal Democrat Julian Huppert (Cambridge) said: ``Asset freezing is a very
strong power but a very necessary power, and because it is so strong, because it
can be so draconian, it must be fair and it must be properly applied. It must
only be applied to those who are actually involved in terrorist activities.''

David Simpson, the DUP's business spokesman, said those who finance terrorists
must face far more severe sentences from the courts.

He said: ``Think too of the kind of terrorist threat that resulted in the 7/7
London bombings and the desire to commit mass murder that some Islamic militant
groups express.

``Those who assist them economically, those who provide the economic and
financial muscle to allow them to obtain their arsenal of murder are complicit
in those murders. They aid and abet those murders.

``To set out a sentencing policy that sets a maximum, not a minimum, sentence of
seven years is wholly unsatisfactory. The tariff should be considerably
higher.''

Since the Government first introduced powers to freeze the assets of terrorists,
£290,000 from 205 different accounts had been cut off, the Commons was told.

Of the 24 people currently subject to such measures, 21 had been charged or
convicted with terrorism offences, David Gauke, the Treasury Minister added.

Under the proposals, suspects who the Treasury ``reasonably believe'' to be
behind terrorist plots can be subject to such legislation.

This is lower than the ``balance of probabilities'' threshold but Mr Gauke said
it was necessary for the new law to successfully prevent terrorist attacks.

Mr Gauke said: ``Whilst a significant majority of those in the UK whose assets
have been frozen have been charged or convicted of a terrorist offence, limiting
freezing only to such people would have two significant drawbacks.

``First, it would prevent the Treasury from freezing assets in cases where it
reasonably believes that someone is involved in terrorism and where it considers
that asset-freezing is necessary to protect the public, but where that person
had not been or could not be charged. This would have a significant cost for
national security.

``Second, this would severely curtail the Treasury's ability to freeze the
assets of international terrorists or terrorist groups operating overseas.

``Many such persons and groups operate in countries where they will not be
prosecuted, perhaps because the country does not have the capability or the will
to prosecute terrorists.''

Mr Gauke added: ``The debate today has been about the balance between national
security and safeguarding civil liberties. I'm convinced that the Bill before
the House strikes the right balance between both.

``It is effective and fair, takes the necessary steps to prevent the raising and
use of funds for terrorist purposes, and sets the terrorist asset-freezing
regime in primary legislation for the first time.''

Kerry McCarthy, shadow Treasury minister, said Labour would support the Bill but
they wanted to be sure it wouldn't be struck down later because of some
perceived illegality.

She added: ``We do broadly support the principles and the intention behind this
Bill but we will be subjecting it to the best scrutiny next week in committee.''

The Bill was given an unopposed second reading and now moves to the detailed
committee stage.

LOAD-DATE: November 16, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                            Redhill And Reigate Life

                            November 15, 2010 Monday

Redhill students turn counter terrorist officers for simulated terror attack

SECTION: NEWS (NEWS)

LENGTH: 373 words


Students in Redhill are this week due to turn into counter terrorist officers
fighting to save the public from attack in a simulated terror incident.

The students at East Surrey College are set to act out the police's role in a
classroom exercise mimicking their on-the-spot decisions and coordinated
response in the event of a terrorist attack.

The two-hour workshop, called All Communities Together (ACT) Now, due to take
place tomorrow, is one of a number of similar exercises which are run across the
country throughout the year.

Their aim is to encourage communities to work together to fight terrorism.

The exercise will be led by counter terrorism officers from Surrey Police and
also the Reigate and Banstead Safer Neighbourhood Team.

Participating students will play the part of a counter terrorist unit in a
mythical town, fed limited intelligence regarding a possible plot, and asked to
make decisions based on that intelligence.

Eventually, when the attack occurs, the teams will have to decide who to arrest
and when, and assess the community impact of the incident and the police
response.

Bob Lamont, community engagement officer for Surrey Police, said: "The exercise
is aimed at any age, but young people seem to find it particularly enjoyable and
learn a lot from taking part."

He said: "It is designed to encourage open and honest debate about sensitive
issues and also highlight the work counter terrorist officers do, and illustrate
the challenges they face.

"ACT Now is not intended to scare people, it's designed to be fun and thought-
provoking, encouraging those who take part to work together."

He said: "I would like to thank East Surrey College for enabling this exercise
to take place and am looking forward to some lively discussions as the students
get to grips with the scenario as it develops."

Chris Long, director of communications at East Surrey College, said: "We are
delighted to be able to work with Surrey Police to offer our students this
exciting opportunity, reinforcing key messages that they are learning during
their Travel and Tourism, and Aviation courses. "Practical exercises such as
these are fantastic ways in which to learn."

The ACT Now workshops were initially devised by Lancashire Constabulary.

LOAD-DATE: November 15, 2010

                              234 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                            Manchester Evening News

                           November 16, 2010 Tuesday

Family's firebomb car attack terror

BYLINE: Lydia Warren

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 321 words


A FRIGHTENED mum has told how she fears her family is being targeted after their
car was wrecked in a firebomb attack.

Aafia and Shekh Malik woke at 3am to see fire outside their home in Wheler
Street, Openshaw.

They assumed it was fireworks but joined concerned neighbours in the street to
see their car engulfed in flames.

The windows of the four-year-old blue Honda Civic had been smashed and a petrol
bomb thrown inside.

They called police and the fire service, but their second car, a dark blue
Nissan Micra, caught light before they arrived.

No one was hurt, but the Honda was written off and four of the house's windows
also cracked in the heat.

The Maliks' children, three-year-old Muneeb and four-month-old Molib, were
asleep in the house at the time of the attack.

Their mother, Aafia, 30, said: We are in bad shock.

It's really distressing and I can't sleep in case it happens again. I'm looking
outside all the time.

I dread to think what could have happened if they'd thrown the firebomb inside
the house. We have two babies what could have happened to them?

Mr Malik, who works for Virgin Media, is unsure why his car was attacked, but
his wife believes it could have been racially motivated.

Mrs Malik, who moved here from Pakistan four years ago, said: We haven't got any
idea why we've been targeted, but we have heard Asian people have had problems
here before, so maybe it's that. We just hope the police catch whoever did this.

The cars were insured but not having them has really affected our lives.

My son goes to nursery ten miles away but I can't take him, and the prams were
in the back of the car and destroyed.

I can't walk far because I recently had a C-section with my second child, so
it's a struggle. It's really affected us.

Police, who said they are unaware of any racial motivation behind the attack,
removed the cars and inquiries are

ongoing.

Anyone with information is urged to contact police on 0161 872 5050.

                              235 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                    Scotsman

                           November 16, 2010 Tuesday

Houses of Parliament put plans in place to deal with terrorist attack

BYLINE: Gavin Cordon

LENGTH: 280 words



HIGHLIGHT: PARLIAMENTARY authorities have drawn up contingency plans to deal
with the threat of a Mumbai-style armed attack on the Palace of Westminster, it
was disclosed last night.


An e-mail circulated to all staff working in the House of Commons and the House
of Lords stresses that there is currently no "specific threat" to parliament,
but that measures were in place to respond if an attack did occur.

The e-mail from the senior Commons official responsible for security, the
Serjeant at Arms Jill Pay, and her counterpart in the Lords, the acting Black
Rod Ted Lloyd-Jukes, said the plan had been drawn up in conjunction with the
Metropolitan Police Service (MPS).

"An armed attack on parliament would result in casualties and significant
confusion," it states. "The latest MPS advice is that an effective contingency
plan should concentrate on evacuating members, staff and visitors away from
danger as quickly as possible.

"Locating, containing and neutralising the threat will be a role for armed
police officers."

In the event of an attack an urgent message will be broadcast ordering the
evacuation of the parliamentary estate, advising people to leave by the nearest
exit.

Some key groups, such as unarmed security staff, doorkeepers and attendants are
to be given special advice on how to lead groups of visitors from the estate and
away from danger.

"Prescriptive directions for the parliamentary estate are impossible to devise;
the incident could be multi-faceted and fast developing," the e-mail states.

The disclosure of the contingency plan comes after it emerged earlier this year
that Western intelligence agencies were investigating a suspected al-Qaida plot
to mount attacks in major European cities.

A Commons spokesman said: "We have contingency plans to cover a range of
emergencies, of which this is one. It does not relate to a specific threat."

LOAD-DATE: March 14, 2011

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                          November 17, 2010 Wednesday

German minister warns of plan for terror attack within weeks

LENGTH: 372 words


German Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere said on 17 November that the
authorities had received a tip-off by a foreign partner according to which there
may be plans for an attack in the country as early as the end of the month.

In remarks made during a press conference and broadcast on German
Deutschlandfunk radio, De Maiziere added that he had asked the federal police to
take appropriate security measures to face up to the current threat level.

In a first clips broadcast on the radio, he said: "According to a tip-off by a
foreign partner, which we received after the Yemen [parcel bomb] incident, a
suspected plan for an attack is to be put into action at the end of November,
and our own most recent findings resulting from an investigation by the Federal
Criminal Police Office in connection with people in Islamist circles confirm
once again, and independently of that, the sustained efforts being made by
Islamist groups to plan attacks in the Federal Republic of Germany. Here, too,
just as in the second case I have mentioned, there are concrete investigative
leads."

In a second clip, he said: "The federal and regional security authorities are
well-prepared for this situation. Already a year ago, wide-ranging measures and
concepts were drawn up and implemented. These are now being applied once again.
That is why I have asked the federal police to take account of the current
threat level by taking security measures adapted to the specific situation, in
particular at airports and train stations. This stands until further notice."

The TV explained that the reference to "a year ago" was to various threatening
videos that had been posted on the Internet, in response to which lists of
objects to be protected had been drawn up. It added that, in addition to
airports and train stations, De Maiziere had said that regional authorities
would work on the protection of public rooms and spaces more generally.
According to the TV, the minister added that this did not mean that it was not
known where an attack might take place, and that the focus on airports and
stations did not suggest that there was a particularly high level of threat
against them.

Source: Deutschlandfunk radio, Cologne, in German 1211 gmt 17 Nov 10

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                          November 17, 2010 Wednesday

Pakistan agencies said fear terror attacks in 10 cities on Id

LENGTH: 247 words


Text of report by Pakistani newspaper Khabrain on 16 November

["'Id al-Adha: Suicide Attacks Feared in 10 Cities, Including Lahore" - INP
headline]

Faisalabad - Suicide attackers may target mosques and imambargahs [place where
Shia Muslims gather to mourn the martyrdom of Imam Hussain bin Ali] in 10 big
cities, including Lahore, Faisalabad, Rawalpindi, Jhang, and Multan, on the
occasion of 'Id al-Adha. The intelligence agencies have sent a report to the
Punjab Government in this regard.

According to the details received, a report, received by the Punjab Home
Department from the intelligence agencies, has warned that to fulfil their
ulterior motives, the suicide attackers can do anything in 10 big cities,
including Muzaffargarh, Multan, Jhang, Lahore, Faisalabad, Gujranwala, Sargodha,
Dera Ghazi Khan, Vehari, and Rawalpindi, during the three holidays [ 17 to 19
November]on 'Id al-Adha. The terrorists can target important political figures,
senior officials, mosques, and imambargahs; therefore, the Punjab Government
should take foolproof measures in all these cities.

Meanwhile, after recovering a land mine from Shah Rukn-e-Alam Express coming
from Karachi to Multan, strict orders have also been given to senior officials
of the Faisalabad railway station to ensure patrol by the railway police at its
installations.

Furthermore, the Home Department has ordered high security alert at all big and
small railway stations.

                              238 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          Press Association Mediapoint

                    November 17, 2010 Wednesday 5:41 PM BST

TUBE STAFF 'HAD NO SPECIFIC TRAINING TO HANDLE TERROR ATTACKS'

BYLINE: Rosa Silverman, Press Association

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 324 words


The devastating terror atrocities in Madrid in 2004 saw 191 people killed and
hundreds more wounded by bombs detonated on commuter trains.

Yet London Tube staff were given no specific training about what to do in the
event of a similar attack in the British capital, the inquest into the 2005 July
7 bombings heard.

A series of Tube workers were asked by a lawyer for some of the victims'
families, Caoilfhionn Gallagher, whether they had been trained in what to expect
in the event of an explosion.

But most of them answered that they had not.

Train driver Jeffrey Porter replied: ``None at all, no.''

Train driver Dave Matthews and former train driver Paul Thompson gave similar
answers.

One witness, trains duty manager Trevor Rodgers, said his training had prepared
him to an extent.

But he added: ``I don't think we were trained to deal with that type of
incident.''

Train driver Simon Blakesley said he had received no training about what to do
in the event of a bomb but had been trained in the Mayday procedure.

Only train driver Craig Aylen said he had received training not only in the
Mayday procedure but also in how to evacuate passengers from a train and what to
do if a suspect package was discovered.

Staff also had to contend with was what was described as a ``stone-age'' radio
system in operation on the London Underground network at the time, the inquest
heard.

Mr Porter, whose Tube stopped alongside the one which was bombed, told of the
problems with the radio, saying the user had no idea whether or not their
message had been received.

Mr Blakesley said the cab radio was ``very old'', although he was generally able
to get hold of someone when he needed to.

Mr Thompson added: ``There were dead spots where you couldn't get through to the
controller in certain areas.''

A new radio system, called Connect, has been introduced since the bombings.

This enables Tube drivers to communicate anywhere within the network, the
inquest heard.

LOAD-DATE: November 18, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                           November 18, 2010 Thursday

Germany boosts security amid 'concrete' fears of Islamist terror attacks

BYLINE: Kate Connolly Berlin

SECTION: GUARDIAN INTERNATIONAL PAGES; Pg. 31

LENGTH: 466 words


Security at German airports, railway stations and major tourist attractions was
heightened yesterday after the government said it had received concrete warnings
that an Islamist terror cell was planning to launch attacks across the country
towards the end of this month.

In city centres, traffic ground to a halt as police imposed emergency controls,
while the number of armed security personnel, particularly at airports, was
significantly increased as travellers were warned to be vigilant.

"The security situation in Germany has become more serious," said the interior
minister, Thomas de Maiziere, in a statement.

"We have concrete indications of a series of attacks planned for the end of
November."

According to senior security forces, Germany's federal criminal police are
investigating information that a terror cell consisting of four Islamists from
India and others from Pakistan is either planning to travel to Germany or is
already operating there. The names of the suspects are known to officials.

De Maiziere added, in an appeal for calm, that Germany would show its strengths:
"We won't be fazed by this."

The warnings follow a recent security scare over parcel bombs sent from Yemen to
the US, one of which went through a German airport before it was intercepted in
the UK. The explosives were hidden in printer cartridges.

De Maiziere made it clear yesterday that the new warning was separate from
previous ones, but had come as a direct result of the Yemen incident, "in the
form of a warning from an international partner," he said, without naming names.

The Yemen parcel bomb plot, he added, had highlighted "the adaptability and
persistence of terrorists in pursuing their aims", and had shown the
"reliability of some leads".

He said German police, working together "with people from the Islamic area,
confirm independently the persistent efforts of Islamic groups to carry out
attacks in Germany".

Security at potential target sites such as airports and stations would be
increased until further notice, he said, adding that while there were reasons
for concern there were "no reasons for hysteria".

Germany has long been considered a target for militants linked to al-Qaida
because of the more than 4,500 military personnel it has based in Afghanistan,
and because of its role as the financial powerhouse of Europe.

Der Spiegel called the warning a "psycho war against Germany", and said the
country had to prepare for the fact that, although it had so far escaped an
attack, it could be about to join the list of victims of al-Qaida strikes.
Warnings had been received before the attacks in Madrid in 2004, London in 2005
and Mumbai in 2008, but to no avail, it said.

Captions:

A German policeman armed with a submachine gun stands guard with a colleague at
Berlin's central railway station

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              241 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                              The Herald (Glasgow)

                           November 18, 2010 Thursday
                                   1 Edition

Germany steps up security after terror attack tip-off

BYLINE: dave graham berlin

SECTION: HS - NEWS; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 580 words


Germany said yesterday it had firm evidence Islamist militants were planning
attacks in the next two weeks and ordered increased security at potential
targets including train stations and airports.

The country s top security official, Thomas de Maiziere, said the move came
after new intelligence came to light. Germans will see a visible response to the
threat, including an increased police presence at transport hubs.

Despite the heightened security presence, he urged calm. Officials did not
provide specific details about the threat.

There is reason for worry, but there is no reason for hysteria,  Mr de Maiziere
said.  We will not allow international terror to limit us in our way of life and
our culture of freedom.

Germany has no colour-coded or number system for measuring security levels
comparable to those in the US, Britain or France    and is more cautious in
publicly discussing the degrees of threat, on the grounds it could endanger
efforts to prevent an attack.

Though Germany has escaped major terrorist attacks   such as the Madrid train
bombings of 2004 and the London attacks of 2005   at least two major plots have
been thwarted or failed before they could be carried out.

Besides the known findings, we now have additional, relevant indications of
possible danger that security authorities agree  justify our assessment that we
are now facing a new situation,  Mr de Maiziere said.

He cited a tip from an unspecified country about a suspected attack planned for
the end of November   though he did not say where it was to take place.

That tip arrived after the interception of two mail bombs mailed from Yemen to
the US   one of which went through a German airport before it was found in
Britain. The Yemen plot points to  the adaptability and the persistence of
terrorists in pursuing their aims,  and also underlines  the reliability of some
leads,  Mr de Maiziere said in a statement to reporters, without elaborating.

He said German authorities had also gathered concrete intelligence of their own,
pointing to  sustained efforts  by Islamic extremist groups to plan attacks in
Germany. Authorities have launched investigations that could lead to charges.

De Maiziere said the current risk assessment was comparable to the one before
last year s national election   when the country also raised security. One
trigger for that alert was a video in which a German speaker threatened a  rude
awakening  if Germans did not push their political parties to withdraw the
country s soldiers from Afghanistan.

By yesterday afternoon, police carrying automatic weapons and wearing protective
gear could be seen patrolling railway platforms at the Berlin s Central Station.

However, Germans did not appear particularly concerned.

I don t feel threatened, otherwise we would not be walking around here in
Berlin,  said Angelika Balkenhoel, arriving from nearby Hamburg.

Mr de Maiziere, a senior figure in Chancellor Anglea Merkel s centre-right
government, had initially played down the threat last month when the United
States and Britain issued warnings that Germany and France could be targeted by
al Qaeda and allied militants.

But earlier this month he acknowledged there were  serious indications  of a
threat to Europe and the United States.

Germany has long viewed itself as a potential target because it has 4590
military personnel stationed in Afghanistan, the third largest contingent of the
150,000-strong international force fighting the Taliban-led insurgency.

LOAD-DATE: November 19, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                 First Edition

Security stepped up after 'concrete' warning of terrorist attacks;
GERMANY

BYLINE: TONY PATERSON

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 30

LENGTH: 215 words


THE GERMAN government is stepping up security at all airports and train stations
after receiving "concrete indications" that terrorist attacks are being planned
in the country for the end of November.

The alert, which comes less than a month after Germany dismissed American
warnings of terror attacks in Europe, has led to increased police patrols in
major cities and the introduction of spot checks at airports and border control
points.

Announcing the measures, the Interior Minister, Thomas de Maizière, said Germany
had received a tip-off from another government that "sustained efforts" were
being made by Islamic extremists to carry out attacks. "There are grounds for
concern but not hysteria," he added.

The tip-off follows the interception of two parcel bombs en route from Yemen to
the United States last month. One of the bombs was sent via Cologne airport,
where security guards failed to detect it. The bomb was eventually discovered in
Britain.

Mr de Maizière was subsequently given a "dressing down" by Chancellor Angela
Merkel for having failed to inform her about the bomb and the security services'
failure to find it. Yesterday's warning was in part designed to correct
impressions that Germany had gone soft on terrorism or was not taking the threat
of bomb attacks seriously.

Police defuse 30kg bomb, foil terror attack in Pakistan's Peshawar

LENGTH: 146 words


Text of report by official news agency Associated Press of Pakistan (APP)

Peshawar: Peshawar police averted a major terrorist attack by defusing a 30
kilogram bomb planted beneath a bridge near a police post here Thursday evening.
The explosive material was dumped in a drum planted beneath a bridge close to
Waheed Abad police post here. The police had prior information about the
suspected explosives. Acting on a tip-off, police conducted a search operation
at Waheed Chowki and found the bomb concealed in a drum. The bomb disposal squad
was called to defuse the device, police said. Officials said the bomb could have
caused many casualties and widespread destruction if it had exploded. Separately
an official of Khasadar force was abducted by miscreants in Bara tehsil of
Khyber Agency.

Pakistan: More than one terrorist organization behind recent attack in Karachi

LENGTH: 484 words


Text of report by Asif Ali Syed headlined "More than one organization involved
in CID center attack: Investigation team" published by Pakistani newspaper Jang
on 16 November

Karachi -- The investigation team that conducted investigations into the
terrorist attack on the CID [Criminal Investigation Department] civil line
office says that more than one organization was involved in the attack on the
CID center. The investigators have expressed doubt that the level of the
terrorist act shows that it cannot be the handiwork of some groups alone.
Therefore, the terrorist organizations launched a combined action. The police
sources say in this connection that it can be gauged from evidence discovered
during the investigation and the condition of the site in the wake of the
explosion that the same group is involved in the CID center [attack] that had
forged alliances against the government and agencies taking part in operations
against the defunct organizations.

The police sources said that when the United States imposed a ban on Al-Qa'ida
[Al-Qa'idah] and the organizations associated with it, actions against defunct
jihadi organizations were launched and these organization were banned. On this,
all organizations had forged an anti-US alliance and against those siding with
it and launched joint terrorist acts across the country. Meanwhile, these
defunct organizations faced shortages of funds due to freezing of bank accounts
and assets of the terrorists. They started launching criminal acts to collect
funds for themselves while the money received from the criminal acts was also
transferred abroad.

In an exclusive interview with Jang, deputy CID Inspector General Saud Ahmed
Mirza said that the investigations into the culprits involved in the CID center
attack make it clear that the CID was a high-value target which no single group
of terrorists could have accomplished. He said that all the terrorist groups are
interlinked and only their names are different. All these people launch such big
acts together. He said all the groups of Lashkar-e Jhangvi and other terrorist
groups are part of the Pakistani Taleban movement. It does not appear to be the
act of a separate group. To a question, Saud Mirza said that the investigation
team could not find any clue about the vehicle used in explosion and it has not
yet been ascertained which vehicle was used to carry the explosive. He said CCTV
footage from several institutions failed to provide any useful information about
the culprits. He said that the process of collecting evidence from the site
continues. To a question, Saud Mirza replied that no alternative arrangement
could be made for the office of the CID civil lines due to which official work
of CID could not start. He said that efforts are under way to rent premises
elsewhere and the CID staff will be given a substitute place.

Source: Jang, Rawalpindi, in Urdu 16 Nov 10

                           November 20, 2010 Saturday

Terrorists planned attack against German parliament - report

LENGTH: 531 words


Text of report in English by independent German Spiegel Online website on 20
November

Officials erected crowd barriers in front of the Reichstag building this week
after the German interior minister put the country on alert for terrorism on
Wednesday [17 November].

It would be an attack on the very heart of democracy. SPIEGEL has learned that
terrorists may have been planning an attack on the Reichstag, the home of the
German parliament and one of the most popular tourist destinations in Berlin.
Two suspected culprits are already believed to be in Berlin.

According to information obtained by from German security authorities,
Al-Qa'idah and associated groups are believed to be planning an attack on the
Reichstag building in Berlin, the headquarters of Germany's parliament and also
an attraction visited by thousands of tourists every day. As part of the attack,
terrorists would seek to take hostages and perpetrate a bloodbath using
firearms.

The information about the alleged plans came from a jihadist who is currently
abroad and contacted the German Federal Criminal Police Office (BKA) several
times in recent days. The jihadist apparently wants to abandon the group. The
information provided by the jihadist informant was apparently the reason behind
German Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere's decision to hold a press
conference on Wednesday warning of an imminent attack in the country.

According to the caller, the terror cell is comprised of six people - two of
whom are believed already to have travelled to Berlin six to eight weeks ago,
and are now staying in the city. Four other perpetrators - a German, Turk, a
northern African and a further man the jihadist could not identify, are
currently waiting to travel to Germany. The attacks are purportedly being
planned for February or March.

Apparent plans for second attack

The second warning backing de Maiziere's concerns came from the United States.
The US federal police, the FBI, sent a cable to the BKA two weeks ago noting
another possible further attack. A Shi'i-Indian group known as the "Saif," or
sword, is believed to have engaged in a pact with Al-Qa'idah and to have sent
two men to Germany to carry out an attack there.

Both were believed to be travelling to the United Arab Emirates on 22 November,
where they would be supplied with new travel papers so that they could continue
on to Germany. The suspects allegedly already possess visas for Europe's
Schengen zone of visa-free travel. The FBI has named Mushtaq Altaf bin-Khadri as
the man behind the attack plans.

The man believed to be trying to smuggle the would-be terrorists into Europe is
54-year-old weapons dealer Dawood Ibrahim, who the United Nations believes is a
major backer of terrorism. He is considered to be one of the men behind the
terror attacks perpetrated in Mumbai in November 2008. The FBI and Germany's BKA
both consider the message to be extremely important. However, the US foreign
intelligence service, the CIA, and both the German foreign intelligence service,
the BND, and its domestic counterpart, the Office for the Protection of the
Constitution, are sceptical.

Source: Spiegel Online website, Hamburg, in English 20 Nov 10

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political

                            November 21, 2010 Sunday

Terror attack in West traced to Pakistan to have "serious" impact - article

LENGTH: 589 words


Text of article by Dr Farrukh Saleem headlined "Capital suggestion" published by
Pakistan newspaper The News website on 21 November

On December 16 1971, Pakistan lost 143,998 square kilometres (land and water) of
her area. Pakistan's National Security Doctrine (NSD), a country's strategy to
survive as a nation-state, was never to be the same again. In Multan, on January
20 1972, President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto laid the foundation of Project-706,
Pakistan's equivalent of America's Manhattan Project that produced the first
atomic bombs.

President Bhutto authorised project costs of US $450 million and by 1985
Pakistan had crossed the 'threshold of weapons-grade uranium production'. Within
two years of crossing the threshold Pakistan had acquired the ability to test a
nuclear device. On May 28 1998, Pakistan conducted a total of five nuclear tests
with the largest reported yield of 25-36 kT. In 2009, Pakistan's peak stockpile
was estimated to be 70-90 warheads with a maximum missile range of 2,500 km.

Pakistan has to survive as a nation-state and Pakistan's NSD must therefore
cater to at least two potential threats. First threat (rated high): a 2,912 km
border on the east with the massing up of the Indian army's Corps XV, IX, XVI,
X, XI, II and I plus the 3rd Armoured Division, 4th Rapid Division and 2nd
Armoured Brigade plus air force stations at Jaisalmer, Utarlai and Bhuj. Second
threat (rated low): a 2,430 km border on the west.

Since 1998, Pakistan has had a tri-podal National Security Doctrine. First leg:
Corps I, II, IV, X, XXX and XXXI headquartered in Managla, Multan, Lahore,
Rawalpindi, Gujranwala and Bahawalpur, respectively. Second leg: Non-state
actors plus FATA [Federally Administered Tribal Areas] as a buffer-zone plus
projection of power into Afghanistan. Third leg: Nuclear deterrent.

Pakistan's tri-podal NSD has successfully catered to threats both in the east as
well as the west. Then came September 11. Pakistan's NSD has since been turned
upside-down. NATO-ISAF has amassed 150,000 troops just west of us (Soviet troops
in the area peaked at 120,000) plus India has penetrated Afghanistan just to
encircle Pakistan plus some of the non-state actors that Pakistan thought were
part of her NSD have now turned against the Pakistani state itself.

Pakistan's NSD, with very little input from civilian governments, is now in a
state of disarray with little or no consensus on how to counter terrorism.
Pakistan's civil society - particularly the political parties and the media -
also lacks the required consensus. And consensus, to be sure, is the principal
prerequisite to a successful counter-terrorism drive.

The PPP finds fighting terrorism in its political interest while the PML-N does
not. The PPP has rightly identified primary drivers behind terrorism as being
indigenous while the other continues to be in a state of total denial.

Then came the floods. With Pakistan's political class making itself completely
irrelevant, the Pakistani army was left to fight terrorism plus provide flood
relief. With a $9.7 billion flood-tag plus a budget in high deficit, the
Pakistani army largely depends on American aid for flood relief. But, American
aid - any foreign aid for that matter - comes with strings attached.

With an absolute lack of consensus within the Pakistani state and society on how
to counter terrorism the bloodbath continues. Furthermore, a strike in the West
traced back to Pakistan will have serious repercussions for us.

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 21 Nov 10

LOAD-DATE: November 21, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2010 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved

Faisalabad, 20 November: Intelligence agencies arrested Rafiq, son of Shafiq, an

Jail for terror attack

THUGS who subjected a 16 year-old schoolboy to a terrifying attack in a park
have been jailed.

Luke Jobe and Reece Holton, both 18, and 20 year-old Michael Tyson, all from
Solihull, West Midlands, admitted their part in the attack at Warwick Crown
Court this week. During the attack youngster was threatened with a knife,
knocked down and kicked.

TERROR ATTACK VICTIM NEEDED 90 STITCHES;
Hooded thugs smash way into man's house

BYLINE: BRYAN BROUGH

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 292 words


A MAN needed more than 90 stitches to a mass of wounds after a frenzied attack
by a brutal armed gang who smashed their way into his home.

Six men brandishing a claw hammer and blades burst into the terrified
44-year-old victim's flat in Paisley's South End.

They repeatedly lashed out at his face, head, body and legs during the horrific
beating.

His home was also ransacked and a number of items, including cash, was taken.

The badly injured man was taken to the Royal Alexandra Hospital where he
received emergency treatment.

One source said: "This man's wounds were horrendous. His face and head were a
mass of wounds and there were injuries too to his body and leg.

"I understand medical staff had to insert more than 90 stitches into his wounds.
He was in a terrible mess."

The vicious assault was at the man's home in the Thrushcraigs area of the town
late on Wednesday night.

A man, who lives close to the scene of the attack, said: "I was told his door
was kicked in around 11.30pm.

"There were at least six men who burst in. Some were hooded, some had scarves
over their faces and all wore dark clothes.

"They inflicted terrible wounds on this man and I think he is still in hospital.

"This must have been terrifying, but why it happened I've no idea.

"Some of the attackers had blades and one carried a claw hammer."

Last night detectives stepped up the hunt for the attackers and appealed for
witnesses.

One officer said: "If anyone saw a group of men in the Thrushcraigs and
Barterholm Road areas, we would ask them to let us know.

"Whatever information you have that might help this inquiry ring Paisley Police
Office on 0141 532 5900 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111."

Police are treating the incident as a serious assault.

                    BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political

                           November 23, 2010 Tuesday

Philippines confirms terror threat, "downplays" terrorist attack capability

LENGTH: 848 words


Text of report in English by Philippine newspaper The Manila Times website on 23
November

[Report by Ana Mae G. Roa with MPC: "Palace confirms terror threat but downplays
attack capability"]

SECURITY OFFICIALS yesterday said terrorists do not have the capability of
staging attacks in Metro Manila even as the government remains on alert with
intelligence reports confirming the threats.

Concepcion B. Clamour, National Intelligence Coordinating Agency assistant
director-general, said current threat level in Metro Manila is moderate, defined
as the intent to undertake a terrorist attack but hampered by lack of capability
to do so.

"The intention has always been there so we maintained moderate or low level for
Metro Manila," she said in a briefing at the Presidential Situation Room located
in Malacanang Park.

Moderate is the second of a four-step threat level assessment of intelligence
and security agencies. Others are low, high and extreme.

Military operations in the provinces of Sulu and Basilan in Southwestern
Mindanao have prevented terrorist groups from operating beyond the region, said
National Security Adviser Cesar P. Garcia, quoting retired Lt. Gen. Ben D.
Dolorfino, former chief of the Western Mindanao Command.

Further, Mr Garcia said terrorist groups are suffering from lack of foreign
funding support, a key factor in mobilizing attacks.

"Money translates to capability," he said.

Some members of Abu Sayyaf, Jemaah Islamiyah and other radical groups may be in
Metro Manila to flee from military operations but not to engage in terrorist
activities, Mr Garcia said.

"So there is no doubt that there could be some of them who are hiding here not
because they are going to engage any terrorist attack but they are trying to
escape from the offensive military organizations being conducted in the southern
Philippines," Mr Garcia said.

Six foreign countries, namely, the United States, Canada, Australia, New
Zealand, the United Kingdom and France have recently issued travel advisories
against the Philippines for alleged terrorist threats.

Malacanang, however, has downplayed the warnings, saying the analysis of the
threat is not consistent with what terrorist groups normally do.

Based on classification, the four terrorism threat levels are:

* low - no information to suggest a specific and imminent terrorist threat in
Metro Manila and other major political and economic centres;

* moderate alert - a terrorist attack is possible but not likely;

* high - strong possibility a terrorist attack within a short time; and

* extreme - grouped into severe or terrorist attack highly likely, and critical
when a terrorist attack has occurred or has just been preempted and follow-up
attacks are expected.

High alert has been raised for some municipalities in Zamboanga Peninsula,
Northern Mindanao, Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao and Socsksargen (South
Cotabato, Sultan Kudarat, Sarangani, General Santos), while the rest of the
country is at low level, said Ms Clamour.

Presidential situation room

Meanwhile, a situation room within the Palace has been set up for President
Benigno S. C. Aquino III to provide a daily assessment of the security situation
nationwide.

The facility headed by Zenaida F. Brosas, assistant director-general of the
National Security Council, will also double up as crisis management operation
centre during national crises.

The Presidential Situation Room was created under Administrative Order 2, signed
in the aftermath of the Aug. 23 bus siege where eight Hong Kong tourists were
killed after being held hostage by disgruntled policeman Rolando D. Mendoza.
Mendoza was also killed after the 10-hour drama in front of the Luneta
Grandstand in Manila.

The national crisis management committee shall be convened at the Presidential
Situation Room if the alert level is high to extreme, Mr Garcia said.

On a related development, Director Eduardo G. Batac, spokesman of the Department
of National Defence (DND ), and outgoing National Capital Region Command
(NCRCOM) chief Maj. Gen. Arthur I. Tabaquero yesterday said in a press briefing
that there is no imminent terrorist threat in Metro Manila, contrary to a
statement Friday thatsupposedly came from NCRCOM.

The statement announced the reassignment of Mr Tabaquero to Eastern Mindanao
Command. The report said several terrorist groups have continued to use the NCR
as a "support base."

Sought for clarification, NCRCOM spokesman Lt. Col. Armand F. Rico said he is
not authorized to comment on the issue.

"What you have seen is a report which is unofficial. We don't know where it came
from; we have to verify it," Mr Batac said.

"The NCRCOM has not yet been turned over [to the new commander]. There should be
no after tour of duty report yet," he added.

Brig. Gen. Jose Z. Mabanta, Jr., Armed Forces spokesman, noted the unsigned
statement was "raw, unverified and needs to be assessed."

Mr Tabaquero said a probe is being conducted on the statement. He added that he
will release an official report upon his turnover tentatively scheduled
tomorrow.

Source: The Manila Times website, Manila, in English 23 Nov 10

Axe terror as raiders attack shop staff

BYLINE: ADRIAN RUTHERFORD

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 148 words


TWO shop workers were attacked with an axe during a terrifying robbery in
Belfast city centre, police said today.

Two men entered the shop in the Gresham Street area around 2.15pm yesterday.

One of the men attacked a glass fronted cabinet with the axe and a struggle took
place with two male members of staff.

One staff member was hit on the arm and leg and the second on the back. Their
injuries are not believed to be serious.

The two robbers made off empty-handed. It is believed they got into a small
silver car in the Gresham Street area and drove down Samuel Street towards
Milfield.

One of the men was described as being 5ft 6 in to 5ft 8in, slim, with a thin
face.He was wearing a black deerstalker hat, black shirt, black sports jacket
and silver tie. The other was said to be 5ft 6in to 5ft 8in, wearing a dark
woollen peak hat and a high visibility jacket with a stripe across the chest.

                              253 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                    Scotsman

                           November 23, 2010 Tuesday

Reichstag shut after warning of terror attack

BYLINE: Erik Kirschbaum

LENGTH: 245 words



HIGHLIGHT: The Reichstag in Berlin was abruptly closed to tourists yesterday
after reports of a plot by Islamist militants to attack Germany's historic
parliament building.


The shutdown of the majestic structure's modern glass cupola and roof terrace
reflected growing worries about terrorism in a country that until now has been
mostly spared violence.

One of Germany's most popular tourist attractions, the Reichstag is visited by
about three million people each year.

Only small groups with advance bookings were allowed past police barricades
yesterday, with thousands of others being turned away.

"It's unfortunate, but I'm sure police have their reasons," said Peter Kalle,
50, a Bavarian tourist, after he and his family were denied entrance. "Dealing
with the terrorist threat is more important than sightseeing."

A spokesman for the Reichstag offered no explanation for the closure, but said
it would last "until further notice". About 60 armed police were stationed
around the building.

Der Spiegel magazine reported on Saturday that a jihadist living abroad had
informed authorities of a plan for armed militants to enter the Reichstag and
open fire. However, police played down the report, saying there were no concrete
details.

Interior minister Thomas de Maiziere said last Thursday authorities were on
guard against threats of an armed attack of the kind that killed 166 in the
Indian city of Mumbai in 2008.

Heavily armed police have since been a fixture at rail stations and airports.

"We want to live freely and without fear in Germany," Chancellor Angela Merkel
said at the weekend. "No terror threat is going to stop us from that."

                               East Kent Gazette

                               November 24, 2010

Terror of attack by rottweiler

BYLINE: Dawn Kingsford

SECTION: Pg. 12

LENGTH: 288  words


A Terrier owner from Sittingbourne is calling for a change in the law to make
dog owners more accountable after a terrifying attack on his puppy.

Thomas Pexton was left covered in blood, after his seven-month-old border
terrier was attacked by a rottweiler while they were out walking in a park.

Mr Pexton, a builder from Chatsworth Drive, says Amber was left riddled with
puncture wounds and spent three nights at the vets.

Still traumatised by the terrifying attack, at the White Horse Country Park near
Detling, Thomas, 36, said: "The rottweiler was off its lead and lunged at Amber.
The man with the dog tried to call him, but had absolutely no control over this
huge, 100lb animal.

"I cannot over-emphasise the severity of the attack, which left me in tears and
my dog in such a terrible state - I thought she was dead.

"I pleaded with the owner and his wife to help, but they basically said just
'get your dog help' and leave us alone."

The incident on November 12 was reported to police, but Mr Pexton says he has
been advised that as there was no independent witness his only course of action
is a private prosecution.

Mr Pexton said: "I feel really let down. My dog was left for dead and I've been
left high and dry. The law has to change.

"Dogs, like cars, are lethal weapons in the wrong hands. It should be a legal
requirement that all dog owners are traceable, perhaps through a compulsory
register, and held accountable in the event of an unprovoked attack like this."

Mr Pexton added: "I am a responsible owner who has thought long and hard about
the introduction of a dog into the family home.

"Now, thanks to this attack, I am fearful of how Amber will view the world and
other animals when she finally gets to go out again."

the police. In a speech to the Royal United Services Institute in London, he

security service, this is undoubtedly asÊ dangerous a time as we have seen for
the UK, and UK interests abroad, since the attempted attacks on the Tiger Tiger
nightclub in LondonÊ and Glasgow airport in 2007."

His comments come amid fears that Islamic terrorists are planning a Mumbai-style
attack on a European city.

Minister to remember India's Mumbai terror attack victims - report

LENGTH: 280 words


Text of report by Indian news agency PTI

Mumbai, 25 November: Indian Home Minister P Chidambaram will lead Mumbaikars
Friday [26 November] in remembering those killed during the 26/11 Mumbai terror
attacks.

On the second anniversary of the audacious terror strike, Chidambaram, Indian
Petroleum Minister Murli Deora and Chief Minister of western Indian state
Maharashtra Prithviraj

Chavan will participate at a commemoration function, to be held at the CNG
filling station in suburban Borivli Friday morning.

P Unnikrishnan, father of slain NSG (National Security Guards) officer Major
Sandeep Unnikrishnan, who has undertaken a cycle tour from India Gate in Delhi,
will join a peace march at the Gateway of India here.

A candle-lit silent prayer rally will be organized by the College of Social
Work, Nirmala Niketan and family members of 26/11 victims, from Cama Hospital
lane to St Xavier's college in South Mumbai.

The Indo-American Society has organized a meeting with Charles Cannon and Kia
Scherr from One Life Alliance, survivors of the terror attacks, as Mumbai
commemorates the city's undying spirit lauded by US President Barack Obama
during his tribute to 26/11 martyrs here earlier this month.

At the CST railway station, there will be a commemoration service for the 26/11
martyrs, a railway official said. A wreath will be laid to remember the 166
people killed during the Mumbai attacks.

Over 50 persons were killed and close to 90 injured when Ajmal Kasab and another
terrorist Ismail started firing indiscriminately at the busy rail terminus in
south Mumbai on that fateful night of 26 November two years ago.

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                            November 26, 2010 Friday

Cyber-terrorists could use supervirus to attack Britain

BYLINE: Morag Lindsay

SECTION: NEWS; 999; Terrorism; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 384 words


A "supervirus" blamed for disrupting Iran's nuclear programme could pose the new
terror threat to the UK, a north-east expert has warned.

Reports yesterday suggested the Stuxnet worm - a computer virus which targets
control systems found in industrial plants - had been traded on the black market
and could be used by terrorists to target power stations, food distribution
networks, hospitals, traffic lights and even dams.

One unnamed source was quoted as saying: "We have hard evidence that the virus
is in the hands of bad guys, and they have realised that this kind of virus
could be a devastating tool."

Ian Allison, head of the School of Computing at the Robert Gordon University in
Aberdeen, said the internet was awash with rumours about the so-called
"supervirus" yesterday.

And while it's impossible to say how much truth is in any of them, he said there
was no doubt that cyber-terrorism was a genuine concern for governments around
the world.

"From what I understand this Stuxnet worm takes computer viruses to a new
level," he said.

"Unlike traditional viruses, these superviruses don't require us humans to have
some part in their transfer - either by sending an e-mail, or using an infected
USB stick which then replicates the virus in another machine.

"They also attack the physical properties of their targets, such as chips or
control systems, rather than just attacking information or data on a machine.

"The question in this case is 'how much of this is hype and how much is real?'

"But there's no doubt that cyber terrorism is something the government is taking
seriously and there will be people working on the development of superviruses,
both from the point of protection and attack."

Iran has denied claims made at the weekend by a former UN nuclear inspections
official that the Stuxnet supervirus is the reason for delays in its uranium
enrichment programme.

But the threat of cyber attacks has become a source of international concern in
recent years.

On April 8, 15% of all internet traffic was routed through China for 18 minutes
in a mysterious incident the Chinese authorities have denied any part in.

The Royal Navy's website was shut down on November 5, allegedly by a Romanian
hacker.

In October, the UK Government declared cyber warfare to be a "tier one" threat
to national security.

Kyrgyz security services "prevent series of terrorist attacks"

LENGTH: 278 words


Text of report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Bishkek, 26 November: Kyrgyz security services and law-enforcement agencies have
prevented a series of terrorist attacks in the country's several towns. They
have arrested several people on suspicion of involvement in plotting the
attacks.

"We can say now that the Kyrgyz security services and law-enforcement agencies
have prevented a series of terrorist attacks in several towns," a source in the
republic's security services told Interfax today.

It said that nine people had already been arrested on suspicion of involvement
in plotting the terrorist attacks. They were arrested in Bishkek and Osh.

The source pointed out that the detainees had begun giving evidence on the
masterminds behind the attempted terrorist attacks.

Earlier the source had told Interfax that "the Kyrgyz security services found
over 10 kilograms of TNT in the capital [Bishkek], which was possibly intended
to carry out terrorist attacks in different parts of the republic".

He said that the it was because of this case that the republic's security forces
were put on alert. He specified that the total weight of the explosive, which
has been found, was equivalent to almost 12 kilograms [of TNT].

"Today President Roza Otunbayeva was due to visit Osh, but it was called off
immediately," the source added.

In the meantime, relevant Kyrgyz departments have not commented on the
situation. A source in the Kyrgyz Defence Ministry has confirmed that all the
security forces were put on alert following an urgent session that was held
behind closed doors last Wednesday.
