                            November 26, 2010 Friday

Indian PM salutes "spirit" of Mumbai on second anniversary of terror attacks

LENGTH: 474 words


Text of unattributed report headlined "PM pays tribute to 26/11 martyrs"
published by Indian public broadcaster Doordarshan News website on 26 November

Joining the nation in remembering those killed in the Mumbai terror attacks,
Prime Minister Manmohan Singh on Friday [26 November] pledged to redouble
efforts to bring the perpetrators of the crime to justice.

"On this day of remembrance, we salute the courage, unity and the resolve of
ordinary Mumbaikars and the brave and selfless action of our men in uniform
during the attack," he said in a statement in New Delhi on the second
anniversary of the Mumbai attacks in which 166 people were killed.

Dr. Singh said, "It is this spirit and strength of character of the Indian
people that will defeat such forces that seek to threaten our social fabric and
way of life".

"We will never succumb to the designs of our enemies. We pledge to redouble our
efforts to bring the perpetrators of this crime against humanity to justice," he
said.

Noting that Mumbai was subjected to a brutal terrorist attack that claimed the
life of hundreds of innocent people, he said the nation joins the bereaved
families in remembering and mourning those who perished in this barbaric attack.

India asks Pakistan to dismantle terror machines

India asked Pakistan to dismantle the terror machine operating on its soil and
bring perpetrators of the Mumbai attacks to speedy justice as the country marked
the second anniversary of the 26/11 strikes.

"Once again I call upon Pakistan to dismantle the terror machine operating with
impunity in territories under its control and to bring all the perpetrators of
the Mumbai terror attacks to speedy justice," External Affairs Minister S M
Krishna said.

In his message on the 26/11 anniversary, Krishna said: "On the second
anniversary of the barbaric terrorist attack in Mumbai, the nation pays
respectful homage to its sons, daughters and foreign guests, whose innocent
lives were cruelly snuffed out."

Ten Pakistan-based Lashkar-i-Toiba terrorists arrived by sea on the evening of
26 November 2008, in Mumbai and targeted different parts of the city, killing
166 people and wounding over 300 during 60 hours of carnage.

India has accused Pakistan of not doing enough to bring the plotters behind the
audacious attacks to justice.

"The day is a stark reminder, that no cause can ever justify terror, either by
state or non-state actors," said Krishna, who is in Colombo on a four-day
official visit.

He said India seeks peaceful, stable and cooperative relations with Pakistan.

"I travelled to Islamabad last July for talks and have also invited my
counterpart to visit New Delhi for further discussions," he said.

"India is committed to resolving all outstanding issues with Pakistan through
dialogue," the Minister added.

Source: Doordarshan news website, New Delhi, in English 26 Nov 10

                            Daily Post (North Wales)

                            November 26, 2010 Friday
                              North Wales Edition

7/7 medics used M&S first aid kits;
LIFE-SAVERS BATTLED A LACK OF SUPPLIES AFTER TERROR ATTACK

BYLINE: SAM MARSDEN

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 452 words


MEDICS treating wounded 7/7 survivors ran out of supplies and had to use first
aid kits from a Marks & Spencer store and a hotel, the inquest into the outrage
heard yesterday.

Paul Dadge, the former firefighter famously photographed hugging victim Davinia
Turrell as she clutched a white burns mask to her face, said there was little
doctors and nurses could do without the right equipment.

Mr Dadge was a passenger on the train behind the one blown up by suicide bomber
Mohammed Sidique Khan at Edgware Road Tube station on July 7 2005, killing six
people.

He described coming across the shocked and injured survivors of the attack and
setting up a casualty station in the Marks & Spencer near the station.

Mr Dadge was pictured helping Ms Turrell across the road to the Hilton Metropole
Hotel after the store was evacuated because of a bomb scare sparked by an
abandoned laptop bag.

He recalled that doctors and nurses were brought to the hotel from nearby
hospitals, but said shortages of supplies meant their efforts were limited to
grading the severity of the victims' injuries, known as "triaging".

"The medical resources on the scene were limited to the two paramedics and the
small number of staff from the London helicopter emergency medical service
team," he said in a statement read to the inquests.

"We had run out of oxygen and dressings and had become reliant on first aid
supplies from Marks & Spencer and the Hilton Metropole Hotel.

"Plus it had become apparent that the police had become aware of the lack of
medical resources on the scene and had begun to blue-light medical staff from St
Mary's Hospital and other hospitals within the area to the scene.

"Nurses, consultants and even a National Health Service priest arrived at the
hotel, although I think it is worth mentioning at this point that it was great,
but without the medical supplies there was not much they could do other than
retriage the people who had initially been assessed by myself and others."

He added there was a "noticeable" delay in ambulances arriving, meaning a large
number of the walking wounded had to be taken to hospital in police riot vans.

The inquest also heard ambulance bosses refused a request for paramedics on a
training course to be sent to treat injured survivors.

Paul Swan, the officer in charge of the emergency medical response to the
suicide attack on a train at London's Edgware Road Tube station, asked for
paramedics on a training course in Fulham that day to be reassigned to treat the
wounded at Edgware Road, but they were not deployed.

Mr Swan told the hearing: "I think there came a point where we were managing the
incident with the resources we had."

welshnews@dailypost.co.uk

                                   1 Edition

India marks terror attack anniversary

BYLINE: mUMBAI

SECTION: WOR; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 226 words


INDIA marked the second anniversary of the Mumbai terror attack with sombre
ceremonies and a renewed promise to seek justice for the 166 people killed in
the assault.

In 2008, 10 Pakistani militants targeted the rich at luxury hotels, killed
tourists at a popular cafe, attacked commuters in a train station and took over
a Jewish centre.

Officers flanked by special anti-terror vehicles marched through Mumbai
yesterday morning from the Oberoi Trident Hotel, one of the attack sites.

Students held a banner that read,  The Great Wall of Mumbai,  as an expression
of defiance toward the attack.

Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said:  We will never succumb to the designs of our
enemies. We pledge to redouble our efforts to bring the perpetrators of this
crime against humanity to justice.

India has refused to resume full-fledged peace talks with arch rival Pakistan
until its neighbour prosecutes those responsible for the attack.

The only gunman to survive the assault, Ajmal Kasab, has been sentenced to death
in India, but none of the seven alleged masterminds arrested in Pakistan have
been put on trial.

Once again I call upon Pakistan to dismantle the terror machine operating with
impunity in territories under its control and to bring all the perpetrators of
the Mumbai terror attack to speedy justice,  Indian external affairs minister SM
Krishna said.

Tbilisi, 28 November: [Georgian] Labour Party leader Shalva Natelashvili has

                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           November 30, 2010 Tuesday

Algiers security heightened; two "terrorists" said planning 11 December attacks

LENGTH: 675 words


Text of report by privately-owned Algerian newspaper Liberte website on 30
November

Security measures have been strengthened in Algiers in order to ward off any new
attempt by the armed terrorist groups to commit an attack.

The security agencies have launched a major operation looking for two terrorists
active in the capital city. They are suspected of making preparations for an
attack with the approach of the third anniversary of the double suicide bomber
attack that targeted the headquarters of the United Nations in Hydra and the
Constitutional Council in Ben Aknoun on 11 December 2007.

It was following a piece of reliable intelligence telling of the presence of two
terrorists in the basement of an apartment building located in the Bachdjarah 3
apartment complex that elements from the National People's Army [ANP], in
coordination with elements from the central division of Algiers's judicial
police, surrounded the apartment late in the afternoon the day before yesterday
[28 November] at about 1800 hours [1700 gmt].

If a source close to the operation is to be believed, a reliable news report
reached the security agencies about a terrorist presence in the neighbourhood.
The search made possible the discovery of a blockhouse set up in the basement of
a closed commercial premise located on the ground floor of an apartment located
on the sixth floor of building 58 opposite the headquarters of Bachdjarah's
Municipal People's Assembly [APC]. Two terrorists were allegedly expected by a
third party who was supposed to house them in that blockhouse but could not be
arrested.

The security agencies are pursuing their investigation to find the two
terrorists "who have been identified as being active terrorists," a security
source revealed to us.

The identifications of people and vehicles have been intensified in recent
months in the capital following news reports indicating that Abu Mus'ab Abd
al-Wadud's Salafi Group for Call and Combat [GSPC; the group now known as
Al-Qa'idah in the Land of the Islamic Maghreb, or AQLIM] is trying to commit a
dramatic attack in the capital city.

Faced with this situation, security measures have already been put in place in
the capital and its environs to deal with new suicide bomber attacks all the
more since the GSPC has not managed to redeploy itself in the wake of the heavy
losses sustained in its ranks. Several terrorist leaders have beenkilled, the
latest of whom was the ex-"amir" of zone 2 and the chief of the GSPC's military
commission, the man named Rachid Abdelmoumen, alias Hodeifa Abou Younes Assimi.

Beyond the reinforcement of policemen and security agents in plainclothes who
are criss-crossing the capital city's neighbourhoods, surveillance cameras have
started to be installed on the city's main arteries and in front of the main
public buildings.

Among the security measures that have been taken the giving to the police, at
each roadblock, of equipment to detect weapons or explosives can also be cited.
It has also been learned that vehicles equipped with explosives detectors are
also criss-crossing the capital to spot suspicious vehicles.

It would be appropriate to remind readers that since the start of the year the
security agencies have succeeded in breaking up more than five networks
providing support to the terrorists as well as the arrest of five terrorists to
the east of Algiers.

Maj-Gen Hamel, the director general for national security, had instructed his
elements to beef up the intelligence work in the fight against terrorism, which
"remains a priority." He declared that Algiers was safe from terrorist attacks.
In his first media appearance, he said he thought that the potential for a new
attack by the armed groups in the capital remained "very low."

He also defended the increase in the number of roadblocks and check points by
the security agencies in and around Algiers. "These roadblocks have been
studied. Some are part of the mechanism for fighting terrorism and cannot be
reduced," he had said.

Source: Liberte website, Algiers, in French 30 Nov 10

                              266 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                             East Grinstead Courier

                                December 2, 2010

Preparing for terror attacks

BYLINE: Gemma Angell

SECTION: Pg. 13

LENGTH: 294 words


Surrey Police are helping hotels guard against the threat of terrorism.

A workshop is being held at the Lingfield Park Marriott Hotel, on Racecourse
Road, to teach managers how to prepare for and prevent a terrorist attack.

Bob Stephens, head of Surrey Police's Counter Terrorism Security Office, said:
"The UK is recognised to be a target for terrorists.

"The question is not if but where and when, and the managers of businesses like
hotels, where many people gather, must be prepared."

Surrey's close proximity to London means it is seen as being at particular risk
of an attack, especially as the national threat of terrorism remains at
"severe".

Hotels are seen as an attractive and soft target for terrorists, which is why
the course is being held.

Mr Stephens added: "Everyone in Surrey, whether a resident, visitor or employee,
can help us maintain the freedoms which we value, by being vigilant.

"Recognise suspicious behaviour and if anything appears unusual or  odd, report
it. Look for people behaving in a manner which is out of place for the time or
location."

At the Marriott Hotel workshop a simulated attack will be carried out to see how
those who attend the workshop cope.

It is one of a number of workshops, going under the name Project Argus and
organised with the help of the National Counter Terrorism Security Office, which
are being held across the county.

Mr Stephens added: "Project Argus is an excellent opportunity to judge how well
prepared your business is, increase your knowledge of terrorist issues, compare
notes with other local hotels, or just a chance for you and selected staff to
experience a well-run security exercise."

The Marriott Hotel workshop takes place on Thursday, December 16 from 10am.

For more information call 01342 830930.

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                            December 3, 2010 Friday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

US facing attack from home-grown terrorists

BYLINE: Alex Spillius

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 563 words


THE sheer volume of terrorist plots against the United States means that the
country will become unable to prevent a fatal attack by a new breed of
extremists radicalised in America's towns and cities, the country's leading
counterterrorism official has warned.

In unusually candid remarks, Michael Leiter, the director of the National
Counterterrorism Centre, said that the nation's defences probably would be
breached by a home-grown radical, after a yearlong period containing several
failed or thwarted attacks that had seen the most intense terrorist activity
since September 11, 2001.

"Although we aim for perfection, perfection will not be achieved. Just like any
other endeavour, we will not stop all the attacks," he said.

"If there is an attack, it may well be tragic. Innocent lives will be lost. But
we still have to be honest, and we have to be honest that some things will get
through.

"To say that we will not successfully defend against all attacks is certainly
not to say that we are not trying to stop all attacks. We are."

The FBI last week arrested Mohamed Osman Mohamud, a 19-year-old Somali-born
American, for plotting to detonate a bomb as thousands of people attended the
lighting of the Christmas tree in the centre of Portland, Oregon.

Speaking at the Centre for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, Mr
Leiter, who advises the US government on the terrorist threat, said: "In this
era of a more complicated threat, a more diverse threat and lower-scale attacks
to include individuals who have been radicalised here in the homeland, stopping
all the attacks has become that much harder."

The threat has risen in part because of the increased involvement of the
Yemen-based al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, and Anwar al-Awlaki, an
Americanborn radical cleric.

Known as AQAP, it has pursued smaller attacks perpetrated by lone operators
which have complicated the challenges facing the US security services still
battling the threat of another attack on the scale of September 11.

AQAP and Al-Awlaki, now living in Yemen, have been linked to Major Nidal Hasan,
an army psychiatrist accused of killing 13 people during a shooting spree at
Fort Hood, Texas, in November, 2009, and to Umar Farouk Abdul-Mutallab, the
Nigerian student sus-pected of the failed attempt to blow up a flight headed for
Detroit last Christmas.

Conceding that the anti-terrorist services had made errors under President
Barack Obama, particularly in the Christmas plot, Mr Leiter asserted that hard
work played a part in bringing about what critics have called lucky outcomes. He
said neither Republicans nor Democrats should claim they had all the answers in
protecting the country.

Offering some positive news, he said that the threat of a catastrophic attack on
the US planned by the traditional al-Qaeda leadership had diminished, along with
the likelihood of a chemical, biological or radiological attack.

In reacting to the next attack America should avoid talk of a clash of
civilisations between the West and Islam that merely fed al-Qaeda's propaganda,
and should avoid portraying terrorists as all-powerful.

"We should not assume that the terrorists are 10 feet tall. The fact that they
get through at times in a relatively free and open society does not mean that
they are all-powerful," he said.

"We have to be taller than them. We have to be more resilient than them."

LOAD-DATE: December 3, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: DTL

SHERIDAN QUIZZES COP OVER 'TERRORIST' GAIL;
tommy on attack over jibes

BYLINE: GRANT MCCABE

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 317 words


SEX scandal politician Tommy Sheridan yesterday claimed cops accused his wife
Gail of "acting like a terrorist".

The former MSP also alleged the police's actions when they interviewed her over
perjury charges could have been linked to her religious faith.

Sheridan's claims came as he was formally acquitted of trying to persuade a
witness to commit perjury.

The Crown also dropped several allegations against his wife.

Swingers Former SSP leader Sheridan is conducting his own defence at his trial
for perjury at the High Court in Glasgow.

He and his wife, both 46, deny lying under oath during his successful defamation
action against the News Of The World in 2006.

The action followed the paper's claims that Sheridan was an adulterer who
visited swingers' clubs.

He won £200,000 in damages after the newspaper printed allegations about his
private life.

Yesterday, the jury was told that Gail was likened to a terrorist after a raid
on the couple's home in Glasgow. One officer, Detective Sergeant Stuart
Harkness, was quizzed by Sheridan over the interviews he conducted with Gail.

The witness was asked: "Did you seek to harass and intimidate my wife?" Harkness
replied: "Not at all." Sheridan asked: "Why did you suggest that she was then
acting like a terrorist?" DS Harkness, who had previously been involved in a
terrorism inquiry, said: "She was failing to engage at all. She did not look at
us.

"Focusing on something else is a technique used by people in that regard."

Sheridan said: "So when a suspect takes up their right to remain silent, you
think it is all right to suggest they are acting like a terrorist?" The
detective said: "It is one thing to remain silent, it is another not to engage."

Sheridan asked: "Was it because she was a practising Catholic and you accused
her of acting like a Provisional IRA terrorist?" DS Harkness replied: "Not at
all." The case continues.

                                   The Mirror

                            December 3, 2010 Friday
                                 Ulster Edition

OFF THE STREETS;
150 PSNI OFFICERS MOVED TO GUARD STATIONS FROM TERRORIST ATTACKS

BYLINE: DAVID YOUNG

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 525 words


A TOTAL of 150 front-line officers will be redeployed to guard police stations
against dissident republican attacks.

They will fill posts left by departing fulltime reservists.

Chief Constable Matt Baggott said no neighbourhood policemen or women would be
moved to guard stations and personnel but conceded officers in response units
would be repositioned.

The move comes after the Policing Board rejected the Chief Constable's proposal
earlier this year to employ private security firms to perform functions carried
out by the Full Time Reserve.

The Reserve is being disbanded in line with policing reforms next March.

Some members reacted angrily with calls for officers on backroom duties to act
as guards instead.

The police are involved in an ongoing drive to move deskbound officers on to the
streets and in the past year almost 600 went back on the beat full-time.

Mr Baggott said: "At the end of March we will have a number of people leaving us
on severance and some of those are doing guarding functions.

"It's clearly right I have to make sure our police stations and our people are
protected. So some of those police officers we've got out there will move back
into those duties.

"Let me be clear about this - we are carrying out reform relentlessly, there are
more police officers I want to move from administ r a t i v e jobs back on to
the street."

He hoped that ongoing negotiations over the PSNI budget would result in his
being able to move more officers onto the front line.

The DUP's Jimmy Spratt, who supported the chief's proposal on security firms,
said the board only had itself to blame for the development.

He added: "I am astounded these officers are being taken off front-line duties.
It's unthinkable that any officers would be removed from response [duties] but
that seems to be what the Chief Constable is indicating.

"The Chief Constable came to the board a number of months ago with a very good
suggestion in relation to armed g u a r d s which would have been much cheaper,
much more cost-effective in every way - the board failed to support that.

"I have to say shame on the board. Now we have a problem and we are taking a
step back as a result and we're losing front-line police officers and the public
will not thank anybody in relation to front-line police officers going off."

But Sinn Fein's Alex Maskey, who opposed hiring security guards, said officers
working on desk jobs could fill the posts without having to cut the front-line
service.

He added: "I was surprised to hear the Chief Constable indicate he could be
reducing the number of officers on the front line.

"Certainly I would not be happy. A commitment was made by this Chief Constable
just months ago that he would be continually working to take officers away from
deskbound duties to put them on the front line working with the community.

"We do see evidence of some growing confidence within some communities and that
primarily is because there are more police officers working within communities
responding more quickly to complaints.

"It obviously flies in the face of trying to build that confidence for the
police service that you would then take officers away."

                            South Wales Evening Post

                            December 3, 2010 Friday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

MEDIC'S TALIBAN AMBUSH TERROR;
ATTACK 'WAS LIKE SCENE FROM THE MATRIX' 'Ambush like scenes from film'

BYLINE: LIZ PERKINS

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1,2

LENGTH: 501 words


A HIGH-RANKING officer has told of the terrifying moment he and his medical team
were ambushed by the Taliban as they tried to rescue casualties.

Lieutenant Colonel Rhys Thomas compared the harrowing situation as "like scenes
from the Matrix".

"We knew we were going to get into harm's way in Nad-e-Ali after being tasked to
retrieve casualties and resupply the patrol base," he said.

"When we left we had 15 seriously injured casualties on board and two
fatalities.

"It was like something from the Matrix when we were coming under fire.

"Afterwards we found out there was a bullet in the gear box of the Chinook."

Lieutenant Colonel Thomas, who is dad to one-year-old Llew, said his wife Sarah,
aged 35, who is a GP in the Army, had some concerns about his job.

He said: "My wife is proud of the work that I do but understandably is anxious
due to the danger involved."

The 39-year-old, from Llandeilo, who is a consultant anaesthetist at Camp
Bastion's field hospital, also works as part of the medical emergency response
team (Mert) - which is like an airborne critical care department.

The attack happened while he and a team of paramedics and a nurse were in flight
on a Chinook above Nad-e-Ali, in Afghanistan.

Lieutenant Colonel Thomas said the medical team were "remarkably unscathed"
following the incident.

"I don't normally smoke but I had a couple of cigarettes that day," he added.

He said the attack happened when Nad-e-Ali was "unchartered territory" as
British troops had only recently explored the area.

He said despite being in the Army for 12 years, after going to Sandhurst, he
felt a "huge" sense of pride and responsibility leading the team.

"You have so many pressures on you," he added.

"Medically it's the most challenging job in the world - we have never been asked
to do so much in so . little time, which is difficult enough without having
people trying to kill you when are doing this work. "It helps to be professional
- you think about it only when you get home." It is the fourth time the
lieutenant colonel has been out to Afghanistan and the second time this year.
The consultant anaesthetist, who is usually based with 16 Air Assault Brigade
said much had changed in trauma resuscitation since he arrived in Afghanistan.
"We didn't go to Bastion until 2006 - we were based just to the north of Kabul
in Bagram," he said. Best "The field hospital was just a tent - the whole
hospital had 60 people working there but it's got around 400 staff now. "It was
nothing like it is now - we probably saw five casualties a day but there were a
lot less forces in the country then. "British military are leading the world in
how we resuscitate and treat our casualties - this could only have been brought
about by our experiences learned in Afghanistan." Lieutenant Colonel Thomas
described the facility at Camp Bastion as "the best and busiest trauma hospital
in the world" and said "it was a great honour to be involved in providing the
care to our brave troops." ? elizabeth.perkins@swwmedia.co.uk

LOAD-DATE: December 3, 2010

Crime probe body says five held for role in Pakistan's Lahore terror attacks

LENGTH: 450 words


Text of report headlined "Five held for attacks on ISI HQ" published by
Pakistani newspaper The News website on 4 December

Lahore: The Crime Investigation Agency (CIA) Lahore on Friday [4 December]
claimed to have arrested five terrorists involved in a terror attack on the
provincial headquarters of Inter Services Intelligence (ISI) and Police Rescue
15 building in 2009.

Addressing a press conference at Police Lines Qila Gujjar Singh, Capital City
Police Officer Lahore Haji Muhammad Aslam Tarin claimed that the terrorists,
belonging to India and Afghanistan, were involved in recent terror activities
carried out at different important places in various cities of Pakistan.

He said that a CIA team, headed by Deputy Superintendent of CIA's Anti-Terrorist
Staff Tariq Ilyas Kiani, had received a tip-off from a resident of Ravi Park,
Shahdara, about the hideout of some terrorists. He said the police team
immediately raided the place and arrested five terror suspects, including
Sarfraz Ahmed, Shabbir Ahmed alias Hafiz Sahib, Umer Hayat alias Qari Ismail,
Hafiz Mahmood alias Abu Qasim and Abid Akram alias Malik Tufaan. Police also
recovered four explosive jackets, eight mortar bombs, 13 fused mortar bombs, one
hand grenade, 32 hand grenade pins, one pistol, one SMG rifle, one roll of
detonator card, 13 fake number plates and dozens of bullets from the possession
of the suspects.

The CCPO said that during preliminary interrogation, CIA officials came to know
that the terror suspects belonged to Al-Tauheed Wal-Jihad Group of
Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP). The group was earlier led by Doctor Umer Kundi,
he said, adding that the accused were well-trained and they had completed their
training at Data Khail, Waziristan.

Mr Tarin said the terrorists had confessed to carrying out terrorist attack on
15/ISI office, adding that they had also confessed to their involvement in
different heinous crimes, including kidnapping for ransom, robbery, dacoity,
dacoity-cum-murder, vehicle lifting and street crime.

While giving details of 15/ISI attack, the CCPO said that according to the
arrested terrorists, the plan was hatched by Umer Kundi who had further ordered
Abid Akram alias Malik Tufaan to get the details of 15/ISI office. He said Abid
Akram also collected funds for carrying out the attack and on May 29, 2009, he
handed over the van used in attack to Yahya, Ali and Idrees, who reached the
target from the Fatima Jinnah Road. Three other terrorists, namely Imtiaz,
Sarfraz and Shabir, who reached the place on their own, provided cover to the
van by indiscriminate firing and later escaped along with Abid Akram from the
scene.

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 04 Dec 10

Shopkeeper in racial attack terror

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 211 words


POLICE were yesterday investigating a brutal racial attack on a shopkeeper.

The 28-year-old victim suffered a sickening tirade of abuse from two loudmouthed
neds.

When the Asian shopkeeper bravely faced up to the yobs outside his business, he
was attacked.

It is understood he was punched and kicked repeatedly about the head and body.

The nasty incident took place outside the new Poundbasket store in High Street,
Johnstone, shortly before 6pm on Friday, November 26.

The street was busy with traffic and shoppers when shouting erupted.

One shopper said she heard a rumpus and looked over towards the store, where a
couple of yobs were shouting and swearing at another man.

She said: "It was dark and I think I heard someone screaming disgusting words.
The shouts seemed to be racial and were directed at an Asian man.

"The Asian guy had another young man with him when the attack began.

"It was the older Asian who was attacked by two men, who were punching and
kicking him.

"It looked like a nasty incident to me." Police have confirmed they are treating
the incident as a "racial breach".

The victim did not have to go to hospital for treatment but suffered bruising.

Police said a man in his late teens was detained in connection with the
incident.

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            December 6, 2010 Monday

Belgian daily reveals more on plans on terror suspect's plans for attack

LENGTH: 764 words


Text of report by Belgian leading privately-owned newspaper De Standaard
website, on 6 December

[Report by Mark Eeckhaut: "Terrorists Targetted Jews, NATO or Sports Event"]

Brussels/Antwerp - Hassan H. from Antwerp is accused of plotting a terrorist
attack in Belgium from his computer. But the US Secret Service were tapping in.

Last Thursday [December 2] the Chechen Aslamblek L. (32) was arrested at Vienna
(Austria) airport. The Chechen, who many years ago lost both arms in the war
with the Russians, was returning with his wife and two children to their home in
Austria after a pilgrimage to Mecca.

L.'s arrest was the 13th to be made in connection with the Belgian judicial
inquiry into a network that was seeking to smuggle Muslim fighters to Chechnya
to combat the Russians. Aslamblek L. is believed to be a leading member of the
group, together with Isa A., a Chechen arrested in Antwerp 10 days ago.

The Federal Prosecutor's Office and Antwerp anti-terrorism investigators rounded
up most members of the group 10 days ago when they raided premises in Antwerp,
the Netherlands, and Germany.

Judicial sources say that the 13 arrests, eight of them in Belgium, result from
an inquiry originally made into one man: Hassan H., a young Moroccan Belgian
from Antwerp.

At the end of last year the US Secret Service intercepted the chat conversations
that Hassan H. conducted in private chat boxes on the extremist website Ansar Al
Mujahideen.

H. chatted with other extremists from Morocco and Saudi Arabia about his plan to
carry out an attack in Belgium. According to the Americans Hassan H. was
serious. The Saudi chatter even said he was prepared to finance the attack. "The
target was not yet decided., but H. had a couple of ideas for possible targets,"
judicial sources told De Standaard.

Among other things, Hassan H. said: "There are a number of places in Belgium
where Jews gather. They would be good places for an attack." Other potential
targets according to Hassan H. were "a train with NATO troops" or "an arbitrary
major sports event."

The US Secret Service passed on the information to colleagues in the countries
in question. In Saudi Arabia, Morocco, and Spain the "chatters," which included
the financier, were picked up on the street and held in custody.

The Belgian investigators were the only ones not to act immediately, first of
all because they did not see in the chat messages enough proof that Hassan H.
was genuinely intent on carrying out an attack. The anti-terrorism investigators
kept a close watch on the terrorist circles of Hassan H. in Antwerp and
monitored his daily comings and goings very closely, by telephone tapping among
other means.

Hassan H. is married with a young daughter and comes from a devout Moroccan
family living in Antwerp.

He and his two brothers, Driss and Asmani, seemed to have close contacts with
extremist Muslims, including some who attended the Bangladeshi mosque on the
Turnhoutsebaan in Borgerhout.

According to our information, the Belgian detectives were unable to find
concrete proof that Hassan H. continued with his plans to carry out an attack
after the arrest of his Internet colleagues.

But they did ascertain that along with a number of extremist Antwerp young
people, including three militants from the extremist group Sharia4Belgium, he
made concrete plans to go and fight in Chechnya.

The Antwerp Chechen Isa A. and the Austrian Aslambek L. planned their routes and
established contacts in Chechnya.

The plan was for the young Antwerp Muslims to go and fight for the rebel
movement Caucasian Emirate set up by rebel leader Doku Umarov.

The group wants to make the northern Caucasus, including Chechnya, an Islamic
republic in which Islamic law is applied and from where unbelievers would be
banned.

The fact that the organization was serious is confirmed by the fact the three
militants arrested in the Netherlands had already been intercepted a few weeks
ago in Turkey, reportedly on their way to Chechnya.

Tomorrow the eight will appear before the Council Chambers in Belgium. This must
decide whether or not they should be remanded in custody on suspicion of
membership of a terrorist organization.

Hassan H. and his two brothers Driss and Asmani are among the eight. A fourth
brother is in jail in Morocco in connection with another terrorism case.

Mohammed H., yet another brother, speaks of a serious misunderstanding. He told
De Standaard 10 days ago that "I know for certain that my brothers have nothing
to do with terrorist attacks. I know them don't I?"

Source: De Standaard website, Groot-Bijgaarden, in Dutch 6 Dec 10

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                            December 6, 2010 Monday
                                   Edition 3;
                                National Edition

Hundreds of 'targets for terror attacks' exposed;
SECURITY

BYLINE: Alex Spillius

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 453 words


THE United States has identified hundreds of sites around the world that it
fears could be targeted in terrorist attacks.

The list, released by WikiLeaks, includes a dozen sites in Britain, including
two telecommunications centres, several undersea communications cables, a
military manufacturing plant and a vaccine production centre.

A February 2009 State Department cable asked embassies around the world to
update a 2008 list of vital interests. Unlike most of the documents made
available by WikiLeaks so far, it was marked "secret".

Though most of the information was in the public domain, its release is likely
to lead to accusations that WikiLeaks did not care if it aided terrorists.

However, Kristinn Hrafnsson, a spokesman for the website, denied that the
information would be useful to radical groups. "While this cable details the
strategic importance of assets across the world, it does not give any
information as to their exact locations, security measures, vulnerabilities or
any similar factors - though it does reveal the US asked its diplomats to report
back on these matters," he said.

The release of the cable, part of a trove of 250,000 that the whistle-blowing
website says it has on file, is likely to infuriate Washington and intensify
apparent US efforts to stop the distribution of the leaked diplomatic cables.

Among the British sites mentioned is a facility manufacturing the vaccine for
foot and mouth disease run by BAE Systems in Lancashire, and the landing station
for the transatlantic Apollo undersea cable at Bude in Cornwall.

Sites in the Middle East included the shipping lanes of Djibouti, an import
terminal in Egypt, the Suez Canal and the oil terminal in Basra.

The list, the Critical Foreign Dependencies Initiative, divides the world into
six regions. It makes clear how the US depends on a range of substances from
smallpox vaccines in Denmark to bauxite in Guinea and liquefied natural gas in
the Middle East. It also includes the email and direct telephone numbers of two
State Department officials.

It makes clear that US military facilities and US government property are not to
be included in the survey, and that foreign governments should not be consulted.

It said: "Posts do not need to report government facilities overseas managed by
[the State Department] or war fighting facilities managed by other departments
or agencies."

WikiLeaks has been offering its archives for download through peer-to-peer
sharing, which allows any user around the world to post them or share them with
other users.

The files include previous WikiLeaks releases, such as information on US
military efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan, as well as the more than 800 US
diplomatic cables released so far.

LOAD-DATE: December 6, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: DTL


                  Copyright 2010 Telegraph Media Group Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                              277 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                   The Mirror

                            December 6, 2010 Monday
                                  Eire Edition

REAL LIFE JAWS;
TERROR AS TOURIST IS KILLED IN THIRD ATTACK

BYLINE: STEPHEN WHITE

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 634 words


A REAL-LIFE Jaws scare swept one of the world's most popular beach resorts
yesterday after a tourist was killed by a shark.

Trippers, including hundreds of Brits, were warned to stay out of the water
following the horrific attack at Sharm el Sheik in Egypt.

Panic spread as the mutilated body of a 70-year-old German woman was washed up
at the Red Sea hot-spot.

Her right arm was torn off and her thigh savaged while she was snorkeling.
Doctors say she died from a "catastrophic" loss of blood.

The tragedy came just days after four divers were badly injured in a spate of
similar attacks.

Rolf Schmid, manager of the Sinai Diver's Centre, said: "It is very unusual to
have so many incidents in such a short time."

"The latest attack happened in a shallow area called Middle Garden north of
Naama Bay, but no sharks have been reported anywhere around here for years."

Local authorities imposed a 48-hour ban on swimming last week after the divers -
three Russians and a Ukrainian - were injured by what is believed to be an
oceanic whitetip.

But just like in the Jaws movie, the death came soon after the beaches were
declared safe.

The shark, or sharks, bit off one diver's hand and caused severe leg and back
injuries to the others.

They were still recovering in hospital at Cairo last night.

The Egyptian Environment Ministry claimed two sharks suspected of attacking the
divers had been caught.

But marine experts insisted they were the wrong ones.

The Hurghada Environmental Protection and Conservation Association said photos
of the dead sharks did not match pictures of a predator taken before one of the
attacks.

A spokesman said: "They are clearly not the same fish."

He added that shark attacks were "extremely rare" and warned against randomly
catching and killing large oceanic sharks in the area.

The group said the recent attacks were probably carried out by a single rogue
shark which is still at large.

Some believe the killer has been drawn to the area after cattle and sheep being
brought in for last month's Islamic feast of Eid al-Adha, died at sea and were
thrown overboard.

The last recorded death from a shark in Egypt was in June 2009, when a French
woman was attacked while diving off the southern Red Sea coast.

In 2004, a shark attacked and killed a swimmer near Sharm el Sheikh. Now local
diving club members are helping to patrol beaches as security measures are
stepped up.

The scare is a major blow to tourism in the area, which attracts millions of
visitors from all over the world.

Beach holidays contribute around a third of Egypt's total income from tourism -
currently running at about EUR15billion a year.

Environmentalists claim the recent attacks are probably the result of the Red
Sea's declining ecosystem.

Hesham Gabar, head of the Egypt's Chamber of Diving and Water Sports. said the
number of sharks in the region has been steadily increasing because of
over-fishing.

He said they were being forced to feed closer to the shore.

9,000

Number of British people in Sharm el Sheikh every day. The local population is
only 35,000.

Horror just like the film

THE shark attacks at Sharm el Sheikh chillingly echo Steven Spielberg's classic
movie Jaws.

Just like in the 1975 film, set on Amity island and starring Roy Scheider as
police chief Martin Brody, the beaches were closed to swimmers after the initial
strike - then quickly re-opened by local officials who insisted they were safe.

And, like the movie, they believed the scare was over when local fishermen went
on a hunting spree and killed the shark they believed was responsible.

In the film marine biologist Matt Hooper - played by Richard Dreyfuss - says it
is the wrong species and the real killer is still on the loose.

In Sharm el Sheik yesterday, many also believe they've got the wrong one - and
are praying there won't be a sequel.

LOAD-DATE: December 6, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

FEARSOME Shark caught by local fishermen, but some believe it is not the right
one

                    BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political

                            December 7, 2010 Tuesday

Terrorist plans to attack foreigners in Sumatra "foiled" - Indonesian official

LENGTH: 426 words


Text of report in English by Malaysian newspaper The Star website on 7 December

[Report by Amy Chew From the "Nation" Page: "Assassination Plan Foiled"]

PETALING JAYA: Terrorist plans to attack foreigners in Sumatra, including
assassinating American executives of a giant oil company, have been foiled with
the arrest of a suspected Indonesian militant in Malaysia.

Fadli Sadama, 27, was nabbed on Oct 13 while travelling in a bus to Johor. He
was deported back to Jakarta last Saturday under heavy guard.

Sadama had allegedly planned to assassinate oil executives working for PT
Chevron Pacific Oil company in Pekanbaru, capital of the oil-rich province of
Riau.

"He (Sadama) planned to kill American executives of Caltex (now renamed Chevron)
by shooting them," Petrus Golose, director of the Indonesian National
Anti-Terror Agency (BNPT), told The Star in a telephone interview from Jakarta.

He said Sadama also planned to shoot foreign tourists travelling in small boats
to the active volcano Anak Krakatau or Child of Krakatau.

(Anak Krakatau was formed on the site of the historic 1883 blast of Krakatau
volcano and is located in the Sunda Straits between Sumatra and West Java.)

Golose said Sadama was a member of the Indonesian Mujahidin Group (KMI) and was
recruited by convicted Indonesian terrorist Toni Togar, who is serving a 20-year
jail sentence for his role in the J.W. Marriot bomb blast in 2003.

KMI was set up and headed by Togar while he was behind bars at the Pematang
Siantar penintentiary in North Sumatra.

Sadama, a loyal supporter of Togar, was planning to free him from the
penitentiary.

"He plotted to kidnap the chief prison warden of Pematang Siantar to be used as
a barter to free Togar," said Golose.

"If Sadama and his group succeeded in freeing Togar, they planned to go to
southern Thailand to train with the separatist Pattani United Liberation
Organization," he said.

Togar has since been moved to the maximum security prison island of Nusa
Kembangan in Central Java.

Police said Sadama had been the field operator of KMI since 2008 and believed to
have "a few people" in Malaysia and Thailand who provided safe houses for him
when he escaped a police dragnet after allegedly robbing CIMB Niaga Bank in
Medan on Aug 18.

"He flew on Wings Air to Malaysia from Medan on Sept 18, a month after the bank
robbery," said Golose.

He said the Indonesian police was grateful to the Malaysian police for their
help and cooperation in arresting Sadama, which helped prevent the terror
attacks.

Source: The Star website, Kuala Lumpur, in English 7 Dec 10

President says Georgia averted "very serious terrorist attacks"

LENGTH: 243 words


Georgian President Mikheil Saakashvili has said Georgia averted "very serious
terrorist attacks" by arresting six persons in connection with several
explosions across Georgia in September-November 2010.

On 7 December the Georgian Interior Ministry said the six had been operating
from breakaway Abkhazia and taking orders from a Russian military officer based
in Abkhazia.

"Georgian police have arrested a group of persons suspected of perpetrating a
very dangerous crime. They are accused of perpetrating several very dangerous
actions, specifically: explosions on Georgia's railway, in the vicinity of the
US embassy and also, a short time ago, near the office of a political party that
killed a person," Saakashvili said, speaking to TV cameras on the tarmac of the
Batumi airport in remarks broadcast by Rustavi-2 TV on 7 December.

"All evidence our law-enforcers have indicates that these persons were acting
from the occupied territory [Abkhazia]. As a result of their arrest, and judging
from the materials that were seized and the current preliminary versions and
speculation - though of course all of this must be proved in court - we have
thwarted some very serious terrorist attacks that had been prepared and for
which they had received instructions and explosive materials. I want to thank
our agencies, our police, for their efficient reaction. I want to call on them
to work even harder."

Source: Rustavi-2 TV, Tbilisi, in Georgian 1100gmt 07 Dec 10

                            December 7, 2010 Tuesday

Georgia arrests six for staging "terrorist attacks" allegedly planned by Russia

LENGTH: 294 words


Deputy Interior Minister Eka Zghuladze has said that the ministry has arrested
six people in connection with "terrorist attacks" staged in Georgia between
September and November 2010, the private Georgian Imedi TV reported on 7
December. Zghuladze also alleged that a Russian officer based in Abkhazia may
have planned the blasts.

"On behalf of the ministry I would like to inform you that the terrorist attacks
staged between September and November have been solved. Specifically, [the
blasts] that occurred on 22 September near the US Embassy in Georgia, on 21
October at the Tbilisi railway station, on 2 October at the Chaladidi railway
bridge in Khobi District, on 28 November on Noneshvili street in the Mukhiani
First Micro District [in Tbilisi] and a terrorist attack staged on the same day
near the central office of the [opposition] Labour Party, which unfortunately
killed Ms Nino Gordezia. On 4 December, the Georgian Interior Ministry detained
Gogita Arkania, who is suspected of physically perpetrating the blast, and five
accomplices," Georgian Deputy Interior Minister Eka Zghuladze said at a special
news conference carried live by the channel.

She went on to quote Gogita Arkania, a resident of breakaway Abkhazia's Gali
District, as saying that he was tasked to perpetrate the aforementioned
assignments by an "officer of the Russian armed forces" stationed in Abkhazia
who supplied him with explosive devices and money.

Zghuladze also alleged that it was established that, before and after every
blast, the Russian officer was briefed about the preparation and conduct of the
blasts by phone and that the phone number used by the Russian officer was
registered to the Russian Defence Ministry.

Source: Imedi TV, Tbilisi, in Georgian 0900 gmt 7 Dec 10

                           December 8, 2010 Wednesday

Terrorist attacks in Russia's North Caucasus double in 2010 - official

LENGTH: 264 words


Excerpt from report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Vladikavkaz, 8 December: Since the beginning of this year, the number of
terrorist attacks in the North Caucasus Federal District [NCFD] has increased by
100 per cent, [Deputy Prosecutor-General] Ivan Sydoruk said at an interagency
meeting of the NCFD law-enforcement agencies in Vladikavkaz on Wednesday [8
December].

"The number of terrorist attacks has increased by 100 per cent, this is the
reality today, and today we are gathered here to work out additional measures to
address the existing problems in this sphere," Sydoruk said.

He also noted that so far in 2010 over 30 counter-terrorism operations were
carried out in which more than 300 militants were neutralized. "In the 10
months, more than 3,000 crimes related to illegal circulation of arms have been
registered in the region. The number of attacks on employees of law-enforcement
agencies and military personnel has reached 529 in the current year, as a result
of which 218 people were killed and 536 people received wounds of varying
severity," Sydoruk said.

"In the same period, 1,665 firearms, 91,846 rounds of ammunition, more than
1,200 kg of explosives and more than 110 explosive devices have been seized,"
Sydoruk said.

[Passage omitted: Sydoruk said prevention measures remain ineffective.]

According to him, arms and ammunition are being supplied to Russia from Georgia
and Azerbaijan.

[Passage omitted: Sydoruk said there were some violations in the work of
law-enforcement agencies.]

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0949 gmt 8 Dec 10

                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political

                           December 8, 2010 Wednesday

Jerusalem neighbourhood Jews say Palestinians attempted "major terror attack"

LENGTH: 479 words


Text of report in English by Israeli settlers' Arutz 7 Radio website on 7
December

[Report by El'ad Benari: "Was Gas Attack Averted in French Hill?"]

Several days ago, residents of Jerusalem's French Hill neighbourhood felt a
strong odour of gas throughout the neighbourhood. Upon inspection they
discovered that Arab residents of the nearby Isawiya neighbourhood cut their gas
pipes, which caused the strong smell. The residents of French Hill are now
convinced that the Arabs planned a major terror attack which was averted only by
a miracle.

On Monday, Arutz Sheva's daily journal spoke with French Hill resident Shosh
Shochat, who represents the neighbourhood during meetings with the authorities.
According to Shochat, "We sat in our house on Motzei Shabbat when we suddenly we
smelled gas and heard the sound of a pipe exploding. We went outside and found
more neighbours who smelled the same thing. It turned out that someone cut the
pipes. We tried closing the gas taps but they were rotten and wouldn't close."

Shochat pointed out that Jerusalem Police and firefighters were quick to arrive
on the scene, but gas company employees did not arrive until three days later.
She added that an investigation the same evening found that 250 families had
their pipes cut.

According to Shochat, this is not just vandalism but another incident in a
series of incidents of terrorism which originate in the nearby Isawiya
neighbourhood.

"They set fire to natural growth," said Shochat. "Throughout the summer there
were fires here, some of them posing a risk to homes. They break windows, damage
public gardens, harass, steal from yards and roam around freely."

She added that now, residents do not allow Jewish boys and girls to walk freely
around the neighbourhood in the evening for fear of attacks. "They come at
night, do what they do, and immediately go the paths to Isawiya."

Just two months ago, a Jewish resident of Jerusalem was attacked in Isawiya.
Baruch Pruss, who works as a repairman, was viciously attacked in the
neighbourhood by Arabs who threw concrete blocks and huge stones towards him. He
only managed to escape the attack thanks to help from older Arabs living in the
area who helped him leave.

"If they've decided to abandon us and return us to the Palestinian [National]
Authority, then [Jerusalem Mayor] Nir Barkat should get up and say it openly:
'We've decided to give you to Abbas'. Then we'll confront him," said Shochat.

She described an intolerable reality in which people who recognize a thief or a
burglar prefer not to confront him for fear of violence, and give up on
contacting the authorities since they are "tired of bureaucracy," as she put it.

"We have become a place of terror," said Shochat and wondered if she as a Jew
would be allowed to wander freely in the streets of Isawiya.

Source: Arutz 7 Radio website, Bet El (West Bank), in English 7 Dec 10

Shop yobs attack worker in raid terror

BYLINE: WFnode

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 147 words


YOUNG thugs left a shop worker with serious facial injuries after a botched
robbery.

Two teenagers attacked the 48-year-old man at the store on Wood Street, in
Middleton after they failed to open the till.

The victim suffered a ruptured eye socket and suspected broken cheek when he was
knocked into a shelf.

He was taken to hospital after the incident, at around 6pm on Tuesday, November
30.

The attackers were aged around 16 to 17, white, and had local accents.

Det Con Russ Clarke said: I would ask anyone who saw anything suspicious in the
area around 6pm or if you saw the offenders going into or leaving the shop to
please get in touch.

We are treating this as an isolated incident but would like to remind all shop
owners to be extra vigilant during the lead up to Christmas.

Anyone with information is urged to call police on 0161 856 8581 or
Crimestoppers, anonymously, on 0800 555 111

                            December 10, 2010 Friday

Pakistan minister says terror attacks likely during Muharram

LENGTH: 382 words


Text of report by staff correspondent headlined "Terror threats in Muharram
exist: Malik" published by Pakistani newspaper The News website on 10 December

Islamabad: Interior Minister Rehman Malik has said that threats of terrorist
attacks are there in the holy month of Muharram and all measures will be taken
to avert the same.

Talking to the media here at the National Police Academy after a meeting of
board of governors on Thursday, he said the government was taking measures to
eliminate corruption from society and nobody would be spared in this regard. He
urged the media to help the government in its anti-corruption drive.

To a question, he said Brahamdagh Bugti was in Kabul and had applied for taking
political asylum in some countries, but 'we have conveyed our reservations in
this regard'. He said the premier announced the Balochistan package for the
province to remove backwardness of the Baloch people, adding Prime Minister
Gillani had asked him to visit Balochistan and review the implementation of the
package.

He said he would soon visit the province and spend some days there to review
progress on the package. He said academic and training courses of police
officials needed to be revised. He said police officials, who would complete
their training from the academy, would be awarded master's degree and sent
abroad for further training. "We are in contact with the Quaid-e-Azam University
for the award of master's degree to successful police officials," he said,
adding the syllabus and duration of classes would be changed and revised in line
with modern and international standards.

He said human rights, children protection, anti-terrorist courses and other
similar topics would be added in revised syllabus. Malik said the academy was
facing shortage of professional teachers.

"It has been decided in the meeting that police officials will be sent abroad
for 15-day training on the completion of their courses from the academy," the
minister said, adding training would be made mandatory for promotion of police
officials.

He said the recruitment in Islamabad police was stopped after complaints of
irregularities in recruitment process, adding the process would soon be
initiated and completed purely on merit.

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 10 Dec 10

CAMILLA ATTACK TERROR;
ROYAL LIMO SMASHED UP BY YOBS AS 20,000 PROTEST OVER FEES VOTE

BYLINE: ADRIAN SHAW

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 110 words


CAMILLA gasps in horror as yobs attack her and Prince Charles's car after
student protests descended into violent mayhem last night.

The royal couple sat terrified as their Rolls-Royce was kicked, pelted with
objects, shaken from side to side and splattered with paint.

Camilla began to cry and clasped Charles's hand as masked thugs surged past
police outriders, smashed a window and tried to overturn the limo.

The attack came after 20,000 protesters paralysed London as ConDem MPs voted to
triple tuition fees to pounds 9,000 a year.

Rioters vandalised Westminster in running battles with police that left 55
people injured including 12 officers.

CAMILLA ATTACK TERROR;
ROYAL LIMO SMASHED UP BY YOBS AS 20,000 PROTEST OVER FEES VOTE

BYLINE: ADRIAN SHAW

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1,4

LENGTH: 267 words


CAMILLA gasps in horror as yobs attack her and Prince Charles's car after
student protests descended into violent mayhem last night.

The royal couple sat terrified as their Rolls-Royce was kicked, pelted with
objects, shaken from side to side and splattered with paint.

Camilla began to cry and clasped Charles's hand as 1,000 thugs surged past
police outriders, smashed a window and tried to overturn the limo.

The attack came after 20,000 students paralysed London in a huge demo as MPs
voted to triple tuition fees.

Student Matthew Brown said: "Charles and Camilla were waving and smiling as they
drove to the Royal Variety show. A security car tried to get through protesters
who shouted 'you can't knock people down!' "

It was then protesters began kicking and shaking the limousine and pelting it
with objects and eggs.

Matthew added: "Charles and Camilla looked shaken and really worried. He leaned
to his driver with panic on his face as if he was telling him to get out of
there fast.

"The car accelerated and was able to speed off." Charles and Camilla were
"unharmed" but looked shaken as they arrivedthe Palladium to meet stars
including Kylie Minogue and Take That. Witness Kather in a was able to speed
off."

Chaffey, 17, said: "There were 100s of protesters on Regent Street and when they
saw the police escort everyone started getting something to throw.

"Someone yelled 'It's Charles and Camilla!' and they threw bins in the road to
stop the car."

PM David Cameron last night. said the attack was "shocking and regrettable".
Police made 22 arrests. Six officers and 43 protesters were in hospital.

                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           December 11, 2010 Saturday

Algerian army kills 12 Al-Qa'idah terrorists in "major" attack

LENGTH: 446 words


Algerian army forces, on 10 December, killed no less than 12 Al-Qa'idah
terrorists in the Sidi Ali Bou Nab forest in Tizi Ouzou, and destroyed 15
hideouts in a "major" military offensive launched on 9 December and handled
jointly with a unit from the special forces, privately-owned Algerian newspaper
El-Khabar website reported on 11 December.

The offensive was in response to a tip-off by family members of a number of
terrorists keen on benefiting from the reconciliation law. Parallel to a move to
disable mobile phone networks to prevent terrorist from remote detonation of
explosives, the joint security forces began intensive shelling, while blocking
all entry/exist points to the forests of Douar Sidi Ali Bou Nab, Mezrana and
Yakouren, El-Khabar reported.

The size of the army force and the weaponry used indicate that the joint
security forces were acting upon accurate information about the whereabouts of
the terrorist groups, El-Khabar reported.

Sources in the area are quoted as saying that heavy artillery and helicopters
were used to comb the forests. And, according to local sources, the offensive is
being run by high-ranking army officers, who had been drafted specifically for
this purpose.

There has been no accurate information on the preliminary toll of this
offensive. However, news circulating say that the army had been besieging a
"dangerous terrorist group" in the Douar Sidi Ali Bou Nab forest, El-Khabar
reported.

Algerian newspaper Al-Fadjr website, on 11 December, covered the same story and
spoke of the killing of seven terrorists and the wounding of 15 others. The
paper said that no less than 5,000 soldiers have been deployed to fight
"remnants" of terrorist groups trying to target public institutions and
defenceless people.

Al-Fadj also said that "the offensive was in response to information confirming
the infiltration to the area of 50 terrorists, including five emirs, in an
attempt to hold a secret conference following the killing of the most prominent
leaders of the terrorist organization by various security forces. The source
also said that the [planned] meeting was supposed to be devoted to the
appointment of a number of new emirs in replacement of those killed."

On 10 December, Qatari Al-Jazeera TV's "Maghreb Harvest" programme said that the
leader of Al-Qa'idah in the Land of the Islamic Maghreb (AQLIM), Abdelmalek
Droukdel, may have been among the 12 terrorists killed in the offensive.

Both Algerian newspapers make no specific reference to Abdelmalek Droukdel.

Source: El-Khabar website, Algiers, in Arabic 11 Dec 10; Al-Fadjr website,
Algiers, in Arabic 11 Dec 10; l-Jazeera TV, Doha, in Arabic 2100 gmt 10 Dec 10

LOAD-DATE: December 11, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2010 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved

                              288 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                                The Western Mail

                           December 11, 2010 Saturday
                                 First Edition

Prince and Camilla exposed to 'serious terrorism threat' bydemonstration clash ;

ATTACKONROYALCAR'MUST BESEENASTERRORWARNING' demonstration clash

BYLINE: SION MORGAN

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 1260 words


POLICE and protection officers charged with safeguarding some of Britain's most
high profile figures are clearly unprepared, security experts said yesterday.

The ease with which a group of seemingly unorganised students attacked a
Rolls-Royce containing Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall would have
sent messages to would-be attackers all over the world, they said.

The image of a horrified Camilla in the back of the royal limousine will be the
defining image of this week's student protests against rises in tuition fees.

The attack, in which the car was doused in paint and a window shattered, has
raised serious questions about royal security,which was breached with apparent
ease by demonstrators on London's Regent Street.

There were calls yesterday for a full independent inquiry into the incident.

International security expert and former senior instructor at the Royal Military
Academy in Sandhurst, Dr Paul Moorcraft, described the incident as a "major
mistake".

"Had it been al-Qaeda it would not have been too difficult for a terrorist to
approach the vehicle with a revolver and unleash three or four rounds into the
car," the former Cardiff University professor said.

"I suppose it maybe demonstrated a touch of arrogance from the Met. There is
maybe a feeling that the Royal Family are untouchable. It was certainly a severe
security breach which exposed a serious terrorism threat. It must be viewed as a
warning."

Secret services expert Gordon Thomas, author of Inside British Intelligence: 100
years of MI5 and MI6, said: "It was a very serious attack, you could see that
just from the shock in the eyes of Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall.

"And don't underestimate the force it took to break one of the car's bulletproof
windows - their aim was clear, to cause harm."

Mr Thomas, from Ammanford, added: "The issue here is police protection and the
effectiveness of the police.

"Yes, officers might be wonderful at blowing their whistles and directing royal
cars through the busy London streets but it is clear that when it comes to their
real role of protection they are not adequately prepared.

"I don't think we want to reach the stage where, like with President Obama, we
see a fleet of huge vehicles surrounded by security, but the issue of police
protection must be addressed.

"Of course it sends out a message to people, to terrorists.

"We all know that they [the royal couple] are in Clarence House, and yesterday
we knew they were travelling to the Royal Variety Performance, for heaven's
sake. It doesn't take any intelligence to work that out so of course incidents
like this send clues to terrorists."

Yesterday, Prime Minister David Cameron told MPs he was "very concerned" about
the "very regrettable" security lapse and said Met Commissioner Sir Paul
Stephenson would report on it.

Sir Paul signalled a "full criminal investigation" to identify those who
threatened the couple and damaged the car.

But Tory backbencher Mark Pritchard insisted the incident could not be left to
an internal Scotland Yard investigation.

Armed royal protection officers were guarding Charles and Camilla when their car
was attacked, Sir Paul said yesterday, adding that the route used by the royal
Rolls-Royce had been "thoroughly recce'd" minutes before the incident.

Sir Paul said the armed officers showed "enormous restraint" during the attack.
"I think what you have to remember is the unpredictability of those, I was going
to call them demonstrators, but these thugs, in the way in which they were
moving around London," he said.

"I do think that the officers who were protecting Their Royal Highnesses showed
very real restraint - some of those officers were armed.

"Their priority was to get that car to the point of safety, which was the venue,
and that was achieved, but it was a hugely shocking incident and there will be a
full criminal investigation into it."

AWelsh member of the Royal Military Police, currently serving as a close
protection officer and used to providing security for international dignitaries,
also defended the officers.

The officer, who wished to remain anonymous to protect his identity, told the
Western Mail: "I think the Royal Protection Force did a good job considering all
the factors.

"Our role is to provide protection so that the royals can do their job. This is
not America, we don't run alongside the cars, what we do is far more covert.

"All our actions are reactions to something else. Yesterday, if someone would
have tried to enter the car then we would have reacted differently.

"Once it was clear the vehicle was being damaged a cordon was created and the
car was able to move through to its destination.

"The only debatable decision was the route the car took.

"Normally it would be planned and checked but from what I have heard from
colleagues, the protestors were moving at such a fast pace there was no way of
reacting in time.

"In any scenario like that an assessment would have been made and in this case
the right call was made."

However, others continued to question the standard of protection yesterday.

Security analyst and former police officer Charles Shoebridge said: "This is a
very serious incident. It ranks amongst the most serious security breaches of
the past decade. Some of the demonstrators yesterday were carrying petrol,
specifically to use in arson attacks. If the can of paint had been a can of
petrol, it would have been very different."

The former intelligence officer, with experience of public order policing, said:
"One can visualise a situation where police felt they had no alternative but to
open fire. It wasn't potentially dangerous. It was dangerous.

"The police will need to look at this in great detail. They need a rapid and
robust investigation to identify how it could have happened.

"The best means of preventing a subject being attacked is to keep him out of
harm's way in the first place."

He said royal protection involved preparation in terms of intelligence and
reconnaissance and in this case "even the general public could have realised"
there were potential problems.

He said Sir Paul should "admit that the police got it wrong" in using the route.

"There were thousands of police on duty so there shouldn't have been a problem
with information.

They could have put an alternative plan into effect, an alternative route. But
they continued to blunder into the demonstration itself.

"This incident raises a question over whether some of the people in positions of
responsibility are the right people for the job. It raises questions of
communication, of proper risk assessment and of management, leadership and
supervision."

Brian Paddick, a former deputy assistant commissioner with the Metropolitan
Police, said: "I don't think that Prince Charles and Camilla should have ever
found themselves in that situation. They should have had motorcycle outriders
well in advance of the car who should have seen what was around the corner and
diverted them on another route."

David Davis, former shadow Home Secretary said: "Sir Paul has very serious
questions to answer about this operation.

"The police always know where the Prince is for obvious security reasons. So why
were professional anarchists and violent agitators allowed to come anywhere near
his car?" Charles and Camilla were visibly shaken but unharmed. A Clarence House
spokesman said the couple understood the "difficulties" the police face and are
"very grateful" for the job they do in "very challenging circumstances".

                            December 12, 2010 Sunday

                                National Edition

Stockholm hit by car bomb terror attack

BYLINE: David Watts

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 34

LENGTH: 445 words


TWO car bombs 300 yards apart brought terror to the centre of Stockholm last
night as Islamist extremists claimed responsibility for the blasts, which killed
one man and injured two other people.

The explosions terrified crowds of people in the heart of the Swedish capital.

Panicked Christmas shoppers fled at the sound of the blasts. The area was sealed
off and the authorities brought in robots to tackle explosives and gas bottles,
which were found in one of the vehicles.

Beside the car was the body of a man who is believed to have been an attacker.
Close by was a bag containing a number of pipe bombs. Petra Sjolander, a police
spokeswoman, said the first explosion had been in another car, which contained
gas canisters.

The Swedish news agency TT said that 10 minutes before the explosions it had
received an email with a sound file attached in both Swedish and Arabic.

The sound file criticised Sweden's "silence" over the publication of caricatures
of the Prophet Muhammad by the Swedish artist Lars Vilks, and the Swedish
contribution to the war in Afghanistan. Sweden has about 500 troops stationed in
the north of the country. "Our actions will talk for themselves," the sound file
said.

"As long as you don't end your war against Islam and your humiliation of the
prophet and your stupid support for the pig Vilks." Vilks's images of the
prophet have attracted little attention in his home country, where he has a
reputation as a self-publicist and for creating images that are designed to
provoke.

The artist describes his own skill as quite limited and the Swedish art
establishment pays little attention to his work.

However, his images have provoked a gathering storm in the Islamic world.

Last spring, a Philadelphia woman was charged with trying to recruit Islamist
terrorists to murder Vilks. In May Muslim protesters assaulted him while he was
giving a lecture about free speech at Uppsala University in southern Sweden. The
attack at the lecture started when a film about Islam and homosexuality that had
been banned from YouTube was shown.

This was the first time that any threats against him had been carried out. Four
days later Vilks's house, also in southern Sweden, was attacked by arsonists.

Windows were smashed and Molotov cocktails were thrown into the house, which
caught fire.

Vilks was not at home at the time. In November a more serious threat to the
artist emerged when a video produced by the Somali terrorist organisation
Al-Shabaab was sent out, threatening him with death. In the video a
Swedishspeaking terrorist appealed to "all the Somali brothers and sisters" in
Sweden to leave that country to travel to Somalia to fight for Al-Shabaab.

                         The Sunday Telegraph (London)

                               December 12, 2010
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Fears for England safety at World Cup;
CRICKET Hosts 'should provide bomb-proof vehicles' to counter threat of
terrorist attacks

BYLINE: Scyld Berry

SECTION: SPORT; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 419 words


England's safety at next year's World Cup in Asia, and that of the 13 other
national teams, will be put at risk from terrorist attacks unless there is a
sudden and major change of strategy, a security expert has warned.

The proposal is for the 14 World Cup teams to travel in ordinary buses from
airport to hotel to ground in the three countries hosting the tournament -
India, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh - in February and March. An armed local police
officer is due to be on board each bus, which will be accompanied by escort
vehicles.

In the light of the terrorist attack in Lahore in March 2009, when gunmen killed
eight people and injured several of Sri Lanka's Test cricketers after bullets
pierced their bus, such arrangements are "hopelessly inadequate", says the
expert, who is calling for bom-bresistant buses to be provided, at a cost of
between £290,000 and £330,000 each. To stage the World Cup, the organisers have
been given £84 million by the International Cricket Council. Providing the
relative security of bomb-resistant buses would cost an estimated £4.2 million,
or five per cent of their total budget.

Before the Lahore attack, the perception was that sportsmen in Asia, and
particularly cricketers, would never be threatened by terrorists. That theory
died with the eight victims in Lahore.

It is understood that the greatest fear of World Cup security advisers is of an
attack on a team in transit by road. Promises by organisers to clear roads for
team buses in the three host countries are not regarded as reliable.

In addition to the attack directly on Sri Lanka's cricketers in Lahore,
terrorists struck in November 2008 at the Taj Mahal Hotel in Mumbai, where
officials and players were gathering for the inaugural Champions League, which
had to be cancelled.

Earlier this year a bomb went off at the stadium in Bangalore where an Indian
Premier League match was about to be staged. The players, including Kevin
Pietersen, were assured that the ground was safe before the game went ahead, but
more bombs were found in the stadium after the match.

Bomb-resistant buses were considered by IPL officials for the eight teams in
this year's competition, but not in time for them to be delivered.

Turkey condemns terrorist attacks in Stockholm

LENGTH: 152 words


Text of report in English by Turkish semi-official news agency Anatolia

["TURKEY CONDEMNS TERRORIST ATTACKS IN STOCKHOLM" - AA headline]

ANKARA (A.A) -Turkey has condemned the terrorist attacks which were staged in
Stockholm, Sweden on December 11.

Turkish Foreign Ministry stated on Sunday that Ankara condemned the attacks, and
wished speed recovery for the people who were injured in the attacks.

Turkey, which always defended that terrorism was unacceptable regardless of its
aim and stressed the importance of international cooperation in fight against
terrorism, was in solidarity with Sweden and its people in such difficult days,
stated the Ministry.

On Saturday, a car blew up in a busy shopping area, followed minutes later by a
second explosion nearby, in Stockholm. Suspected bomber was killed while two
people were wounded in the attacks.
