                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            December 13, 2010 Monday

Pakistan: Karachi police chief hints at terror attacks on Ashura

LENGTH: 278 words


Text of report by staff correspondent headlined "Terrorism threat on Ashura,
says CCPO" published by Pakistani newspaper Dawn website on 13 December

Karachi, Dec 12: Claiming that strict measures had been taken to tackle any
untoward situation, the city police chief said here on Sunday [12 December] that
there was a threat of terrorism in Karachi on Ashura-i-Muharram.

Capital City Police Officer [CCPO] Fayyaz Ahmed Leghari was speaking to newsmen
after presiding over a meeting of police officers held at the Garden police
headquarters.

He said that the security plan for the main processions to be taken out on the
9th and 10th of Muharram had been reviewed. The police would take over the
control of all buildings on the route of the processions on the 8th of Muharram,
he added.

The CCPO said that 5,700 policemen would be deployed along the route of the main
procession.

In addition to the deployment from the regular police, 1,000 men belonging from
the special police group, crime investigation department, special branch and
traffic would also be deployed for the security of the processions, he added.

He said the processions would be monitored through security cameras which had
been installed along the route and at the Nishtar Park.

All makeshift shops, cabins, pushcarts or any type of boxes would be removed
from the route of the procession, he said.

Media persons, vehicles of the participants of the procession and ambulances
would be issued special passes to enter the procession, he added.

Later, the CCPO inspected the security arrangements at the Numaish area from
where the procession would be taken out.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 13 Dec 10

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            December 13, 2010 Monday

Terrorist attack in Sweden shows no country in Europe safe - Polish paper

LENGTH: 332 words


Text of report by Polish newspaper Rzeczpospolita on 12 December

[Editorial by Piotr Zychowicz: "The War on Terror Continues"]

Islamic mujahidin - as they described themselves - have carried out suicide
attacks in the capital of a European country. They set off bombs in a shopping
district in Stockholm at a time when hordes of Swedes were doing their Christmas
shopping. It was only because of a technical glitch with the bombs that a
tragedy was avoided. There could have been hundreds of victims if the bombs had
gone off as planned.

The target of the attack was one of the most liberal countries in Europe that
welcomes immigrants with open arms and generously provides them with social
benefits. A country that is known for its tolerance and respect for human
rights. In recent years alone, Sweden has granted asylum to 1,000 Iraqi refugees
for humanitarian reasons.

The attacks in Stockholm show that radical Islamists have no mercy for anyone.
If it turns out that the attack was carried out by immigrants, the Swedes'
liberalism may turn against them. The moral of this story is a bitter one: no
country in Europe is safe today, regardless of the policies it conducts.

A significant amount of time has passed since the last spectacular attacks in
Europe. The massacre in Madrid took place in 2004 (191 fatalities) while the
attacks in London occurred in 2005 (52 victims). The explosions in Stockholm
should therefore come as an alarm bell for intelligence agencies. Islamic
terrorists are still in the game, they are still dangerous, and next time they
may be luckier.

Unfortunately, one may get the impression that the West's drive to combat
radical Islam has weakened recently. It is said that US President Barack Obama
has even prohibited his associates from using the term "the war on terror" owing
to its status as a relic of the loathed George W Bush era. If this war really
does not exist anymore, then what happened in Stockholm?

Source: Rzeczpospolita, Warsaw in Polish 12 Dec 10

TheWorld

SWEDISH police said that two explosions in central Stockholm were an act of

               Copyright 2010 Midland Independent Newspapers plc
                              All Rights Reserved

                              295 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                BreakingNews.ie

                     December 13, 2010 Monday 07:21 AM GMT

Tolerant Sweden shocked at terror attack

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 726 words


Sweden was reeling today after two explosions targeted the tolerant and open
nation that had not seen a terrorist attack in more than 30 years.

Two people were wounded in central Stockholm on Saturday in what appeared to be
the first suicide bombing in Sweden's history.

A car exploded in the middle of the Christmas shopping frenzy, shooting flames
and causing several smaller blasts as people ran screaming from the scene.

The blast that killed the suspected bomber, named in some reports as an
Iraqi-born Swede who was a student in the UK, came moments later a few streets
away from the car explosion on a busy street.

Experts said the bomber probably did not succeed in detonating all the
explosives and could have caused much greater damage.

Police have not confirmed that the attack was motivated by Islamist views, but
an audio file sent to Swedish news agency TT shortly before the blast referred
to jihad, Sweden's military presence in Afghanistan and a cartoon by a Swedish
artist that depicted the Prophet Mohammed as a dog, enraging many Muslims.

"Now the Islamic state has been created. We now exist here in Europe and in
Sweden. We are a reality," the voice said in the file. "I don't want to say more
about this. Our actions will speak for themselves."

Meanwhile police in the UK were searching a property in Bedfordshire after
reports said the bomber lived in Luton and studied at the University of
Bedfordshire.

Swedish prime minister Fredrik Reinfeldt said the attack was "unacceptable" but
urged Swedes not to jump to "premature conclusions" that "create tension which
paints pictures that are then difficult to change".

"Sweden is an open society ... which has stated a wish that people should be
able to have different backgrounds, believe in different in gods ... and live
side by side in our open society," Mr Reinfeldt said.

Swedes, with a tradition of welcoming immigrants and a culture of transparency,
began questioning their self-image of being a secure nation after the 1986
murder of prime minister Olof Palme.

In 2003, the fatal stabbing of foreign minister Anna Lindh in a department store
was a wake-up call for many, but there have been no major terrorist strikes.

"We had a terrorist attack in the 1970s from the Rote Armee Fraktion of Germany,
but if this is a suicide bomber it is the first time in Sweden," security police
spokesman Anders Thornberg said.

"It's very serious and it's very tragic that these things have come to Sweden
too."

Yesterday the district where the explosions occurred was eerily quiet and empty
for a mid-December weekend.

"We're used to seeing things like this on the news. This was a lot closer to
home but it still doesn't feel very tangible," said Eric Osterman, a 26-year-old
student.

German tourist Melanie Ziethmann, 34, said she heard the explosion on Saturday
but did not realise what it was until a friend in Germany contacted her to make
sure she was safe.

"We were surprised that this happened in Sweden," she said. "It was quite
shocking. I thought it was very safe here."

In October Sweden raised its terror threat alert level from low to elevated
because of what police called "a shift in activities" among Swedish-based groups
that could be plotting attacks.

Days later, police made several arrests over an alleged bomb plot in the
country's second-largest city, Gothenburg. The suspects were later released and
police said the city was no longer deemed to be under threat.

Magnus Norell, a terrorism expert at the Swedish Defence Research Agency, said
it was just a matter of time before Sweden was hit by a terror attack.

"Sweden isn't an isolated island, even if we might think that sometimes," he
said. "We have only been lucky so far."

Mr Norell said Sweden had the same problem with worsening radicalisation among
Islamic groups as other countries, with young men travelling to training camps
in countries such as Somalia and Pakistan.

"The whole idea is that this is a global war for them and that the target exists
everywhere, all over the world," he said.

Yesterday around 100 people assembled in chilly central Stockholm for a peaceful
demonstration organised by Swedish Muslims for Peace and Justice.

Samaa Sarsour, 26, one of the main organisers of the rally, urged the crowd to
punch the air and kick out their feet in a display of defiance against the
hijacking of religion by extremists.

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                            December 13, 2010 Monday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Trio 'would launch terror attack' if control orders are lifted

BYLINE: Duncan Gardham

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 259 words


Three terrorist suspects will launch attacks if they are released from house
arrest, MI5 has warned the Government as it delayed for a second time a decision
on whether to scrap controversial control orders.

An announcement originally due this month has been pushed back to January, as
Nick Clegg, the Deputy Prime Minister, considers the advice of the security
services, who have warned that three British citizens under the orders would
commit acts of terrorism if they were not closely monitored.

Newspapers are banned from identifying individuals, but The Daily Telegraph can
disclose there are eight control orders still in place. The individuals have
been allowed to visit parks, go to college and, in one case, visit a nightclub.

"AY", from Birmingham, allegedly flew into Britain on a false passport to help
plan the trans-Atlantic airlines terror plot. He was in touch with key figures
in the plot, including al-Qaeda commanders in Pakistan.

"AM", from Lancashire, was an associate of Rashid Rauf, a senior al-Qaeda
commander, who was allegedly set to meet AY for instructions on how to make a
bomb and record a martyrdom video.

"BM", from Ilford, Essex, was said to be an organiser who had been given
explosives training and could contact senior al-Qaeda figures.

Jamie Bartlett, the head of the violence and extremism programme at Demos, a
Left-wing think tank, said: "Those who wish to see control orders abolished must
satisfactorily explain what they would do with those individuals currently under
an order."

Duncan Gardham

                              297 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                               Independent Extra

                            December 13, 2010 Monday
                                 First Edition

We must hold fast to our values in the face of terror;
Leading Articles Stockholm attack

SECTION: COMMENT; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 587 words


The investigation into the attempted terror attack in Stockholm at the weekend
is still in its early stages, but there are some tentative conclusions that can
be drawn. The first is that the attack was incompetent. The car bomb had
similarities with previous failed attempted attacks in New York, Glasgow and
London. And the individual found dead in the area had been carrying an explosive
device, which would seem to suggest that this was the bomber himself.

But the incompetence of the execution allows no complacency. Although just two
people were hurt (other than the presumed bomber), this could easily have been
lethal. Six years after the Madrid train bombings, the threat of terror still
haunts Europe's streets.

An email sent before the attempted attack suggests that this attack was
motivated by Sweden's military involvement in Afghanistan and the fact that a
Swedish cartoonist, Lars Viks, in 2007 drew a picture of the Prophet Mohamed in
a local newspaper that offended many Muslims.

The Mohamed cartoons affair, which began in 2006 in Denmark, continues to have
repercussions. In January, a Somali man broke into the home of the Danish
cartoonist Kurt Westergaard armed with a knife and an axe. In September an
(unsuccessful) letter bomb was send to Jyllands-Posten, the Danish newspaper
that published the original offending cartoons.

So how should democracies respond to this insidious threat, driven as much by
religious offence as anger at Western military actions abroad? The answer is
that we need to keep calm and defend our liberal values. The solution is not
censorship of magazines or newspapers. In May an attempt was made to burn down
Mr Viks's home. However offensive his art might be to some, he needs to be
protected by the Swedish authorities. And the same is true of other Nordic
cartoonists who now find their lives under threat.

Nor can censorship of ideas be any sort of solution. This is directly relevant
to Britain since the Home Secretary, Theresa May, is considering banning Terry
Jones, the American pastor who threatened to burn the Koran on the anniversary
of the September 11 attacks, from entering Britain to address an English Defence
League rally in February. Ms May has the power to exclude an individual from
coming to the UK if they are not conducive to the public good - and she has been
lobbied by anti-extremist groups to bar Mr Jones's entry. But the Home Secretary
needs to think very hard before exercising this power. Unless it can be shown
that Mr Jones will directly incite violence, it would be better not to make a
martyr of him. The Obama administration made a mistake in giving Mr Jones's
pathetic threatened Koran-burning stunt publicity by condemning it. A UK travel
ban could compound this error.

Equally, the solution is not repressive domestic measures. The previous Labour
government took a disastrous wrong turn when it responded to the September 11
attacks by detaining terror suspects without charge and curtailing freedom of
speech through the religious hatred act.

The terror threat against the populations of Western states is real. But it
needs to be treated like a criminal conspiracy, rather than an emergency that
requires the suspension of our liberal traditions. Our police and intelligence
services are adequately equipped to meet the threat. Our existing laws are
capable of dealing with those who resort to violence to further their goals. And
our societies are strong enough to withstand these challenges, providing we do
not compromise our values.

LOAD-DATE: December 12, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: IE

                              All Rights Reserved

                              298 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                    RTE News

                     December 13, 2010 Monday 11:43 AM GMT

Stockholm blasts were 'a terrorist attack'

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 747 words



HIGHLIGHT: Sweden's chief prosecutor has said that two explosions in Stockholm
last night which killed two and wounded one were 'a terrorist attack'.


Swedish police investigating two blasts that rocked central Stockholm last
night, killing one person and wounding two have said that they had good leads
into what they said were 'terror crimes'.

Before the explosions, the Swedish news agency TT received a threatening letter
about Sweden's military presence in Afghanistan and caricatures of the Prophet
Mohammad drawn several years ago by a Swedish cartoonist.

A senior Swedish security police official told a news conference that the blasts
were being treated as 'terror crimes' and police had established good leads.

Anders Thornberg, director of operations at the Security Police, said police
could neither confirm that the man who died was a suicide bomber nor discuss his
identity, as some family members had not yet been informed.

'We are investigating this as terror crimes according to Swedish law, we have
not raised the security threat level and said that the police were stepping up
their presence in the capital.'

A car burst into flames near a busy shopping street in the city centre, followed
by explosions inside the car which police said were caused by gas canisters.

The second explosion, 10 to 15 minutes later took place 300 metres away and
killed one man and wounded two people.

Reaction to the bombing

In a message on Twitter, Sweden's Foreign Minister Carl Bildt said 'Most
worrying attempt at terrorist attack in crowded part of central Stockholm.
Failed - but could have been truly catastrophic.'

The Imam of Stockholm's grand mosque has condemned twin blasts which targeted
shoppers in the Swedish capital, killing one person, believed to be the bomber.

Sheik Hassan Mussa has deplored 'all forms of attacks, violence, fears and
threats against innocent people, whatever the motive or pretext,' in a statement
sent to the Swedish news agency TT.

Police vans cordoned off several streets around the body and towed away the car.
The rest of the city centre was calm, with people having a normal Saturday night
out.

Several hours after the blast, the man's body was still lying on the pavement,
covered with a white sheet.

Swedish newspapers all said the dead man had blown himself up. Dagens Nyheter
quoted a man called Pascal, a trained medic, as saying: 'It looked as if the man
had been carrying something that exploded in his stomach.

'He had no injuries to the face or body in general and the shops around were not
damaged.'

The Aftonbladet quoted a source as saying the man was carrying six pipe bombs,
of which only one exploded, and a rucksack full of nails and suspected explosive
material.

The paper quoted eyewitnesses as saying the man was shouting in what was
believed to be Arabic.

TT said the email it received was also sent to the Security Police and had sound
files in Swedish and Arabic.

'Our actions will speak for themselves, as long as you do not end your war
against Islam and humiliation of the Prophet and your stupid support for the pig
Vilks,' TT quoted a man as saying in one recording.

TT said the threat was linked to Sweden's contribution to the US-led NATO force
in Afghanistan, where it has 500 soldiers, mainly in the north.

It also referred to caricatures of the Prophet Mohammad by the Swedish artist
Lars Vilks, who depicted the Prophet with the body of a dog in a cartoon in
2007.

Most Muslims consider any depiction of the founder of Islam offensive.

Islamist website identifies the bomber

Meanwhile, an Islamist website Shumukh al-Islam has identified the bomber as
Taymour Abdel Wahab and published a photograph it said was him.

A statement accompanying the photo said: 'It is our brother, Mujahid Taymour
Abdel Wahab, who carried out the martyrdom operation in Stockholm.'

Swedish intelligence agency Saepo have refused to confirm the Yemeni Islamist
website's claimed identification of a man behind weekend bomb blasts in
Stockholm.

Evan Kohlmann, a US terrorism consultant, told Reuters that a small militant
Islamic community had been based in Sweden for some time. But he thought the
incident on Saturday, if an attack, was one man's work.

'Given the scale of this attack and the target, I suspect this is a homegrown
local extremist who may or may not have connections to any actual terrorist
organisation.

'We've seen a flurry of attempted attacks across northern Europe by similar lone
wolf militants who were, in one way or another, enraged by the cartoon
controversy.'

Police spokesman Kjell Lindgren said it was not clear what had started the fire
that made gas canisters in the car explode.

LOAD-DATE: December 13, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication


     Copyright 2010 RTE Commercial Enterprises Ltd / Radio Telefís Éireann
                              All Rights Reserved

                              299 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                               The Sun (England)

                            December 13, 2010 Monday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Scotland

Cyber terror attack would leave all of us spooked

BYLINE: SHAF Rasul

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 40

LENGTH: 563 words


I'M a big fan of BBC series Spooks - a tense drama about the different
challenges faced by the British security service.

I guess it stems from my love of James Bond and my early desire of growing up to
be an MI5 operative.

Bringing down the bad guys and being the personification of cool always seemed
like a great lifestyle and career choice for me.

However my newsagent father told me to get my head out the clouds, go to
university and study law.

I took his advice and my ambitions to be a spy were dashed from an early age.

Spooks gives you a thrilling insight into MI5's efforts in protecting us from
increasing security threats. It's gripping stuff as the agents, below, defuse
potential dangers and balance international relations with their spy
counterparts from across the globe.

Gossip I watched a recent episode that focused on a dispute with the Russians
who planned to bring the UK to a standstill by disabling our online digital
communication networks.

For a start, could they really do that? Maybe it's just fiction - but it's a
scary proposition.

If we were to go offline for even a morning it would cost our economy billions -
we wouldn't be able to trade on the global markets, international trade would be
down and it would obliterate our transport infrastructure.

Not to mention the personal inconvenience.We use the net for everything from
shopping and checking train times to getting the latest gossip.

I know a few people who would have a complete and utter breakdown if they were
unable to log-on to Facebook or Twitter for a few hours.

In all seriousness, we all have some level of internet dependency.

So it was interesting when Google released its annual list of most searched
words and terms last week, giving a snapshot of the stories and trends that have
captured our imagination in the past 12 months. Tellingly, the most popular was
Facebook which now has 26million users in Britain.

However the "zeitgeist" also revealed the public's continuing obsession with
celebrities. Teen pop sensation and Usher prodigy Justin Beiber, Ellie Goulding
and US firework Katy Perry were among the most-searched celebs.

Fashion designer Alexander McQueen and TV presenter Kristian Digby, who both
died this year, also featured high on the list. High-profile divorces also
earned their own category this year. British web users browsed for the latest
gossip on Cheryl Cole, Tiger Woods and Eva Longoria.

Even WWF legend Hulk Hogan's three-year-old divorce from Linda Bollea was the
subject of intense interest, assisted by photographs of Bollea partying on a new
yacht, which she named Alimoney.

However zeitgeist also reveals the glum underbelly of the internet. The report
found that some of the most common searches were for "I feel lonely," "I want
love" and "I hate love". Google's new business development manager Matthew
"Chewy" Trewhella said: "A lot of people trust their search engines to find
other people going through the same thing," adding that the US search engine
giant recently added the Samaritans' number to the results page for "suicide".
It's a touch alarming that a growing number of us are increasingly seeing the
internet as a companion and something we expect answers from. So I'm now left
only to hope that MI5 is using all its powers to protect our country from a
cyber terror strike.

It appears an attack would damage a lot more than just our economy.

LOAD-DATE: December 13, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: SUN

                           December 14, 2010 Tuesday

Pakistan interior minister confined to room after hoax calls about terror attack

LENGTH: 295 words


Text of report by staff reporter headlined "Hoax calls confine minister to room"
published by Pakistani newspaper Dawn website on 14 December

Islamabad, 13 December: Interior Minister Rehman Malik was confined to a room in
the interior ministry for over an hour after the ministry received three hoax
calls about possible terrorist attacks on the minister, a senior official of the
ministry told Dawn on Monday [13 December].

The unidentified caller in his first call said that there was bomb planted in
the building. In the second call he said the minister would be attacked and the
third call was about carrying out attack on the minister at his residence.

"Some other senior officials were also moved to the room along with the
minister," the official said.

The security personnel of the ministry and bomb disposal squad combed each and
every room of the ministry for the bomb, the official said. They used sniffer
dogs and explosives and metal detectors but could not find anything.

The search was completed within four hours and later the blocks were declared
safe.

It could not be ascertained that who in the ministry received the calls. Many
attempts were made to contact director media Nawazish Ali Asim but he neither
responded nor received telephone calls.

Sources said security personnel also combed the minister's residence.

Meanwhile, the interior minister ordered Federal Investigation Agency (FIA) to
take record of the three mysterious calls so that their callers could be
arrested for making hoax calls.

It has also been learnt that the security of interior minister, who already
enjoys heavy security around him, has been enhanced and he had been advised to
avoid his appearance in the public as much as possible.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 14 Dec 10

                           December 14, 2010 Tuesday

Pakistan intelligence agencies warn of terror attacks on Muharram processions

LENGTH: 367 words


Text of report by official news agency Associated Press of Pakistan (APP)

Karachi, 14 December: Intelligence agencies have warned of possible terrorism on
Muharram processions, commander Sachal Rangers (Sindh), Brig. Waseem Ayub, said
here on Tuesday [14 December]. "We have received intelligence reports of
attempts by the banned organizations, jihadi groups and Al-Qa'idah to target
processions specially during 8th, 9th and 10th Muharram," he told a press
conference at Rangers Headquarters.

He said 7,143 personnel of Rangers have been deployed all over the province to
provide security to the people at mosques, imambargahs and processions. At least
67 imambargahs have been declared most sensitive, 19 imambargahs and 112 mosques
sensitive till Chehlum across the province, he pointed out.

Brig. Waseem said that ulema [clergy] of all schools of thought have been
appealed to create awareness among the people to cooperate with the law
enforcement agencies to meet any emergency. He said Karachi and interior of
Sindh have been divided into three zone by the Rangers and added that no private
vehicles and motorcycles will be allowed to reach near the areas pointed out for
religious congregations. In cooperation with the ulema, he said, a minor change
in the route of the procession will take place on 9th and 10th of Muharram due
to security concerns, otherwise, the processions will pass through the old
routes.

The Special Rapid Rangers, team of Bomb Disposal Squad, sniffer dogs of Rangers
will remain alert, along with the personnel of police, along the routes of the
procession, besides the aerial surveillance, he added. In addition, meetings
have also been held with the higher authorities of traffic police to ensure
smooth flow of traffic during the Muharram processions. Brig. Waseem said that
round-the-clock monitoring has also been arranged in coordination with the City
District Government Karachi (CDGK), the police department and Rangers. Moreover,
the Rangers in collaboration with the police have also undertaken strict checks
on vehicles at exit and entry points of the metropolis, he added.

Source: Associated Press of Pakistan news agency, Islamabad, in English 1144gmt
14 Dec 10

                               Leicester Mercury

                           December 14, 2010 Tuesday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Suicide bomber's call for new terror attacks;
RADICAL: STUDENT'S MESSAGE FROM BEYOND GRAVE

BYLINE: PA NEWS STAFF

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 372 words


The Stockholm suicide bomber called for more terrorist attacks on European
targets in a message from beyond the grave.

Taimour Abdulwahab al-Abdaly, 28, killed himself and wounded two people in a
botched suicide attack in the Swedish capital on Saturday afternoon.

An Arabic will apparently written by the multilingual Iraq-born university
graduate was posted on one jihadist internet forum.

The document called for more attacks in Europe and Sweden.

Security analyst Evan Kohlmann, of Flashpoint Partners, said a user who posted a
photograph of al-Abdaly also identified Swedish companies as potential targets.

ORDERS He added that the terrorist suggested he was carrying out the orders of
the "Islamic State of Iraq'' by undertaking the attack.

Al-Abdaly, an Iraq-born graduate of Bedfordshire University, left his wife and
three children at their family home, in Luton, to travel to Sweden several weeks
ago.

Swedish investigators said he visited his family in Tranas where his father was
celebrating his birthday.

But on Saturday, he loaded his white Audi with gas canisters and travelled to
Stockholm in a bid to wreak carnage on streets packed with Christmas shoppers.

Evidence from the scene indicated the car failed to explode and al-Abdaly was
killed about 300 metres away when explosives strapped to his chest detonated.

Police suspect the device may have exploded prematurely as the terrorist walked
to a nearby subway station or department store laden with three bombs.

The attack has once again thrown the spotlight on Luton as one of the nation's
focal points for religious tensions.

The town has been the scene of several clashes involving Islamic activists,
including several marches against the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

It raised further questions at how successful the Government and education
authorities have been at driving radicals from British universities. The suicide
attack came after former University College London student Umar Farouk
Abdulmutallab attempted to bring down a US aircraft on Christmas Day.

Religious leaders said al-Abdaly was driven out of the Luton Islamic Centre for
preaching about suicide bombings and attempting to recruit extremists.

The suicide bomber attended for a couple of months in 2006.

                                   The Mirror

                           December 14, 2010 Tuesday
                                  Eire Edition

WOMAN, 87, SAVED FROM FIRE TERROR BY GARDAI;
ARSON ATTACK A 'MISTAKE'

BYLINE: RORY TEVLIN

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 358 words


TWO hero gardai saved an 87-yearold woman from her burning home after thugs
mistakenly targeted her house in a sick arson attack.

May O'Gorman was lucky to be alive after mindless criminals set fire to her home
at Morrogh's Hill in Cork city at around 4.30am yesterday.

An accelerant was poured through her letter box and set alight but gardai
believe Ms O'Gorman was not the intended victim of the cowardly attack.

Neighbours alerted Gardai at around 5am when smoke was seen billowing from the
house, where she lives alone.

Garda John O'Sullivan and Reserve Garda Peter Clifford broke down the door and
rescued her from her bedroom in a dramatic escape.

The pensioner was treated at Cork University Hospital for smoke inhalation and
later released.

Gardai O'Sullivan and Clifford were also treated in hospital.

Ms O'Gorman's son-in-law Noel Woods said she was badly shaken by the incident
but thankfully not badly injured.

He added: "It was about half past four, quarter to five and we heard banging on
our door and it was the guards. They told my wife that there had been a fire up
in her mother's house.

"We are just living around the corner from it and we went up and the fire
brigade and the guards were there. She was taken away in an ambulance and thank
God she is not too bad. It was mainly kind of fright and smoke but she is shaken
over it, it is an awful thing to happen."

Noel said May was asleep in bed at the time of the attack and it could have
ended in tragedy if gardai had not acted so quickly.

He said: "She was a bit dazed but she looked frightened. She has had a fall
recently that shook her a bit but apart from that she was in great form. It is a
sign of the times I think, it's only when it hits your door that you realise the
things that are going on."

The house was badly smoke damaged in the blaze and a full technical examination
was carried out at the scene. Gardai are hunting for a man spotted in the area
at the time of the attack who was wearing a black beanie hat, brown jacket and
jeans.

Detectives appealed to the public to contact them on 021 494 6200 if they
noticed any suspicious activity in the Blarney Street area yesterday.

Stockholm bomber calls for terror attacks in his will posted on website

BYLINE: STAFF REPORTERS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 441 words


The Stockholm suicide bomber called for more terrorist attacks on European
targets in a message from beyond the grave.

Taimour Abdulwahab al-Abdaly, 28, killed himself and wounded two people in a
botched suicide attack in the Swedish capital on Saturday after noon.

An Arabic will apparently written by the multilingual Iraq-born university
graduate was posted on one jihadist internet forum last night.

The document, published on Shumukh al-Islam, the site which first identified him
as the bomber, called for more attacks in Europe and Sweden. Security analyst
Evan Kohlmann, of Flashpoint Partners, said a user who posted a photograph of
al-Abdaly also identified Swedish companies as potential targets.

He added that the terrorist suggested he was carrying out the orders of the
"Islamic State of Iraq" by undertaking the attack.

Al-Abdaly, an Iraq-born graduate of Bedfordshire University, left his wife and
three children at their family home in Luton to travel to Sweden several weeks
ago.

Swedish investigators said he visited his family in Tranas where his father was
celebrating his birthday.

But on Saturday he loaded his white Audi with gas canisters and travelled to
Stockholm in a bid to wreak carnage on streets packed with Christmas shoppers.

Evidence from the scene indicated the car failed to explode and al-Abdaly was
killed about 300 metres away when explosives strapped to his chest detonated.

Police suspect the device may have exploded prematurely as the terrorist walked
to a nearby subway station or department store laden with three bombs.

The attack has once again thrown the spotlight on Luton as one of the nation's
focal points for religious tensions.

The town has been the scene of several clashes involving Islamic activists,
including several marches against the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

And it raised further questions at how successful the Government and education
authorities have been at driving radicals from British universities.

The suicide attack came after former University College London student Umar
Farouk Abdulmutallab attempted to bring down a US aircraft on Christmas Day.

Religious leaders said al-Abdaly was driven out of the Luton Islamic Centre for
preaching about suicide bombings and attempting to recruit extremists.

Farasat Latif, secretary of the Luton Islamic Centre, said the suicide bomber
attended for a couple of months in 2006 or 2007. He described how al-Abdaly was
"bubbly" and "well-liked" but harboured increasingly radical and violent views.
Mr Latif said senior members thought they had "led him back to the truth" but he
stormed out after the chairman exposed him as a violent radical.

rifle and hundreds of rounds of ammunitions were recovered from the accused, he
added. The accused is a resident of Orangi Town, he added.

AIRPORT TERROR ATTACK HEROES ARE HONOURED;
IT'S TAKEN MORE THAN THREE YEARS TO HAVE THE BRAVERY OF ALL THE MEN RECOGNISED
BUT FINALLY..

BYLINE: Amy Devine

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 430 words


SEVEN heroes of the Glasgow airport terror attack were yesterday finally
honoured for their bravery.

The group, which included two policemen, stopped the bombers from murdering
thousands of holidaymakers when they drove a jeep packed with gas canisters into
the terminal.

But the heroes were overlooked when only baggage handler John Smeaton was
awarded the Queen's Gallantry Medal two years ago.

The Record nominated havea-go heroes Alex McI lveen, Michael Ker r and Stephen
The Record nominated havea-go heroes Alex McIlveen, Michael Kerr and Stephen
Clarkson for awards.

And along with sergeant Torquil Campbell, PC Stewart Ferguson, Michael McDonald
and Henry Lambie, they were given a Queen's Commendation for Bravery at a
ceremony attended by depute first minister Nicola Sturgeon yesterday.

Taxi driver Alex, 47, said: "This is fantastic. It's long overdue and I'd like
to thank the Record for nominating us. Without that we probably still would have
had no recognition for what happened."

Alex, of Glasgow, dedicated his award to his dad Ralph, who died 12 weeks ago.

Alex had just arrived at the airport on July 30, 2007, when he saw terrorists
Bilal Abdullah and Kafeel Ahmed drive a Cherokee jeep into the terminal.

He tore a tendon in his foot as he kicked burning Ahmed.

Stephen, 44, of Glasgow, was waiting to pick up relatives when he knocked Ahmed
to the ground. He said: "This means the world to us. It's affected us all in
different ways and now we want to get on with our lives."

Heating engineer Michael Kerr, of Denny, Stirlingshire, who was returning from
holiday in Menorca, suffered a broken leg tackling the bombers.

The dad-of-two, 43, said: "I didn't stop to think before I rushed in to help and
I hope others would do the same in that position."

Check-in attendant Michael McDonald also helped wrestle one of the terrorists to
the ground while airport ambassador Henry held off one of them with a fire
extinguisher.

Sergeant Campbell met off duty PC Ferguson, who was at the airport to meet
relatives, and the pair eventually brought down and arrested the bombers.

Depute first minister Sturgeon said: "The actions of these men represent deeply
impressive conduct and bravery.

"Collectively, they demonstrate how ordinar y people doing how ordinary people
doing ordinary things can sometimes reveal extraordinary courage and resilience
in extremely dangerous circumstances."

Strathclyde Police chief constable Stephen House said: "If it was not for the
bravery of the people being awarded today, there would have been disastrous
consequences that would still be felt now."

LOAD-DATE: December 15, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: HEROES: From left, Henry Lambie, Stephen Clarkson, Michael McDonald,
Sgt Torquil Campbell, PC Stewart Ferguson, Michael Kerr and Alexander Mcllveen

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             Paisley Daily Express

                                 First Edition

AIRPORT TERROR ATTACK HEROES HONOURED;
Magnificent seven receive Queen's bravery award

BYLINE: LYNN JOLLY

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 492 words


SEVEN heroes who played crucial roles in foiling the terror attack on Glasgow
Airport received bravery awards yesterday in front of their proud families.

The magnificent seven received the Queen's Commendation for Bravery at a
ceremony hosted by Deputy First Minister Nicola Sturgeon in Edinburgh.

Retired police sergeant Torquil Campbell, from Renfrew, and PC Stewart Ferguson,
from Paisley, were among those who were honoured.

They were joined by Glasgow Airport workers Henry Lambie, from Paisley, and
Michael McDonald; as well as taxi driver Alexander McIlveen; Stephen Clarkson,
who was at the airport to collect relatives and Michael Kerr, who was returning
from a holiday.

Guy Clark, Lord Lieutenant of Renfrewshire, was among the guests who were there
to pay tribute to the airport heroes.

And Ms Sturgeon said each of them can be proud of their actions that fateful day
back on June 30, 2007.

She told the Paisley Daily Express: "The immense gratitude and admiration of
everyone in Scotland goes to those whose courageous actions helped to avert a
major disaster.

"It is fitting that those who showed such courage and commitment to public
safety should be honoured in this way. We must never forget how privileged we
are to have such dedicated emergency professionals and volunteers on our side."

The airport attack was mounted by two bombers who drove a burning Jeep filled
with home-made explosives into the main terminal building.

Terror came to Paisley's doorstep as Iraqi doctor Bilal Abdulla, who worked at
the town's Royal Alexandra Hospital, and his accomplice Kafeel Ahmed staged the
car bomb attack.

Ahmed, 28, was engulfed by flames during the attack and died from his injuries a
month later.

Abdulla, 29, was jailed for at least 32 years at Woolwich Crown Court after he
was found guilty of conspiracy to murder and conspiracy to cause explosions.

Sergeant Campbell was just 50 yards away from the Jeep when it crashed into the
airport building and was attacked by Abdulla as flames ripped through the
vehicle.

When Ahmed emerged from the Jeep with his body engulfed by flames, PC Ferguson
used a fire extinguisher in a bid to save the terrorist's life.

Former fireman Mr Lambie also played a hero's role after he heard a loud bang
and headed towards the Jeep as it lay stuck in the main doors of the terminal.

He started to evacuate the building and helped to tackle the blaze.

Stephen House, Chief Constable of Strathclyde Police, said that, if it was not
for the bravery of the people being honoured at yesterday's ceremony, there
would have been "disastrous consequences that would still be felt now."

He added: "The courage shown by all of my officers, especially Sergeant Campbell
and PC Ferguson, can never be underestimated and I have nothing but admiration
and gratitude for them and the others.

"Their actions that day potentially saved the lives of many and it is only
fitting that we recognise this."

LOAD-DATE: December 15, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:  BRAVE: Sergeant Torquil Campbell (left) and PC Stewart Ferguson were
among those honoured at yesterday's ceremony

                               The Times (London)

                          December 15, 2010 Wednesday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Tests raise alarm over security at Sellafield;
Nuclear sites vulnerable to attack by terrorists ; Tests raise Sellafield alarm

BYLINE: Sean O'Neill ;Robin Pagnamenta

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1,10

LENGTH: 600 words


A top secret anti-terror review is under way at Britain's nuclear power plants
after the discovery of security weaknesses at the giant Sellafield reprocessing
site.

The Times understands that an urgent assessment is being carried out by HM
Inspectorate of Constabulary, which has been extended to cover protection of
pipelines, oil refineries and other key elements of the critical national
infrastructure.

But the focus is on Sellafield, in Cumbria, where construction of a bunker to
store 100 tonnes of raw plutonium was completed this year.

The £118 million facility, which holds enough plutonium to build thousands of
nuclear bombs, makes the plant an even greater target for a potential terrorist
attack.

Scotland Yard's Counter-terrorism Command and MI5, which operates the Centre for
the Protection of National Infrastructure, have been consulted during the review
process.

The police watchdog's document, which is nearing completion, will have a
restricted circulation among ministers, police chiefs and security officials.

It is understood that ministers were so concerned about the potential security
weakness at Sellafield that they demanded that the review be widened. One source
described it as "an extremely sensitive piece of work".

Details of what sparked the review have not been disclosed but security sources
denied that there had been any breach at Sellafield by intruders. The Times
understands that concerns about protecting the plant could have come to light
during a "red team exercise", when special forces pose as terrorists or foreign
agents. Troops carry out such exercises regularly to test security at large
infrastructure facilities and other potential targets.

The East London al-Qaeda cell that plotted in 2006 to blow up transatlantic
airliners in midflight also had in its possession an alternative target list of
nuclear power stations, oil and gas terminals and undersea pipelines.

One of the gang, Assad Sarwar, had compiled the second hitlist that included an
annotated diagram of the layout of the Bacton gas terminal in Norfolk and
detailed plans of the Coryton oil refinery in Essex.

This month the WikiLeaks website was criticised when it published a secret list
of industrial and civil assets around the world that the United States believes
require high levels of protection. But it is Britain's huge, and growing, stock
of plutonium that is the big security problem for the Government.

It is public knowledge that it is housed in the discreetly named Sellafield
Product and Residues Store, which was opened in May.

The bunker, which looks like an anonymous warehouse, is made of 36,000 cubic
meters of concrete and the same amount of steel as the Eiffel Tower. It took 500
construction workers five years to build and has the largest declared plutonium
stockpile in the world. The US and Russia may hold more but they have never
admitted it.

Most of the plutonium contained here is a by-product of the reprocessing of
spent nuclear fuel after it has been used to generate electricity.

France and Japan recycle their plutonium by making a fuel mixed with uranium
that can be burnt in power stations. This generates electricity and is the most
efficient way of disposing of plutonium. In Britain, however, no government has
been willing to broach the subject. The only other option would be to build a
permanent underground store at huge cost.

The Civil Nuclear Constabulary, the armed police force that guards British
nuclear plants, refused to comment on the review .

The Department of Energy and Climate Change said: "Security arrangements are
kept under constant review."

LOAD-DATE: December 15, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: TIM


                    Copyright 2010 Times Newspapers Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                              311 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           December 16, 2010 Thursday

Russian official says series of terror attacks thwarted in Bashkortostan

LENGTH: 499 words


Text of report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Ufa, 16 December: The UFSB [Federal Security Service Directorate] for
Bashkortostan prevented a series of terrorist attacks that had been planned to
target crowded areas in the republic this summer, the head of the directorate
Viktor Palagin said at a news conference at the press centre of the
Interfax-Volga news agency in Ufa on Thursday [16 December].

According to Palagin, 18 improvised explosive devices were found and seized
during special operations. Terrorists "planned to blow up one of the district
police departments, seize weapons, carry out at least 18 explosions in public
places and on transport in order to paralyse the republic, and go to Afghanistan
through Kazakhstan".

The head of the directorate noted that the person who had made the explosive
devices was already testing them in abandoned houses and barns to determine
their impact and power.

In addition, five arms caches and two suspected terrorist camps were found in
Bashkortostan during the summer.

"The caches contained small arms, terrorist equipment, clothing, long term
storage food, gas cylinders. Some people associated with them have been
detained, they are giving testimony, there will be a court hearing," Palagin
said.

According to him, the activities of clandestine structures of the international
terrorist organization Hizb-ut-Tahrir were stopped in the republic this year,
and 12 people have been brought to criminal responsibility.

The so-called Oktyabrskiy, Chishminskiy and Askinskiy "jamaats" were also
neutralized, eight people have been arrested, Palagin said.

The head of the directorate expressed regret over the fact that the courts
considering the cases of members of religious extremist underground
organizations often limited the punishment to suspended sentences.

"Previously, the courts sentenced them to 7-12 years, and most of the prisoners
started to mend their ways. In recent years, none of those who received
suspended sentences started to mend their ways. We believe that the courts
simply underestimate the threat posed by terrorist organizations," he said.

In order to prevent extremism and terrorism, the directorate has started to give
warnings, but it is "all down to individuals: for one person it is enough to
invite him and speak to him, he will understand everything, while that's useless
with others," the head of the directorate said.

According to him, Bashkortostan's Federal Security Service Directorate works
with the church and mosques, but this is [only] effective "until they (potential
terrorists - Interfax) join jihad".

The head of the directorate noted that the current disagreement between the
Central Spiritual Administration of Muslims and the Spiritual Administration of
Muslims of Bashkortostan does not allow to use training facilities and train
imams.

"No one is going to take away their sovereignty, they should get closer," he
thinks.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1116 gmt 16 Dec 10

                                   The Mirror

                           December 16, 2010 Thursday
                                 1 Star Edition

NUCLEAR SITE IS TERRORIST ATTACK RISK;
SECURITY

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 37

LENGTH: 133 words


NUCLEAR power plant security is being urgently reviewed after Sellafield was
found to be vulnerable to a terrorist attack. Special forces carrying out "red
team exercises" to test security at highprofile targets are thought to have
exposed flaws.

A pounds 118million bunker capable of storing enough material to build thousands
of nuclear bombs has just been built at the Cumbrian plant.

The policing watchdog, in consultation with MI5, will now carry out a review to
boost protection of the site, to prevent a "terrorist spectacular".

But the findings will only be circulated among a group of police chiefs,
ministers and spooks.

An al-Qaeda cell caught plotting to blow up jets in 2006 also had nuclear sites
on its hit-list.

A G o v e r n m e n t spokesman yesterday declined to comment "on security".

NUKE SITE TERRORIST ATTACK RISK

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 37

LENGTH: 113 words


NUCLEAR power plant security is being urgently reviewed after Sellafield was
found to be vulnerable to a terrorist attack.

Special forces carrying out "red team exercises" to test security at
high-profile targets are thought to have exposed flaws.

A new pounds 118million bunker capable of storing enough material to build
thousands of nuclear bombs has just been built at the Cumbrian plant.

The policing watchdog will now carry out a review to boost protection at the
site to prevent a "terrorist spectacular".

An al-Qaeda cell caught plotting to blow up jets in 2006 also had nuclear sites
and oil refineries on its hit-list.

A Government spokesman declined to comment "on security".

                            December 17, 2010 Friday

Chabahar terror attack aimed at Islam - Iran MP

LENGTH: 322 words


Text of report in English by Iranian news channel Press TV website on 16
December

A lawmaker for Iran's Sistan-Baluchestan Province has condemned the Wednesday
[15 December] bomb attack in the region as aimed at undermining the Islamic
establishment in the country.

"The enemies have long been fuelling sectarian conflicts in Pakistan and intend
to spread the security crisis inside Iran," Mowlavi Nazir Ahmad Salami told IRNA
on Wednesday.

"Groups who engage in such terrorist and criminal acts are backed by Israel and
the United States, and their final goal is afflicting Islam and the Islamic
Republic establishment [in Iran]."

The lawmaker said the enemies are attempting to drag the religious communities
in the country into a confrontation.

"But the Iranian people are well aware and have reached political maturity and
thus will never be ensnared by the enemy," he emphasized.

"Certainly, the Shi'i and Sunni Muslims in this province (Sistan-Baluchestan)
are determined to maintain solidarity among them and will confront such
currents," Salami noted.

On December 15, terrorists targeted a crowd of Shi'i mourners marking the
anniversary of the martyrdom of Imam Husayn (PBUH) - the third Shi'i Imam and
the grandson of the Prophet Mohammad (PBUH) - in the southeastern city of
Chabahar.

At least 33 people lost their lives in the massive bomb explosion which also
left more than 95 others injured.

Iranian Interior Minister Mostafa Mohammad Najjar blamed the terrorist attack on
"a number of terrorists that are being trained beyond [Iran's] eastern borders
in Pakistan."

He said that the terrorists received equipment and training from foreign
elements, adding that the Islamic Republic has warned Pakistan against providing
a haven for terrorists.

Meanwhile, Chabahar governor Ali Bateni said security forces have arrested one
of the perpetrators of the terrorist attack.

Source: Press TV website, Tehran, in English 0828 gmt 16 Dec 10

                               Leicester Mercury

                            December 17, 2010 Friday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Man tells of terror after witnessing shark attack;
SHAKEN UP: KEEN SNORKELLER SAW ONE OF FOUR INCIDENTS

BYLINE: ALAN THOMPSON

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 489 words


A holidaymaker has spoken of his horror after witnessing one of four shark
attacks in the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheikh.

Keen snorkeller Neil Hammond was walking along the seafront in the Baron Palms
resort when he heard screams and shouts coming from the sea, less than 100 yards
offshore.

The 66-year-old looked out to see two swimmers racing back to the shore and a
third man on his own in the water with the sea around him turning red.

Mr Hammond, from Ab Kettleby, near Melton, said: "The two swimmers were going so
fast it was like they were Olympic athletes. Their hands were going around like
windmills.

"Another man had been left out on his own in the water.

"Everyone was shouting and screaming and I could see the water was turning red.

BADLY INJURED "I don't think I'll ever forget the pure panic. It was horrific
and just like the film Jaws."

The man, thought to be one of two Russian holidaymakers injured in a recent
spate of shark attacks at the resort, was rescued by a speedboat which raced to
his aid.

Mr Hammond said: "The people in the speedboat grabbed the man and pulled him
into the boat. He was alive but had obviously been badly injured because of the
amount of blood there.

"We could easily have been in there snorkelling. It could have been any one of
us and it's quite possible that I won't ever snorkel around that area again."

Mr Hammond was on his tenth trip to the country with wife June, 65, and some
friends, when he witnessed the attack on December 1. The attacks on three
Russians and a Ukrainian prompted Egyptian authorities to close the beaches.

However, they were re-opened several days later. After swimmers returned to the
water, a 70-year-old German woman was killed while she was snorkelling in the
Red Sea.

Mr and Mrs Hammond, who spent 11 days in the resort, have always gone
snorkelling in Sharm el Sheikh, including in Shark's Bay where the attacks took
place.

Mrs Hammond said: "Notes were sent round to the hotels after the attack Neil
witnessed saying the beaches were closed for 72 hours. "But the next day there
were still people in the water despite the Egyptian people trying to get them
back onto the shore.

"The German woman was killed after they re-opened the beaches. "There was a
feeling of disbelief.

"I think I'll be hard pushed to go snorkelling there again. It's just something
that's never happened before.

"They caught and killed a couple of sharks, but how do you know you've got the
right ones? "The Egyptians were at a loss because all watersports were cancelled
and how long do you close the beaches for?" Shark experts investigating the
series of attacks have recommended banning feeding fish and dumping carcasses in
the water.

They also suggested building observation towers on the beach at Sharm el-Sheikh
and running naval patrols to alert tourists against attacks.

They have said the beaches should not re-open until the patrols and observation
towers are up and running.

LOAD-DATE: December 17, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: RESORT: Sharm el Sheikh
PANIC: Neil and June Hammond pictured at Sharm el Sheikh where Mr Hammond
witnessed an attack

Russia: Chechen law enforcers say slain man wanted to stage terrorist attack

LENGTH: 180 words


Chechen law enforcers have said that a man, killed in Chechnya's Sunzhenskiy
District, when he put up armed resistance to policemen on 18 December, intended
to stage a terrorist attack, the Kavkazskiy Uzel website reported on 20
December.

The website noted that on the same day, the inauguration of a transport junction
was held on the Kavkaz federal highway attended by a number of high-ranking
Chechen officials.

"A weapon, ammunition and explosives found inside a car make us to assume that
he was preparing a large-scale terrorist attack. This can be proved by the fact
that the incident took place near Assinovskiy - literally ahead of the start of
the festive opening ceremony of the two-level transport junction," the website
was told at the republic's law enforcement agencies.

Prime Minister Odes Baysultanov, parliament Speaker Dukuvakha Abdurakhmanov,
other ministers and high-ranking officials attended the opening ceremony, the
website noted, adding that an investigation was under way to identity the slain
man.

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           December 21, 2010 Tuesday

Al-Arabiya TV reports on UK anti-terror moves, fear of Mumbai-type attack

LENGTH: 389 words


Dubai Al-Arabiya Television in Arabic at 1307 gmt on 20 December carries the
following announcer-read report: "The British police have announced the arrest
of 12 people in a large-scale anti-terrorism campaign. They also noted that they
arrested five people in Cardiff, Wales; four others in Stoke, central England;
and three more in London. The police added that they were all arrested on
suspicion of committing, preparing, or inciting an act of terror in Britain."

Immediately afterward, the channel carries a live satellite interview with
journalist Husni al-Imam, from London. Asked why people use Britain to launch
attacks, Al-Imam says: "Britain has been strongly criticized since the 1980s for
becoming Londonstan [in reference to Pakistan and Afghanistan]. There were
allegations that London hosted such groups so as to ward off their evil deeds
and acts of terror. The British Government denied these allegations. There were
many examples, such as Abu-Hamzah, Umar Bakri, and others. In fact, following
the 11 September terrorist attacks in the United States, and later the 7 July
terrorist attack in London, the British Government might have radically changed
its position. Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair noted then that the rules
of the game had changed. However, the documents leaked by WikiLeaks noted that
after the 7 July incidents, Britain has been struggling to combat extremism by
fundamentalist and terrorist groups in Britain."

Asked if the Stockholm bomber justifies the fears expressed by some people that
these groups use Britain to launch further attacks in Europe, Al-Imam says:
"There are strong fears that cause concern, especially after what happened in
Stockholm, given that the bomber used to live in Luton, near London." He adds:
"According to media leaks, the arrest of this group today came as a result of
the fear that bombings similar to the Mumbai attacks might occur."

Asked about the consequences of these fears, Al-Imam says: "First is the
consolidation of intelligence operations. We all know that the British MI5 is
very active. Second is the placing of these groups under surveillance and
monitoring their activities in terms of teaching and indoctrination. I think
that the British Government has clearly failed in this respect."

Source: Al-Arabiya TV, Dubai, in Arabic 1307 gmt 20 Dec 10

                              321 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                           December 21, 2010 Tuesday

Suspects held over alleged plans for terrorist attack: Arrests in London,
Cardiff, Stoke and Birmingham Police enter homes wearing chemical suits

BYLINE: Steven Morris

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 686 words


Five men in Cardiff were among 12 arrested yesterday by counter-terrorism
detectives acting to prevent an alleged plot to attack multiple targets in the
UK.

Three of the suspects were detained early yesterday morning in Riverside in
Cardiff, an area close to the Millennium Stadium with a large Bangladeshi
community. Two others were arrested in Ely, a largely white working-class area.

Councillors, who were told of the arrests, said police had indicated that the
men seized were British nationals of Bangladeshi descent. The men are believed
to be aged between 23 and 28.

The other arrests were made in London, Stoke-on-Trent and Birmingham.

In Riverside, Cardiff police attention focused on a seven-bedroom Victorian
house, understood to be occupied by a middle-aged couple who run a take-away
restaurant, and their two sons. It is not clear whether any family members were
among those arrested.

Officers who were carrying out a search of the property also seized a Mercedes
estate car.

Neighbour Marc Davies, 26, said: "I was driving to work when I saw police all
suited up - it looked like they were wearing chemical suits."

"There were police everywhere, there were vans parked up on the side of the road
and it looked all go.

"I was absolutely shocked, this is a normal part of Cardiff."

Next door neighbour, Avtar Singh, said: "I'm very surprised . . . They are in
their 50s and run a restaurant. I know them to say hello to in the street.
They've lived here for around six or seven years.

"I was fast asleep when the police arrived. I woke up at 7am and there were all
flashing lights outside."

Greg Maciaj, the other next door neighbour, said he had done some building work
for the couple at their restaurant. "They are lovely people, decent people, and
very friendly," he said.

Ward councillor Mohammed-Sarul Islam said there had been some trouble in recent
months with young local people promoting radical views at local mosques. There
had also been some trouble around the time of the general election in May, he
said, when some election posters had been vandalised, but there was no violence.

Islam said the community would have no sympathy for anyone with extreme Islamist
views: "This is a peaceful community and we are shocked that there seem to be
idiots like this," he added. Islam said he had been told the men were all
British nationals.

Another councillor Ramesh Patel said he had been told by police that the
majority" of those arrested were from the Bangladeshi community.

Neighbours said a police raid also took place at a flat above a takeaway
restaurant in Ely, two miles from the house in Neville Street. A young couple in
their 20s or early 30s live there, according to neighbours.

Eyewitnesses did not see any arrests being made at the address, which also
occurred in the early hours of yesterday morning.

One shopkeeper, who runs a convenience store across the road from the flat said
he was just lifting his shutters at around 5.30am when he saw 20 people outside
the door of the flat.

They knocked on the door but broke it down when there was no answer. In Cardiff
city centre there were fears that crowded shopping centres and bars could have
been a terrorist target. Some shopkeepers said there had been rumours ahead of
the arrests that the city could be under threat.

A highly-placed source in the police operation said that the alleged plot was
targeting shopping areas in the West Midlands and important sites in London.
There has been no indication that locations in Cardiff were an intended target.
South Wales police refused to comment saying it was an anti-terrorist operation
mounted by the West Midlands force.

Forensic searches in Stoke-on-Trent were centred on Grove Street, Cobridge,
where more than a dozen police vehicles had gathered.

Officers were present inside three end-terrace properties and a group of four
uniformed police were seen entering a fourth house. Police activity was also
reported to be under way in the Tunstall and Shelton areas of the city.

Captions:

The street in Stoke where three addresses were raided by anti-terrorism officers
Photograph: Lindsey Parnaby/Newsteam

LOAD-DATE: December 21, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2010 Guardian Newspapers Limited

                              322 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                          The Journal (Newcastle, UK)

                           December 21, 2010 Tuesday

Yard Boss Tells Of Terror Attack Fear

SECTION: A; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 382 words


BRITAIN'S top counter terrorism officer said last night that the arrest of 12
suspects in four cities over fears they were preparing to launch an attack was
"absolutely necessary".

Scotland Yard Assistant Commissioner John Yates warned searches of homes in
London, Cardiff, Stoke and Birmingham could take days to complete as police
prepare to question the men.

He said the case highlighted how the public must remain vigilant and urged
anyone who witnesses suspicious activity to report it as the national threat
level remains severe.

Speaking outside New Scotland Yard, Mr Yates said: "With the information we
have, I believe today's arrests were absolutely necessary in order to keep the
public safe."

The 12 suspects, aged between 17 and 28 and at least five of whom are of
Bangladeshi origin, were arrested during 5am raids at homes in London,
Stoke-on-Trent, Birmingham and Cardiff at 5am. Police swooped over fears the
group were ramping up their activities after months of surveillance and
monitoring by counter terrorism officers and colleagues at MI5.

Sources said they were investigating if the gang were inspired by al Qaida, but
played down speculation they may have been planning a Christmas or New Year bomb
attack.

They said that although police have gathered enough information to fear the
suspects pose a threat, they remain unclear about exactly what their intentions
may have been.

Officials said the operation was not linked to the recent failed Stockholm
suicide bombing or the Yemen al Qaida printer bomb plot and was not modelled on
the Mumbai commando-style atrocity. Police officers undertaking the raids were
unarmed, suggesting police had no information that the men had guns, explosive
devices or other potential weapons.

The operation was led by West Midlands Police's counter terrorism unit,
supported by Scotland Yard's Counter Terrorism Command, South Wales Police and
Staffordshire Police.

All 12 suspects were detained on suspicion of the commission, preparation or
instigation of an act of terrorism in Britain.

Iraqi officials claimed last week that captured insurgents believed the
Stockholm bombing was part of a series of Christmas season attacks. But  British
and German officials insisted there were no specific threats to their countries
over the festive period.

                              324 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                BreakingNews.ie

                     December 24, 2010 Friday 01:13 PM GMT

Mumbai police hunt 'terror attackers'

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 349 words


Police are searching India's financial capital for four men who authorities
believe entered Mumbai to carry out a terrorist attack.

A terror alert was issued for the city, where a three-day terrorist siege in
2008 killed 166 people.

Despite checkpoints and some road closures, traffic and activity in most of
Mumbai was normal today.

Police have received credible information that at least four men belonging to
the Pakistan-based Lashkar-e-Taiba militant group have entered the city and were
planning to strike during the holiday season, said Himanshu Roy, joint police
commissioner of Mumbai Police.

India blames Lashkar for the 2008 assaults.

"The four men are planning violent attacks that are going to cause destruction,"
Roy said. "The four have recently arrived in Mumbai. We believe the threat is
serious."

Pakistani officials could not immediately be reached for comment.

Police set up checkpoints along major roads in the city, put additional men on
patrol duty at public places and released computer photographs of the four
suspects.

Roads were also closed near the Taj Mahal hotel and Mumbai's landmark Gateway of
India. Mumbai is also home to Bollywood, the country's prolific film industry.

Roy identified the four men but said their nationalities were not known.

In March, Mumbai police said they prevented a major terrorist strike after they
arrested two Indian men, allegedly preparing to hit several targets in the city.

Then in September, police issued a terror alert for the city during a popular
Hindu festival after a tip off that two Islamist militants were planning a
terror strike.

India has called on Pakistan to crack down on terrorists thought to be operating
from their soil. Lashkar-e-Taiba is banned by Pakistan's government but it still
thought to have support in Pakistan's powerful military and intelligence
community.

In the 2008 attack, several gunmen laid siege to two luxury hotels - including
the Taj Mahal - a Jewish centre, a popular restaurant and Mumbai's crowded main
train station. The lone surviving gunman was captured and earlier this year
sentenced to death.

LOAD-DATE: December 24, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication


                    Copyright 2010 Thomas Crosbie Media Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved

                              325 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                       BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           December 25, 2010 Saturday

Kenyan security forces on alert over possible terror attacks

LENGTH: 1125 words


Text of report by Juma Kwayera entitled "Police on high alert over possible
terror attacks" published by Kenyan privately-owned daily newspaper The Standard
website on 25 December; subheadings as published

Security agencies are on red alert following a new warning more and deadlier
terrorist attacks are imminent during this festive season.

Consequently, The Standard On Saturday has reliably learnt intelligence
personnel in the military, police, and national spy agency have had their annual
leaves cancelled after last Monday grenade attack on a Kampala-bound bus.
According to sources, security focus is now on aliens.

While the country experiences a high influx of illegal migrants, the police who
have taken the flak for failing to detect and prevent crime are on their part
turning the heat on their employer, the government, which they accuse of
under-funding despite increased insecurity.

However, opinion remains divided over whether the frequency of grenade attacks
is a result of lack of resources. A senior military intelligence officer blames
"security leaks" on general apathy, not resources.

Sporadic attacks

"Apart from South Africa and Egypt, Kenya has the best intelligence service in
Africa. At the moment we are in dilemma about how to respond to terrorist
threats. Any form of retaliation has the potential to escalate the sporadic
attacks into a full scale regional conflict that will suck in Arab countries
sympathetic to Al Shabab's cause," says the officer, who preferred anonymity for
fear of reprisals.

Police Spokesman Eric Kiraithe says government failure to match surveillance and
intelligence gathering with increased population that consists a rising
proportion of foreigners has spread thin the police force following years of a
hiring freeze and a high turnover of personnel.

Kiraithe concedes security agencies are hamstrung; hence lag behind terror
groups' criminal activities. The inability of the police to crack down on
serious crime has over the past year elicited the public concern that ineptitude
and corruption have enabled the terrorist gangs to thrive on Kenyan soil.

"Salaries alone cannot turn around the performance of the police. We need
substantive reforms that go beyond salaries and good laws. We appreciate we have
a new constitution, but a good law should be the icing on the cake," says the
spokesman.

The grenade explosion on a Kampala-bound bus in which three people died and 26
were injured was the eleventh incident this year, averaging one attack a month.

The attack illustrated further to an established pattern of terror acts - when
the nation's attention is diverted from security matters to heightened political
activities or festivities.

The latest attack has thrown forced security machinery into a spin, as the
public accuses the police of ineptitude for failing to detect the crime in
advance. However, Kiraithe accuses decision-makers in government of getting
national security priorities upside down.

Illegal immigrants

"In every crime report, we talk about increased illegal immigrants. We talk
about the need for the size of the police force to match the population. We are
not talking personnel, but also the growth in resource allocation, which must
match the growth of crime," says Kiraithe.

Prime Minister Raila Odinga, during the prime minister's time in parliament,
admitted the force lacks requisite tools and funding to cope with the spiralling
terror-related crimes, corroborated Kiraithe's sentiments.

With Kenyans already in a carnival mood, security agencies warn that terrorists
strike when security issues are not a priority. Our intelligence sources
disclosed that, with the public piling pressure for decisive action foreign
criminals, the government is reviewing its options.

Agreeing that the security situation is grim, sources in the three agencies told
The Standard On Saturday the Government is considering a review of various
options to counteract the Al Shabab threat.

However, an international security expert, Opiyo Ododa, while acknowledging
Kenya's precarious position, says military retaliation would only escalate a
volatile situation.

"Terrorism trends in Kenya and the wider East Africa suggest that terrorists
strike when security matters are not a priority. During Christmas festivities
people throw caution to the wind as they huddle in worship centres to celebrate.
There are parties, communal gatherings, and entertainment activities to
commemorate the occasion," says Ododa, a researcher and lecturer at the
International Centre for Security Studies at the National Defence College at
Karen, Nairobi.

The Kampala twin attacks on restaurants in July demonstrate how the terrors
attacks are planned with huge congregations in mind. The strikes were undertaken
during the final match of World Cup tournament in South Africa, which claimed 76
lives and injured more than 100 people, who were watching the match at public
fora in Uganda.

The attacks precipitated international travel alerts that warned visitors
against congested public places such as political rallies, religious assemblies
or cinemas. Such an alert was sent out by the US embassy in Kenya. The advisory
that expired on 22 October warned of the looming spectre of intensified
terrorist attacks. Since the 11 July bombings in Uganda, for which the
Somalia-based Al-Shabab terrorist group has claimed responsibility, there have
been increased threats against public areas across East Africa," the advisory
reads, a warning Ododa says is still valid heading into the Christmas season.

Ododa says Kenyans should be on alert in places such as supermarkets, churches,
bus termini, and banks that are increasingly becoming crowded.

The warning is informed by a grenade attack in a Karatina supermarket early in
the first quarter of the year. Although there were no casualties, there was a
state of alarm when around the same time police in Nairobi intercepted an
explosive being ferried to Nakuru in public service vehicle.

A few months later, a man was intercepted with detonators in a Garissa-bound bus
during a high alert ahead of the arrival of US Secretary of State Hillary
Clinton. This before two grenade explosions occurred in Mombasa's crime-infested
Kongowea shantytown. The most devastating grenade attacks occurred in the
countdown to the constitutional referendum last August. In the triple strikes on
a "No" campaign rally at Uhuru Park, three people died and scores were injured.
Before the referendum, a church leader was arrested in Limuru with 12
detonators.

The latest in a series of grenade attacks were early this month's attacks on
police officers in Kasarani and Eastleigh estates in Nairobi in which three
people were killed.

Source: The Standard website, Nairobi, in English 25 Dec 10

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript
