                             The Observer (London)

                               December 26, 2010

European terror attack feared after fighters quit Lebanon base

BYLINE: Mitchell Prothero Beirut

SECTION: OBSERVER WORLD NEWS PAGES; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 602 words


Intelligence services in the the Middle East and Europe are scrambling to track
down more than two dozen fighters linked to al-Qaida who recently left their
base in southern Lebanon.

The missing men are thought to have gone to Europe by a newly established route
through Syria, Turkey and the Balkans, and intelligence sources in Lebanon warn
that the group seems to be operational and could be planning attacks in Europe
in the holiday season.

"Yes, they have left the camp," said Munir al-Maqda, a senior Palestine
Liberation Organisation official in the Ain el-Hilweh refugee camp, where the
fighters had been hiding for the past few years. Because the Lebanese army is
not allowed to enter the country's 13 Palestinian refugee camps, militants have
long sought refuge inside them. Two Lebanese intelligence service officials -
who could only speak off the record - said Lebanon was co-operating with
European intelligence services to hunt the militants, who are described as
"extremely dangerous".

The militants, who based themselves in an area on the outskirts of Ain el-Hilweh
- Lebanon's largest and most densely populated refugee camp, with more than
50,000 people living within a square mile - had been a disparate group of
freelance fighters and jihadists thought to have carried out a number of attacks
in Lebanon over the last five years against the Lebanese army, Christian
districts and UN peacekeepers in southern Lebanon.

Yesterday a senior militant commander, Ghandi al-Sahmarani, was found killed on
the outskirts of the camp. Islamist sources blamed Fatah officials in charge of
security, pointing to a series of assassinations of Islamic militants by
mainstream security forces in Ain el-Hilweh over the past few years intended to
pressure militants into surrendering to the authorities or to quit their camp
haven.

Stephen Tankel, of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, has done
research in Ain el-Hilweh and describes the militants who have now left as
potentially dangerous because of their lack of overall control. This means that
the group are receptive to outside direction, and leaves them open to new ideas
and strategies, such as becoming operational in Europe as their options in
Lebanon dwindle, Tankel said.

"They may not have been super-organised, but that does not mean they are not
potentially dangerous," he said. "First, a number of them fought in Iraq, where
they will have gained combat experience and, perhaps, some explosives expertise.
Second, it's safe to assume that many of them are prepared to undertake
'martyrdom' operations. That said, they would benefit from guidance in terms of
targets [choosing and surveying them] and logistical support in Europe."

In view of their "street credibility" among European jihadists, Tankel suggested
that the group might be better able to operate successfully in Europe than in
Lebanon, where they were closely monitored, not only by the intelligence
services but by the Shia militant group Hezbollah, which is bitterly opposed to
al-Qaida's Sunni Muslim ideology.

One European Union intelligence official confirmed that an operation to hunt
down Arab fighters from Lebanon was under way, but could not link them to recent
concerns about holiday attacks by al-Qaida. "We have received warnings of a
significant militant plot in Europe during the holidays and we have been warned
about these missing fighters from Lebanon," the official said. "But we wish we
knew if the two threats were related."

Captions:

Militant leader Ghandi al-Sahmarani was found assassinated yesterday near the
Ain el-Hilweh refugee camp in Lebanon.

Reuters

                                 Sunday Herald

                            December 26, 2010 Sunday
                                   1 Edition

Terrorist attacks kill 80 people in two continents as police seize Somali gang

BYLINE: NO BYLINE

SECTION: HS - NEWS; Pg. 49

LENGTH: 657 words


TERRORISTS killed at least 80 people on two continents this weekend as European
police swooped on a Somali gang alleged to have been plotting an attack in the
Netherlands.

Bombings were reported in Pakistan and Nigeria, while 12 African men were
arrested in Rotterdam after a tip-off from the Dutch intelligence service.

The bust in the Netherlands  second city caught 12 men aged from 19 to 48.
Security officials said they were planning an attack in the near future, but
declined to give details of where this might be.

Security across Europe is often stepped up during the festive season, and
vigilance has been increased this year after the Nigerian  underpants bomber
attempted to bring down a plane over Detroit on Christmas Day 2009. The suicide
bombing in Sweden and attacks on two embassies in Rome have also heightened
concerns.

Six of the arrested Somalis live in Rotterdam, five have no permanent address
and one resides in Denmark, Dutch authorities said.

France has also beefed up its security arrangements, calling in plain-clothed
police patrols to guard tourist sites through the festive period, with 6000
additional police drafted in for Hogmanay.

As international attention was focused by the latest spate of activity, Britain
condemned the female bomber believed to be responsible for the Pakistan
explosion.

The burka-clad woman is thought to have claimed at least 43 lives and injured a
further 100 people in a suicide attack on Friday against a crowd of people
queueing for food at an aid distribution centre.

The death toll from the blast, in the town of Khar, close to the Afghan border
where the Taliban and al-Qaeda have strongholds, is expected to grow  as some of
the wounded succumb to their injuries.

Foreign Office minister Alistair  Burt said the atrocity reinforced the need for
international co-operation against terror.

He said:  This appalling attack on innocent refugees is a cruel reminder of the
indiscriminate aims of the terrorist and an example of why the world must work
together to do all we can to confront a menace without boundaries.

Many of the people killed and injured in the attack had already been displaced
by fierce fighting between militants and the Pakistani military.

The blast coincided with a Pakistani security operation which killed  around 40
rebels in Mohmand, a nearby tribal region.

Helicopters ferried the wounded and dying to hospital.

Pakistani Prime Minister Syed Yusuf Raza Gilani condemned the slaughter, and
vowed to continue the country s fight against militants. The perpetrators had no
regard for humanity or religion, he said.

The Taliban has already claimed responsibility for the attack.

On Friday and early yesterday, two separate attacks in Nigeria killed a further
40 or more people.

The deaths were reported after a series of explosions around the city of Jos, in
the central region. At least 74 people were injured or left in a  critical
condition.

The incident was politically motivated, Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan
said. However, a second outbreak of violence that killed six or more people at
two churches on Friday night appeared to be sparked by religious tensions.

What happened (in Jos) was not religious, it was political   the aim of the
masterminds is to pit Christians against Muslims and start another round of
violence,  the governor of Plateau state said.

In the second set of attacks, petrol bombs were thrown at churches, killing four
worshippers, a Baptist pastor and a security guard late on Christmas Eve.

In a separate development, Yemen announced last night that it would establish a
special anti-terror force to tackle the rising threat of al-Qaeda in four
restless provinces.

The resurgent terror network has been of increasing concern to the west, with
the Arabian Peninsula now widely seen as a hotbed of global terror.

Al-Qaeda s regional arm claimed responsibility for the failed attempt  last year
to blow up a passenger plane over Detroit.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                  Sunday Mail

                           December 26, 2010, Sunday

TERRORIST BUSBY ON NEW JAIL ATTACK RAP

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 263 words


TARTAN terrorist Adam Busby Jnr has been charged with attacking a prison guard
in a maximum security jail.

It is the second time in the last two months that Busby has been accused of
violence against prison officers.

In the latest incident Busby, 35, is alleged to have attacked David Dunn in a
cell in the segregation area at Shotts Prison in Lanarkshire.

It is claimed he punched and injured the officer on the head and body on
September 9. Busby, who is serving his time for terrorist offences, was not at
Hamilton Sheriff Court when the case was heard last week.

His solicitors asked for the case to be continued for several weeks to allow
further investigations.

Sheriff Shiona Waldron adjourned until January 19.

Busby was convicted last month of attacking warders who opened his cell door in
the segregation unit at privately run Addiewell jail in West Lothian in March.

He cut one officer's lip with a punch. His second blow glanced off the second
warder's head.

At Livingston Sheriff Court, Busby was found guilty of assault and given an
extra six months in jail. He was then moved to Shotts.

Busby, whose dad Adam Snr founded the Scottish National Liberation Army, was
jailed for six years last year for a hoax bomb campaign targeted at politicians.

He said he did it to highlight the ill-health of his dad, who was jailed for
four years in Ireland in July this year for bomb hoaxes.

Busby Jnr sent shotgun shells to English-born MSP Mike Rumbles during his terror
campaign.

He also claimed he had sent explosives to First Minister Alex Salmond and made a
series of hoax bomb calls.

                                 Sunday Express

                            December 26, 2010 Sunday
                                U.K. 1st Edition

Al Qaeda plot New Year terror attack

BYLINE: By James Fielding

SECTION: NEWS; 19

LENGTH: 220  words


SECURITY services are on red alert amid fears that one of Osama bin Laden's
henchman could launch a New Year terror attack in Britain.

MI5 chiefs think Al Qaeda mastermind Saif al-Adel has sent orders to followers
in the UK v ia the internet disguised as Christmas wishes.

They believe 12 men seized by counter-terror officers last week may have
contacted al-Adel, now in hiding on the Pakistan-Afghan border.

However, a small group of suspects of Bangladeshi, Pakistani and Somalian origin
who may have visited terror training camps abroad last year could still be at
large in London, Cardiff and Manchester.

Trafalgar Square on New Year's Eve, January sales or the City of London are all
possible targets for a terrorist attack.

An MI5 source said: "Al Qaeda are planning to attack this country sometime
between Christmas Day and New Year. Police have arrested 12 men who were in the
final stages of one such attack, but they haven't got them all.

"Al-Adel is suspected of sending code words in the form of Christmas greetings
to a number of websites, which are being picked up in Britain. These are really
instructions on what to do next and GCHQ is now racing against time to decipher
them."

Al-Adel is thought to be behind the 1998 US embassy bombs at Dar es Salaam, in
Tanzania, and Nairobi, in Kenya, that killed hundreds.

                              330 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                            December 27, 2010 Monday
                                   Edition 2;
                                National Edition

Don't evacuate shops if there is a terror attack, security chief warns;
TERROR

BYLINE: Duncan Gardham

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 435 words


SHOPPERS and office workers should not be evacuated from buildings in the event
of terrorist attacks, government security advisers are telling employers.

They say people are safer inside a building when a bomb goes off elsewhere.

Nine out of 10 injuries are caused by flying glass when a device explodes,
according to Det Chief Insp Chris Phillips, the head of the National
Counter-Terrorism Security Office. "How to protect Oxford Circus from a
terrorist attack is very difficult," he told a security conference, referring to
the shopping crowds in central London.

"One of the issues is moving people from one place to another. Do we want to
move them outside? Probably not. And yet we are all trained to traipse out on to
the street when alarms go off."

DCI Phillips says that unless people are inside the building where the bomb is,
they should stay where they are in case they walk into the path of the explosion
as they are being moved out. The advice directly contradicts that given by fire
officers, who recommend that buildings should be evacuated when a fire breaks
out.

Mr Phillips says that crowds of people are ideal targets for bombers, especially
those who have strapped devices to themselves like the recent Stockholm bomber.

The advice is similar in the event of a Mumbai-style shooting attack, where
fleeing members of the public could be picked off by terrorists.

However, those inside a building attacked by terrorist commandos stand a better
chance if they escape rather than hide, assuming they can find a safe route out.

DCI Phillips says there is a case for introducing different fire and bomb alarms
in buildings and for issuing advice over a Tannoy.

The National Counter-Terrorism Security Office is responsible for giving advice
to companies that are considered "crowded places" including shopping centres,
office blocks and sports grounds, as well as smaller employers.

The unit is based at the Centre for the Protection of National Infrastructure,
part of MI5. DCI Phillips said that he often had a lukewarm reception when
giving advice about how to deal with a terrorist attack because people believed
he was "making it all up" about the threat.

He said attacks in London, Glasgow, Exeter and Bristol in recent years showed
that anyone could be affected.

"When something does happen it probably won't be the emergency services making
the key decisions," he added.

"It may be the person being paid £5.50 an hour at the front gate."

The issue was highlighted at the July 7 inquest where a number of emergency
responders were told not to go on to the Underground in case there were
secondary devices.

LOAD-DATE: December 27, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: DTL


                  Copyright 2010 Telegraph Media Group Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

Indian southwestern state on high alert over possible terror attacks

of southern India's most influential English daily The Hindu on 28 December

Bangalore: Security in the State has been tightened following intelligence
inputs from the Union Government reportedly suggesting of a terror attack in the

chaired a meeting of senior police officials.

Chief Minister B.S. Yeddyurappa, who chaired a high-level meeting here on
Monday, told presspersons: "Security has been tightened in the State after a
terror alert was sounded by Central Intelligence agencies.

"A high alert has been sounded, especially in coastal districts."

                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           December 28, 2010 Tuesday

Iraqi TV shows recorded videos of "terrorists" describing roles in attacks

LENGTH: 3426 words


At 1812 gmt on 24 December, Iraqi government-controlled Al-Iraqiyah TV carries
the second episode of a talk show entitled "Exclusive to Al-Iraqiyah" prepared
and presented by host Abd-al-Karim Hamadi.

Before the host interviews his guest in studio Major General Ahmad Abu-Raghif,
general director of the Domestic Affairs Department at the Interior Ministry,
Al-Iraqiyah airs a video showing footage of a number of members of the Islamic
State of Iraq, who were arrested in a security operation entitled the Qabdat
al-Haqq, Fist of Righteousness, describing their roles in a number of attacks in
Al-A'zamiyah, Al-Bayya, Al-Qahirah, and other places.

Attacks on Police and Army Checkpoints in Al-A'zamiyah Area

The first report shows Amir of Baghdad Hudhayfah Abd-al-Sattar al-Battawi,
"arrested leader of terrorist group" operating in Baghdad. Al-Battawi begins by
saying that he received instructions to attack police and army checkpoints in a
certain area in Baghdad and take control of the area "even if for few moments."
Al-Battawi says: "When we received the instructions, I consulted with Al-Askari
and the Umara [heads] of units on the best and most important places to carry
out this operation."

The report then shows Abd-al-Majid al-Alwani, "arrested terrorist", saying: "He
told me we will hit them today, in Al-A'zamiyah." Asked about whom they would
target, Al-Alwani said: "The guards."

Firas Fadil Abd-al-Dulaymi, who was arrested in the Qabdat al-Haqq Operation,
began by saying: "We first went to explore the area and then carried out the
operation the next day. We had some fighters for the other checkpoints."

"Arrested terrorist" Ali Jawad Kazim, aka Ali Kia, says: "We were four persons,
actually three. Qusay was my senior. He was my direct supervisor. We caught
sight of the target in front of us. We began exploring the area in Al-A'zamiyah
days before [the operation.] My rank was of a major."

Al-Battawi goes on to say: "After discussions and consultations, we agreed that
the best place to carry out the operation is the Al-A'zamiyah neighbourhood on
Umar Street, which we selected. We then began our preparations for the operation
with the assistance of Abu-Ammar, who was the Amir of Al-Rusafah [leader of the
unit in Al-Rusafah]. This operation was to take place in his section.
[Abu-Ammar] was assigned to complete the preparations for this operation by
providing fighters and weapons. We assisted him in the meticulous planning for
the operation."

"Arrested terrorist" Umar Fayyad Jasim, aka Qusay, is shown as saying: "I
received instructions from Abu-Ammar to attack checkpoints and set fire to
vehicles in Al-A'zamiyah. We explored the place. My direct orders were to seize
control of the beginning of Umar Street. We, Abu-Ammar and I, went to explore
the place one day earlier. He prepared a car and weapons." Fayyad Jasim adds:
"We scheduled the attack at noon. Abu-Ammar ordered me to set the vehicle on
fire."

Kazim says: "Qusay and Firas went out. It was the zero hour. It was around 1400
or 1430 [1100 or 1130 gmt]." Kazim goes on to say that a man told him to move
because it is prohibited to park there. He added that when he asked Qusay what
to do the latter told him the drive to the main street. Kazim then says that
when he exited the street his companions carried out the operation, noting that
he could hear the sound of the rounds being fired. Kazim says that he tried to
reach the group but was unable to do so because of the traffic. He adds that
after smashing into four or five cars he reached them but then the car was
unusable and they had to abandond it.

Fayyad Jasim says: "Two of the checkpoint soldiers were standing near a vehicle.
Farsi and I attacked the soldiers. I had a gas tank with me. So, we set fire to
the vehicle. Ali Kia was with me while Abu-Idris was covering us."

Abd-al-Dulaymi is shown as saying: "Qusay and Abu-Idris approached [the cars] on
foot while carrying sidearms and Kalashnikovs. Qusay set the car ablaze along
with two dead bodies. We retreated to the car but it was hit. We then retreated
on foot. We raised our guns in a booth inside Al-A'zamiyah."

The report then shows video footage of the terrorists while setting fire to the
car in Al-Azamiyah.

"Arrested terrorist" Abd-al-Sattar Jasim, aka Abd-al-Azim says: "Abu-Ammar was
the one in charge of this operation. About four cars participated in the
operation. I was driving an olive green Peugeot. There was a regular car ahead
of us, another Peugeot, and a third car that I did not recognize. Our mission
was to attack the checkpoints without covering our faces, kill the soldiers and
policemen at the checkpoints, and set fire to the vehicles with their
passengers."

Kazim says: "We could not handle the guards. Qusay, Farsi, the wanted Firas, and
I took our guns and escaped. We are the ones shown in the video."

The video report shows the full video footage of the attack in Al-A'zamiyah.

Al-Battawi says: "The explosives group was assigned to a certain task. They were
to cut off all the roads leading to the street so that all reinforcements are
unable to reach the area when the fighters reach the street and work on taking
control of the checkpoints. All the roads leading to Umar Street were cut off,
including Antar Square, 20th Street, and Balasim Palace. Roadside bombs were
planted on all these roads. Every patrol that came through these roads was
targeted with a roadside bomb which cut off all roads. This facilitated the
operation and the withdrawal."

Video footage then shows the mother and brother of a victim of the attack called
Muhammad al-Azzawi. Azzawi's mother says that his corpse was charred to the
point that they could only identify him with his socks.

Attacks on Jewellery Shops in Al-Bayya and Al-Bunuk Neighbourhoods

Another part of the video shows Al-Battawi saying: "During my leadership, the
group was mostly self-funded. The funds majorly came from the attacks in the
areas of Al-Bayya and Al-Mansur. We used the gold we stole from there to fund
our operations and reconstruct the group."

Umar Fayyad Jasim says: "I received instructions from the same person,
Abu-Ammar, to participate with a man called Ziyad in the attacks on the
jewellery shops. Our first operation was the attack on the gold shops in
Al-Shu'lah area. The man called Ziyad prepared for the operation." Fayyad Jasim
adds: "We scouted the shops; aman named Yasir and myself."

The video footage then shows Abd-al-Sattar Jasim saying: "We received
instructions to attack the jewellery shops in order to obtain money to fund the
operations, because the organization was in need of funds."

"Arrested terrorist" Abdallah Abd-al-Fattah, aka Ziyad, begins by saying: "The
Al-Shu'lah operation was a qualitative operation. [The attack targeted] the
jewellery shops in Al-Shu'lah; four of them. Fifteen people, maybe 18,
participated in the operation." He goes on to say: "After we took the gold, we
delivered it to the [central] headquarters to deal with it."

Fayyad Jasim says: "After this operation, we carried out an attack on the
jewellery shops in the Al-Bunuk area. Again, I worked with Ziyad in the attacks
on jewellery shops in the Al-Bunuk area. We used guns with silencers to carry
out the attack. Ziyad and a man named Abu-Hajj killed the shop owners while I
collected the gold. We took the gold and then withdrew. Another group of
fighters killed the policemen in the Al-Bunuk area."

Abd-al-Fattah says: "We and the fighters were assigned to attack the jewellery
shops in the Al-Bayya area. We had one Kia microbus and two smaller cars." He
adds: "We were between 15 and 20 persons. We were tasked with this operation
because, as we were told, the group needed funds." Abd-al-Fattah then says: "We
received orders from the headquarters to explore the Al-Bayya target. We were
there to explore it. Some members of Al-Qa'idah, with the knowledge of the
leader who gave the orders of course, began to explore the area for days until
we could obtain a car and prepare the fighters. We agreed to carry out the
operation at noon, around 1200 [ 0900 gmt]."

Abd-al-Sattar Jasim says: "Since we were unable to leave the Al-Bayya using the
car, it was decided that we keep the car in Al-Bayya and leave with our weapons
on foot."

Abd-al-Fattah adds: "Months later, we received orders to attack a jewellery shop
in the Al-Bunuk neighbourhood." He further says: "We were told to pick whomever
we want as partners in the operation. They told us that they will bring in some
people from Al-Karkh and Al-Rusafah." Abd-al-Fattah says: "We carried the
operation around 1600 [ 1300 gmt]. I was there with Qusay, Abd-al-Azim, and
Ahmad. All of them belonged to sectors of the group which I knew well." He goes
on to say: "Two entered the shop; Qusay and maybe Ahmad. I waited outside. Then
we came under gunfire from the surrounding area. They tried to hurry them. They
killed the shop owner. We did not know who had opened fire on us." Asked about
the people who had been with him, he says: "Qusay, Abd-al-Azim, Ahmad, and some
people from other sectors whom I do not remember well. There was another one
with us. We could not take him back with us. He was arrested by the security
forces."

The report then shows a video footage of security members uncovering weapons and
explosives.

Attacks Against Al-Arabiya TV; Police Officers, Checkpoints, Jewellery Shop in
Al-Qahirah Area

Umar Fayyad Jasim says: "I received orders from Abu-Ammar to join forces with a
man called Abu-Jasim and his fighters to attack a jewellery shop in the
Al-Qahirah area. We carried this attack with them using guns with silencers. We
took the gold." Jasim adds: "We then killed the owners of the shop."

"Arrested terrorist" Abd-al-Rahman Hamid al-Basrawi, aka Wathiq, says: "The
office of Al-Arabiya TV was attacked [ 26 July] because the channel fought
against my kind of thinking. It voiced its rejection of it, made films against
it, and raised awareness against it." He adds: "The best to do was to attack it
so as to deter it. The plan was to get a booby-trapped car inside the building,
but this was too difficult to achieve. We then thought the Korak Company
[maintenance company] was near the Al-Arabiya TV office." Al-Basrawi says: "We
got an Iraqi suicide bomber - an Iraqi national. We booby-trapped the car. He
then took the car, entered the building with a [false] ID, and parked the car in
the parking lot."

The video shows footage of the aftermath of the attack on the office of
Al-Arabiya TV.

Hisham-Abd-al-Hamid Abbas al-Dulaymi says: "We were tasked with attacking police
patrols on four streets in Al-Yarmuk."

Abd-al-Dulaymi says: "We carried out the second attack on traffic policemen. It
was carried out at approximately 0500 [ 0200 gmt] in Maysalun Square. The
explosive charges were planted inside the [police] booth."

Ya'rub Qahtan Abd-al-Hamid says: "The attack that followed was against the
traffic police near Tariq Abu-Shabat Street, Al-Waziriyah area." He adds: "Azhar
carried out the attack. We were riding another car; Abu-Ayyub and Husayn
attacked them. He shot at him with a silenced gun, took his gun, and got back
into the car."

"Arrested terrorist" Tahah Khudayr Sulayman Muhammad, aka Abu-Hashim, says:
"Qusay gave us orders to attack traffic police and plant explosive charges
targeting them."

Ali Jawad Kazim says: "We planted two explosive charges in the Al-Baladiyat area
and on the Muhammad al-Qasim highway."

Umar Fayyad Jasim says: "We then carried out an attack against an Iraqi Army
checkpoint in the Al-Ghadir area. Abu-Ammar gave us the orders. Abu-Ammar
selected the checkpoints [to be attacked]. He gave the orders to Abbas, a man
called Abu-Ahmad, and myself. We attacked the checkpoint, killed the soldiers,
and then retreated."

Hisham Abd-al-Hamid Abbas al-Dulaymi says: "We shot a police officer in Al-Tubji
with silenced guns." He adds: "Then we shot a police officer in Al-Waziriyah. We
shot him with guns and machineguns. He was driving his car near a gas station
near Al-Waziriyah." Asked how they identified police officers, Al-Dulaymi says:
"Through car plates or if they were in uniform." Asked whether they used to
target specific people, Al-Dulaymi says: "No, we just go out and shoot."

Suicide Attack Against Ahtar Hotel

Abd-al-Sattar Jasim says: "Ziyad was ordered to provide me with a GMC car loaded
with weapons. The car contained sticky bombs and machine guns. I was to deliver
the car to a specific location. I took the car to the specified location, the
Al-Radwaniyah area, where a man named called Yasir had to be waiting. I had to
deliver the car to him at a specific hour after sunset. I went there but did not
find Yasir, so I went back. On my way back, I came across a checkpoint, at which
Interior Affairs police stopped me and asked for the car license. I was arrested
and brought back to the ministry. When they searched the car they found the
weapons."

This is followed by a video footage of the seized GMC car and the explosives
found inside and the suicide attack against the Ashtar Hotel.

Abd-al-Rahman Hamid al-Basrawi says: "My next job was the attacks against the
hotels. After we received orders from Amir Hatim," adding: "He told us to scout
the target and so we did. Following these orders we purchased the cars; the car
which carried out the attack on Ashtar Hotel. It was a Ford, seven or 11
passengers. The explosives team drove the car near the target. Then, the suicide
bomber named Asim drove to Ashtar Hotel and carried out the attack from
Abu-Nawwas Street."

This is followed by video footage of the suicide bomber Asim driving the car
which was used in the attack and footage of the explosion.

Al-Basrawi says: "The Al-Hamra Hotel attack was a joint operation, a double hit.
A man would clear the road using his weapon, elevate the bar closing the
entrance, and allow the car to enter the hotel."

This is followed by video footage showing the group which cleared the road for
the booby-trapped car to enter the hotel.

Preparations for Attack Against the Our Lady of Salvation Church

Al-Battawi says: "We also received orders to blow up as many cars as possible in
as many locations as possible in Baghdad. The orders required that we blow up no
less than 12 or 13 cars." Al-Battawi goes on to say: "We were busy preparing for
the attack on the church. At the time, we ordered all sections to prepare and
get ready for this operation. Every section was to blow up at least five cars.
We agreed that this was to happen two days after the attack on the church. We
also agreed that these [explosions] should be synchronized. As I recall, they
were scheduled to take place between 1830-1900 [1530-1600] in order to maximize
chaos and lack of security on the streets."

This is followed by video footage showing the aftermath of the car bomb
explosions.

Host Hamadi and Maj Gen Abu-Raghif begin discussing the video footage.
Abu-Raghif begins by saying: "Our investigations with the arrested terrorists
showed that they worked and gathered in specific places, particularly near the
posts of US forces." Abu-Raghif adds: "Most of these [terrorists] are criminals
who have a criminal history in murder and robbery."

Abu-Raghif says: "As I said in the last episode, we depended greatly on the data
base which we compiled throughout our investigations with the accused whom we
had arrested in earlier incidents. Actually, through the documents obtained by
the investigators, we were able to identify the terrorists and criminals who
committed these heinous crimes. Based on that, we worked on the methods of track
down these terrorists."

Abu-Raghif says: "After that we began a thorough tracking operation and were
able to arrest an important figure whom we believed would be the key to the
Al-A'zamiyah case." Abu-Raghif further says: "He [Ali Jawad Kazim, aka Ali Kia]
was arrested in the Al-Qahirah neighbourhood."

Abu-Raghif says: "We found out that some of them burn some of their filmed
terrorist operations on CDs. They then try to slip these CDs inside the houses
of the security personnel [as threat messages]."

Abu-Raghif says: "Following the arrest of this man [Ali Jawad Kazim, aka Ali
Kia], we were able to seize these CDs which they used in threatening the
security members." He adds that Kazim was a wanted criminal. Abu-Raghif says:
"The investigations showed that [Kazim] began his [criminal] career in planting
explosive charges on the airport road." Abu-Raghif says that Kazim did not
reside in the Al-Qahirah area, where he was arrested, adding that he used to
live in the Baghdad al-Jadidah area but the Al-Qahirah area was within his work
territory, and he went there to distribute the threat CDs.

Abu-Raghif goes on to say that after a thorough search of Kazim's car, they were
able to uncover documents tt helped them to identify and track down his partners
in crime.

Asked if Kazim, aka Ali Kia, was involved in any terrorist attacks other than
the one in Al-A'zamiyah, Abu-Raghif says that he confessed to planting roadside
bombs on the Baghdad Airport road, as well as killing a man and stealing his
car, a Peugeot, which he and his partners used later in a bombing attack.
Abu-Raghif adds that Kazim and his partners also killed another man and stole
his car, a Kia, and later booby-trapped the car and detonated it in the
Al-Saydiyah area. Abu-Raghif adds that Kazim was wanted for the blasts in
Al-Sadr City and Al-Karradah, adding that the yellow Peugeot was one of the cars
that was detonated in Al-Sadr City.

Asked about the attack on the checkpoints in Al-A'zamiyah, Abu-Raghif says:
"Such attacks are hatched by some groups which come from the Al-Karkh and
Al-Rusafah areas." Abu-Raghif adds: "They used five cars to carry out this
attack, in addition to the group which planted the explosive charges on the
roads leading to the checkpoints." Abu-Raghif notes: "Most of the people who
participated in the Al-A'zamiyah operation were arrested."

Asked about the inconsistencies shown in the statements of the group's members,
Abu-Raghif says: "The details [of the operation] do not reach the regular
members of the [terrorist] group; they stay within the circle of their leaders.
They receive instructions from the main command which consults with the rest of
the sections' commanders. They receive their specific instructions during the
course of the actual operation."

Abu-Raghif goes on to say that Umar Fayyad Jasim, aka Qusay, was among three men
arrested in a raid on a house in the Al-Baladiyat area. Abu-Raghif adds that he
was later identified by Kazim, aka Ali Kia.

Asked about the attack on the office of Al-Arabiya TV, Abu-Raghif says that the
terrorists were disguised as maintenance workers, and had used false IDsto enter
the building of the Korak Company, which is adjacent to Al-Arabiya office adding
that they carried out their attack from there. Abu-Raghif says that the
explosives used in the attack weighed around 500 kilograms, adding that the
suicide bomber was an Iraqi national.

On the attacks on the jewellery shops, Abu-Raghif says that some of the stolen
jewelleries were used in funding the terrorist operations, and others were given
to the wives of the killed terrorists.

Abu-Raghif says: "This group assassinated 88 persons, including security members
and figures, and officials."

Abu-Raghif says that the security forces tracked down Abu-Hashim and Firas
through the confessions of Qusay, who had said that he paid a six-month
electricity bill of their safe house.

Abu-Raghif goes on to say that they uncovered two cars, which the terrorists had
used in the attacks on the checkpoints, in that house, adding that they found
guns with silencers attached to them. Abu-Raghif says that the confessions of
the criminals led the security forces to five munitions caches; namely, in
Al-Ghadir, Al-Zayyunah, Al-Baladiyat, Al-Za'faraniyah, and Al-Muzmarah, near
Al-Zayyunah.

This is followed by a video showing footage of the aftermath of the attack on
the Our Lady of Salvation Church, and an unidentified person saying: "I was
among the people who plotted and supervised this operation. I was among those
who carried out this operation. I was around 200 meters away from the church.
One of the executers of the attack came in driving the car which carried the
explosives used in the attack. There was another car that carried Kalashnikovs
and hand grenades."

The host concludes by thanking Abu-Raghif and says that they will discuss the
footage shown earlier in the next and last episode of this series.

Source: Al-Iraqiyah TV, Baghdad, in Arabic 1812 gmt 24 Dec 10

                               Belfast Telegraph

                           December 28, 2010 Tuesday
                                 First Edition

Nine in court over alleged Christmas terror attacks plot

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 434 words


NINE men have been remanded in custody charged with planning a pre-Christmas
terror attack in the UK.

The suspects, aged between 19 and 28, and from Cardiff, London and
Stoke-on-Trent, were held a week ago during a series of dawn raids by
counter-terrorism officers.

They appeared in the dock at City of Westminster Magistrates Court in three
separate groups.

Each spoke only to confirm his name, date of birth and address, before Senior
District Judge Howard Riddle remanded them to appear at the Old Bailey on
January 14.

Twelve men were held during the raids by unarmed police on December 20 in
London, Cardiff, Stoke-on-Trent and Birmingham.

Two men from Cardiff and one from London have been released without charge.

The nine suspects are charged with conspiring to cause by an explosive substance
an explosion or explosions "of a nature likely to endanger life or cause serious
injury to property in the UK" between November 6 and December 21 this year.

They are also accused of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of
terrorism between November 6 and December 21, including downloading,
researching, obtaining and discussing materials and methods; researching,
discussing and carrying out reconnaissance on and agreeing potential targets;
travelling to and attending meetings; and igniting and testing incendiary
material.

The suspects from Cardiff are Gurukanth Desai (28), of Albert Street; Omar
Sharif Latif (26), of Neville Street; and Abdul Malik Miah (24), of Ninian Park
Road.

The suspects from London are Mohammed Moksudur Rahman Chowdhury (20), of
Stanliff House, Tower Hamlets, and Shah Mohammed Lutfar Rahman (28), of St
Bernard's Road, Newham.

The suspects from Stoke- on-Trent are Nazam Hussain (25), of Grove Street; Usman
Khan (19), of Persia Walk; Mohibur Rahman (26), of North Road; and Abul Bosher
Mohammed Shahjahan (26), of Burmarsh Walk.

Last week's raids came after several months of surveillance and monitoring by
police and MI5 officers.

At the time the country's top counter-terrorism officer, Metropolitan Police
Assistant Commissioner John Yates, said it was "absolutely vital" for the public
to remain vigilant.

The operation was the most high-profile anti-terror raid in Britain since April
2009, when 12 men were detained across northern England.

All were released without charge but authorities still insisted they had
thwarted an al-Qaida bomb plot that was based in Manchester.

CAPTION: Mohammed Moksudur Rahman Chowdhury (left) and another of the nine men
charged with planning an alleged pre-Christmas terror attack leave Westminster
Magistrates Court in a police van PA Wire

                            The Independent (London)

                           December 28, 2010 Tuesday
                                 First Edition

Nine men charged with plotting terrorist attack;
COURTS

BYLINE: Michael Savage

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 230 words


Nine men have been remanded in custody after being charged with plotting a
terrorist attack on British targets in the run-up to Christmas.

The suspects, from Cardiff, London and Stoke-on-Trent and aged between 19 and
28, were charged with terrorism offences including conspiracy to cause
explosions. They appeared at Westminster magistrates' court in three groups and
spoke only to confirm their name, date of birth and address.

They were among 12 men held following co-ordinated dawn raids in London,
Cardiff, Stoke-on-Trent and Birmingham a week ago. Two men from Cardiff and one
from London were released without charge.

Those in custody have been charged with conspiring to cause an explosion "of a
nature likely to endanger life or cause serious injury to property in the UK"
between 6 November and 21 December.

The charges also include preparing for a terrorist act during the same period by
downloading and discussing methods, carrying out reconnaissance on an agreed
target and testing explosives. The nine will appear at the Old Bailey on 14
January.

Gurukanth Desai, 28, Omar Sharif Latif, 26, and Abdul Malik Miah, 24, are from
Cardiff. Mohammed Moksudur Rahman Chowdhury, 20, and Shah Mohammed Lutfar
Rahman, 28, are from London.

The other four suspects - Nazam Hussain, 25, Usman Khan, 19, Mohibur Rahman, 26,
and Abul Bosher Mohammed Shahjahan, 26 - are from Stoke-on-Trent.

9 REMANDED OVER TERROR ATTACK CLAIM;
BRITAIN Briefing

NINE men were remanded in custody charged with planning a pre-Christmas terror
attack.

The suspects, aged between 19 and 28, and from Cardiff, London and
Stoke-on-Trent, were held a week ago during a series of dawn raids by
counter-terrorism officers. They appeared in the dock at City of Westminster

                              336 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                    Scotsman

                           December 28, 2010 Tuesday

'Terror nine tested bombs for attack' - prosecutors

BYLINE: Angus Howarth

LENGTH: 365 words



HIGHLIGHT: Nine men have been remanded in custody charged with planning a
pre-Christmas terror attack, including carrying out test explosions.


The suspects, aged 19 to 28, and from Cardiff, London and Stoke-on-Trent, were
held a week ago during a series of dawn raids by counter-terrorism officers.

They appeared at City of Westminster Magistrates' Court in three separate
groups.

Each confirmed his name, date of birth and address, before Senior District Judge
Howard Riddle remanded them to appear at the Old Bailey on 14 January.

Twelve men were held during police raids on 20 December in London, Cardiff,
Stoke-on-Trent and Birmingham.

Two men from Cardiff and one from London have been released without charge.

The nine suspects are charged with conspiring to cause, by an explosive
substance, an explosion or explosions "of a nature likely to endanger life or
cause serious injury to property in the UK" between 6 November and 21 December
this year.

They are also accused of engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of
terrorism between 6 November and 21 December, including by downloading,
researching, obtaining and discussing materials and methods; researching,
discussing and carrying out reconnaissance on and agreeing potential targets;
travelling to and attending meetings; and igniting and testing incendiary
material.

The suspects from Cardiff are Gurukanth Desai, 28; Omar Sharif Latif, 26; and
Abdul Malik Miah, 24.

The suspects from London are Mohammed Moksudur Rahman Chowdhury, 20, of Tower
Hamlets; and Shah Mohammed Lutfar Rahman, 28, of Newham.

The suspects from Stoke-on-Trent are Nazam Hussain, 25; Usman Khan, 19; Mohibur
Rahman, 26; and Abul Bosher Mohammed Shahjahan, 26.

Last week's raids came after several months of surveillance and monitoring by
police and MI5 officers.

At the time, the country's top counter-terrorism officer, Metropolitan Police
Assistant Commissioner John Yates, said it was "absolutely vital" for the public
to remain vigilant.

Sue Hemming, head of the Crown Prosecution Service Counter Terrorism Division,
said yesterday: "I have today advised the police that nine men should be charged
with conspiracy to cause explosions and with engaging in conduct in preparation
for acts of terrorism with the intention of either committing acts of terrorism,
or assisting another to commit such acts.

CITY SUSPECTS CHARGED WITH CHRISTMAS BOMB PLOT;
Nine accused of planning terror attack remanded by court

BYLINE: Alford

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 96 words


THREE Cardiff men have been charged with plotting a terror attack in the run-up
to Christmas.

Gurukanth Desai, 28, Omar Sharif Latif, 26, and Abdul Malik Miah, 24, all from
the city's Riverside area, have been remanded in custody.

Together with six others from London and Stoke-on-Trent, they appeared in court
in London yesterday charged with preparing to commit acts of terrorism,
including researching and discussing methods and targets, and conspiring to
cause an explosion.

Members of Cardiff's Riverside community yesterday spoke of their shock.

                               The Sun (England)

                           December 28, 2010 Tuesday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Scotland

7/7 bombers killed my sister...I'm telling kids of all cultures her story to
stop terror attacks from happening again;
ESTHER LAUNCHES SCHOOL 'CITIZENSHIP' CLASSES

BYLINE: AMANDA REVELL WALTON

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 44,45

LENGTH: 1409 words


A WOMAN whose sister was killed in the 7/7 bombings is turning her loss into a
positive force in Britain's schools.

Esther Hyman was told her sister Miriam escaped the 2005 London terror attack
unscathed when she was evacuated from King's Cross Station following three
blasts on the Tube.

But by a terrible twist of fate, the pretty freelance picture editor, aged 32,
was killed instantly when the double decker bus she then boarded was blown up in
Tavistock Square.

Now Esther has teamed up with the school they both attended to launch innovative
"citizenship classes" in her sister's memory to combat extremism.

And she hopes the pilot scheme will be rolled out nationwide to help prevent
more terrorist atrocities.

Esther, 41, who refers to Miriam by her nickname "Mim", says: "Mim wasn't just
my sister, she was my closest friend and confidante.

"When I was told they'd identified her body, I felt like I'd been bashed over
the head. There were a few split seconds of nothingness before the pain started
to set in."

It would have been more than understandable for Esther to be consumed by
feelings of hatred towards the al-Qaeda extremists who orchestrated the deadly
July 7 attacks.

But this was not the case for the former primary school teacher.

Esther, who lives in Oxford, explains: "I've had very few moments of anger. It
just seems so futile.

"I feel more a sense of gloom because as human beings it's about time we just
grew up, got over what divides us and instead concentrated on what we have in
common - and stopped killing each other."

In the years following the outrage Esther has worked tirelessly to do something
to prevent another 7/7.

She explains: "There are groups of people out there who would like to drive as
big a wedge as possible between communities. I'm determined not to allow that to
happen."

Esther says: "The aim of the new project is to teach children social cohesion
and good citizenship.

"We want to stop young people from seeing our cultural differences as something
bad and start seeing them as interesting - to make youngsters enthusiastic about
each others' differences, not fearful.

"Mim never saw people as being of a particular race or religion.

"We have a dad who is from Streatham in London and a mum who is originally from
Calcutta in India - and they're both Jewish. Mim loved that we had all these
mixed influences and treasured them."

The idea for the citizenship classes first took shape after Esther and a charity
she and her parents set up in Mim's memory helped establish The Miriam Hyman
Children's Eye Care Centre in Orissa, India, in July 2008.

She says: "The centre is a fitting and lasting memorial to Mim who was a
brilliant artist and loved nature. She didn't discover she was short-sighted
until she was in her teens and when she first wore glasses it was a revelation
to her.

"She said she could see every leaf on every tree for the first time. So we
thought this would have been close to her heart. Since it opened, there have
been more than 20,000 outpatients' appointments and more than 2,000 surgeries."

After the hospital was up and running, Esther and those involved with the centre
wanted to start addressing the issues behind 7/7. She explains: "We held
seminars and there was a lot of discussion on the need for society to focus on
what people have in common - seeing our diversity as something to be valued.

"We asked ourselves, 'Where can we make the biggest, most positive impact?' The
answer was obvious - education. The young people of today are the citizens of
tomorrow."

Esther and her mum Mavis, 79, approached the head of the all-girl Copthall
Secondary School in Mill Hill, London, where Esther and Miriam had been pupils.

Esther says: "Mum and I went to visit the headteacher Jane Beaumont, two years
ago.

"Although it's single sex, the school is the perfect place for the classes to be
developed as there is a real mixture of pupils from different backgrounds,
cultures and faiths."

Over the next year and a half, Esther and Mavis had countless meetings with the
head and together they worked out how a programme of lessons could fit in with
the curriculum.

Esther explains: "By hearing what happened to my sister, the children will
hopefully be able to see what can happen when there is hatred and intolerance of
other cultures.

"These issues are very difficult to approach in school because they are very
controversial. By doing it through a personal story it will be less
confrontational."

Pupils will also study the area in India where the eye care centre is based.

Esther explains: "They'll learn a little bit about the history and the geography
of the area, how that influences the economy and look at the country's food,
arts and religion.

"The aim is to get children to look around them and be interested in others who
may have a different home life and background to themselves,"

The classes will be piloted with Year 9 students and be woven into at least
seven areas of the National Curriculum.

Esther says: "So,. for example, in dance classes pupils will put together their
own dance based on what they've learnt."

Although it is now more than five years since the 7/7 attacks, Esther believes
the fact extremist acts continue to hit the headlines means there is a real need
for this kind of teaching.

She cites the example of Roshonara Choudhry, 21, from East Ham, London,
sentenced to life imprisonment last month for stabbing former minister Stephen
Timms.

Muslim Choudhry became radicalised after watching hatefilled teachings of
extremist preachers on the internet.

Esther say: "It's exactly young girls and boys like this who we really hope the
activities could influence in a positive way.

"We really want to reach children who do not have much contact with other
communities in their day-to-day lives.

"We'd be more than happy if the classes were taken up in faith schools, where
children are only surrounded by those from a very similar culture and religion
to their own." In fact Esther hopes the classes, which any educational
institution will be able to download in the form of an electronic resource pack,
will eventually be used throughout the UK in primary and secondary schools - and
in English-speaking countries -worldwide.

For Esther and her family, the launch of the pilot classes in memory of Mim has
come at a time of sadness.

The full horror of what happened on 7/7 is being relived daily in central London
at an independent coroner's inquest, expected to last up to five months.

Esther, who was working as a medical secretary at the John Radcliffe Hospital in
Oxford at the time of the bombings, recalls that initially she wasn't too
worried about her sister.

Her father John, 77, spoke to Mim shortly after the third bomb had gone off on
the London underground.

Esther recalls: "She told him she'd been evacuated at King's Cross and was going
to go and have a coffee and try to get an idea of how the situation was panning
out."

Tragically Mim instead jumped on the double decker bus bound for Tavistock
Square, left.

Over the next few days Esther and her family and friends desperately tried to
find her, distributing photos to the media and putting up "missing" posters
around London.

It took four days before Esther and her family were told that Miriam had
definitely been on that bus.

Esther says: "Dad called and said, 'I'm sorry darling, but Mim's been identified
by her dental records.' "I remember saying 'OK' and putting the phone down."

Esther says she immediately knew "nothing would ever be the same again" but she
realised she had to accept what had happened to her sister and do something
positive and constructive.

It was this decision which led her to attend an open day at her local mosque in
Oxford just five weeks after 7/7. She explains: "I went and introduced myself as
the sister of one of the bomb victims.

"I said I was there to extend the hand of friendship and to make sure they knew
that I didn't blame them for the actions of a radicalised few."

Esther adds: "I have learnt that you can't control what happens to you in life
but you can control how you respond to it.

"We hope Mim's legacy will be a better vision of the future - where we are more
each others' friends or, if not friends, at least just respecting each others'
rights.

"That is a vision Mim would have related to."

To donate to the Miriam Hyman Memorial Trust see miriamhyman.com.

'There seconds of nothingness then pain hit me'

'Mim's story shows what hatred can do in a society'

Futile

Hatred

Legacy

LOAD-DATE: December 28, 2010

children at Copthall School; and the bombed Tavistock Square bus on which Miriam
died

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                          December 29, 2010 Wednesday

Pakistan MPs express concern over increasing terrorism, drone attacks

LENGTH: 650 words


Text of report by official news agency Associated Press of Pakistan (APP)

Islamabad, 28 December: Members of the National Assembly Tuesday [28 December]
expressed serious concern about increasing incidents of terrorism and linked it
with drone attacks. They called upon the government to get these attacks halted
which are disturbing law and order and hurting the economy of the country.

PPP [Pakistan People's Party]-Sherpao leader Aftab Ahmed Khan Sherpao said that
more then five drone attacks were reported in tribal areas during the last 24
hours, adding that these attacks were resulting in terrorism and extremism in
Pakistan. He said the government claims that it is against these attacks and
asked then why the joint resolution of the parliament regarding the drone
attacks has not been implemented. He said the government should table the joint
resolution in the House to review the situation because the increasing number of
drone attacks are causing collateral damage as well as resulting in extremism.
Sherpao warned that any military operation in South Waziristan would further
deteriorate the situation.

JUI-F [Jamiat-i-Ulema-i-Islam-Fazlur Rehman] leader Maulana Atta ur Rehman said
that the US forces came to Afghanistan to eliminate terrorism however they have
completely failed to curb the menace which has also affected Pakistan. He also
referred to the joint resolutions of the Parliament on drone attacks and called
for implementation of these resolutions in true letter and spirit.

PML-N [Pakistan Muslim League - Nawaz Sharif] leader Hanif Abbasi said the
government should make its policy clear on drone attacks and let the people know
about any agreement in this regard. He said innocent people have been killed in
drone attacks which were ultimately resulting in terrorism and extremism. He
said the government should arrest the assassins of Shaheed [martyred] Benazir
Bhutto and called for joint struggle to expose her assassins, adding that
Shaheed Benazir Bhutto was an asset of the country and she had remained Prime
Minister for two times.

MQM [Muttahida Qaumi Movement] leader Dr Wasim also expressed concern about law
and order situation and terrorism in the country and called for all holding
parties' conference (APC) to find out a strategy to curb terrorism, suicide
attacks.

PPP leader Fouzia Wahab was also concerned about terrorism and suicide attacks
and said that instead of summoning APC the issue should be debated by the House.
Meanwhile, Dr Darshun staged a walk out from the House to protest increasing
incidents of kidnapping of minorities for ransom in Sindh and other parts of the
country. Adviser to Prime Minister on the directions of Deputy Speaker went to
protesting parliamentarian to bring him back in the House.

Pakistan Muslim League-N chief whip Sheikh Aftab took a strong line on recent
increase in drone attacks in Pakistan's tribal areas and termed it a dent in the
country's sovereign status. He recalled Pakistan's prestige which it acquired in
the comity of nations on becoming the seventh nuclear state in the world and the
first in the Islamic world, but lamented over its inability to be able to stop
drone attacks.

"If we have to live we have to live as a sovereign country. We would not allow
our sovereignty to be compromised," he said. He drew attention of the House to
the shutting down of industry in Faisalabad, country's industrial hub owing to
long power and gas outages. Closure of industry would definitely cast negative
impacts at a juncture when prices had already soared very high in the country,
he argued.

Sheikh Aftab urged the government to make what he called important decisions to
improve law and order, eradicate unemployment and boost economy. He stressed for
re-opening of industry, and institution that were once profit-making.

Source: Associated Press of Pakistan news agency, Islamabad, in English 1505gmt
28 Dec 10

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           December 30, 2010 Thursday

Bosnia: Custody of group charged with terror attack on police station extended

LENGTH: 1063 words


Text of report by Bosnian wide-circulation privately-owned daily Dnevni avaz, on
28 December

[Report by F. Vele: "Terrorist Palislamovic Calls Prosecutor 'Lying Slut,' State
Judge 'Fool'"]

Yesterday's [ 27 December] hearing before the B-H [Bosnia-Hercegovina] Court to
determine the custody of Haris "Oks" Causevic and others charged with the 27
June terrorist attack on the Bugojno Police Administration, turned into an
unprecedented drama!

Extension of Custody

Responsible for the drama was Naser Palislamovic, suspected of organizing this
terrorist attack, which resulted in the death of police officer Tarik Ljubuskic
and severe injuries of his colleague Edina Hindic. Palislamovic in the basest
manner insulted State Prosecutor Tatjana Kosovic and Prosecutor Ozrenka
Neskovic.

The court extended the custody of Causevic, Palislamovic, and Adnan "Maca"
Haracic for another three years from the date of confirmation of the indictment.
The court extended the custody of Emin Osmanagic, Nedzad Kesko, and Haris Spago
for one year. Their custody was extended over the threat of escape, possible
influencing of witnesses and accomplices, possible repeat perpetration or
completion of the crime, and possible violation of peace and order.

Palislamovic started provoking as soon as the names of the defendants were
called out. When asked whether he was present in the courthouse, Palislamovic
said, "I was replaced and they did not bring the right guy." Claiming that he
did not recognize the State Court, he urged the judge to "move on." He then
laughed annoyingly and told judge Kosovic that she was "a fool" and "crazy."

When Judge Kosovic asked Haracic if he was married, Palislamovic shouted, "He is
waiting for you!" He then said that the judge needed "a psychiatrist."

He subsequently started provoking Prosecutor Neskovic. During her explanation as
to why the defendants' custody should be extended, Palislamovic shouted, "Cut it
short! You ramble on and on!"

"You should tell us where you hid the white Nissan. You rotten woman... You
lying slut... You musrik [nonbeliever] whore... I will send you a man to show
you where the Nissan is. You will see who you are dealing with... All of you are
musrik vermin! You were in the gutter. You are made of clots [as published]. Who
gives you the right to try me?" Palislamovic shouted in a fit, banging his fist
on the table and saying that he was a believer.

He then shouted "Allahu Akbar!" twice in the courtroom.

This unprecedented incident in the State Court ended when Judge Kosovic ordered
police officers to take the rampant Palislamovic out of the courthouse. This
behaviour was the reason why Fahrija Karkin, Palislamovic's ex officio lawyer,
decided yesterday to stop defending him. He said that although he had defended
all sorts of people in the past, he would not defend someone who disrespected
the State Court. He wavered all fees.

Repeat Perpetration

Prosecutor Neskovic explained that the B-H Prosecutor's Office had a vast number
- 94 - of pieces of evidence against the defendants, as well as statements of
many witnesses. According to her, this evidence was sufficient to conclude that
the defendants had committed the crimes they were charged with. She warned that
a large number of witnesses were concerned about their own safety.

Speaking about the defendants' possible repeat perpetration if released, she
pointed out that some of them had been collecting in Bugojno vast quantities of
arms, ammunition, and explosive ordnance - which they had intended to use to
carry out terrorist attacks on unspecified targets - ever since 2008.

The weapons were discovered only after the attack in Bugojno. Neskovic said that
the investigation conducted thus far had not identified the people from whom
they had obtained the weapons, and had not determined how they had obtained the
money to pay for the arms - the latter being a matter of particular interest.

"The arms were collected over a period of several years. Because no one knew
about it, they might gath er it unobserved again. We discovered another
explosive device that was ready to use, along with the stick and the charges.
After the attack Haracic dug it out of the ground and threw it in the Visocica
River," Neskovic said.

Yesterday lawyers warned that Kesko received ethnically offensive remarks from
one of the guards in the Orasje Prison. This, along with economic reasons, was
grounds for the lawyers' motion that the defendants be moved to the B-H Court's
detention unit in Sarajevo.

[Box] Haris Causevic: I Am Not a Bosniak; I Am a Bosnian

Addressing the court, Causevic said that the prosecutor was behaving like
"Dzemila the psychic" because she did not have grounds to say that Bugojno
residents were concerned about his possible pretrial release. According to him,
this was a case of "social engineering" and propaganda so that the public would
condemn him before the verdict was pronounced. He requested that his data not
say that he was a Bosniak because he was of Bosnian ethnicity.

"They want to turn me into a caveman. They claim that I wanted to assassinate
all politicians, which is nonsense. I am not Radovan Karadzic. This is a
political indictment... I am warning the court not to fall for these tricks. The
prosecutor knew that I had been tortured, but she covered it up. They broke my
leg with crowbars. This is the reason why they hide my photographs from the
investigation. Do not be the ones who generate terrorism. Let me go," Causevic
said, among other things.

He asked Judge Kosovic that a laptop be brought to him in prison, but the judge
refused. He said that, in that case, he would not be responsible if someone on
the Internet were to use his identity and write all sorts of things.

Sweeping Generalizations

Seeking release of their clients, the lawyers said that the B-H Prosecutor's
Office presented evidence in an inadequate manner. According to them, there was
not sufficient evidence to specify the responsibility of each of the defendants.
They said that sweeping generalizations were made about the threat of escape or
undue influence, without proof that this truly could happen.

Previous Convictions

Naser Palislamovic: forgery, domestic violence, and threat to safety.

Adnan Haracic: theft.

Emin Osmanagic: robbery.

Haris Spago: damaging of other people's property.

Source: Dnevni avaz, Sarajevo, in Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian 28 Dec 10 p 2

LOAD-DATE: December 30, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           December 30, 2010 Thursday

Russian paper describes strategic force response to terrorist attack in USA

LENGTH: 695 words


Text of report by the website of liberal Russian newspaper Vremya Novostey on 13
December


[Report by Yuriy Golotyuk: "Avoiding War: Russian Military Ordered Not to
Prepare for Attack against US"]

In the words of the "Vremya novostey" newspaper's top-level sources of at the
Russian military agency, the "first hour and a half" following the terrorists'
strikes against Washington and New York" were the most dangerous for the world.
The US Army responded to the terrorists' acts by putting troops at the highest
levels of combat readiness with lightning speed. The uncertainty of the threat
and the monstrous scale of the terrorists' acts compelled the Americans to act
in keeping with a worst case scenario: all forces - including its nuclear
arsenals - were urgently prepared to repel aggression. This could only prompt a
retaliatory reaction: Russia automatically was forced to heighten the combat
readiness of its subunits that cover the country's territory, including the air
defence troops and aerospace troops, the Air Force and the Navy, and augmenting
watch shifts were immediately summoned to the Strategic Missile Troops' command
points.

In this situation any new provocation -particularly along the line that is
contiguous with the "zones of responsibility" of the Russian army and the armies
of the US and its NATO allies - was fraught with the danger of a further
uncontrolled escalation of conflict. In a chaotic condition anyone would be
nervous. Particularly in response to the ongoing military preparations in the
States, which led to putting the American armed forces in a "delta" state
(signifying the army's readiness to repel aggression unleashed against the US,
meaning war); this formally required the Russian military leaders to declare a
"period of threat." This signifies the urgent deployment of our nuclear
submarines from their bases along combat patrol routes, the concentration of
missile complexes in back-up positions, moving combat aviation to forward area
basing airfields, and so forth.

It is now difficult to judge at which of these stages the Russian army was
ordered to cease its involuntary "preparation for war" and to not compete with
the Americans in a combat readiness level. Judging from everything, the order
came following an urgent meeting in the Kremlin that President Vladimir Putin
conducted with the ministers of the militarized bloc. Afterward the Russian
General Staff cancelled the Navy's deployment of surface vessels and submarines
to sea and partially reduced the Air Force's level of combat readiness. As
stated at the main command of the national Air Force, at the request of the
American side the Air Force command made urgent adjustments in the Russian
strategic bombers' exercise that was then underway. In the words of the Air
Force main command press secretary, Col Drobyshevskiy: "The practical actions
during the manoeuvres were cancelled," which means that the Russian bombers
cancelled their sorties in the direction of the US, Canada, Norway, Great
Britain, and Iceland. Moreover, they acknowledged at the main command that the
additional steps taken to strengthen control over Russia's air space continued
to operate. All flights directly over Moscow and St Petersburg were banned
(except for special flights), and the tracking of the aircraft of foreign
airlines flying over the country along international air corridors was
heightened. According to our information, the resources of the National Missile
Attack Warning System (SPRN) were fully activated (usually the SPRN radars only
operate at 30 to 50 per cent of their capability), as were those that track
America and those that are focused on the "southern missile-threat direction"
(primarily the Middle East and the Persian Gulf zone). The Russian military
intelligence organization was ordered to "use all available capabilities to
track what was taking place": in the coming days additional technical
intelligence gathering ships were to be deployed to sea, and space troops combat
crews urgently prepared to launch the observation satellites that were available
in their arsenals.

Source: Vremya Novostey website, Moscow, in Russian 13 Dec 10

LOAD-DATE: December 30, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

Terrorist plot to attack newsroom;
World Bulletin

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 100 words


Danish police arrested five suspected Islamist militants who were reported to
have been planning to attack a newspaper that printed cartoons of the Prophet
Mohammed in 2005.

They had planned to enter a Copenhagen office block housing several newspapers,
including offices of the daily Jyllands-Posten, to "kill as many as possible of
those around", police said.

A machine gun with a silencer, ammunition and plastic strips that could be used
as handcuffs were seized.

Jyllands-Posten first published the cartoons of the Prophet, provoking protests
against Danish and European interests in Muslim regions.

WORLD BULLETINS

FOUR people were arrested yesterday suspected of planning a terror attack
against the Danish newspaper that printed the Prophet Mohammed cartoons.

The Danish Security and Intelligence Service, known as PET, said three of the
four men were Swedish residents.

Jakob Scharf, the head of PET, said that "an imminent terror attack has been
foiled". He described some of the suspects as "militant Islamists".

PET said the group was planning to enter the building where the Jyllands-Posten
daily has its Copenhagen newsdesk and wanted "to kill as many people as
possible".

Syria strongly condemns Alexandria terrorist attack

LENGTH: 196 words


Text of report in English by state-run Syrian news agency SANA website

Syria on Saturday [1 January] strongly condemned the vicious terrorist attack
which took place near a church in Alexandria City in the brotherly country of
Egypt.

In a statement to Sana, an official source said as Syria considers that such
terrorist crimes target the national unity and the religious pluralism in Egypt
or other Arab countries, it stands by the brotherly country of Egypt in
confronting terrorism and fighting anything that could harm the Egyptian
national unity.

The source expressed Syria's condolences to Egypt and the families of the
innocent victims, wishing them quick recovery.

The source stressed that Syria is sure of Egypt's keenness on preserving its
national unity and Arabism.

Earlier, the Egyptian authorities announced that a criminal car bomb took place
near a church in Alexandria City killing 21 peoples and injuring 79.

The Egyptian Nile TV Channel cited the Ministry of Interior as saying it is
likely that the explosive device used in Alexandria incident might be carried by
a suicide bomber died in the incident.

                       BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             January 3, 2011 Monday

Report says east Africa likely target for terror attacks

LENGTH: 686 words


Excerpt from report by Jeremiah Kiplang'at entitled ''EA countries likely Al
Qaeda targets, says report'' published by Kenyan newspaper The EastAfrican
website on 3 January

East Africa remains a fertile ground for terrorism, says a new report. The
report by a Maplecroft, a UK-based risk advisory consultancy, finds that Kenya,
Uganda and Tanzania are all at risk of being targeted by terrorist groups.

The group puts Uganda among countries that are top targets of Al-Qa'idah or
other regional extremist groups like Al-Shabab of Somalia. Other countries in
this category of "extreme risk" are Somalia, Pakistan, Algeria, Iraq, Iran,
Afghanistan, Israel, Yemen, the United States and Indonesia, among others.

Kenya is rated as "high risk" while Tanzania, though it is put under "low risk"
countries, is considered by virtue of its proximity to Somalia a potential
target.

East Africa has experienced multiple grenade attacks and two deadly bombings
over the past six months. On 11 July, explosions at two pubs in Kampala where
football fans were watching the World Cup final killed 83 people and injured
scores of others.

The most recent was an accidental explosion in Nairobi that killed the man who
was trying to smuggle a grenade on to a Kampala-bound bus. This incident, with
its minimal loss of life, would have passed under the radar of the international
community had it not been that it involved, directly or indirectly, the three
senior countries forming the East African Community [EAC].

The grenade, according to Kenya Police Commissioner Matthew Iteere, was in the
possession of a Tanzanian national, Albert Olando Mulanda, and he is thought to
have been heading to Uganda, to presumably detonate it there or on the bus
itself, which was full of Ugandan nationals.

Uganda has become a particular target of Al-Shabab terror attacks in retaliation
for the presence of Ugandan troops in Somalia, who make up the bulk of the
African Union Mission in Somalia, Amisom, sent there to bolster the fragile
Transitional Federal Government.

Somalia, which has been without a government for almost two decades, occupies
the top position among the "extreme risk" countries, and states neighbouring
Somalia appear to be at serious risk of being the foremost targets, according to
the report, titled Terrorism Risk Index 2010.

Kenya, the only country in the EAC that shares a border with Somalia, has
witnessed a number of grenade explosions in the recent past; authorities have
blamed an influx of explosives from their Horn of Africa neighbour.

The index assesses countries' safety from terror. Investors use such reports to
decide where to put their investments; with this ranking, east African countries
might suffer an investor-drought in the near future. Maplecroft Chief Executive
Officer Alyson Warhurst confirmed this on the company's website, saying
businesses were being targeted in terrorism prone areas and that it was
essential to carry out such field studies.

"For business, assessing exposures to terrorism is becoming increasingly
necessary," Prof Warhurst said. East Africa could have earned its ranking by
virtue of the number of attacks it has suffered over the period (June 2009 to
June 2010) the study was carried out.

"The index looked at terrorism-related activities from June 2009 to June 2010 to
assess the frequency of terrorist incidents and the intensity of attacks, which
includes the number of victims per attack and the chances of mass casualties
occurring," said the report.

The index also includes a historical parameter assessing the number of attacks
between 2007 and 2009 and looks at whether a country is at risk from a
long-standing militant group operating there. The report comes at a time when
EAC is preparing a security protocol to tackle terrorism in the region.

The chairperson of the EAC Council of Ministers, Hafsa Mossi, said recently that
the protocol to fight "global terrorists including Al-Shabab insurgents" has
been finalized but needs further deliberations before adoption. [Passage
omitted: Story quoting a news agency]

Source: The EastAfrican website, Nairobi, in English 3 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 3, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                              All Rights Reserved
