                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             January 3, 2011 Monday

Pakistan police arrest terror attack suspect in Punjab

LENGTH: 640 words


Text of report by S. Raza Hassan headlined "CID explosion suspect arrested in
Punjab" published by Pakistani newspaper Dawn website on 3 January

Karachi, 2 January: A suspect said to be linked to the 11 November bombing of
the CID offices in Civil Lines was picked up the following day from a Punjab
district, it emerged on Sunday [2 January].

Investigators believed that a number of attackers, who had opened the barrier
and gate of the complex after shooting down the Frontier Constabulary men to let
an explosive-laden truck move in, had escaped.

At least 17 people were killed and scores of others wounded in the blast on the
premises of CID offices on Beaumont Road on the night of 11 November, 2010. The
attack was carried out at 8.20 pm [0320 gmt], when only a few people were
present in the office.

Well-placed sources, who declined to name the suspect, told Dawn that he was
picked up by operatives of an intelligence agency in Rahimyar Khan district on
12 November, when he was returning from Karachi. The suspect was associated with
the proscribed Tehrik-i-Taleban Pakistan, the sources said.

"After the CID blast, the suspect left for Rahimyar Khan the following morning
in a passenger bus and was detained in the district by some intelligence
operatives."

They said the Sindh police had been provided intelligence reports in advance
that a suspect might travel to the province to supervise an attack on a
law-enforcement establishment. The sources said the Punjab police had passed on
the information, including a universal serial bus [USB] which contained the
video clip of the CID Civil Lines building and some other sensitive
installations, about two to three months before the attack was carried out. The
video clip had been made with a pen camera, the sources added.

The USB was seized from the suspects who had been arrested by the Lahore police
in connection with the attacks on the Ahmadis' place of worship in May last
year.

On May 28, 2010, the attackers and suicide bombers stormed two mosques belonging
to the minority Ahmadi sect in Lahore shortly after Friday prayers, killing
around 80 people.

The Lahore police arrested six suspects linked to the attacks on the two
mosques.

Following the arrests, Lahore police chief Mohammad Aslam Tareen told the media
that the suspects belonged to the banned militant outfit, Harakat al-Jihad
al-Islami, as did those who had carried out the attacks.

The Punjab police had passed on all relevant information extracted from the
suspects including the contents of the USB to the Sindh police, the sources
said.

Acting on the information, the Special Police Group personnel were posted
outside the offices of the CID Civil Lines. However, when nothing happened, the
CID took the information as a matter of routine and the SPG personnel were
withdrawn after some time. The sources said: "The SPG personnel were withdrawn
just a few days before the blast."

In the following days of the CID blast, a person called a CID officer from a
public call office in Landhi and expressed the hope that the police must have
got the message and warned of similar attacks in future, the sources said.

The CID offices were known for investigation of terrorism and other high-profile
cases after the provincial police officer some time ago decided that the CID,
which was originally tasked with intelligence gathering, would also be doing
investigation and interrogation of suspects.

Even press conferences were organised in recent months at the offices of the CID
which was basically mandated to gather intelligence.

According to some senior police officers, the CID should be allowed to do
intelligence work only as was originally envisaged. "CID officers are not
supposed to hold press conference, it is unthinkable in Punjab," an officer
said.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 03 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 3, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2011 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved

                              349 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             January 3, 2011 Monday

US drone attacks killed 41 per cent "terrorists" in 2010 - Pakistan paper

LENGTH: 731 words


Text of report by Amir Mir "Drones killed 59 per cent civilians, 41 per cent
terrorists" published by Pakistani newspaper The News website on 3 January

Lahore: Of the 1,184 persons killed by the American drones in 124 attacks in
2010, around 59 per cent were innocent civilians while the remaining 41 per cent
were terrorists belonging to numerous militant groups based in the
Pakistan-Afghan tribal belt.

According to the data gathered by The News primarily from local and
international news sources, 703 of those who were perished by the US drones
between 1 January and 31 December, 2010, were civilians, including women and
children, while 481 others were commanders, fighters and activists of different
militant groups. The drones hit three types of targets in the tribal belt -
terrorists' compounds, houses sheltering the terrorists and vehicles carrying
the terrorists.

Of the 124 drone strikes, the largest number - 53 [or 43 per cent of the total
drone attacks] - were directed at alleged terrorists' compounds, followed by 41
strikes [or 33 per cent of the total attacks] targeting houses allegedly
sheltering the terrorists while the remaining 187 attacks [or 24 per cent of the
total strikes] were directed at vehicles which were allegedly carrying the
terrorists. As the velocity of the American drones has increased enormously
under the Obama administration, they are now hitting their targets with
precision.

As a matter of fact, despite a sharp increase in both the frequency and total
number of casualties resulting from Predator strikes, civilian casualties have
gone down compared with the figures of 2008 and 2009. But still, for each
terrorist killed by the drones in 2010 in the Pakistani tribal areas, around two
innocent civilians also had to die. Of the total 1,124 persons killed in the 124
drone attacks, the largest number of people - 638 [or 54 per cent of the total
casualties] lost their lives when the US drones targeted the alleged terrorists'
compounds. The 359 persons [or 30 per cent of the total casualties were perished
when the drones targeted houses allegedly sheltering the terrorists while the
remaining 187 persons [or 16 per cent of the total casualties] got killed when
the drones hit vehicles allegedly carrying the terrorists. The majority of the
drone attacks in 2010 took place in the Waziristan region administered by four
powerful Taleban groups - the Mehsuds, Mullah Nazir, Hafiz Gul Bahadar and
Haqqanis. Since 2006, the drone strikes focused on two regions: North Waziristan
and South Waziristan.

Yet, over the past two years, there has been a dramatic shift in the location of
the drone strikes. In 2009, 42 per cent of the Predator attacks took place in
North Waziristan and 51 per cent in South Waziristan.

However, 83 per cent of the total drone attacks in 2010 have targeted North
Waziristan. Key Pakistani Taleban commanders Mullah Nazir and Waliur Rehman are
based in South Waziristan; Jalaluddin Haqqani and Sirajuddin Haqqani in North
Waziristan, Hafiz Gul Bahadar, Al-Qa'idah's chief operational commander Saif Al
Adal and his Pakistani right hand Ilyas Kashmiri are based in North Waziristan;
the Tehrik-i-Taleban Pakistan Ameer Commander Hakeemullah Mehsud is based in
Arakzai Agency and Faqir Mohammed is based in Bajaur Agency. All these factions
of militants shelter Al-Qa'idah and various other anti-US terrorist groups.

However, 12 such militant groups remained the prime targets of the American
Predator strikes in 2010, which included the fugitive leaders of Al-Qa'idah, the
leaders of the Pakistani and Afghan Taleban, the commander of the Islamic Jihad
Group, Uzbekistan Islamic Movement, Turkistani Islamic Party, Islamic Army of
Great Britain, Haqqani Militant Network, Lashkar-e-Islami, Lashkar-e-Jhangvi,
Lashkar-e-Zail and Brigade 313.

According to group-wise break-up of the 481 militants killed in drone attacks in
2010, 127 belonged to the Haqqani militant network, 123 belonged to the
Tehrik-i-Taleban Pakistan, 38 belonged to Al-Qa'idah, 34 belonged to
Lashkar-e-Islami, 31 belonged to Islamic Jehad Group, 27 were Afghan Taleban, 24
be longed to Turkistani, 19 belonged to Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, 18 belonged to
Islamic Army of Great Britain, 17 belonged to Uzbekistan Islamic Movement, 12
belonged to Lashkar-e-Zil and 11 belonged to the Brigade 313.

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 03 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 3, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2011 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved

                              350 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             January 3, 2011 Monday

Algerian terrorist attack in Kadiria damages rail line, disrupts traffic

LENGTH: 227 words


Text of report by Algerian newspaper Le Jeune Independant website on 3 January

A homemade bomb buried in the ground right next to the tracks exploded yesterday
[2 January] in Kadiria, located 20 or so kilometres to the east of Lakhdaria, in
the wilaya of Bouira. This attack occurred at around 1330 hours as a freight
train passed through coming from Algiers and going to Beni Mansour, in the
wilaya of Bejaia, at the edge of the city of Kadiria, a source from the National
Rail Transport Company (SNTF) indicated. According to our source, the explosion
quite fortunately did not result in human losses though there were materiel
damages, especially to the car beneath which the blast occurred as well as to
the track, which was completely damaged in that spot. Right after the device's
explosion, a search was kicked off by the security forces, which suspect the
existence of other bombs buried on the tracks or around them. A team of
explosives specialists was dispatched to the scene to check whether there are
other still buried devices, our source indicated.

SNTF officials were forced to delay the departures of the rail cars going to
Setif and Bejaia until further notice. Our source indicated that travellers were
informed in time and that all measures have been taken for the safety of users.

Source: Le Jeune Independant website, Algiers, in French 3 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 3, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                       BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            January 4, 2011 Tuesday

AU condemns terrorist attacks in Egypt

LENGTH: 174 words


Text of report in English by state-owned Ethiopian news agency ENA website

Addis Ababa, 2 January: African Union (AU) chairperson, Dr Jean Ping has
condemned the terrorist attacks which targeted places of worship in the Egyptian
city of Alexandria on New Year's eve that led to the loss of many lives and
wounded several persons.

According to a press statement AU issued on Sunday [2 January], Ping has learnt
fatal attack with dismay and grief.

Ping has condemned in the strongest terms what he calls "the heinous terrorist
acts which cannot be justified under any circumstances". He extends his
heartfelt condolences to the people and government of Egypt as well as to the
bereaved families and prays for the speedy recovery of those wounded.

The chairperson reiterates the total rejection of all forms of terrorism and
sectarian violence.

Ping reaffirms the determination of the AU to combat terrorism and to continue
its support for the efforts being deployed by member states in this regard.

Source: ENA website, Addis Ababa, in English 2 Jan 11

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            January 4, 2011 Tuesday

Pakistan's Swat "devastated" by flood, terror attacks in 2010

LENGTH: 928 words


Text of report by privately-owned Pakistan television AVT Khyber News on 1
January

[Presenter] Swat is a region which has been badly affected by the continuing
spell of terrorism and insecurity, and the recent destructive floods exposed
this region to many other problems. Khyber News correspondent in Swat, Niaz
Ahmad Khan, has prepared a report on the major incidents of terrorism and
reconstruction works in Swat in year 2010.

[Niaz Ahmad Khan] Year 2010 was declared as the year of peace for the terrorism
and flood-hit people of Swat. Considerable efforts were made in Swat during the
first six months of year 2010 to restore peace, undertake reconstruction and
promote tourism, and peace festivals were held in Mingora and Kalam. Prime
Minister Syed Yusuf Raza Gillani, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) Chief Minister (CM)
Amir Haider Khan Hoti, Army Chief Gen Ishfaq Pervez Kayani and representatives
of several countries visited Swat.

Four suicide attacks took place in Mingora during the first six months, in which
40 people were killed and 174 others injured. Moreover, a blast occurred at a CD
shop in Mingora market in broad daylight, which destroyed dozens of shops also.

Overall, the security situation remained good and the writ of the government
writ in Swat was maintained.

DPO (District Police Officer) Swat district, Qazi Ghulam Farooq, comments on the
security situation:

[DPO Farooq speaking in Pashto] You can see that 2010 was very good in terms the
security situation compared to past years. If you look at 2009 and earlier
years, you will see that the writ of the government had completely ended in the
region and there was a Taleban government everywhere. There were mine blasts,
suicide attacks and killings everywhere. At the present time, you can see that
the morale of the police is very high and the people's trust in the police has
been restored. God willing, we will not allow the situation to change. Our
infrastructure has not been completed yet. God willing, the trust of the people
will be restored fully after our infrastructure is completed. Thanks to Allah,
it is still in very good condition, but once the infrastructure is completed we
will consider our personnel much safer. They will be given houses because it is
very cold here and our performance will improve after all arrangements are
completed. In terms of the number of our personnel, their weapons and their
training, we are quite satisfied. We have started giving heavy-weapons training
to our personnel also. God willing, everything will proceed well.

[Niaz Ahmad Khan] Hundreds of people lost their lives, thousands of homes were
destroyed and thousands of people were affected by fierce floods that hit Swat
in July last year. Floods destroyed some 64 km of roads and destroyed several
big bridges on the main roads, which created serious problems for the common
people. Moreover, business activities in Swat were also badly hit. Chairman of
the Traders Association in Swat, Abdul Rahim, comments on the situation:

[Abdul Rahim speaking in Pashto] Damaged roads and bridges have devastated our
business and these destroyed bridges are a huge impediment to our business
activities. Our business cannot grow unless the communication system, roads and
bridges are rebuilt. And we vehemently complain that despite such massive
destruction, the government has not taken any effective step so far that could
allow people to make a living and resume their business activities.

[Niaz Ahmad Khan] Terrorists had destroyed a number of schools in Swat during
the last few years, because of which thousands of students were deprived of an
education. The government had repeatedly claimed that they would rebuild these
destroyed schools and homes, but these claims did not produce any concrete
results. Former president of Private Schools Association Swat (PSAS) and
spokesman of national peace jerga, Ziauddin Yusufzai, comments on the effect on
the education sector:

[Ziauddin speaking in Pashto] Only seven or eight schools out of 176 schools,
which were completely destroyed [during the Taleban rule in Swat], have been
reconstructed so far. And around 170 schools are still to be rebuilt. Moreover,
some 98 schools were destroyed by floods and there are no signs of their being
rebuilt either. We are extremely saddened by this state of affairs. If the
children of President Asif Ali Zardari or Mian Nawaz Sharif [chief of Pakistan
Muslim League - Nawaz Sharif (PML-N)] or a bureaucrat would have been studying
at these schools, then surely some alternative arrangement would have been made.
But as these are the schools attended by the children of the oppressed and poor
people of Swat, no attention is paid to them. Our children are still sitting in
tents during severe cold or hot weather. And no one has made any proper
arrangements for them.

[Niaz Ahmad Khan] A major military operation in Swat was accomplished in 2010,
but the dead bodies of militants were still being found in parts of Swat and
more than 300 dead bodies were found in the region. In this regard, the military
spokesman said that these militants are being killed during search operations.

Mostly, military authorities are empowered in Swat, but still the provincial
chief minister and ministers have paid visits to the region. KP Forest Minister
Wajid Ali Khan has claimed that their government has resolved around 80 per cent
of the problems of the people in Swat.

Following a prolonged lack of security, the people of Swat were badly affected
by floods in 2010.

Source: AVT Khyber TV, Islamabad, in Pashto 0000gmt 01 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 4, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                                  M2 PressWIRE

                            January 4, 2011 Tuesday

Norway condemns terrorist attack in Egypt

LENGTH: 199 words


January 2, 2011

Norway has reacted strongly to the terrorist attack on a Coptic church in
Alexandria, Egypt, just after midnight on 1 January. "I condemn this attack in
the strongest possible terms," said Foreign Minister Jonas Gahr Støre.



At the same time Mr Støre stressed that the Egyptian authorities are responsible
for safeguarding freedom of belief and the rights of religious minorities. The
bomb attack was targeted at Christian Copts who were attending midnight mass on
New Year's Eve. At least 21 people were killed and many others injured in the
blast.

"Christian Copts have the right to practise their religion freely. We are
following the situation in Egypt closely and expect the Egyptian authorities to
defend freedom of religion. It is also important that the authorities now call
for calm and urge all Egyptians to join together in the fight against
terrorism," said the Foreign Minister.

About 10% of Egypt's population are Christian Copts. In the past few years there
has been growing tension between religious groups in the country.

"My deepest sympathy goes to those who were injured or lost loved ones in the
attack, and to all the people of Egypt," said Mr Støre.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                            Manchester Evening News

                           January 5, 2011 Wednesday

Smash teenager dies on her 18th birthday ; Wedding joy for champion athlete ;
Diversions for burst pipe work ; Tribute to fall death walker ; Knife terror of
women as robber attacks car

BYLINE: WFnode

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 440 words


A TEENAGER was killed in a horrific road accident on the day she celebrated her
18th birthday.

Simone Hill was in the back seat of a Volkswagen Golf when it collided with a
Honda Accord on Monday evening.

It left Simone, of Reddish, Stockport, with severe head injuries and she was
pronounced dead at the scene.

Among the poignant tributes and flowers left at the site on Reddish Road,
Reddish, was a row of pink 18th birthday balloons and a card saying Birthday
girl'.

Simone's family have paid tribute to her, saying: From the first second to the
last, Simone was full of life. She cared for everybody she knew and was cared
for by everybody she knew.

She had the eyes of an angel and a smile that would brighten everybody's day.
Her memory will live on in all who knew her.

Her family, mum and dad, brother Liam and partner Luke all adored her and
everyone that knew her will miss her forever and always.

The accident happened near the junction with Rupert Street at 5.40pm and left
the Golf turned on its side.

A man driving the Golf managed to escape from the car uninjured and another
passenger was left with only minor injuries.

But firefighters had to pull Simone, a former Reddish Vale Technology College
pupil, from the wreckage.

Tributes were left at the scene including a note that said: How can God take you
away from us? You are the best and most beautiful friend.

And among those sent to M.E.N media websites was one from her cousin Heath
Hogan.

He said: I will miss you cuz, can't stop crying, love you with all my heart.
Happy birthday Simone, have a good one up there, I'll see you soon.

Jenny Campbell, headteacher at Reddish Vale Technology College, said Simone had
become a popular figure during her five years at the school, which she left in
June 2009.

She added: Simone was well-known by the staff and pupils because of her bubbly,
bright personality. Our thoughts are with her family and friends at this time.

Police have appealed for witnesses and are particularly keen to speak to the
driver of a car that turned from Reddish Road into Rupert Street at the time of
the accident. The car was not involved in the collision.

The accident coincided with a change of shift at the nearby Morrisons store and
one worker helped emergency services in the aftermath.

Gareth Riley, deputy store manager at Morrisons, said: A lot of staff heard the
crash and one staff member who is first aid trained comforted another lady at
the scene.

It was a horrific accident and a tragic loss of life. We were shocked and more
than anything felt sadness and sympathy for the family.

Anyone with information can contact the road policing unit on 0161 856 6173.

                              355 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            January 6, 2011 Thursday

Two acquitted in India's Mumbai attack case associates of terror group - lawyer

LENGTH: 523 words


Text of report by Indian news agency PTI

Mumbai, 5 January: Describing Faheem Ansari and Sabauddin Ahmed as
"co-conspirators" in the 26/11 Mumbai attacks, special public prosecutor Ujjwal
Nikam on Wednesday [5 January] told the Bombay High Court in the Indian state of
Maharashtra that the trial court had erred in acquitting the duo by giving them
the benefit of doubt.

Nikam cited 21 circumstances to establish how Faheem and Sabauddin were closely
associated with LeT [Lashkar-i-Toiba] leaders Abu Kafa and Zaki ur Rehman
Lakhvi, and had acted on their instructions to help carry out the terror
attacks.

Nikam said that both had prepared maps of target locations in Mumbai and passed
them on to LeT in Pakistan which gave them to the 26/11 attackers.

Faheem had obtained a Pakistani passport on 1 November, 2007 using forged
documents. The passport was seized from him after his arrest in Uttar Pradesh,
the northern state of India, in another case on 10 February, 2008, Nikam said.
The passport carried Faheem's photo and entries showed that he left Karachi on
15 November 2007, and arrived in Kathmandu in Nepal on the same day. The
Pakistani government had confirmed that he had stayed in that country, Nikam
said.

Soon thereafter Faheem visited Mumbai in December 2007 and sought admission in a
computer institute under a fictitious name of Sahil Pawaskar. He stayed under
the same name in a rented house in South Mumbai where targets of 26/11 attack
were located, although he owns a house in a Mumbai suburb where his family
lives, the prosecutor argued.

Faheem stayed in Mumbai till 3 January, 2008, and again went to Nepal. Between 4
January 2008 and 1 February, 2008, Naruddin Shaikh, a close of friend of Faheem,
met him in Kathmandu and saw Faheem giving maps of Mumbai targets to Sabauddin,
said Nikam.

Nikam further pointed out that one of these maps was found in the pocket of
slain terrorist Abu Ismael who was killed during the terror attack.

Justices Ranjana Desai and R.V. More then asked why the map found in Ismael's
pocket did not bear blood stains or wrinkles in that case.

The prosecutor said that Ismael had suffered bullet injuries in the left portion
of the body while the map was found in his right side pocket. Nikam however
conceded that although there were blood stains on corners of right pocket the
blood drops had not percolated inside.

Explaining the absence of wrinkles on the map, Nikam said it was illogical to
expect this. However, one can expect marks of folds on the map. Wrinkles can
appear only when the map is spoilt or crumpled by the one carrying it, he
argued.

In this case, the map had folds but not wrinkles, he pointed out. To prove his
point, Nikam demonstrated by folding two pieces of paper and putting them in his
pocket. The court was shown that they bore marks of folds but not wrinkles.
Nikam argued that the trial court had failed to ask Faheem to explain how his
photographs and handwriting appeared on the admission papers of computer
institute under the fictitious name. Faheem had neither denied nor admitted
this.

Source: PTI news agency, New Delhi, in English 1503gmt 05 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 6, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2011 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved

BLADE TERROR ATTACK IN PUB

SECTION: EDITORIAL; OPINION, COLUMNS; Pg. 36

LENGTH: 91 words


THREE men armed with a sword, a machete and a knife burst into a pub and
attacked four revellers.

Two men and two women - all in their 20s - were treated in hospital after the
incident.

Police are now examining CCTV footage in a bid to identify the hooded attackers.

It happened at the Wig and Pen pub in Paisley on Sunday night and one of the
female victims said: "The whole thing was terrifying."

A police spokesman said: "The pub was very busy with customers after the Old
Firm match. We are appealing for anyone who saw anything to come forward."

                                   The Mirror

                            January 6, 2011 Thursday
                                 1 Star Edition

ENEMY WITHIN;
MI5: 500 BRITISH JIHADISTS ARE PLOTTING TERROR ATTACKS

BYLINE: CHRIS HUGHES; JON CLEMENTS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 35

LENGTH: 233 words


MORE than 500 British Islamic extremists are plotting terror strikes here,
secret figures obtained by the Daily Mirror reveal.

Some of the jihadists, being watched by MI5 and counter-terror police, have
already obtained bomb-making materials.

The figure, which fluctuates between 450 and 550, represents the number of
monthly probes by our spies at any one time.

A counter-terror source said: "Make no mistake, these people represent extremely
serious threats to UK citizens.

"The threat of a mass atrocity against the public is real. Some of them not only
have the intent but also the material needed to carry out that intent."

Some would-be terrorists under surveillance are potential lone bombers. These
are the most difficult to monitor because they do not discuss their plans.

A small number are watched by intelligence officers abroad as they plan attacks
on British interests overseas.

The Government is spending more money than ever to thwart terror plots like the
2007 attack on Glasgow airport.

MI5 is funded by the Treasury's Single Intelligence Account, which has soared to
pounds 2billion for 2010/11. It also funds MI6 and GCHQ. The budget for all
three agencies will go up by pounds 1bn next year and remain at that level until
at least 2015.

MI5's staff roll has risen by around 1,500 to 3,800 since the September 11
attacks, although a further increase of 400 has been put on hold due to cuts.

LOAD-DATE: January 6, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: THREAT Abbas Iqbal of the "Blackburn Resistance" was jailed for terror
offences FLAMES Glasgow airport bomb

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                            Copyright 2011 MGN Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved

                                   The Mirror

                            January 6, 2011 Thursday
                                 3 Star Edition

ENEMY WITHIN;
MI5: 500 BRITISH JIHADISTS ARE PLOTTING TERROR ATTACKS

BYLINE: CHRIS HUGHES; JON CLEMENTS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 263 words


MORE than 500 British Islamic extremists are planning terror strikes in the UK,
according to secret figures obtained by the Daily Mirror.

Some of the jihadists, who are being watched by MI5 and counter-terror police,
have already obtained bombmaking materials.

The figure, which fluctuates between 450 and 550, represents the number of
monthly live investigations carried out by undercover spooks at any one time.

A counter-terror source said: "Make no mistake these people represent extremely
serious threats to UK citizens - the threat of a mass atrocity committed against
the public is real.

"Some of them not only have the intent but the material needed to carry out that
intent and they represent the most serious threat."

Some would-be terrorists under surveillance are potential "lone wolf" bombers.
These are the most difficult to monitor because they do not talk about their
plans.

And a small number are being watched by intelligence officers abroad as they are
planning attacks on British interests overseas. The Government is spending more
money to uncover terror plans, like the attack on Glasgow airport and the
"Blackburn Resistance" plot, than ever before.

MI5 is funded by the Treasury's Single Intelligence Account - which has soared
to pounds 2billion in 2010/11. It also funds MI6 and GCHQ.

The budget for all three agencies will go up by pounds 1billion next year and
remain at that level until at least 2015.

The number of MI5 employees has gone up by around 1,500 to 3,800 since the 9/11
attacks although a further increase of 400 has been put on hold due to cutbacks.

                                BreakingNews.ie

                      January 7, 2011 Friday 07:30 AM GMT

UK raises terror level in anticipation of attack

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 61 words


Britain has raised its terrorist threat level for major transport hubs,
including airports and London railway terminals, from substantial to severe.

There is no suggestion of any intelligence of an imminent attack however and
officials are stressing the change is precautionary.

However, the decision has been made as intelligence shows a New Year attack is
highly likely.

                                  Daily Record

                            January 7, 2011, Friday

TERROR ATTACKS THREAT

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 187 words


POLICE in London are being put on increased terror alert today amid fears of
fresh attacks.

More cops are being deployed at transport hubs, including Heathrow and Luton
airports.

And it is understood that British Transport Police officers have been ordered to
cancel days off today.

Last night, Scot land Yard declined to comment on the report, saying they never
discuss the specifics of terrorism-related operations.

The Home Off ice said the country faced a real and serious threat f rom ter ror
i sm but declined to go into detail.

Severe And the Government said the threat level from international terrorism
remains at "severe" - meaning an attack is highly likely.

The level has not changed since January 2010.

One major concern has been that terrorists could launch Mumbai-style gun attacks
in public places.

Security chiefs ordered an acceleration in police training to prepare for such a
threat last autumn.

It followed the uncovering of the early stages of an al-Qaeda plot in September.

The plan involved a series of co-ordinated attacks in the UK, France and
Germany.

The 2008 attacks in Mumbai claimed the lives of 166 people.

                              361 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                                  The Express

                             January 7, 2011 Friday
                                U.K. 3rd Edition

Mumbai-style terror attack on UK is now 'highly likely'

BYLINE: By Jessica Pickin

SECTION: NEWS; 02

LENGTH: 197  words


POLICE reinforcements are being sent to guard airports and other major transport
hubs across London today amid fears that a terrorist attack is "highly likely",
it emerged last night.

Emergency service workers are also being briefed on how to handle a Mumbai-style
attack.

Sources say that some transport police are being forced to cancel leave in order
to be on duty.

MI5 and the Home Office set the nationwide terror level threat, which is
currently at "severe."

But the joint terrorism analysis centre based in MI5 also appoints threat levels
to individual elements of infrastructure.

The threat level has now been raised in relation to airports and London's
transport system and a memo was sent to airports and Transport for London
confirming the chances of an attack. A Metropolitan Police spokesman said:

"The threat level to the UK is at severe, which means that an attack is highly
likely, and has been since January 2010.

"We will police accordingly and use a range of covert and overt tactics, which
remain under constant review.

"Events at East Midlands Airport and speculation about Mumbai-style attacks
serve as a reminder of the enduring threat we face from terrorist groups."

LOAD-DATE: January 7, 2011

                              362 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                                    Scotsman

                             January 7, 2011 Friday

Public warned in terror attack alert

BYLINE: James Tapsfield

LENGTH: 310 words



HIGHLIGHT: THE public has been warned to be vigilant of terrorism after
security was reportedly tightened at transport hubs in the UK, last night.


Extra police are reported to have been deployed on the rail network and at
Heathrow  airport amid "intelligence chatter" over possible terrorist  attacks.

But Scotland Yard and the Home Office stressed that the overall threat level in
the country had not been raised to the highest "critical" level - which would
mean an incident was expected imminently.

Unconfirmed reports suggested transport police had been told to cancel days off
scheduled for today.

A Scotland Yard spokesman said: "The threat level to the UK is at severe, which
means that an attack is highly likely, and has been since January 2010.

A Home Office spokesman added: "There is a continuing need for everyone to
remain vigilant and to report any  suspicious activity to the police."

Last night members of St Mark's Coptic Church of Scotland in Kirkcaldy arrived
at their traditional Christmas Mass to discover a police guard outside the door.

Fife police offered to protect the congregation after the church was one of
three churches threatened on an Islamist website.

The church, which celebrates Christmas on 7 January was targeted following
unrest between Moslems and Christians in Egypt.

Parishoner Subhi Hashwa said the atmosphere in the church was "calm but subdued"
and  that six policeman stood outside as around 300 coptic Christians of all
ages, from all over Scotland celebrated their traditional  mass.  Father Mark
Aziz said: "We thank the police for being with us - it made people feel more
calm."

Last night in the US, two   workers were slightly burned when separate packages
sent to state government buildings 20 miles apart released smoke and the smell
of sulphur when they were opened.

Authorities   were also  investigating a third suspicious package at a state
office building in Baltimore and a fourth at the courthouse, but it was not
clear if they were related to the other two.

LOAD-DATE: March 14, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: TS

                              364 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                              Lancashire Telegraph

                             January 9, 2011 Sunday

Haslingden family's terror after arson attack

BYLINE: Peter Magill

SECTION: HASLINGDEN (HASLINGDEN)

LENGTH: 328 words


A FAMILY have spoken of their terror after a suspected arsonist caused a
radiator to explode and blow the windows out of a Haslingden home yesterday.

Neighbours of the property in Blackburn Road were awoken unexpectedly in the
early hours by the blast, which also damaged the front bedroom window of an
adjacent house.

Fire and police investigators believe a fire was set underneath a radiator in
the front bedroom of an empty terraced house, on the corner of Union Street.

Inside the appliance the water converted to steam, eventually causing it to
explode and shatter four upstairs and downstairs window.

Ann Holden, who was sleeping in the bedroom next door to the blast, said: "It
was absolutely horrendous. I just heard a bang and ran out into the street.

"I am scared to live here now because of this."

Her son David Groves, who was sleeping nearby, added: "When I heard the bang I
thought we were all for it."

The family, which also includes David's father John Groves, say the neighbouring
house has been empty for four or five months and has been targeted by vandals
previously.

Rawtenstall fire station crew manager Tony Spencer said police and fire
investigators believe somebody had broken into the property and deliberately
started the fire.

He said: "When we arrived both upstairs windows were smashed and glass was
covering the street, with smoke issuing from upstairs.

"The fire was right at the side of a small radiator. The heat caused the water
inside to expand and turn to steam and it has to go out somewhere.

"The radiator ended up on the other side of the room, but the force of the
explosion had all but put out the fire.

"There was minimal damage from the fire and the house was very sparsely
furnished anyway.

"The property next door heard the bang - it even cracked the glass on the inside
pane of their double glazed upstairs window."

Four firefighters used breathing apparatus, a ventilation unit and a thermal
imaging camera during the 90-minute incident.

LOAD-DATE: January 10, 2011

                            Birmingham Evening Mail

                            January 10, 2011 Monday
                                 First Edition

PM'S SHOCK AT DEADLY ATTACK;
Latest on the Arizona shooting terror

BYLINE: Brian Hutton

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 384 words


DAVID Cameron expressed his shock and sadness at the assassination attempt on a
US politician which killed six people, including a young girl.

Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords, who was shot through the head by a gunman at a
public event, remains in a critical condition in hospital.

A 22-year-old suspect, named as Jared Loughner, is being held in custody and US
police are also searching for a possible accomplice. In a message sent to US
President Barack Obama, the Prime Minister extended Britain's sympathies and
said "violence and hate" must not be allowed to stifle political debate.

"Like everyone in Britain, I was shocked and saddened by the shootings which
took place in Tucson, Arizona," he told the president. "Our hearts go out to all
of those who have been caught up in this terrible incident.

"That such an attack should have taken place against a member of Congress as she
was meeting her constituents in a shopping centre on a Saturday morning is
especially shocking to all of us who believe in democracy. I am keeping
Representative Giffords in my thoughts and prayers as she battles for life,
together with all of those who have been wounded."

Shadow foreign secretary Yvette Cooper said: "The tragedy in Arizona is truly
appalling.

"Congresswoman Giffords and those at this public event were involved in
something so normal yet important for any democracy: meeting, talking and
debating.

"Our thoughts are with those who have lost loved ones and wishes for a speedy
and full recovery are with those who have been injured."

Mrs Giffords, a 40-year-old Democrat married to an astronaut, was targeted as
she spoke with constituents at a regular "Congress on your corner" event outside
a supermarket in Tucson, Arizona. Doctors have expressed cautious optimism that
she will survive but a federal judge and a nine-year-old girl were among the
dead - with 11 others also wounded.

Flags were flying at half mast in Washington as investigations continue into
whether the shooting was politically motivated after a recent mid-term election
campaign described as vitriolic.

The suspected gunman was tackled to the ground by bystanders. A hunt is now on
for a second individual police believe may also have been involved.

President Obama described the shooting as an "unspeakable act".

                              366 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           January 12, 2011 Wednesday

State Duma committee head sees West's hand in Russia terror attacks

LENGTH: 549 words


The chairman of the State Duma economic policy committee, Yevgeniy Fedorov, has
said that Western "special services" were behind terrorist attacks in Russia.

He was speaking on Gazprom-owned, editorially independent Ekho Moskvy radio in
the 12 January edition of the "Narod Protiv" programme, which was mainly devoted
to the discussion of possible Western sanctions against Russian officials
involved in the second trial of businessman Mikhail Khodorkovskiy.

Fedorov, who is a member of the ruling One Russia party, claimed that
Khodorkovskiy had been given a fair trial and that the Western criticism of it
was a "massive propaganda attack on Russia". Another element of this "attack",
according to Fedorov, was Western support for opposition politicians such as
Boris Nemtsov.

"This powerful political machine is not just working in relation to
Khodorkovskiy. This is a law of international political competition. In combat
conditions, competition is between tanks and aircraft, while in peacetime it is
between media as well as the use of terrorist attacks and various special groups
like that of Nemtsov," Fedorov said.

He went on to claim that Nemtsov's activities were overseen by the US State
Department, while "terrorist attacks are the remit of special services".

He suggested that Russian media organizations, including state-controlled
Channel One, were under Western influence. He contrasted Russian TV's news
agenda with that of Western stations. "Nine in 10 news reports on Euronews are
positive, while in Russia, on all channels that broadcast news, including
Channel One, nine in 10 news reports are negative. This is a certain strategic
mechanism for destabilization," he said.

He claimed that "100m dollars a year is officially earmarked for the Russian
media" in the United States, while "the German budget earmarks about 100m euros
for propaganda work in Russia".

Discussing the new prison term for Khodorkovskiy, he said that it signified "a
major strengthening of Russian sovereignty" and dealt "a major blow to
corruption". He argued that ordinary business people in Russia were now less
likely to break the law because they realized that even "Khodorkovskiy, with his
money, influence and US State Department support, has been unable to bribe his
way to freedom". "When Europeans and Americans defend Khodorkovskiy, they defend
corruption in Russia," he added.

Discussing a possible Western travel ban against Russian officials involved in
the Khodorkovskiy trial, Fedorov said that allowing Russians to travel to the
West was "one of the levers to influence our decisions", which the West could
ill afford to give up.

"These sanctions are purely political and amount to pressure on Russia. In that
respect, I believe they are wrong. On the other hand, I am very calm about them
because I think that they will either be lifted very quickly or not introduced
at all," he said. He added that a travel ban could even have a positive effect
on Russian officials as it would "strengthen their patriotism".

He acknowledged that many Russian officials liked travelling to the West and
even had relatives living there, although he was not one of them. "I try not to
travel abroad because I am bored there," Fedorov said.

Source: Ekho Moskvy radio, Moscow, in Russian 1707 gmt 12 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 13, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                            i-Independent Print Ltd

                                January 12, 2011
                                 First Edition

Hindu terrorists may be behind attacks;
Panorama Around the world in 10 stories INDIA

BYLINE: Andrew Buncombe IN DELHI

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 209 words


India is being forced to confront disturbing evidence that increasingly suggests
a secret Hindu terror network may have been responsible for a wave of deadly
attacks previously blamed on radical Muslims.

A confessionin court from a Hindu holy man suggests that he and several others
linked to a right-wing Hindu organisation planned and carried out attacks on a
train travelling to Pakistan, a Sufi shrine and a mosque as well as two assaults
on Malegaon, a town in southern India with a large Muslim population. He claimed
the attacks were launched in response to the actions of Muslim militants. "I
told everybody that we should answer bombs with bombs," Swami Aseemanand, 59,
whose real name is Naba Kumar Sarkar, told a magistrate during a closed hearing
in Delhi. "I suggested that 80 per cent of the people of Malegaon were Muslims
and we should explode the first bomb in Malegaon itself."

Police in India have suspected for some time that Hindus may have been
responsible for the attacks between 2006 and 2008, and in November of that year
several arrests were made, including that of a serving military officer.

But the confession, obtained by an Indian news magazine, is perhaps the most
damning evidence yet that Hindu extremists were responsible.

                              369 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                            The Independent (London)

                           January 12, 2011 Wednesday
                                 First Edition

Hindu holy man reveals truth of terror attacks blamed on Muslims

BYLINE: Andrew Buncombe in Delhi

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 917 words


INDIA IS being forced to confront disturbing evidence that increasingly suggests
a secret Hindu terror network may have been responsible for a wave of deadly
attacks previously blamed on radical Muslims.

Information contained in a confession given in court by a Hindu holy man,
suggests that he and several others linked to a right-wing Hindu organisation,
planned and carried out attacks on a train travelling to Pakistan, a Sufi shrine
and a mosque as well as two assaults on Malegaon, a town in southern India with
a large Muslim population.

He claimed the attacks were launched in response to the actions of Muslim
militants. "I told everybody that we should answer bombs with bombs,"
59-year-old Swami Aseemanand, whose real name is Naba Kumar Sarkar, told a
magistrate during a closed hearing in Delhi. "I suggested that 80 per cent of
the people of Malegaon were Muslims and we should explode the first bomb in
Malegaon itself. I also said that during partition, the Nizam of Hyderabad had
wanted to go with Pakistan so Hyderabad was also a fair target. Then I said that
since Hindus also throng [a Sufi shrine in] Ajmer we should also explode a bomb
in Ajmer which would deter the Hindus from going there. I also suggested the
Aligarh Muslim University as a target."

Police in India have suspected for some time that Hindus may have been
responsible for the attacks carried out between 2006 and 2008, and in November
of that year several arrests were made, including that of a serving military
officer. But the confession of Swami Aseemanand, obtained by an Indian news
magazine, is perhaps the most damning evidence yet that Hindu extremists were
responsible. It also suggests those involved were senior members of a religious
group that is the parent organisation of India's main opposition party, the
Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).

"The evidence is not conclusive but people have to take notice of this," said
Bahukutumbi Raman, a former national security adviser and now a leading regional
security analyst. "This could aggravate tensions between India's [Hindu and
Muslim] communities. It will create problems."

The revelations in Tehelka magazine, bear added significance following the
comments of Rahul Gandhi, widely expected to be a future prime minister, in
which he said he believed the growth of Hindu extremists presented a greater
threat to India than Muslim militants. According to a cable obtained by
WikiLeaks, last year Mr Gandhi told the US ambassador to Delhi, Timothy Roemer:
"Although there was evidence of some support for Laskar-e-Taiba among certain
elements in India's indigenous Muslim community, the bigger threat may be the
growth of radicalised Hindu groups, which create religious tensions and
political confrontations with the Muslim community."

At the time, Mr Gandhi's comments were strongly condemned by the BJP. But the
main opposition party has been pushed on to the back foot by the testimony of
Swami Aseemanand, which suggests many of those involved in the bombing plots
were members of religious organisations such as the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh
(RSS).

The RSS is considered the BJP's ideological parent. This week, the RSS's leader,
Mohan Bhagwat, claimed extremists had been forced out. "Elements nurturing
extremist views have been asked to leave the organisation," he said. "A majority
of the people whom the government has accused... had left voluntarily and a few
were told that this extremism will not work here."

Among the incidents initially blamed on Muslim militants was a bomb attack in
February 2007 on the Samjhauta Express, travelling between Delhi and Lahore. Of
the 68 deaths, most were Pakistani citizens returning home. The attack took
place a day before Pakistan's Foreign Minister was due to arrive in India for
peace talks.

Swami Aseemanand was arrested in Haridwar last November, having apparently been
in hiding for more than two years. In his 42-page confession to the magistrate,
he reportedly claimed he had been spurred into action by a series of Muslim
attacks on Hindus, in particular the assault on the Akshardham temple in Gujarat
2002 that left at least 29 people dead. "This caused great concern and anger in
me," he said.

THE ATTACKS UNDER SCRUTINY

Samjhauta Express

In February 2007, two firebombs exploded on the train commonly known as the
'Friendship Express' which travels across the Indo-Pakistani border. Most of the
68 victims and 50 injured were of Pakistani origin. Three further unexploded
suitcase bombs were later found on the train.

Mecca Masjid

An attack on the Mecca Masjid mosque, which is in Hyderabad's old city, left 14
people dead in May 2007 - with five apparently killed by police firing on a
furious mob after the incident. Swami Aseemanand apparently said that the site
was chosen because the local administrator wanted to be part of Pakistan during
partition.

Ajmer

A famous Muslim shrine in the city of Ajmer in Rajasthan, about 350km south-west
of Delhi, was targeted by bomb attacks in October later that year. Two people
were killed and 17 injured near the scared shrine, which houses the tomb of a
13th-century Sufi saint. Swami Aseemanand said the blast was intended to deter
Hindus from going there.

Malegaon

In September 2008, three bomb blasts killed 37 people in the Muslim-majority
city of Malegaon, situated about 160 miles north-east of Maharashtra's state
capital, Mumbai. Muslims had been attending prayers when the bombs exploded in a
sacred burial ground, also injuring more than 125 people.

LOAD-DATE: January 11, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: IA

                            Manchester Evening News

                           January 12, 2011 Wednesday

Sword attackers brought terror to World Cup party'

BYLINE: WFnode

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 352 words


A WORLD Cup party ended in bloodshed when two men attacked guests with samurai
swords, a court heard.

Michael Holt, 31, and Gareth Wilkes, 29, went on the rampage after storming into
a house following England's goalless draw against Algeria, it was said.

A jury at Bolton Crown Court heard that Mr Holt punched a terrified woman in the
face after she tried to stop him going into her daughter's bedroom.

Peter Candleholder, prosecuting, said the attack took place in the early hours
of June 19 at a house on Eastwood Close, Bolton.

The host, Nina Williams, invited Holt, of Sandhill Close, Bolton, to come in
after she saw him walking the past the house at around midnight. But he turned
violent and punched guest John Bullough, it was said.

He was thrown out after knocking Mr Bullough to the floor and raining punches
down on him, the court heard.

Minutes later Holt returned with Mr Wilkes, who lived at nearby Tartlet Place.
Both had swords, the court heard.

The prosecution said the pair attacked Ms Williams' partner, Jason Waring, with
the sword, cutting his arm, leg, wrist and tongue.

In a statement, Ms Williams said: Michael then stormed upstairs. I was
frightened for the children so I followed him up.

I tried to stop him on the landing but he hit me in the mouth. I begged him not
to hurt the children.

The court heard Holt slashed at another man while upstairs. Paul Treble,
defending, asked her why she did not call the police straight after Holt
allegedly hit the first guest.

He said guests had a grudge' against Holt and deliberately invited him in to
attack him.

Mr Treble said Holt was hit over the head with a bottle in the initial
confrontation and had been chased down the street by a gang of people from the
party.

Holt denies assault occasioning actual bodily harm and two counts of wounding
with intent. He also denies a charge of assault by beating in relation to Nina
Williams.

He admits possession of an offensive weapon and unlawful wounding in relation to
the attack on Jason Waring.

Mr Wilkes denies possession of an offensive weapon, unlawful wounding and
assault against Nina Williams.

                                The Bolton News

                            January 14, 2011 Friday

Woman's terror at firework attack

SECTION: BOLTON NEWS (BOLTON NEWS)

LENGTH: 238 words


A TERRIFIED woman fled a smoke-filled flat after a man posted a firework through
her letterbox.

The firework, believed to be a multi-shot device and about nine inches long,
exploded in a hallway shared by four flats in Market Street, Farnworth.

Police are now investigating whether the alleged arson attack may be linked to a
wave of firework-related incidents across Farnworth over the last few days.

Katie Bluer, aged 20, was asleep at her friend's flat when she was woken by the
fire alarm at about 9.30am yesterday morning.

She said: "As soon as I opened the door I was engulfed in smoke. It was like an
eggy smell, so I knew it wasn't a normal fire.

"I thought it was a bomb or a firework. It was frightening.

"I just jumped down the stairs because I couldn't see a thing, and ran to the
door.

Nobody knew I was here, so if it had caught fire I could've lost my life."

One of her neighbours, who asked not to be named, said: "Whoever did this, I
hope they don't let them out. They should be banged up for 30 years."

The firework caused no serious damage, but scorched a loose piece of carpet in
the hallway.

A police spokesman confirmed that no one had been injured.

A nearby shop worker, who also asked not to be named, said he had chased someone
down the street after they let fireworks off outside his shop on Wednesday.

Ã A 20-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of arson with intent to
endanger life and remains in custody.

                                Evening Gazette

                           January 15, 2011 Saturday
                                  1st Edition

MY ROAD RAGE TERROR;
Attack with 'crook lock' could have killed me I COULD HAVE DIED 'Rage' victim
tells of ordeal

BYLINE: MIKE MORGAN

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 564 words


AN ELDERLY road rage victim has described the moment he was struck in the face
by a BMW driver wielding what was believed to be a metal crook lock.

Pensioner John Allan, pictured, from Marske, told the Gazette the blow could
have killed him.

As reported, a verbal altercation between a group of cyclists and motorist
Benjamin Alan Daniels on a narrow country lane led to Daniels being convicted of
assault. Teesside Crown Court heard Daniels, 30, of Harlech Close,
Middlesbrough, who was driving behind the four cyclists in Potto, lost his
temper when they held him up. He then lashed out at Mr Allan, who is more than
twice his age. Daniels admitted common assault after causing a cut to Mr Allan's
face. Judge Howard Crowson gave Daniels a one-year community order with 80 hours
unpaid work and supervision. He was also ordered to pay pounds 200 compensation.
Retired Mr Allan said after the case that he accepts the decision of the court.
But he feels the potentially serious results of the unprovoked attack may not
have been fully appreciated. He said: "This was road rage and we were innocent,
not doing anything.

"He could have fractured my skull. A blow with a heavy object like this could
have had very serious consequences. "As I looked into his open car window to
talk to him he was sat in the driving seat, picked up this implement and swung
it towards me without any warning. "It struck me on the side of my face with a
really heavy blow and knocked me over on my bike. "I fell backwards onto the
car. "If it had hit me on the temple it could have killed me. As it was, it
loosened several teeth. This was a very over the top response to what was
basically a disagreement which he had caused. "The message I'm trying to get
across to any drivers in a similar situation is it's not worth using a weapon to
be aggressive.

"There were passing places just yards ahead." Daniels, a self-employed, married
man with children and good references, told police the cyclists were abusive to
him and Mr Allan was "aggressive in a confrontation." But the court heard that
Daniels twice reversed to confront Mr Allan then struck him with the implement.
Mr Allan, 67, and three friends were cycling around villages in North Yorkshire.
They heard Daniels revving his car's engine behind them. Prosecutor Shaun Dryden
said Daniels drove aggressively trying to get past on May 11 last year. He said
as the cyclists went into single file, the BMW "flew past them, driving too fast
and too close".

The cyclists protested. Daniels drove off about 20 yards before stopping and
reversing. When Mr Allan asked Daniels what he was doing, the motorist replied:
"Bloody cyclists." Daniels sped off - but then screeched to a halt and reversed
back to the group, which was when Mr Allan went to the car window and was
struck. Daniels was arrested after one of the cyclists took his registration
number.

A yellow crook lock matching the object which struck Mr Allan was found in his
wife's car, the court heard. David Lamb, defending, said both parties shouted
and swore at each other before the blow. Judge Howard Crowson gave Daniels a
one-year community order with 80 hours unpaid work and supervision. He was also
ordered to pay pounds 200 compensation. Mr Allan told the Gazette he's been a
keen cyclist since age 16, covered thousands of miles and never encountered such
an incident before

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            January 18, 2011 Tuesday

Northwest Pakistan blast "terrorist attack" - police

LENGTH: 236 words


Text of unattributed report headlined "Deadly explosion was terrorist attack:
police" published by Pakistan newspaper The News website on 17 January

Peshawar: A minibus explosion in northwest Pakistan that killed 17 people and
injured 11 others Monday [17 January] was a terrorist attack triggered by a
timed bomb, police said.

Revising an earlier report that the blast had been caused by exploding gas
cylinders, police in Jawarza, near the restive town of Hangu, said the minibus
had been planted with about 10 kilogrammes (22 pounds) of explosives.

"The report of the bomb disposal squad shows that explosive materials fitted
with a timer were placed near the gas cylinders which caused the explosion,"
district police chief Abdul Rashid said.

"The death toll has risen to 17 and five bodies still remain unidentified, as
they have have been burnt very badly," he added.

The mangled and burned-out wreckage of the minibus and another passenger vehicle
were left at the scene.

Rashid said most of the passengers in the minibus had been killed, along with
two people travelling in a pick-up truck nearby when the blast occurred.

Senior police official Masood Khan Afridi confirmed that the blast was caused by
high-intensity explosives.

"It was a terrorist attack," he said. "We are looking for the owner of the
vehicle, as the driver was killed in the blast," he added.

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 17 Jan 11

Islamov, was killed during an operation to detain him.

                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           January 19, 2011 Wednesday

Nearly 60 people killed in terror attacks in Russia's Kabarda-Balkaria in 2010

LENGTH: 348 words


Text of report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Nalchik, 19 January: Thirty-seven employees of the law-enforcement bodies and 20
civilians died as a result of terrorist attacks in Kabarda-Balkaria in 2010,
Interior Minister of the Republic of Kabarda-Balkaria Sergey Vasilyev has said.

Addressing the ministry's board meeting on the results of the past year,
Vasilyev said that the statistics of crimes committed by members of the bandit
underground against residents of the republic made it possible to draw a
conclusion "about the clear inadequacy of the measures taken to stabilize the
situation in the republic, a lack of an adequate reaction to the bandits'
raids", the press service of the Interior Ministry of the Republic of
Kabarda-Balkaria reported on Wednesday [19 January].

"The work of operational services deserves particular criticism. Practically all
the crimes that caused considerable public reaction were committed by people who
had been on the wanted list for more than one year, that is, they do not leave
the territory of the Republic of Kabarda-Balkaria, continuing to draw new
members from among young people into their ranks, and expand the accomplice
base," the press service quoted Vasilyev as saying.

The statement says that the interior minister of the Republic of
Kabarda-Balkaria described the organization of work to deprive the bandit
underground of its financial backing, discover and close channels of its
funding, including from abroad, as being no good at all.

"The failure of this area of work is not the consequence of systemic oversight
of the year 2010, but is that of more than five years," Vasilyev said.

On the basis of the board meeting, the interior minister of the Republic of
Kabarda-Balkaria took a decision to make a whole range of the heads of leading
services and subunits of the ministry answer in a disciplinary manner for
serious failings in their work, which had resulted in impermissibly poor
indicators of operational-service work, the press service noted.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1405 gmt 19 Jan 11

Tajik police reportedly avert two terror attacks

Two [alleged] terror attacks have been averted in the town of Khujand, the
administrative centre of [northern Tajikistan's] Sughd Region, the Regnum
Novosti news agency has learnt from a source at the regional interior
directorate.

Two suspicious vehicles with transit [presumably temporary registration] numbers
were discovered outside the buildings of the interior directorate and the Sughd
regional state security directorate yesterday evening, the source said.

Six kg of explosive in TNT equivalent was uncovered in one of the vehicles, and
sappers rendered it harmless. "It was not possible to open the second vehicle,
and a decision was made to drown it in the Syr Darya River," the source said.

                               Grimsby Telegraph

                           January 22, 2011 Saturday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Cabby's terror at knifepoint attack;
Taxi driver held up by two thugs who refused to pay

BYLINE: Paul Smith

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 409 words


A TAXI driver has spoken of the "terrifying" moment he was attacked at
knifepoint after two passengers refused to pay a £6.70 fare.

The two men punched and strangled him, before pulling out the six-inch blade and
demanding cash, making off with about £30.

Links Taxis driver Gary Hambling, 36, of Willingham Street, Grimsby, said he now
wants to use his experience to make people aware of the vulnerability of taxi
drivers in the area.

At about 9.30pm on Thursday, Mr Hambling received a call to pick up two men from
a takeaway in Hainton Avenue, Grimsby.

One man got into the front, and another - wearing a hooded top - sat in the
back. They asked to be taken to a car park behind Wingate Parade in the Willows
Estate.

Mr Hambling said: "It seemed strange to be going to that area at night time, so
I thought to myself that I would stay on the main road.

"We were having a normal chat on the way there and everything was totally fine.

"When I pulled on to Wingate Road at about 9.45pm, I looked up to see how much
it would cost and then I felt a blow to the back of my head."

The front passenger had punched him, while the man in the back grabbed him from
behind, strangling him so he couldn't move.

He was punched twice more before the front passenger pulled out a knife and
demanded cash.

Mr Hambling said: "I just said 'take it, take it, I have got a new-born baby'.

"I have done the job for about 15 years and never had anything like that happen,
it was frightening."

He said: "We are very vulnerable.

We are just carrying out a public service and we should have some respect,
because a lot of drivers do not get the gratitude they deserve."

Mr Hambling praised the efficiency of the police who responded to his call.

He said that in the future, when picking up passengers, anyone wearing a hooded
top will be asked to take it off. He is also looking into getting CCTV in his
car.

A spokesman for police in North East Lincolnshire said: "The first suspect who
was travelling in the front passenger seat at the time is described as being a
white male between 20 and 25years old, between 5ft 6 and 5ft 9in tall and clean
shaven.

"He had blond, short, spiky hair and a navy jumper.

"The second suspect, who was travelling in the back seat behind the driver, is
described as being a white male, aged in his 20s, of stocky build, wearing a
grey, hooded top with the hood pulled up."

Can you help? Call Humberside Police on 0845 6060222, quoting log number 619 of
January 20.

LOAD-DATE: May 11, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: ATTACKED: Taxi driver Gary Hambling.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                      ITN

                            January 24, 2011 Monday

'Dozens dead' in Moscow terror attack

LENGTH: 169  words


At least 31 people have reportedly been killed and 20 injured in a terrorist
suicide bomb attack at Moscow's Domodedovo airport.

The airport is the busiest hub of three in the Russian capital.

The Interfax news agency gave the death toll as 31, while the state-run news
agency RIA said more than 130 people had been injured.

Russian agencies are reporting that the blast occurred inside the airport's
international arrivals hall.

Smoke billowed out of the baggage claim area and people were seen running out of
the emergency exits at the airport, according to local media.

Russia's chief investigator was quoted as saying the blast was a terrorist
attack.

Moscow suffered its worst attack in six years in March 2010 when two female
suicide bombers from Russia's volatile Dagestan region set off explosives in the
metro, killing 40 people.

The Kremlin is struggling to contain an Islamist insurgency in the mainly Muslim
North Caucasus, and rebels have repeatedly vowed they will take their battle to
the Russian heartland.

Islamabad, 24 January: President Asif Ali Zardari has strongly condemned the

                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            January 25, 2011 Tuesday

Russian journalists urge more prompt TV coverage of terrorist attacks

LENGTH: 802 words


Excerpt from report by Russian state news agency RIA Novosti

Moscow, 25 January: Russian general television channels must interrupt
broadcasts promptly when tragedies, such as the terrorist attack in Domodedovo
airport [in Moscow on 24 January], take place, and must inform viewers about
events, if only briefly and without "footage", experts have said. [Passage
omitted: details of the attack]

The first news reports with information on the tragedy were aired on [Russia's
state-controlled] Channel One TV, [Gazprom-owned Russian] NTV and [Russian
official state television channel] Rossiya 1. "One cannot say that major general
TV channels were not doing their job," the head of the Television and Radio
Broadcasting Department at the Journalism Faculty at Moscow State University,
Anna Kachkayeva, has said. "Still, a delay of two hours compared to information
already available on news agencies and in other media, on the radio for example,
and I am not even talking about Twitter or social media, probably annoys the
people who would like to see this appear more promptly and intelligibly," she
added. This is a second terrorist attack to show that television is "hopelessly
lagging behind, given its technology and the impossibility of narrating events
without images", she said.

The previous large-scale transport-related terrorist attack in Russia took place
on 29 March 2010, when two female suicide bombers blew themselves up on the
Lubyanka and Park Kultury underground stations in Moscow. A total of 40 people
died and 100 people were injured then. Accusations were also launched then over
channels "lagging behind".

"Of course by and large, as soon as information comes in, [broadcasts] should be
interrupted and in this case it does not matter whether there is footage or not.
Many are held back as radio is one thing, and television requires pictures. But
in reality, nothing is preventing us from simply giving information. One can
simply show views of Domodedovo and say the first thing that is available,"
journalist Svetlana Sorokina said for her part. General television news channels
"are quite sluggish and not quick to react to urgent developments", she added.
"Although this is strange because our life has taught us that these abnormal
situations occur with dismaying frequency. News services must therefore already
be adapted to this," she said. Sorokina also recalled that during the March
terrorist attacks in the underground, "major TV channels grounded to a halt" and
did not immediately go on air with information about the incident.

Major TV channels always take into account that people "should not be irritated
or disturbed", Kachkayeva said. "However, when a sense of tragedy persists, yet
there is laughter and soap operas being shown during evening prime time, this
provokes certain dissonance," she added. "There are certain human factors that
perhaps should not be shown as means of respect for a tragedy, compassion for
those affected," she said. "For example, Dozhd TV channel went live 10 minutes
after the tragedy was reported. [State-owned English language] Russia Today and
[state-owned 24-hour Russian language] Rossiya 24 channels had rolling captions
by 1700 [Moscow time; 1400 gmt] and after, and the presenter tried to keep
viewers up to date even without footage, by reading out news agency reports,"
she added. Furthermore, the TV channel STS cancelled its scheduled evening
premiere of its "Technology of a big explosion" project.

At the same time, the experts remarked that general TV channels gave quite full
coverage to the Domodedovo attack after 1900 [Moscow time; 1600 gmt]. "In the
evening, they (the general TV channels) constantly interrupted their programmes
for reports that by and large were repeated but were accompanied by what the
Russian president [Dmitriy Medvedev] and (health and social development
minister) Tatyana Golikova had said. The initial figures from the Russian
Emergencies Ministry were given and there was some elaboration. But I maintain
that information should be reported immediately, at least factually," Sorokina
added.

According to Kachkayeva, "television is not likely to be this source of
information" for the majority of people who are used to getting information
online. "But one should understand that under such circumstances, people are
still waiting, the TV is still switched on, and even if they are distracted by
entertainment and the radio is on and there is Internet access, television is
still a very important means of communication with people, and for reporting
tragedies. That is why it is important to consider a combination of speed and
responsibility," she added.

RIA Novosti has not received comments from the TV channels on this subject yet.

Source: RIA Novosti news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0956 gmt 25 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 25, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                              All Rights Reserved

Pakistan PM condemns terror attack in Moscow

LENGTH: 197 words


Text of report by official news agency Associated Press of Pakistan (APP)

Islamabad, 24 January: Prime Minister Syed Yusuf Raza Gillani has strongly
condemned the terrorist attack in Moscow, in which many precious lives were lost
and a large number of persons have been injured.

The prime minister in a message to his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin,
conveyed the sentiments of the government and people of Pakistan and said that
the government and people of Pakistan expressed their complete solidarity with
the people and leadership of Russia. "We strongly condemn this heinous act of
terrorism against innocent persons, which further underscores the imperative
need for the international community to unite strengths and efforts in combating
terrorism," the prime minister said.

Pakistan, the prime minister said, itself has been subjected to numerous
terrorist attacks in which thousands of persons have been killed. "We understand
and share the pain and sorrow of the Russian people and offer to the Russian
leadership and all those affected our sincere sympathies and condolences," he
said.

                                   The Mirror

                            January 25, 2011 Tuesday
                                 1 Star Edition

CARNAGE;
35 KILLED IN SUICIDE TERROR ATTACK AT MOSCOW AIRPORT

BYLINE: GREIG BOX TURNBULL

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 475 words


TWO Britons were last night said to be among 35 people killed in a suicide bomb
blast at Moscow's busiest airport.

The terrorist shouted "I will kill you all" moments before setting off his
devastating device, which was packed with shrapnel, screws and metal balls to
cause maximum carnage.

More than 180 people were injured when it ripped through the crowds near the
busy Asia Cafe as friends and relatives greeted passengers in the arrivals hall
at Domodedovo airport.

The bomber unleashed his attack at 16.32 just four minutes before BMI flight
BD891 landed from the UK.

Most of the Brits on that jet and the 165 people on BA flight BA872, which had
landed 45 minutes earlier, were believed to have escaped the carnage.

Mark Green, a passenger from the UK, had only been out of the terminal for two
minutes when the bomb went off as heavy snow fell.

He said: "Literally, it shook you. As we were picking up the bags to put them
into the back of the car, there was an almighty explosion. It reverberated
through our bodies. There was a pause of 30 seconds before people started
running out of the terminal, s o m e we r e injured, some were covered in blood.

"People were obviously in a state of shock and panic.

"Security services were running around trying to keep people to one side, keep
people calm, trying to move the injured to one side."

Witness Artyom Zhilenkov said: "He exploded right in front of my eyes. A man in
a black coat, black hat - I noticed nothing else as he walked out of the check
out zone and e x p l o d e d t o pieces.

"I only survived because I stood b e t we e n t h e columns with many people
waiting in f r o n t of me."

Alexey Spiridonov, who works at a car rental company close to where the bomb
exploded, added: "Lots of body parts were around, blood was everywhere. Such a
horrific scene." A police source said a severed head belived to belong to a
suicide bomber was found among the bodies. He was reported to be an
"arab-looking man aged 30-35".

"The head belongs to a man from the Caucasus aged 30 to 35," said the source.
The Caucasus includes the tinderbox republics of Chechnya and Dagestan, both
with strong Islamic extremists opposing Moscow's rule.

Russian president Dmitry Medvedev cancelled a planned trip to Switzerland after
the outrage and imposed a security clampdown at all airports and train stations.
He vowed: "The organisers will be tracked down and punished."

Security was immediately stepped up across the Russian capital, on the metro and
at the other two airports.

In Britain the Foreign Office warned against travel to Russia.

Security at Domodedovo, Russia's busiest airport faced criticism in 2004 after
two suicide bombers blew themselves up in mid-air, killing all 90 people aboard
two flights.

Late last night there were claims authorities may have been warned about a
possible terror attack a week ago.

LOAD-DATE: January 25, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: HORROR J Bloodied victims of the bomb RESCUE 3 Medics help a bomb
victim SHOCK J A child weeps on his mother

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
