                                  Eire Edition

'I WANT TO KILL YOU ALL';
35 DIE IN SUICIDE TERROR ATTACK AT PACKED AIRPORT

BYLINE: GREIG BOX TURNBULL

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6,7

LENGTH: 452 words


A SUICIDE bomber shouted: "I will kill you all" moments before setting off his
device that slaughtered 35 people at Moscow's busiest airport.

The bomb was packed with shrapnel, screws and metal balls to cause maximum
carnage.

More than 180 people were injured when it ripped through the crowds near the
busy Asia Cafe as friends and relatives greeted passengers in the arrivals hall
at Domodedovo airport.

Mark Green, a passenger from the UK, had only been out of the terminal for two
minutes when the bomb went off at 4.32pm as heavy snow fell. He said:
"Literally, it shook you.

"As we were picking up the bags to put them into the back of the car, there was
an almighty explosion.

"It reverberated through our bodies. There was a pause of 30 seconds before
people started running out of the terminal, some were injured, some were covered
in blood.

"People were obviously in a state of shock and panic.

"Security services were running around trying to keep people to one side, keep
people calm, trying to move the injured to one side."

Witness Artyom Zhilenkov said: 'He exploded right in front of my eyes. A man in
a black coat, black hat -I noticed nothing else as he walked out of the check
out zone and exploded to pieces.

I only survived because I stood between the columns with many people waiting in
front of me."

Alexey Spiridonov, who works at a car rental company close to where the bomb
exploded, added: "Lots of body parts were around, blood was everywhere. Such a
horrific scene."

A police source said a severed head believed to belong to a suicide bomber was
found among the bodies.

He was reported to be an "arab-looking man aged 30-35".

"The head belongs to a man from the Caucasus aged 30 to 35," said the source.

The Caucasus includes the tinderbox republics of Chechnya and Dagestan, both
with strong Islamic extremists opposing Moscow's rule.

Russian president Dmitry Medvedev cancelled a planned trip to Switzerland after
the outrage and imposed a security clampdown at all airports and train stations.

He vowed: "The organisers will be tracked down and punished."

Security was immediately stepped up across the Russian capital, on the metro and
at the other two airports, which received diverted passengers.

Security at Domodedovo, Russia's busiest airport faced criticism in 2004 after
two suicide bombers bought tickets illegally from airport personnel and boarded
planes there.

They blew themselves up in mid-air, killing all 90 people aboard two flights.

In March the Russian capital's underground system was rocked by two female
suicide bombers from Russia's volatile Dagestan region, who detonated their
explosives on the busy metro system during rush hour, killing 40 people and
injuring more than 80.

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           January 26, 2011 Wednesday

TV show discusses reasons behind terror attacks in Pakistan

LENGTH: 573 words


Karachi-based Dawn News in Urdu at 1505 gmt on 25 January 11 broadcasts their
regularly scheduled investigative talks show "Reporter." Hosted by seasoned
journalist Arshad Sharif, "Reporter" provides "news and critical discussion"
focusing on military affairs, war on terrorism, and other major political events
in Pakistan. Participants include prominent analysts and political
personalities.

Reception: Good

Duration: 60 minutes

Guests: 1. Senator Haroon Akhtar; 2. Zafar Ali Shah, leader Pakistan Muslim
League - Nawaz [PML-N]; 3. Pakistan People Party [PPP] leader Yasmin Rehman.

Arshad Sharif begins the programme by saying that he will discuss reasons behind
terrorist incidents and law and order situation in Pakistan. Sharif states over
4,000 people had been in killed in Pakistan since 2002 in different suicide and
bomb blasts.

Akhtar says these incidents are taking place due to intelligence failure. Akhtar
questions why intelligence agencies have failed to track down financial sources
and training centres of the terrorists. Akhtar points out towards increasing
intolerance in Pakistan and says even peaceful religious rallies are not
tolerated in the country.

Sharif asks Shah whether there is any international link to the terrorist
attacks in Pakistan in order to create sectarian conflict. Shah replies: "I am
100 per cent sure that there is an international interference". Shah adds
Pakistan has involved itself in the war on terror to a point where it cannot
pull back. Shah reiterates it is evident that terrorist attacks are part of
international conspiracy. Shah opines Pakistan needs a foreign policy review.

Sharif questions regardless of international element, why have we failed to
destroy terrorist camps that exist in Pakistan. Akhtar says some Gulf countries
are supporting certain sects and Pakistan cannot name these countries as
Pakistan has good relations with these countries. Akhtar is of the point of view
that Pakistan should serve its interests first. Shah claims India is running
terrorists camps in Pakistan.

Sharif asks Rehman what the government has done to eliminate terrorist camps in
Pakistan. Rehman says president of Pakistan is pursuing policy of education and
development in the areas where suicide bombers are recruited from.

Shah claims the government is incompetent and unwilling to deal with the issue.
Dawn news correspondent Hassan updates on suicide attack in Lahore. Akhtar says
when state fails to provide education to the young, parents send their children
to religious schools. He adds it is difficult for the graduates of religious
schools to get a job. Thus, he states, it is easier to corrupt the minds of such
children. Akhtar also suggests many countries pledged to establish employment
opportunity zones in tribal areas. However, he claims, the present government
has not done any work in this regard. Rehman negates Akhtar by saying that
Pakistan did not receive any funding for the mentioned plan.

Sharif asks Shah what steps opposition parties can take to counter terrorism in
Pakistan. Shah says opposition is not creating hurdles for the government and it
is allowing the government to functions smoothly in order to tackle all the
issues. Shah reiterates Pakistan needs to change its foreign policy.

Talk show continues to discuss role of parliament in economic policies. Sharif
thanks the guests and concludes the programme.

Source: Dawn News TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1505gmt 25 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 26, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                              All Rights Reserved

                       BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           January 26, 2011 Wednesday

Moscow airport attack "ominous shift" in terrorists' strategy - SAfrican paper

LENGTH: 237 words


Text of report by South African privately-owned, established daily newspaper The
Star on 26 January

[Editorial: "Moscow Terror"]

Monday's suicide bombing at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport represents an ominous
shift in strategy by terrorists seeking to publicise their cause.

No one has claimed responsibility for the blast, which left at least 36 people
dead, including four foreigners and at least 110 injured, including visitors. It
is hard to see how targeting foreigners by bombing the international arrivals
hall of Russia's busiest airport would garner any sympathy for the bombers, with
the attack bearing the hallmark of militants fighting for a separatist state in
the North Caucasus region.

Perhaps sympathy is not what these terrorists are looking for, but rather to put
pressure on the Russian government by hitting at tourism and harming investor
confidence. But in those aims, too, their attack was misplaced. Tourism has
never begun to reach its potential in Russia and as for foreign investment, a
sad reality of the world today is that terror can strike anywhere at any time.

Instead the result of the attack will be twofold: a strict tightening of
security at Russian transport hubs and all the inconvenience which comes with
that, and a vicious response by the Russian authorities to the presumed
attackers, and all the bloodshed which comes with that.

Source: The Star, Johannesburg, in English 26 Jan 11 p 14

LOAD-DATE: January 26, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                              All Rights Reserved

                              391 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           January 26, 2011 Wednesday

Terrorist attacks affect Russia's investment attractiveness - president's envoy

LENGTH: 416 words


Text of report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Davos, 26 January: Although terrorist attacks have an impact on the investment
attractiveness of Russia, terrorist threats exist in other countries too, the
Russian president's envoy to the North Caucasus Federal District Aleksandr
Khloponin has said.

"Any terrorist attack affects the investment climate not only, say, in the North
Caucasus, but also in Russia as a whole. These are questions of security, these
are very serious questions and the threat of terrorism is not limited to
Russia," Khloponin told reporters at a briefing in Davos.

Khloponin recalled that recently increased security measures had been introduced
in European countries, such as Germany and the UK

He said that the situation in Russia's North Caucasus is "tense but stable" and
stressed that a lot of work needs to be done to combat terrorism, violent crime,
and corruption, and to resolve employment problems in that region.

Speaking about security measures in that region, Khloponin stressed that work
was being done in this area non-stop, including in transport security.

"Because we in the Caucasus have become accustomed to this threat, we take
precautionary measures very seriously. This work is being done," Khloponin said.

Speaking about the Domodedovo airport tragedy [a suicide bomb attack in which
over 30 people died on 24 January], Khloponin said suicide bombers who commit
terrorist attacks present a new challenge to security systems, and that the
prevention of such attacks is a difficult task.

"You can not put a metal detector on each square centimetre. If you install a
metal detector at the airport entrance, a large number of people will gather
there and a suicide bomber can set off an explosive device in the crowd that is
waiting to get through," Khloponin said.

He recalled a recent terrorist attack in Vladikavkaz, when a terrorist was not
allowed to enter the market, so he set off the bomb nearby. In this case
intelligence work and very tight interaction between intelligence agencies and
the public are very important.

The envoy said that, for example, a very large number of terrorist attacks had
prevented in the North Caucasus.

"I can say that intelligence services managed to prevent about 100 terrorist
attacks in the North Caucasus, and in Russia too, last year," Khloponin said.

Nevertheless, he stressed that lessons must be learnt from the Domodedovo
tragedy.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1615 gmt 26 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 26, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                              All Rights Reserved

                               Lincolnshire Echo

                           January 26, 2011 Wednesday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

FATHER KILLED IN AIRPORT TERROR ATTACK;
Sleaford businessman dead afterMoscow bomb blast

BYLINE: Emma Pearson

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 211 words


A LINCOLNSHIRE father-ofone was among 35 people killed in the bombing of Moscow
airport.

Gordon Cousland, 39, had a six-month-old daughter and was due to get married in
the spring.

The property consultant, who grew up in Scredington, near Sleaford, had just
landed in Russia when he became caught up in the horrific blast in the airport's
crowded international arrivals hall on Monday afternoon.

His brother, Robin, who farms near Scredington, said: "He was going to Russia on
Monday and we heard a blast reported on the radio and thought 'oh no, he could
be involved'.

"We tried to phone his mobile phone and could not get an answer.

Normally, when he visits a place, he is pretty good at phoning to say he has
arrived.

"As the evening went on, we heard nothing from him and began to fear the worst.

"Late Monday night, we passed information to the Foreign Office as we thought he
was missing and his company were doing the same thing and they couldn't contact
him.

"We received word later that night about it."

Mr Cousland, who was due to marry his fiancée in April, is the youngest of five
children. The rest of his family are from Scotland.

The blast, which killed 35 people and injured another 110, is believed to be the
work of separatist terrorists.

FULL STORY... SEE PAGE 2

LOAD-DATE: January 27, 2011

                             Paisley Daily Express

                           January 26, 2011 Wednesday
                                 First Edition

GRIPPED BY FEAR;
Park is a no-go zone after sex attack terror

BYLINE: BRYAN BROUGH

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 443 words


TERRIFIED women yesterday told how a Paisley park has become a 'no-go zone' as
cops hunt an evil sex beast who struck in broad daylight.

The pervert - who subjected a 46-year-old woman to a nightmare ordeal in Barshaw
Park - was still at large yesterday and a number of families have vowed to steer
clear of the area until he is caught.

Police have appealed for help to track down the twisted fiend, who dragged his
victim into bushes, tried to rape her, held a pair of scissors at her throat and
slashed her on the face.

When the Paisley Daily Express paid a visit to the park yesterday afternoon, it
was virtually deserted and the few visitors who had ventured out said the sex
attack has left them feeling uneasy.

Mum-of-two Elaine Russell, 47, told the Express: "I have friends who are no
longer coming to the park because they are worried about what happened and you
really can't blame them.

"Instead, they are going to another park a few miles away.

"The sooner this man is caught, the better." Archie Peters, 65, who has lived
near Barshaw Park for most of his life, added: "People are scared to go there
now - and no wonder.

"Whoever this attacker is, he's dangerous and there is a real fear that he could
strike again.

"I know more police have been in and around the park since the attack happened
and it's good to see officers on patrol but it's fair to say that everyone will
breathe easier when this pervert is arrested."

Paisley couple Myra and FrankWest, who also live close to Barshaw Park, said
they have been left horrified by the sex attack.

Myra told the Express: "It's awful to think that the Turn to Page 5

From Page One poor woman just went for a walk in the park and this happened to
her.

"I find it all very frightening but at least I've got Frank with me to make me
feel safe."

The powerfully-built sex beast struck as his victim was walking alone close to
Barshaw House - a former care home and hospital which is now occupied by luxury
flats - on January 20.

He jumped on her back, sexually assaulted her, threatened to kill her and
slashed her.

As the thug ran off, his brave victim managed to stagger to a shop more than
half a mile away and staff there alerted the police.

She is still recovering from her nightmare ordeal.

Last night, police hunting the pervert said they are waiting for the results of
forensic tests and are following up a number of lines of inquiry - but still
need more help from the public.

Anyone with information about the attack is asked to ring Paisley Police Office
on 0141 532 5900 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

                       BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           January 27, 2011 Thursday

Ethiopia downplays fears of terrorist attack at AU summit

LENGTH: 357 words


Text of report by Argaw Ashine entitled "Ethiopia downplays fears of terrorist
attack at AU summit" published by Kenyan privately-owned newspaper Daily Nation
website on 27 January

Ethiopian authorities have downplayed the 'reliable terrorist attack risk' at
the forthcoming African Union (AU) summit later this week in Addis Ababa,
notified by Western countries.

Ethiopia's Foreign Ministry's spokesperson Ambassador Dina Muftui told the
Nation that the country was aware of the risk but it was not beyond the control
of the government.

"It is not such imminent and Ethiopian security have contained possible threats
and its security forces are working to ensure safety. There is a threat and we
are aware of it but it's a bit exaggerated by Western countries," Ambassador
Dina said.

He added, "Our region is always prone to terrorist attack and it's not such a
surprise for such kind of alert."

Several Western governments have warned their citizens in Ethiopia of credible
threats of terrorist bomb attacks during the AU summit.

Australia's Foreign Ministry issued a serious security alert for Ethiopia on its
website. Other Western embassies in Addis Ababa, including US and Britain have
also sent out a warning.

French President Nicolas Sarkozy, UN chief Ban Ki-Moon and more than 30 African
head of states are expected to attend the summit in Addis Ababa this week.

Ethiopia has blamed its arch-foe Eritrea for a move to discredit Ethiopia's
ability to host the summit.

A week ago, Ethiopian security forces arrested seven individuals who are
allegedly trained in Eritrea and a member of Ethiopian rebels in Ogaden (Somali)
region of Eastern Ethiopia.

The Somali extremist group Al-Shabab claimed responsibility for twin suicide
bomb attacks in the Ugandan capital, Kampala last July, weeks before the city
hosted the last AU summit. More than 70 people were killed in the blasts, which
struck two public viewing centres during the World Cup soccer finals.

Ethiopian government has installed tight security all over the city in Addis
Ababa, including public places surrounding of the city.

Source: Daily Nation website, Nairobi, in English 27 Jan 11

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           January 27, 2011 Thursday

Slovak analyst: terror attack raises questions about Russia's internal stability

LENGTH: 480 words


Text of report by Slovak privately-owned independent newspaper Sme website, on
26 January

[Commentary by Peter Schutz: "Terror in Instalments"]

Russia does not have such strong a symbol as 9/11 and the Twin Towers, but it
has all the more candidates for such an emblematic milestone. This time,
Domodedovo is the most recent entry in the very long list of venues of horrors -
Budyonovsk, Dubrovka, Beslan, and so forth.

In the coming days, analysts of strategic security and Russia's internal policy
will pick apart the causes that led to the tragedy and questions of whether or
not it was preventable. From the safe (?) [question mark as published] distance
of Central Europe, it is possible to postulate that Russia is among the world
epicentres of terror, which is testified to by a list of approximately 20
incidents of this type since the time when Vladimir Putin became president for
the first time.

We can think only the worst about Chechens, Dagestanians, Ingushetians (and
others), or, more precisely, the fundamentalist wings of their national
resistance. However, a decade of terror - with the most recent and,
unfortunately, probably not the last, stop at Domodedovo - primarily destroys
the myth about Putin as a politician who brought peace and order to Russia after
the "crazy" era of Yeltsin.

This is not meant to say that it is guaranteed that a standard democrat of a
European type would handle the Caucasus issue from the Kremlin. It only means
that "controlled democracy," which the Russian specifics allegedly require, has
also failed and continues to fail.

Current President [Dmitriy] Medvedev speaks of "anarchy" prevailing at the
airport. The investigation, if it is not manipulated, will hopefully produce a
certain trustworthy version about responsibility and culprits.

Let us keep to ourselves the speculation that the investigation will be
restricted to airport personnel and will not go to higher echelons, but in a
situation where it is known that air transport is a magical target for
assassins, the inability of the authorities to guard elementary security proves
that the Russian state is a combination of chaos and corruption. This is one of
the reasons why Medvedev's wish to introduce security measures of Israeli or US
types in Russia must be taken with a hefty grain of salt.

If the US ambassador to Moscow says (what luck that we have WikiLeaks!) that "in
present-day Russia, secret services cooperate with classic organized crime," it
also does not come as a great surprise that intelligence information, which was
allegedly available, was not used in a timely fashion.

Russia has another horrible disaster caused by fanatics behind it. Along with
sympathies that the incident has provoked, it has also raised, with a new
urgency, a question about the basic internal stability of this superpower.

Source: Sme website, Bratislava, in Slovak 26 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 27, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2011 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved

                            The Independent (London)

                           January 27, 2011 Thursday
                                 First Edition

Georgia's President says terror attack in Moscow was 'payback'

BYLINE: Shaun Walker and Kim Sengupta in Tbilisi

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 34

LENGTH: 419 words


Mikheil Saakashvili, the President of Georgia, told The Independent yesterday
that attacks like Monday's suicide bombing at a Moscow airport were "payback"
for Russia's policies in the North Caucasus, as he compared the country to a
"crocodile ready to swallow you up".

Mr Saakashvili and the Russian leadership have exchanged regular insults since
the 2008 war between the countries over the breakaway territories of South
Ossetia and Abkhazia, but his comments are likely to enrage Moscow, coming so
soon after the blast at Domodedovo Airport that killed 35 people.

Speaking in the Georgian capital last night, President Saakashvili - whose
country's two breakaway regions are recognised by Moscow as independent states -
accused Russia of trying to destabilise neighbouring countries by encouraging
secessionist movements.

"I discussed this personally with Vladimir Putin a while ago. I said to him that
the payback for his country for supporting separatists would be that violence
would come back to hit them as well," Mr Saakashvili said. "Putin said, 'No, if
anyone tries anything against us, we shall crush them like cockroaches,' while
jabbing and twisting his thumb on the table in front him."

Before his interview with The Independent, the Georgian President made similar
comments in a televised question-and-answer session. "Russia has a political
mentality which is on the level of a reptile, like a crocodile ready to swallow
you up," Mr Saakashvili said. There is a well-documented personal enmity between
Mr Saakashvili and Mr Putin. The Georgian President once said that talking to Mr
Putin was "like somebody standing with an axe at your head and saying: "Don't
worry, everything's OK, close your eyes and relax.'"

Mr Putin, meanwhile, has made fun of the time that BBC cameras caught Mr
Saakashvili chewing the end of his tie. He also reportedly told French President
Nicolas Sarkozy that he wanted to "hang" Mr Saakashvili "by the balls".

Critics of Mr Saakashvili, who came to power in the Rose Revolution of 2003
promising democratic reforms, worry that the Georgian President is aiming to
become a powerful prime minister when his second presidential term ends in 2013,
just as Mr Putin did in 2008.

Yesterday, Mr Putin said preliminary investigations into Monday's blast
suggested that the bomber did not come from Chechnya. It was unclear whether he
meant he had no links to the North Caucasus, or was from a neighbouring republic
such as Dagestan. He also ruled out negotiation with terrorist groups.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: IA

Woman's rape attack terror

BYLINE: WFnode

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 178 words


A WOMAN was raped in a horrific attack by two men as she made her way home from
a night out.

One man held her arms behind her back while the other raped her.

The victim was attacked in Blackley in the early hours of Sunday.

She managed to break free and run off.

The man who raped her was described as a tall white man, wearing a grey jumper
with a zip and a hood and blue jeans.

Det Con Guy Laycock, from North Manchester CID, said: This was a horrible and
frightening experience for this young woman.

We are determined to find her attackers and ensure justice is done for her.

If you saw something in the early hours of Sunday morning or know something that
might help us catch the person responsible, please contact me.

I'd also like to remind people of some things to help them stay safe while out:
plan your journeys meticulously, arrange transport in advance, travel in groups
where possible and, if you must walk on your own, stick to busy well-lit areas.

Anyone with any information on the incident should call 0161 856 3566 or
Crimestoppers, anonymously, on 0800 555 111.

                            South Wales Evening Post

                           January 27, 2011 Thursday
                                   Edition 3;
                                National Edition

Critics attack reworking of terror orders;
National newsround

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 125 words


PLANS to relax restrictions imposed on suspected terrorists and rebrand
controversial powers used to keep tabs on them are little more than "control
orders lite", critics have said.

Liberty, the civil liberties campaign group, accused the Government of bottling
the decision on the future of counter-terrorism powers, saying, "control orders
are retained and rebranded, if in a slightly lower-fat form".

The new powers announced by Home Secretary Theresa May will no longer need to be
reviewed every year, a clear signal that the restrictions against suspected
terrorists against whom prosecutions cannot be brought are here to stay.

The term "control order" has been scrapped and will be replaced with "Terrorism
Prevention and Investigation Measures".

                               The Sun (England)

                           January 27, 2011 Thursday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Ireland

I sat on the ground as they [...];
MODEL BAIBA'S ATTACK TERROR

BYLINE: FIONA WYNNE; JASON JOHNSON

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 552 words


A STUNNING model's dreams of a catwalk career are hanging by a thread after a
vicious attack.

Baiba Engele has told how she is terrified to leave her home following the
unprovoked assault.

The Latvian-born 24-year-old beauty was repeatedly kicked with high heels and
punched by two WOMEN.

Baiba was jumped on from behind as she left Bed's nightclub on Francis Street in
Newry, Co Down. She was kicked in the head, stomach and legs during the beating
last weekend.

The model was left bleeding on the ground and rushed by police to Daisy Hill
Hospital in the city.

She was later treated at Dublin's St Vincent's Hospital and has since been
allowed home.

One line of inquiry is that the attack may have been racially motivated.

Baiba said: "I was at the nightclub celebrating a friend's birthday and these
two girls began picking on me - I have no idea why, only they can answer that.

"I don't know if they were jealous or if it was racial or what the problem was.

"After the nightclub closed we were outside and all of a sudden they came up
behind me and attacked me.

Shocked "It has all been caught on CCTV cameras. I really can't even remember
all the details as I was so shocked.

"I remember sitting on the ground and they were kicking me in the legs and the
stomach and the head. I remember covering my face and my head as best I could.

"The police and the bouncers pulled them away from me.

"The police brought me to hospital then and I also had to go to hospital in St
Vincent's for three hours to get more check-ups.

"My head is really swollen and it's very sore. Mostly I'm just shaken. I keep
thinking how easy it would be to kill someone, especially with high heels, it
was very shocking.

"Nothing like this has even happened to me before. My ankle is sprained and my
ribs are bruised and sore.

"I know it's just two individuals - I've been in Ireland for five years and have
never had anything bad to say about the people.

"I am frightened to be on the street or in the house on my own now though. It's
a horrible experience."

Her spokesman added: "Baiba's a very quiet person and she was just out with
friends for a regular night out.

"She got a real hiding from these girls for no reason, she does get attention
from men of course, but what can she do - live in a bubble? "Nobody deserves to
be treated like this. She will need a lot of help to get over it."

One 23-year-old woman has been arrested by police probing the incident.

Cops were yesterday continuing to scour CCTV footage of the street from the
early hours of Sunday.

Blonde Baiba, a multi-media student at Dundalk Institute of Technology, moved to
Ireland aged 18.

The 5ft 8in beauty was spotted by a scout at Dublin's DCFE online clothing
retailer and has since seen her career take off. The PSNI said officers were
called to an incident in the area early on Sunday.

A spokeswoman said: "Shortly before 2.30am it was reported that a woman aged in
her 20s had been assaulted.

"She was taken to hospital by police with injuries which, at the time, were not
believed to be life-threatening."

The arrested woman was charged with assault occasioning actual bodily harm and
disorderly behaviour and made an initial appearance at Newry Magistrates' Court
on Monday.

It's understood that cops are seeking a second female in connection with the
attack.

fiona.wynne@the-sun.ie

                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political

                            January 28, 2011 Friday

No evidence of stone shrapnel in Moscow airport terror attack

LENGTH: 296 words


Law enforcement agencies do not possess confirmed information about the
involvement of Palestinian terrorists in the blast that occurred at Moscow's
Domodedovo airport on 24 January, Russian news agency Interfax reported on 28
January, quoting a source in the investigations group.

"We have no information to prove this," the source said.

Earlier the newspaper Rossiyskaya Gazeta reported that the terrorists used the
so-called "stone" bomb in Domodedovo terrorist attack. Bombs like this are
largely applied by Palestinian suicide bombers, the newspaper added.

Today it is known that the bomb that was activated at the airport was filled
with fragments of metal fittings and small metal balls. The stone shrapnel found
in the bodies of the dead and injured could have come off the floor of the
airport arrivals hall, where the attack took place, the source added.

Later Russian news agency RIA Novosti quoted doctors of Moscow in-patient
clinics who say they did not take out any granite chips from the tissues of
those injured as a result of the Domodedovo terrorist attack when they performed
operations on them.

Doctors of the Moscow in-patient clinic number 20 told RIA Novosti that only
metal fragments were removed from the tissues of the two people injured in the
attack. The doctors said their state of health is satisfactory. Konstantin
Kotenko, the director-general of the federal medical and biophysical centre
named after Burnazyan, is quoted as saying that plastic was also removed from
the tissues. "In a confined space, with kiosks and other objects nearby, you
would have plastic and other fragments [in the tissues]," Kotenko said.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0648 gmt 28 Jan 11; RIA Novosti
news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0721 gmt 28 Jan 11

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           January 29, 2011 Saturday

Pakistan to again seek access to Mumbai terror attack witnesses - report

LENGTH: 402 words


Text of report by Indian news agency Text PTI

Islamabad, 28 January: Pakistan will again seek access to witnesses of the 2008
Mumbai terror attacks to record their statements and a formal request will be
filed with India in this regard, according to a media report on Friday [28
January].

This will be the second time that Pakistan will be making such a request,
unnamed officials of the Interior Ministry were quoted as saying by 'The Express
Tribune' newspaper.

The Federal Investigation Agency (FIA) has identified 16 Indian citizens to
testify regarding information shared by Ajmal Kasab, the lone surviving attacker
who has been sentenced to death by an Indian court.

If permission is received from New Delhi, a two-member Federal Investigation
Agency (FIA) team will travel to India and also discuss matters pertaining to
post-mortem reports with officials of police stations in Mumbai, the officials
were quoted as saying.

The commission will also consult legal experts who are "contesting Kasab's case
on behalf of the federation in the anti-terrorism court No 3 in Rawalpindi", the
report said.

Interior Minister Rehman Malik had requested his Indian counterpart P
Chidambaram last year to allow a special team of the FIA to record statements of
witnesses and key personalities, including the magistrate who recorded Kasab's
confession and the police officer who led the investigation into the Mumbai
terror attacks that killed 166 people.

In a related development, an FIA investigation team has informed the interior
minister that the probe was not making any progress "because of India's
unwillingness to allow the Pakistani commission to record Indian investigators'
statements".

"During investigations, Kasab told the Indian magistrate that two majors of
Pakistan Army were involved in the pre-attack conspiracy," the newspaper quoted
its sources as saying.

The FIA has also filed a petition in the Lahore High Court asking for Kasab and
Fahim Ansari to be declared proclaimed offenders or fugitives.

Khwaja Sultan, the counsel for Lashkar-i-Toiba commander Zakiur Rehman Lakhvi,
one of the seven accused in Pakistan, contended there was no legal basis for
Pakistani investigators recording the statements of Indian nationals.

"How can FIA officials record statements of Indian citizens? There is no such
treaty between the two countries," he said

Source: PTI news agency, New Delhi, in English 1514gmt 28 Jan 11

Russian investigators report solving Domodedovo airport terrorist attack

LENGTH: 122 words


The terrorist attack at Moscow's Domodedovo airport committed on 24 January has
been solved, the official spokesman for the Russian Investigations Committee,
Vladimir Markin, has said, as reported by Russian RIA Novosti news agency on 29
January. Further details will be made public later, the report quoted him as
saying.

"There are a number of suspects who are being investigated for their involvement
in organizing and carrying out the terrorist attack at Domodedovo. Efforts to
detain them are under way," a source in the law-enforcement agencies told
Interfax news agency later on the same day.

Moscow blast 1 Russia Two London businessmen were among 35 people killed when a
female suicide bomber attacked a Moscow airport on Monday. Gordon Cousland, 39,
and Kirill Bodrashov, 38, died in the international arrivals hall at Domodedovo
airport, Russia's busiest. Just before detonating her explosives, the terrorist
screamed, "I will kill you all." At least 168 people were wounded.

Chechen militants, who have been behind other terrorist acts in Russia,
including last year's double suicide bombing on the Moscow underground that
killed 40, are the main suspects.

Cousland's brother, Robin, said, "We're all just completely shocked. It's
devastated the family."

Allen stumped 10 America On Wednesday a federal judge in Houston, Texas ordered
the billionaire Allen Stanford to undergo detox for a drug addiction that has
rendered him incompetent to stand trial. At a hearing earlier this month a
district judge, David Hittner, declared Stanford unfit to stand trial on charges
that he led a £4.5 billion fraud scheme based in Antigua. Psychiatrists said his
addiction to an anti-anxiety medication as well as a brain injury he suffered in
2009 in a jail fight have left him unable to think clearly.

The financier, who created the eponymous Stanford Super Series Twenty20 cricket
competition, has pleaded not guilty to 21 counts of fraud, money laundering and
obstruction.

Brought to book 9 Japan The man facing charges of raping and murdering the
British teacher Lindsay Hawker in 2007 has written a book detailing his time on
the run. Tatsuya Ichihashi was arrested in 2009, 2Å years after the
22-year-old's body was found buried in sand in a bathtub on the balcony of his
Tokyo flat.

Ichihashi, 32, wrote the book, Until I Was Arrested, in the 14 months after he
was caught. It documents his efforts to change his appearance by cutting his
lips with scissors to make them appear thinner and slicing moles off his face.
He also paid to have plastic surgery - and was caught when doctors reported
their suspicions about him to police.

Ichihashi is in custody awaiting trial and has offered to donate proceeds from
the book to Lindsay's family, who issued a statement saying they were
"disgusted" that he was being allowed to publish the book.

Hero honoured 7 Australia A solider has been awarded the Victoria Cross, the
country's highest military honour. Corporal Benjamin Roberts-Smith, 32, was
given the medal for single-handedly overpowering Taliban machinegunners
attacking his platoon in Kandahar province in Afghanistan last October.

"You went to Afghanistan a soldier; you came back a hero," the country's prime
minister, Julia Gillard, said at the ceremony last Sunday. Roberts-Smith, the
father of twin girls, said: "I saw a lot of brave men do a lot of brave things
that day."

Extended family 6 America The talk show host Oprah Winfrey revealed on air on
Monday that she has discovered a half-sister she previously did not know about.
Winfrey, 57, described it as "the miracle of all miracles", and said that she
learnt last autumn about Patricia, her half-sister who was given up for adoption
by their mother soon after her birth in 1963. Oprah and Patricia, 47, met on
Thanksgiving Day.

"It was a beloved moment," the presenter said. Winfrey had a late sister, also
called Patricia, who struggled with drug addiction and died in 2003. "It feels
to me like you are Pat on her very best day," Winfrey told her half-sister. "You
are what she wanted to be without the drugs."

SECTION: NEWS REVIEW;FEATURES; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 92 words


Gay murder 5 Uganda David Kato, a leading gay rights activist, was beaten to
death at his home after a newspaper printed his photo and called for him to be
killed.

Last year, under the headline "Hang Them", the Ugandan Rolling Stone newspaper
printed Kato's picture on the front page as part of a piece that published the
names and photos of "Uganda's 100 top homos". The editor of the magazine, Giles
Muhame, said that he did not condone the murder.

"We want the government to hang people who promote homosexuality, not the public
to attack them," he said.

Divided they stand 4 West Bank A cache of 1,600 leaked documents from the Middle
East peace process revealed that the Palestinians offered major concessions to
Israel in a vain effort to forge a peace settlement.

According to the documents, released by the Arab television station Al Jazeera,
the Palestinians offered a deal on East Jerusalem that would have allowed Jewish
settlements to remain on their land. They were also willing to accept that only
10,000 refugees would return to their homes, a fraction of the 5m displaced
Palestinians.

The chief Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, dismissed the papers as "lies and
half truths".

TOP STORIES FROM AROUND THE WORLD ; 'Swinger' jailed and a terrorist airport
attack kills 35

SECTION: NEWS REVIEW;FEATURES; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 103 words


Mandela 'stable' 3 South Africa Nelson Mandela, the former president, was
released from hospital on Friday after being rushed there on Wednesday with an
acute respiratory infection.

Initial reports about the former president's condition were vague, which led to
panic that he was close to death. However, the country's surgeon-general, VJ
Ramlakan, sought to calm fears on Friday. He said Mandela had "received
treatment and has responded very well. He is stable but will be monitored
closely".

He added: "Medically there is no need to panic. For a 92-year-old he surprises
us on a daily basis with his powers of recovery."

Running battles;
TOP STORIES FROM AROUND THE WORLD ; 'Swinger' jailed and a terrorist airport
attack kills 35

SECTION: NEWS REVIEW;FEATURES; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 125 words


Running battles 2 Egypt At least 35 people died last week in widespread
demonstrations. Tens of thousands took to the streets in defiance of an official
ban on public gatherings, and riot police fought running battles with
demonstrators who were demanding an end to the 30-year rule of the president,
Hosni Mubarak. Just after midnight on Friday night, the president dismissed the
government and said a new cabinet would be formed the following day.

Among the protesters was Mohamed ElBaradei - the Nobel peace prize-winning
former head of the UN's nuclear watchdog - who returned to Egypt on Thursday to
take part in the protests. "I am going back to Cairo and back onto the streets,
because, really, there is no choice," he said.

Subordinate claws;
TOP STORIES FROM THE UK ; 'Swinger' jailed and a terrorist airport attack kills
35

SECTION: NEWS REVIEW;FEATURES; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 113 words


Paleontology British scientists have discovered a parrot-sized dinosaur, a
distant cousin of TyrannS osaurus rex, it was revealed on Tuesday. The
fossilised remains of Linhenykus monodactylus, pictured above, uncovered near
the Chinese city of Linhe, suggest that the dinosaur stood 2ft tall on a
bird-like frame. One stunted claw on each forelimb may have been used to scoop
up insects, "rather like an armadillo", said Michael Pittman, part of the
British team that found the skeleton.

Pittman, of University College London, added that the dinosaur would not have
appeared very scary: "You'd see a very small animal, probably below your hip
height, with a very small gracile skull."

Sheridan jailed;
TOP STORIES FROM THE UK 'Swinger' jailed and a terrorist airport attack kills 35

SECTION: NEWS REVIEW;FEATURES; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 188 words


Courts Tommy Sheridan, former leader of the Scottish Socialist party (SSP), was
jailed for three years on Wednesday after being convicted of perjury. In order
to win a £200,000 defamation suit against the News of the World, Sheridan lied
on oath, a jury decided at Glasgow High Court.

The 46-year-old sued the Sunday tabloid in 2006 after it ran a number of exposés
claiming he had enjoyed extramarital affairs and had visited a swingers' club.
He won his claim but had to return to court last year to face charges that he
had lied in the original case by denying both an affair with a SSP member,
Katrine Trolle, and a trip with her to a Manchester sex club.

Despite hearing lurid details of her husband's activities in court, Sheridan's
wife, Gail, pictured above with him, defended him throughout. The former air
hostess told jurors in the original libel trial that if she believed her husband
had cheated on her he would be "in the Clyde with a piece of concrete" tied to
him and she would be "in court for his murder".

As Sheridan was led away to the cells last week, he turned to his wife and said,
"Take care; all the best."

One lord a-lying;
TOP STORIES FROM THE UK ; 'Swinger' jailed and a terrorist airport attack kills
35

SECTION: NEWS REVIEW;FEATURES; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 134 words


One lord a-lying Parliament The former Tory peer Lord Taylor of Warwick was
facing a two-year jail sentence last week after being found guilty of expenses
fraud. The 58-year-old barrister argued that the six claims he had submitted to
the House of Lords, totalling £11,277.80, were made in good faith because it was
a common practice among peers to claim expenses "in lieu of a salary".

Taylor had listed a home in Oxford, which was owned by his half-nephew, as his
main residence, enabling him to claim for travel between Oxford and London and
for overnight stays in the capital. In fact he lived in Ealing, west London.
"The impression I got was that expenses weren't things that you were repaid for,
but that they were actually allowance," he told the court. He was released on
bail pending sentencing.

SECTION: NEWS REVIEW;FEATURES; Pg. 10,11

Proper Charlie Protests Charlie Gilmour, the adopted son of the Pink Floyd
guitarist David Gilmour, has been charged with violent disorder and theft of a
mannequin leg. The 21-year-old was among thousands of students who gathered in
Trafalgar Square and Parliament Square ahead of the Commons vote last month to
treble the maximum level of university tuition fees to £9,000.

The Cambridge University undergraduate was photographed hanging from a Union
flag on the Cenotaph. In his apology the following day the student described his
actions as a "moment of idiocy" and admitted he did not realise the monument
commemorated Britain's war dead. He will appear at Westminster magistrates'
court on February 10.

TOP STORIES FROM THE UK ; 'Swinger' jailed and a terrorist airport attack kills
35

SECTION: NEWS REVIEW;FEATURES; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 102 words


Blaze tragedy Deaths A mother tried in vain to rescue her four children from a
fire that engulfed a house in Ashbourne, Derbyshire on Tuesday. Rachel Henson,
44, managed to escape from the blaze and woke neighbours but they were unable to
open the front door to save Tommy, 9, Alisha, 6, Rocco, 4, and Appolonia, 2, who
were sleeping upstairs. Firefighters rescued two of the children, but they died
later in hospital.

Carol Bowler, 50, a neighbour, said: "I went outside and saw people putting
ladders up to a bedroom window. Rachel managed to get out. She was sobbing and
screaming, 'Are any of my children alive?' "

Two legs good;
TOP STORIES FROM THE UK ; 'Swinger' jailed and a terrorist airport attack kills
35

SECTION: NEWS REVIEW;FEATURES; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 114 words


Two legs good Nature Footage, pictured below, of a gorilla walking upright at a
Kent animal park has become a YouTube sensation, racking up more than 250,000
views in the past few days. The clip shows Ambam, a 21-year-old silverback,
standing 6ft tall and then walking like a human on his hind legs at Port Lympne
wild animal park, near Hythe, Kent. Gorillas usually get around by "knuckle
walking" - using the padded backs of their front hands to support themselves as
they move around the floors of forests or zoos.

Ingrid Naisby, a keeper at the park, said, "He's always liked to stand up. It's
about getting his balance right and he's well practised. He has perfected it."

Excess luggage;
TOP STORIES FROM THE UK ; 'Swinger' jailed and a terrorist airport attack kills
35

SECTION: NEWS REVIEW;FEATURES; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 171 words


Excess luggage Crime An American weapons dealer allegedly smuggled more than 80
handguns into Britain, where they were offered to criminal gangs in the north of
England at up to £5,000 apiece, it was reported on Tuesday. The guns, which
include 20 Glock 9mm semi-automatic pistols, were bought for about $500 (£325)
each in a North Carolina gunshop.

Authorities in London and Washington held crisis talks after Steven Greenoe, 37,
a private security consultant, was accused of trafficking the dismantled weapons
in his hold luggage. He was stopped at least once when airport screening
detected "multiple firearms" in his bags, but managed to talk his way onto the
flight from Atlanta to Manchester.

Five guns have been recovered in Britain and tests show that one was used in a
drive-by shooting in Manchester last October. The former Scotland Yard
counter-terrorism chief Andy Hayman said: "This makes a mockery of the stringent
checks we all endure at US airports ... Steven Greenoe's guns could have just as
easily been bombs."

A selfless act;
TOP STORIES FROM THE UK ; 'Swinger' jailed and a terrorist airport attack kills
35

SECTION: NEWS REVIEW;FEATURES; Pg. 10,11

LENGTH: 123 words


A selfless act Armed forces Private Martin Bell was named as Britain's 350th
military fatality in Afghanistan since operations began in 2001. The soldier,
24, from 2nd Battalion the Parachute Regiment was killed in a blast from an
improvised explosive device to the south of Nahr-e-Saraj in Helmand province on
Wednesday. He had disobeyed a direct order and gone to the aid of a colleague
who had been injured by another device. Superiors said he was a hero whose
selfless act cost him his life.

Lieutenant-Colonel Andrew Harrison, commanding officer, 2 Para, said, "Private
Martin Bell died going to the assistance of a critically injured friend in the
most dangerous combat circumstances imaginable; 'greater love has no man than
this'."

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            January 31, 2011 Monday

Daily says "Indian mind" behind Russia accusing Pakistan for terror attack

LENGTH: 216 words


Text of daily headlined "Russia's suicide attack allegation against Pakistan"
published by Pakistani newspaper Ausaf on 28 January

Russia has accused Pakistan of Moscow suicide attack, without offering proof in
support of its allegation. It shows that Indian lobby against Pakistan has
become highly active on global levels. It is very much probable that India would
have asked Russia to directly hurl the allegation for this accident on Pakistan.

Chechen warriors might have carried out the Moscow suicide attack, since they
have direct enmity with Russia. Moreover, it is very likely that it could be a
joint action of Al-Qa'idah and Chechen warriors. Al-Qa'idah possesses enough
capability to conduct this type of attacks with the local support.

However, all this is realistic review. Russia did not opt for realism in this
regard and, as a result of the alleged Indian incitation, hurled the allegations
against Pakistan. It is exactly the same case as whenever some incident takes
place in India, it hurls the allegation against Pakistan within hours, without
any kind of proof.

In the wake of the India-Russia close relations, it is very much possible that
Indian mind could be working behind this allegation, which is very expert at
such deeds.

Source: Ausaf, Islamabad, in Urdu 28 Jan 11, p 10

LOAD-DATE: January 31, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2011 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved

                              426 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            January 31, 2011 Monday

Chechen leader blames terrorist attacks on nationalists, opposition, West

LENGTH: 709 words


No security system will be able to avert future terrorist attacks, President of
Russia's Chechen Republic Ramzan Kadyrov has said. Extremism has to be tackled
at the spiritual level, he added. He was speaking in an interview with popular
Russian TV host Tina Kandelaki and prominent journalist Andrey Kolesnikov as
part of their programme "Unreal Politics", broadcast on Russian Gazprom-owned
channel NTV on 30 January.

Kadyrov described the terrorist attack at Moscow's Domodedovo airport on 24
January as "a common distress, common grief".

Asked whether he knew of effective mechanisms to prevent such attacks, Kadyrov
said: "Indeed, the real fight against terrorism and extremism is spirituality.
Today we can stop one terrorist, another one, a third one, but it cannot go on
like this. We should bring up the younger generation in such a way that they
know what religion is, what Islam is, what Christianity is, so that we do not
have any differences between each other. We should conduct a policy of
explanation and propaganda in relation to this younger generation."

Asked whether he knew anything about the Nogayskiy Dzhamaat terrorist group
which, according to the investigation, is allegedly responsible for the
Domodedovo attack, Kadyrov said: "There is a group of shaytans [devils], and
they need to be destroyed." He went on to say that "very strong states and
special agencies were behind them. It is not like a simple man decided to go to
Domodedovo and stage a terrorist attack," he said. Asked whom exactly he
suspected to be behind "the simple man", Kadyrov answered briefly: "The West".

Speaking about measures he had taken to curb terrorism in Chechnya, Kadyrov said
he had employed all the available means. "Today, I, too, plan operations, take
measures, and I like this job because I protect people's lives," he said. "What
we also did was, we gathered all our spiritual leaders together and developed a
spiritual programme."

He also described measures against Wahhabi propaganda on the Internet: "I
specially bought computers and put 15 people at them. They answered their
[Wahhabis'] questions day and night, they tried to convince them that they were
wrong, that the prophet did not say this at that time. And we proved that the
Koran does not say that. And today 98 per cent are on our side, and two per cent
on theirs. And two per cent is also a lot. And one should find such a common
language with young people so that they do not go to Manezhka [Square in Moscow,
where race rally took place in December 2010], do not kill, do not blow up."

Kadyrov also advocated jailing opposition leaders to resolve the problem,
saying: "What is [leader of the Russian People's Democratic Union Mikhail]
Kasyanov displeased with? He is the former chairman of the government, in his
time he [changes tack] What is [opposition politician Boris] Nemtsov not happy
about? They also served in the same state. They claimed we conducted the right
policy. What are they looking for today? One should jail them all, first of all,
and all their supervisors. After that nobody will be interested in coming out to
Manezhka."

"One should not play around with them, then there will be order and no
inter-ethnic conflicts. [Leader of Russian Liberal-Democratic Party Vladimir]
Zhirinovskiy should be expelled from the State Duma, he who allegedly defends
Russian politics and insults Caucasians. We Caucasians are Russians, too. And
Russia is our Fatherland. We used to die in the name of Russia. And he freely
insults us, humiliates us. If we get rid of such people, if we put nationalists
in prison and expel them from [government] structures, then there will be
order."

Speaking about his career plans, Kadyrov, who is only 34 now, said he did not
intend to move further up the career ladder. "I am a warrior. I can be a good
warrior, I know how to lead a squadron after me and perform tasks," he said.

He went on to reiterate his admiration for Russian Prime Minister Vladimir
Putin. "I am trying to be like Vladimir Putin. We do not need to look for
others, invent something new. There is a man who serves his state, his people,
day and night. And I try to conduct the policy which he conducts," he concluded.

Source: NTV, Moscow, in Russian 2050 gmt 30 Jan 11

LOAD-DATE: January 31, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                              All Rights Reserved

                      Western Morning News (Plymouth, UK)

                            January 31, 2011 Monday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Woman tells of her hammer attack terror

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 226 words


A woman has described how she was attacked in broad daylight by a man wielding a
hammer.

Michelle Jenkins said she was shopping in Cornwall Street, near Plymouth City
Market, on Saturday when the man ran up to her and brandished a hammer in her
face. Mrs Jenkins, 40, instinctively pushed him away and was not hit.

The man, whom she believes may have been homeless and suffering mental health
problems, was later arrested. Businesswoman Michelle, from Plymouth, said: "I
had just dropped off my husband and parked the car behind the former Woolworth
store. We were about to buy some Euros.

I was walking between the car park and Cornwall Street, just putting my keys in
my pocket, when the man ran up and brandished the hammer right in my face. He
didn't say anything.

"I took him off guard, shoved him back and got out of the way.

"I was just in the wrong place at the wrong time."

Mrs Jenkins said the man was about 5ft 3in, scruffy and in ragged clothes, and
appeared to have possessions in bags and a trolley.

She said: "He looked like he was sleeping rough."

Mrs Jenkins' husband, Robert, 34, found her being comforted by another woman,
and phoned the police to report the attack.

His wife then witnessed the man being arrested.

¦ An unemployed 45-year-old man was arrested at 10.20am on Saturday on suspicion
of possessing an offensive weapon in a public place.

LOAD-DATE: January 31, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: WMN


                 Copyright 2011 Western Morning News (Plymouth)
                              All Rights Reserved

                              428 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            February 1, 2011 Tuesday

Airport vulnerability to terror attacks probed by Russian TV show

LENGTH: 684 words


The 30 January edition of "Reporters' Stories" programme on privately-owned Ren
TV, titled "Effect of the exploded bomb" and presented by Leonid Kanfer, was
prompted by the 24 January bombing attack on Moscow's Domodedovo airport.
Presenter noted that this was the first time that terrorists blew up a facility
as closely guarded as an international airport. Some of the questions the
programme sought to answer included why the special services were again not held
responsible for the death of people and whether Russians are prepared to live
under conditions of total control.

Survivors' views

An eyewitness to the attack, Artem Zhilinkov, said that the main entrance to the
terminal in Domodedovo was not guarded and there was another side entrance
through which "anything could be smuggled in". Another survivor, Yuriy Vartanov,
was interviewed in his hospital bed, saying that he expected a second explosion
to occur. Vartanov said that two people who he thinks were suicide bombers as
they looked tense and determined, could be told apart from the rest of the crowd
but there were no trained spotters in the arrivals hall. Vartanov said that no
searches or examinations were conducted, most likely because there was no
funding for checks.

A survivor of the March 2010 suicide bombing on Moscow metro, Vladislav
Martiyanov, said that it was wrong that Domodedovo continued to work as normal
after the bombing, and that everyone had to be evacuated to prevent a second
bombing. Alina Golubeva, who travelled on the Nevskiy Ekspress train which was
blown up in November 2008, said that she did not notice any increase in the
security measures since the bombing despite the government's pledges.

Security issues at the airport

Domodedovo is thought to be Russia's best-equipped airport, with cutting-edge
security equipment. Natsionalnaya Oborona (Russ: national defence) magazine
editor in chief Igor Korotchenko was interviewed, saying that while the
equipment may have been in place, the personnel were not present and thus
examination was not conducted, due to slackness. Former head of the explosions
department of the USSR state security committee (KGB), Vladimir Mikhaylov, said
that the explosives used in the attack on Domodedovo could not be detected by a
metal detector. He added that checks on security operations are ineffective as
they are conducted by the security services themselves and not controlled by any
outside bodies. A security officer at Moscow's Vnukovo airport was interviewed,
saying that she thinks increased security regime should be maintained but they
will need more personnel.

Domodedovo's six-level security system was profiled, but the presenter says that
crowds forming in front of the airport after metal detectors are enacted may be
as attractive to terrorists as those inside the terminal building. Domodedovo's
system is contrasted with the Israeli approach whereby security personnel rather
than equipment is crucial to ensuring airport security.

Influence of corruption

State Duma deputy Gennadiy Gudkov told the programme that any terrorist can
smuggle anything anywhere, safe in the knowledge that he would be freed from
control by bribes, and can get any papers for money. Gudkov said that "the whole
country are terrorists' accomplices". Corruption has to be tackled in order to
get rid of terrorism, Gudkov said, adding that people who made their fortunes on
corrupt deals and now prevent the fight against corruption are terrorists' main
accomplices.

Irina Krutova, a relative of victims of a 2004 aircraft suicide bombing which
was made possible by a R1,000 (about 33.5 dollars) bribe to a duty policeman at
Domodedovo and to the fact that the pre-flight examination group was
undermanned, was interviewed, saying that an investigator advised them to
withdraw a lawsuit against Domodedovo. Krutova says that "such untouchable
people own shares in Domodedovo that it's scary to even think about them". There
were no apologies from the authorities or from Domodedovo apart from monetary
compensation, she alleged.

Source: REN TV, Moscow, in Russian 1105 gmt 30 Jan 11

Osh, 1 February: Kyrgyz President Roza Otunbayeva has said that according to
information of special services, there is a possibility of new terrorist attacks

She said that above all "it is necessary to teach pupils and students [how to
behave during terrorist attacks]".

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                            February 1, 2011 Tuesday
                                   Edition 2;
                                National Edition

An attack by cyber terrorists is likely warns security minister;
News Bulletin

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 197 words


Britain is likely to come under cyber attack from terrorists, the security
minister, Baroness Neville-Jones, warned yesterday.

The potential for Islamic radicals to launch computer assaults on critical
infrastructure, such as power stations and communications networks, was being
taken into account as new security defences were built, she said.

"There is also a risk, likely to grow over time, that terrorists will develop
the ability to hack into critical infrastructures and online systems," she told
an internet conference yesterday.

"A cyber attack attempted by terrorists, if not inevitable, is of so great a
likelihood that we bear it in mind in developing operational capabilities."

In October, the Strategic Defence and Security Review allocated £650million to
improving cyber security.

Details of how the new budget will be carved up across Whitehall are still being
finalised, but Baroness Neville-Jones, who has responsibility for
counter-terrorism, said it was a priority to ensure that "terrorists find it
hard to conduct cyber-attacks".

Fears over cyber attacks by terrorists have grown since last year, when the
Stuxnet virus disrupted the Iranian nuclear enrichment programme.

                              Western Daily Press

                            February 1, 2011 Tuesday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Blame game fears raised after bomb blast at Russian airport;
Russia specialist Dr Gregory Schwartz calls for tougher questioning to prevent
terror attacks

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 772 words


As the dust of last week's explosion at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport settles, the
initial tragic drama of bodies, ambulances, hospitals and officials appearing on
television screens and in print turns to questions, finger-pointing and
blamelaying.

Almost immediately President Dmitry Medvedev stated that the airport authorities
are responsible for the negligence that allowed two men to come in unobstructed
to the arrivals hall. He has subsequently blamed the airport's poor security
policies and practices for the deadly blast that killed 35 people and injured
more than 100 others.

In the meantime, airport officials have tried to shield their reputation (and
careers) by blaming the police, an act which has brought the wrath of the
president, who has lashed out at the managers and called such actions "immoral."
Further up the line, Medvedev had already dismissed several top transport
officials, demanding that the transport ministry be "brought to their senses."

Privately, many former lukewarm supporters of changes to the anti-terrorism laws
in the UK have been voicing concerns about Theresa May's announced changes, and
what they might imply in light of the ostensible persisting dangers of
international terrorism.

Indeed, labelling the February and August 2004 and the March 2010 Moscow Metro
suicide bombings, the 2002 Nord-Ost Theatre hostage taking, and the September
1999 Moscow apartment bombings as aspects of international Islamic terrorism is
a preferred rhetorical device often used by the Russian government. As in the
earlier incidents, the early pronouncements from officials and media in the
Domodedovo case have followed a similar pattern, insisting the attacks must have
come from radical Islamists in Chechnya, Ingushetia or Dagestan.

Recently there have been calls to restrain such emphatic pronouncements, if not
an explicit criticism of official policies or military doctrine.

Now Prime Minister Vladimir Putin has said that investigations have shown there
was no Chechen trace in the recent bombing.

The slight change of rhetoric may be an attempt to deflect a growing scepticism
from the Russian public, who feel (mostly privately, but increasingly in public)
that the last decade of military campaigns and micromanagement of local politics
in the North Caucasus has brought them no closer to security.

Originally, the Russian authorities have been happy to paint their prolonged
fight against armed militants in the North Caucasus as part of a global War on
Terror. Western governments, in turn, have been happy to keep quiet about
Russia's affairs in the region to carry on their own wars. But the parallels
between terrorist threats East and West, aside from being politically
convenient, are hardly plausible.

The Russian government of the early 2000s waged a bloody war in North Caucasus
which killed thousands of civilians, destroyed towns, villages, roads,
infrastructure, and with them any hope of a quick return to normality. It
celebrated its eventual 'victory' by giving the Chechen people a present in the
form of a puppet regime headed by a former separatist militant turned loyalist,
Ramzan Kadyrov. It has been claimed by many, most famously by Anna Politkovskaya
in her posthumously published diaries, that this defector to the Kremlin has
been running Chechnya like a private fiefdom, with an iron fist and with
complete impunity.

Money poured to the region by the Kremlin has ended up in the pockets of a
narrow clique of people loyal to Kadyrov, rather than the schools, hospitals and
infrastructure of the republic.

In the midst of the all this, many young people, whose futures have been
blighted by the poverty and the lawlessness of the last decade, have been
leaving towns and villages to join more hardened, radicalised militants in the
surrounding mountains. For these youth, radicalisation is a political choice,
representing an attempt to break a cycle of violence and hopelessness.

Understandably, flitting from pillar to post about which agency or person to
blame for the security breach allows the people in power to deflect attention
from the real problems that underlie the resentment and political hopes of the
people of North Caucasus. It forces the media to focus on the detail while
ignoring the larger picture. Perhaps, therefore, more probing questions should
be asked by those in the media and in the governments about the conditions of
those blamed for the attacks, if there is a serious desire to forego terrorist
attacks in both Russia and more widely.

'It forces the media to focus on the detail while ignoring the larger picture'
Bath University's Dr Gregory Schwartz

LOAD-DATE: February 1, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         The Evening Standard (London)

                           February 2, 2011 Wednesday

SCIENTIST'S TERROR ATTACK FEARS OVER VIRUS 'SUPERLAB'

LENGTH: 270 words


MARK BLUNDEN

ONE of Britain's leading bio-scientists today voiced fears over the safety of a
£600 million virus "superlab" planned for St Pancras.

Professor Guy Dodson, who has worked at Oxford University, warned that the
14-storey, maximum security site containing viruses including malaria,
tuberculosis, bird and swine flu, cancer cells and HIV would need to be
"bulletproof".

He told the Standard: "The issues are if you have an earthquake, some idiot lets
a bomb off or there's a fire at St Pancras International.

"These are extreme examples but you don't want that building to suffer a serious
knockabout when you've got this material in there.

"The unspoken concern is terrorism because it's a natural target. We need to
know the capacity they have for dealing with the unexpected." The biochemist's
fears echo those of some of the thousands living nearby.

The UK Centre for Medical Research and Innovation will have several underground
laboratories.

Professor Dodson is also concerned that vibrations from Tube trains running
through King's Cross and Euston could ruin delicate and expensive laboratory
equipment.

In written evidence to a Commons Science and Technology select committee
inquiry, he wrote: "I fear that the £600 million funding will not be sufficient
to meet the uncertainties in building and equipping the laboratories."

The consortium behind the project includes the Medical Research Council, Cancer
Research UK and the Wellcome Trust. The centre, which has won planning
permission from Camden council and been approved by London Mayor Boris Johnson,
said biosecurity will be among the tightest in Britain.

                               The Times (London)

                           February 2, 2011 Wednesday
                                   Edition 2;
                                National Edition

'Financial terrorists' pose grave risk to US;
Attacks may have caused 2008 crisis, report says

BYLINE: Alexandra Frean

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 882 words


The US financial system remains vulnerable to a co-ordinated act of "financial
terrorism" that risks taking down the US economy and collapsing the dollar,
according to a confidential report commissioned by the Department of Defence in
Washington.

The document warns that forces hostile to the US could mount a "focused effort
to collapse the dollar by dumping Treasury bonds" and urges the security
services to conduct a further risk assessment "outside of traditional Washington
and Wall Street circles".

It also suggests that the financial meltdown of 2008, which wiped out an
estimated $50 trillion of global wealth, may not have been the spontaneous
result of poor regulation and bad risk assessment among financial institutions,
but a co-ordinated series of attacks by "financial terrorists intent on
destroying the American financial system". The disclosure of the report's
contents to The Times came as the FBI confirmed that it had warned major Wall
Street institutions of a potential threat to their businesses and executives
after an al Qaeda-linked magazine, Inspire, suggested that financial markets
could be a target of attack.

A spokesman for the FBI in New York confirmed yesterday that security briefings
for Wall Street firms took place last month, but said that the information that
was discussed was "not imminent, not specific". The briefings reflect concerns
in some quarters of the Pentagon about the vulnerability of America's financial
and economic system to terrorist attack.

The FBI move follows revelations in The Times this week that stock exchanges in
Britain and the United States have turned to the security services for help
after discovering that they were the victims of terrorist plots and attempted
cyber attacks that aimed to spread panic in leading global financial markets
last year.

The 110-page document commissioned by the Irregular Warfare Support Program
(IWSP) of the US Department of Defence is entitled Economic Warfare: Risks and
Responses. It has been circulated among defence chiefs in Washington but has
never been made public. It was delivered to the IWSP in June, 2009, eight months
after the collapse of Lehman Brothers triggered the financial crisis, but has
remained under wraps since then as the attention in Washington focused instead
on introducing financial reforms. It resurfaced two months ago when it was
submitted by the Department of Defence to the Financial Crisis Inquiry
Commission (FCIC), the official US Government-appointed body investigating the
causes of the 2008 crisis. The report examines the possibility that gaps in the
US financial regulatory system "were subject to exploitation not only by greedy
capitalists seeking profit, but also by financial terrorists intent on
destroying the American financial system". It adds that high levels of debt,
especially housing debt, taken on by American households added to the country's
vulnerability.

Drawing heavily on academic and other texts, the report outlines a scenario in
which US economic security could be undermined in a three-phase attack. The
first could have been the surge in oil prices fuelled by speculators in 2007.
The second phase would have begun in 2008 with a series of bear raids targeting
US financial services firms, most particularly Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers,
in which investors bet that the stock of those companies would fall in value.

The third phase could take the form of a direct economic attack on the US
Treasury and US dollar, the report says.

"A focused effort to collapse the dollar by dumping Treasury bonds has grave
implications including the possibility of a downgrading of US debt and...
removing [the dollar] from reserve currency status," it says.

"Such an event has already been discussed by finance ministers in major emerging
market nations, such as China and Russia, as well as Iran and the Arab states,"
it adds.

The report suggests that any number of foreign-based individuals or
organisations, ranging from sovereign wealth funds to Russian mobsters and
al-Qaeda and even one or more of Brazil, Russia, India and China could have the
means and motive to perpetrate or commission acts of financial and economic
terror on the US. While it does not accuse any of these parties of wrongdoing,
it outlines the potential threat they pose and concludes that the fact that
there is reasonable credibility to this threat "justifies very serious
consideration".

"Ignoring the likelihood of this very real threat ensures a catastrophic event,"
it warns. The report recommends the creation of a special unit to "implement
appropriate counter-measures to emerging threats in co-ordination with key
defence, intelligence, and financial agencies".

The document's author, Kevin D Freeman, is the founder and chief executive of
Freeman Global Investment Counsel, a boutique investment advisory firm. He was
commissioned by the Department of Defence in 2009.

Although the views contained in the report represent Mr Freeman's views and not
those of the Department, e-mails seen by The Times confirm that the department
commissioned the report, circulated it among defence chiefs and passed it to the
FCIC in November or December last year.

The US Department of Defence declined to comment on the report.

How The Times revealed the plots on Monday

                           February 3, 2011 Thursday

Most Russians fear terrorist attacks - poll

LENGTH: 299 words


Excerpt from report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Moscow, 3 February: The majority of Russians (68 per cent) fear to fall victim
to a terrorist attack, the results of a survey carried out by the Public Opinion
foundation in 43 constituent parts of the Russian Federation on 29-30 January
suggest.

The quarter of Russians show fearlessness in this issue. Similar figures, 70 and
23 per cent respectively, were observed by sociologists in April 2010 just after
the terrorist attacks in Moscow metro stations Lubyanka and Park Kultury.

According to sociologists, out of 98 per cent of those surveyed, who are aware
of the terrorist attack in [Moscow airport] Domodedovo, 65 per cent believe that
the terrorist attack could have been prevented, 14 per cent think it would be
impossible and 19 per cent could not answer.

Fifty-one per cent believe that the terrorist attack will be uncovered, 31 per
cent doubt this, and 19 per cent could not answer.

One in five (26 per cent) think that terrorists' aim was to terrorize and
frighten people, 10 per cent believe that criminals wanted to destabilize the
situation in the country, to incite ethnic hatred and war, and seven per cent
think terrorists wanted to demonstrate their power and to remind of themselves.

First feelings the respondents had about news on the terrorist attack in
Domodedovo were compassion for victims, pity, grief (51 per cent), helplessness,
feeling of insecurity, fear for themselves and loved ones (21 per cent),
vexation, grievance, thoughts about the guilt of special services and
politicians (16 per cent), shock, distress, horror (11 per cent), indignation,
anger, abhorrence of terrorists and desire to revenge (10 per cent). [Passage
omitted]

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0753 gmt 3 Feb 11

BA SLEEPER 'PLOTTED 7/7 TYPE ATTACK';
TERROR

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 23
