AN alleged terrorist sleeper at British Airways accused of plotting to blow up a
plane had hoped to take part in "another July 7", a court heard yesterday.

Islamic extremist Rajib Karim planned to train as cabin crew and form a terror
cell to get a bomb on a flight to the US, the jury was told.

Woolwich crown court in South London heard a coded message found on his computer
read: "A small team can be the beginning of another July 7". And emails from his
brother Tehzeeb in Pakistan said British citizens were "legitimate targets".

IT worker Karim, 31, of Newcastle, admits terrorist activity, producing a video
and fundraising for a terrorist group, but denies preparing to commit terrorist
acts.

The trial continues.

                                  Eire Edition

HE DROVE THE CHIP VAN OVER ME, I THOUGHT I WAS BEING MURDERED;
ATTACK VICTIM'S TERROR

BYLINE: RORY TEVLIN

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 353 words


A CHIP van owner who was beaten in a brutal robbery yesterday revealed how she
thought she was going to die during the ordeal.

Wendy Taaffe, 34, from Louth, yesterday described how a masked attacker threw
her to the floor and drove over her with her own van.

He She is still recovering from the vicious beating doled out as she set up
Wendy's Whistle Stop Chippy outside Ardee at around 6.45am on January 22.

The assault left her bruised and battered, with a fractured leg, spine and
broken ankle.

She yesterday told how the cowardly thugs showed her no mercy as she lay injured
on the ground.

Wendy said: "From my house to where I travel to is about 12 miles.

"When I pulled up I got out of the jeep and I only put my hand on the gate and I
could hear a car running and I got back in.

"The next thing I know I got pulled out of it. I got the biggest shock of my
life.

"He threw me on the road as if I was a bit of dirt and I got an unmerciful blow
to the back of the head. He got into the jeep and out of sheer temper I got up
because all that was going through my head was, 'You are not taking my jeep and
my van, no way'.

"That is my life. I got up and he hit me on the side of the face. As he was
taking off I stumbled and fell and he drove the chip van over me.

"I thought I was being murdered and said, 'Please God don't let them kill me'.

"The guy that attacked me was wearing a black balaclava, black gloves and never
spoke one single word.

of "I tried to punch him but I have never got a beating like it. They showed no
mercy."

Wendy was forced to crawl to a nearby house to get help for her horrific
injuries.

She was released from hospital on Monday and will be forced to wear a back brace
for the next six weeks.

But the defiant businesswoman yesterday vowed the thugs would not frighten her
from the spot she has been serving food from for 14 years.

She said: "I have been through hell. I would not wish it on my worst enemy. I
love my work and I said to my sister, 'I am going back, I will not be bullied'."

Her chip van was recovered by the gardai 500 metres from the attack but
detectives are still searching for the jeep.

AU chief condemns terrorist attacks in Mauritania

LENGTH: 183 words


Text of report in English by state-owned Ethiopian news agency ENA website

Addis Ababa, 4 February: The chairperson of the African Union Commission (AUC),
Jean Ping, strongly condemned the recently attempted terrorist attack in
Nouakchott, which was successfully foiled and could have caused carnage.

According to a statement AU sent to ENA [Ethiopian News Agency] on Thursday [3
February], the chairperson congratulated the Mauritanian authorities for their
vigilance and action that have made it possible to prevent a catastrophe, and
reiterated AU's support to Mauritania and other member states in their efforts
to deal effectively with terrorism.

The statement said the attempt demonstrates, once again the need for sustained
and coordinated efforts among African states, within the framework of relevant
AU instruments, to prevent and combat the scourge of terrorism.

The AU commission reiterated its determination to spare no effort in enhancing
the effectiveness of counter-terrorism cooperation across the continent,
according to the statement.

Text of report by state-owned Ethiopian TV on 4 February

The terrorist attack, which masterminded by the Eritrean government, planned to
hinder the recently held AU summit has been foiled.

The National Intelligence and Security Authority and Federal Police Joint
Anti-Terrorist Task Force in a statement it issued said that explosives of C-4
type with their detonators were seized.

The task force said some OLF [Oromo Liberation Front] suspects, who plotted the
plan with the Eritrean government's directives, have been arrested in Semen
Mazagaja Bet, in Addis Ababa, after securing an arrest warrant from a court.

The Eritrean government in the past had made similar effort to hinder AU summit
through its mercenaries. However, its destructive plans were foiled, the
statement noted.

                              The Herald (Glasgow)

                            February 4, 2011 Friday
                                   1 Edition

Cartoonist attacker is convicted of terrorism

BYLINE: Mette Fraende copenhagen

SECTION: Pg. 14

LENGTH: 516 words


A Danish court has found a Somali man guilty of terrorism and attempted murder
for trying to kill a cartoonist whose 2005 drawing of the Prophet Mohammad
stirred up Muslim outrage around the globe.

Mohamed Geele, 29, broke into the home of cartoonist Kurt Westergaard armed with
an axe and a knife on New Year s Day last year. Mr Westergaard was at home with
his five-year-old grand-daughter Stephanie at the time.

Geele screamed  You must die!  and  You are going to Hell! , the cartoonist told
the court during the trial.

He locked himself in his panic room   a reinforced bathroom   leaving Stephanie
alone in the living room because his attacker was  after me, not the people
around me .

The little girl was unhurt in the attack.

Geele tried to get into the bathroom, hacking at the door with his axe, but fled
when he heard police sirens.

Still armed, he was shot and wounded by police arriving at the scene, who then
arrested him.

Yesterday, Geele was acquitted on another attempted manslaughter charge, brought
because he threw his axe at a police officer who arrived to arrest him, but was
convicted of assaulting the officer.

During the trial, Geele said he was not planning to kill Mr Westergaard,  just
scare him.

The court in Aarhus was expected to sentence Geele today. He could face life in
prison, although such sentences are generally reduced to 16 years under Danish
law.

Speaking after the verdict, Mr Westergaard said:   I am an old, peaceful man and
I am not vindictive, but I am very satisfied.

I ve never been in doubt that he was a terrorist who wanted to kill me. He was a
holy warrior yelling and shouting as he was hammering the axe on the  bathroom
door.

According to local media, the terror verdict stemmed partly from Mr Westergaard
s status as a symbol of freedom of speech and democracy in Denmark, so the
attempted attack on him was deemed by the court to be an attack on the nation as
a whole.

Mr Westergaard s caricature of the Prophet was one of a dozen cartoons
lampooning Islam published by the Danish daily Jyllands-Posten, which led to
violent protests in 2006 and threats to cartoonists, journalists and the
newspaper.

Most Muslims consider any depiction of the founder of Islam offensive, and
protests resulted in at least 50 deaths.

Mr Westergaard s drawing  of the Prophet with a turban resembling a bomb
attracted most attention. The cartoonist has lived for years under police
protection following numerous threats against him and the newspaper.

On December 29 last year, Danish and Swedish police arrested five men suspected
of plotting a  Mumbai-style  attack to kill as many people as possible at the
Copenhagen building that houses the newspaper.

One of the men was subsequently released. Three others remain in custody in
Denmark and one in Sweden, facing charges of planning an act of terrorism.

Danish security police have said the arrests prevented an imminent attack that
would have been like a 2008 rampage by Pakistani gunmen in the Indian city of
Mumbai.

The men held in Denmark, one Tunisian and two Swedish citizens, will next appear
in court on February 24.

LOAD-DATE: February 4, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: GH

'Terror' attack on Danish cartoonist

BYLINE: Allan Hall

Berlin A court in Denmark has convicted a Somali man of terrorism after he armed
himself with an axe and a knife and smashed his way into the home of a newspaper
cartoonist who had drawn a caricature of the Prophet Muhammad that caused a
storm of protest around the Muslim world (Allan Hall writes). Mohammed Geele,

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: TIM


                    Copyright 2011 Times Newspapers Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                              442 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                       BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           February 5, 2011 Saturday

Ethiopia foils terrorist attack coordinated by Eritrea

LENGTH: 266 words


Text of report in English by state-owned Ethiopian news agency ENA website

Addis Ababa, 5 February: An attempt coordinated by the Eritrean government to
obstruct the recent 16th ordinary session of African heads of state and
government was foiled.

Explosive called C-4 and accessories transported to Addis Ababa via Djibouti
were put under control. Alleged Oromo Liberation Front (OLF) instruments and
their collaborators were also arrested following court orders while undertaking
activities to commit the crime.

The explosive was intended to be used to obstruct the session. However, the
National Intelligence and Security Service managed to foil the attempt as it was
aware of the plot earlier.

The police have been investigating the cause of the alleged criminals put under
control in an area locally called Semien Mazegaja in the capital.

The explosive is similar to the one exploded in Kampala, Uganda.

Recently explosive was put under control in Afar and Amhara States while being
transported to Ethiopia from Eritrea following tips from the public.

The Joint Anti-terror Taskforce of the National Intelligence and Security
Service and the Federal Police lauded cooperation of the public to abort the
destructive acts of the Eritrean government.

The taskforce recalled that similar terrorist acts coordinated by the Eritrean
government were attempted to obstruct AU sessions held earlier in the country.

The taskforce called on the public to continue cooperation and said that
detailed information on the attempt will be made official soon, it said.

Source: ENA website, Addis Ababa, in English 5 Feb 11

                              Liverpool Daily Echo

                           February 5, 2011 Saturday
                                  1ST Edition

HAMMER GANG CAGED;
Robbers sentenced to a total of 40 years for terror attacks

BYLINE: BEN ROSSINGTON

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1250 words


THEY smashed their way into houses, balaclavas and masks covering their faces,
screaming demands for car keys or jewellery while threatening their terrified
victims with knives, swords, sledgehammers, machetes, chisels and a shotgun.

Today, the reign of terror for one of Merseyside's most violent and prolific
gang of 'burst in' burglars was over.

The five members of the crew - Craig Murphy, Gary Moffatt, Jason Nee, Anthony
Akins and Jamie Williams - are starting a combined 40 years behind bars after
being sentenced at Liverpool Crown Court.

In just two months they carried out 27 burglaries, going after cars they liked
the look of - stealing a high-powered Vauxhall, a top-of-the range VW Golf, an
exclusive Audi, a couple of 4x4s, a BMW and a pacy Honda - and subjecting the
owners of the cars to terrifying ordeals.

Murphy, 19, originally from Stockbridge Village; Moffatt, 22, of The Spinney,
also Stockbridge Village; Akins, 19, of Aylton Road, Huyton; Nee, 21, of
Lynstead Road, Dovecot; and Williams, 18, of Woodlands Road, Huyton, all pleaded
guilty to conspiring to commit burglary and aggravated burglary.

A sixth defendant, Jason Nee's brother Jamie, 23, also from Dovecot, was jailed
for a year after admitting perverting the course of justice.

ECHO He reported his Mazda 3 stolen when in reality his brother had been using
it to carry out the burglaries. mobile For news/sport/text ECHO to In their
spree, the gang:. Stabbed victims who didn't respond quickly enough to demands
for car keys, jewellery or cash. Threatened to cut the hand off a pensioner if
his wife didn't show them where the safe was. Told the same couple they were
"considerate" burglars because they hadn't broken in the night before, as they
had planned, because the couple had young family round. Threatened a boy
watching TV with a shotgun before firing it into the stairs in the house.
Marched a mum around her home by her hair in front of her distraught children.
Smashed one victim in the face with a clawhammer after he bravely tried to keep
them out of his house and away fromhis wife and four-year-old son. Told a couple
their car was being stolen to order and they would "get it back on the
insurance". Left an eight-month-old baby with cuts to his head after smashing
their way through a patio window, sending glass flying everywhere.

Their victims had no idea of the horror they were about to face.

Most had not been home from work long when they became the next on the gang's
hit-list.

They were relaxing with their families moments before their world was turned
upside down.

Yesterday the court was packed out with victims wanting to see the gang face
justice.

There was no pattern to their spree. They simply drove around and picked their
victims based on the car parked on the drive or the house they lived in.

They struck in West Derby, Woolton, Childwall, Croxteth, Gateacre, Bootle,
Huyton, Prescot, Maghull, St Helens, Whiston, Lancashire and North Wales,
stealing cars from one address and using them in the robbery of the next.

The crimes police can link the gang to began in December 2009. On February 5,
2010, Moffatt, Akins, Williams and Nee were caught and the spate stopped over
night.

They were arrested hiding in a cupboard in the ladies' toilet in the Granada
Bingo Hall, better known as Bugsy's, in Dovecot. On the floor around them was
the 'burglar's uniform' of balaclavas and gloves they had tried to shed.

The chase that led to their arrest began when the police helicopter spotted a
stolen VW Golf R32. What followed was a high-speed pursuit through the city
until the gang made their bid to escape.

In the back of the Golf were sledgehammers and other items the gang used in
their raids.

DCI Allan James headed up the specialist team - codenamed Operation Oxford -
that was tasked with catching the gang when it became clear police were dealing
with one crew.

life 67800 He said: "At first we thought we had a force-wide problem but we soon
realised it was bigger than that and this team were targeting addresses outside
of Merseyside too.

"Oxford was made up of a number of highly experienced detectives, all with their
own specialisms and expertise.

"We were put together on February 1 and following the arrest of Moffatt and
others on February 5, this kind of break-in stopped.

"We were confident we had identified the main players but then we had to set
about proving it.

"It was only after a lot of hard work putting the pieces together that in July
we were confident we had the evidence to prove a conspiracy and we made the
final arrests."

During the early morning strike, Anthony Akins was Tasered in the testicles as
he tried to take on the police storming his home.

DCI James said: "Evidence gathering continued after that date to make the case
as strong as possible and I think that shows in the fact they all pleaded
guilty.

"They've never said anything to us in interview. Not a word. So we've had to
prove it all and we've obviously done that.

"To be confronted and threatened by someone in your own home is an extremely
alarming and distressing experience that the victims will have to live with for
the rest of their lives.

"I hope that these sentences will, in some way, bring closure and some comfort
to the victims and their families whose lives these men have blighted."

By the time the spree was stopped by police, the gang had graduated to raiding
off-licences, stealing the cash machine from one and trying to steal another
from a second on consecutive nights.

Sentencing the gang - most of whom come from decent families, the court heard -
Judge John Roberts said: "This was a wide ranging conspiracy where young men
were out of control, on the rampage and came to terrorise their victims at home.

"It was done in the belief they could do what they want with impunity.

"These burglaries were truly shocking."

. To see footage of the chase from the police helicopter, log on to
www.liverpoolecho.co.uk VICTIMS LEFT WITH NIGHTMARES IN THEIR harrowing victim
impact statements put before Judge John Roberts, those who faced the gang
raiding their homes spelt out the lasting impact of their ordeals.

They all spoke about having their homes "violated" and feelings of anger,
anxiety, sadness and fear.

Many still sleep with the light on at night and of those who haven't sold up
already, many are looking to move to somewhere new.

And some were questioning the point of working hard to live in comfort when
their property can be taken by thugs in an instant.

One family's father said: "At the time, the feelings of anger became overwhelmed
by my feelings of inadequacy that I was unable to protect my family from harm in
their own home.

"I honestly believed that as time passed, the feeling of insecurity in my own
home would also pass but I continue to feel disturbed at the slightest noise
outside the house in the evening and it seems ridiculous that a simple task like
taking rubbish out to the bins brings with it such feelings of apprehension."

One women, confronted in a separate incident, said: "The incident has turned my
whole world upside down and my life will never be the same again. This year has
been a complete blur to me and I have been left in a complete state of shock.

"I do not want to be left alone in my own home.

"There is not a day goes by that I do not think about what has happened to me. I
don't sleep well at night and wake at the smallest noise... and when I do sleep
I have nightmares."

LOAD-DATE: February 5, 2011

                       BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            February 6, 2011 Sunday

Ugandan police warn of possible terror attacks on Valentine's Day

LENGTH: 316 words


Text of report by Andrew Bagala entitled "Police warn on Valentine Day bomb
threat" published by leading privately-owned Ugandan newspaper The Daily Monitor
website on 6 February; subheadings as published

That romantic gift or bouquet of red flowers that has been delivered to your
home or office on Valentine's Day may not be from a lover but a terrorist who
wants you and your family dead, the Inspector General of Police, Maj-Gen Kale
Kayihura, has cautioned.

The police are taking nothing for granted and are sending out warnings that
terrorists could use Valentine's Day on February 14, just three days to the
presidential elections, to disorganize the country.

While issuing a new terror alert yesterday at the media centre in Kampala,
Maj-Gen Kayihura appealed to the public to exercise popular vigilance and
neighbourhood watch if we are to avert terror attacks. "Look out for suspicious
or abandoned items or packages such as bags, cars, boxes, unexpected gifts,
flowers, flasks mails and parcels," he said.

Al Shabaab suspected

Maj-Gen Kayihura said they suspect al-Shabaab and al-Qa'idah cells in
collaboration with Allied Democratic Forces to be behind planned attacks.

Al-Shabaab terrorists claimed responsibility for the twin bombings in Kampala
which killed at least 76 people and injured dozens of others at Kyadondo Rugby
Club and Ethiopia Village Restaurant on July 11, 2010.

Safety measures

Over 34 bomb suspects, including Ugandans and Kenyans, were arrested and charged
with murder and terrorism.

Security agencies have also been ordered to reinstate safety measures in
congested places like taxi parks, markets, embassies, hotels and other strategic
areas within the city.

The public is urged to reach police on the following numbers:

0414256366, 0414250611, 0414256367, 0414254561, 0414254262 to report suspicious
item or people.

Source: Daily Monitor website, Kampala, in English 6 Feb 11

                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political

                            February 8, 2011 Tuesday

Russian FSB head submits list of officials to be punished over terror attack

LENGTH: 247 words


Implementing Russian President Dmitriy Medvedev's instructions, Director of the
Federal Security Service (FSB) Aleksandr Bortnikov has submitted to the head of
state a list of officials that are to bear responsibility for the terrorist
attack at Domodedovo airport, the Kremlin has said, as quoted by Russian news
agency Interfax.

"Yes, the instruction has been fulfilled and the list of officials has been
submitted to the president," presidential spokeswoman Natalya Timakova has said.

On 27 January Medvedev told the Russian Interior Ministry and FSB to offer
proposals before 5 February on the responsibility of officials with these
bodies, who are responsible for combating terrorism and providing security on
transport.

Russian Interior Minister Rashid Nurgaliyev had already dismissed acting head of
the LUVD (leadership of the transport police directorate) Police Col Aleksandr
Trushanin, acting first deputy head of the LUVD Aleksandr Budtsov and acting
deputy head of the LUVD Aleksandr Degterev.

In an earlier report Interfax quoted a source in the Russian Interior Ministry
who said that no more dismissals were planned in the ministry and all personnel
decisions in relation to the Domodedovo terrorist attack had already been taken.

"The Russian Foreign Ministry has taken most tough decisions in relation to the
terrorist attack committed at Domodedovo on 24 January," the source told the
agency.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0707, 0657 gmt 8 Feb 11

                                Kentish Gazette

                               February 10, 2011

Gran tells of terror as gang attacked James in her home

LENGTH: 437 words


by Annette Wilson

kentishgazette@thekmgroup.co.uk

A WOMAN told a jury how she froze with shock when three men armed with knives
and a baseball bat burst through her front door and attacked her grandson.

Elsie Keeling said she was standing holding her little granddaughter's hand when
her grandson James Middleton came in, pushed the door shut and told her to get
out of the way.

Moments later the door slammed open and she watched as her grandson tried to
shield himself with his arms as he was attacked with a knife.

She was giving evidence in the trial of five Whitstable men, three of whom deny
attempting to murder Mr Middleton last May.  The prosecution say Mr Middleton,
20, was repeatedly stabbed by Jim Chambers and Lee Dryburgh and hit with a
baseball bat by Alfie Rossiter.

Two others were allegedly outside attacking a car which contained Mr Middleton's
girlfriend and another woman who had allegedly been sexually assaulted by
Chambers earlier that day.

Mrs Keeling said Mr Middleton had arrived at her home at 35 Belmont Road,
Whitstable, and was about to go out again when he came back and shouted at her
to get out of the way.

"The front door slammed open. I was at the bottom of the stairs, and a person
came in followed by two more. James went down on the floor and was protecting
himself," said Mrs Keeling.

As he tried to shield himself she saw a knife go down past his head. The third
man came in with a bat but she did not see what he did with it.

"I was rooted to the spot holding my granddaughter's hand and James was beside
me. I froze with shock. Then I told her to run and we ran into my daughter's
house next door," she said.

The two houses were joined by a conservatory and as she went to go back to her
house, James came through covered in blood and said "get back Grandma".

"He pushed me back into next door and locked the door. He said they were chasing
him."

She said her daughter took over once he was there and Mrs Keeling wanted to go
back to fetch another child who was still in her home.

"I don't know how I was feeling. I was shocked. I just wanted to get back to my
grandson."

She did not see where the three men were and did not see anything outside
relating to the car.

"When I went back, James was on the stairs with my other daughter looking after
him. He was bleeding quite badly and I just got hold of him and he said 'I don't
feel too good Grandma'. I told him he was going to be all right."

She said in her home, there was blood spattered everywhere and marks on the wall
which she presumed were caused by the bat. An internal door was broken and her
front door also damaged.

The trial continues

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            February 11, 2011 Friday

Pakistan report discusses reasons behind rising terror attacks in northwest

LENGTH: 738 words


Text of report by Ismail Khan headlined "Mardan attack highlights flaws in
security strategy" published by Pakistan newspaper Dawn website on 11 February

Peshawar: The suicide bombing at Punjab Regiment Centre (PRC) in Mardan on
Thursday [10 February] was the deadliest on a security installation since
Pakistan Army launched an operation against militants in the Mehsud heartland of
South Waziristan in late 2009.

This was the third attack in the region on major installations of the Punjab
Regiment. The first attack, more devastating than the one on Thursday, took
place in the regiment's base in Dargai and claimed the lives of 40-odd recruits
in late 2006.

The second attack was more brazen as three armed militants, two of them wearing
suicide vests, tried to penetrate deep into the PRC in Mardan in July last year.
All three assailants were gunned down.

That a teenaged boy, wearing the school uniform of the army school situated on
the premises of the PRC, was used to carry out the suicide attack on Thursday
hardly came as a surprise. The militants have used teenagers as bombers in the
past.

Indeed, there have been at least two incidents involving women bombers,
including the one who killed 45 non-combatants queuing up for rations at a World
Food Programme outlet on Dec 25.

However, the way militants continue to plan and execute attacks, despite claims
by government and security forces that the back of militancy had been broken,
has come as a surprise.

The PRC bombing has all the footprints of the Swat Taleban, who are now
reportedly safely ensconced in the border region of Bajaur and Mohmand, along
the border with Afghanistan.

The area now is the target of a military/paramilitary operation and some
security officials believe that the recent surge in attacks is the result of the
push to flush out militants from their last remaining sanctuary in the region.

This may well be true in the context of the recent spate of attacks in Peshawar
and Charsadda, the two districts adjoining the Mohmand tribal region.

But the attacks are more sporadic and more widespread. Since mid-January, the
militants have carried out numerous attacks, bombings, suicide bombings and
target killings of policemen, military and paramilitary personnel and
non-combatants in the districts of Kohat, Hangu, Karak, Bannu, Dera Ismail Khan
and several parts of the tribal areas.

Security officials discern a tactical shift in the militants' strategy as
terrorists increasingly target policemen in the settled districts by way of
bombings and assassinations.

Several factors may be behind the surge in these attacks following a longish
pause that brought a semblance of normality in the once volatile region.
Complacency may be a reason, apparently emanating from the feel-good environment
and the belief within the security establishment that the tough battle had been
won.

However, the picture may not be rosy at all. There is a stalemate in Bara
sub-district in Khyber tribal region for close to two years now, with no durable
solution in sight. Darra Adamkhel and the Frontier Regions of Peshawar and
Kohat, too, are not fully under control.

Lack of fighting personnel and other resources is being cited as one of the
major reasons for the security forces' inability to finish their work in the
areas around Peshawar and some southern districts of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.

This may be true. But while it was clear that militants would sneak into the
urban areas after being driven out of their tribal sanctuaries, no steps seem to
have been taken to expand the human intelligence network to catch those trying
to find new nests to roost.

The most important piece missing from the military's Counter-Insurgency (COIN)
strategy -- which is described as Clear (the area of militants), Hold (the
area), and Transfer (it) -- seems to be the last factor mentioned (transfer the
area).

Had the military been able to transfer to the civilian administration an area
after clearing it of militants, it would be in a position to carry on the fight
in some other area.

The existing strategy may be working in Swat but not so much in other areas.
Lack of vision and that of clear benchmarks has contributed to the prevailing
situation.

So, unless those formulating the strategy sit up and begin to gather the
necessary tools to make it work, what has been won and regained after tremendous
sacrifices may be lost.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 11 Feb 11

LOAD-DATE: February 11, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                              All Rights Reserved

                              Lancashire Telegraph

                            February 13, 2011 Sunday

'Doomsday' terror attack simulation in Lancashire

BYLINE: Chris Gee

SECTION: EAST LANCASHIRE NEWS (EASTLANCASHIRE)

LENGTH: 322 words


A TERROR attack on an aeroplane was the "doomsday scenario" created in
Lancashire this weekend in one of the biggest emergency simulations ever staged
in the region.

More than 150 fire officers and dozens of personnel from other emergency
services were involved in the 15-hour operation which also involved the scenario
that nuclear radiation had been released.

To ensure realism, an 80ft aircraft fuselage had been embedded by crane into a
two storey industrial unit at the scene of the operation, Washington Hall Fire
Training Centre, near Chorley.

Fire crews from throughout East Lancashire were called to the scene, including a
specialist decontamination team from Burnley, one of only two in the county.

Around 40 "casualties", in gory makeup were employed to simulate victims of the
incident and played their part to the full as screams could be heard among the
staged fires and from within the aircraft.

Other fire services involved in the exercise, codenamed Operation Dakota, were
Greater Manchester, Merseyside, Northern Ireland, Isle of Man and Sellafield.

The Air Ambulance was also in attendance and another element of the day were two
"fatalities", including a crash-test dummy which had been wedged high up in a
tree.

One of the exercise directors on the day was Darryl Sturgess, who lives in
Darwen and is a member of the urban search and rescue team.

He said: "This a massive challenge for all the services involved and our aim is
for it to be as realistic as possible.

"All the teams involved had no prior knowledge that they would be doing this
today.

"The circumstances we developed are as close as it could get to a worst case
scenario and will help all the services train and prepare for major incidents."

The premise of the day was that terrorists attempted to hijack an aircraft
carrying dignitaries and radioactive materials into Warton aerodrome.

Following resistance from passengers the plane crash-landed in Chorley.

LOAD-DATE: July 16, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                  Sunday Mail

                           February 13, 2011, Sunday

BATTERED BY TARTAN TERRORIST;
BUSBY JAIL ATTACK RAP

BYLINE: NORMAN SILVESTER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 212 words


TARTAN terrorist Adam Busby has been given an extra four months in jail for a
violent attack on a prison guard.

He had admitted punching and injuring warden David Dunn in a segregation cell at
maximum-security Shotts Prison last September at an earlier court hearing.

Last week Busby, who is serving a six-year term for terrorist offences, appeared
amid high security at Hamilton SheriffCourt for sentencing.

SheriffThomas Millar told him he must serve the four months once he has finished
the six-year term.

It is the second time recently Busby has got extra jail time for attacks on
prison officers.

He was also convicted last November of attacking warders who opened his cell
door in the segregation unit at Addiewell jail in West Lothian. He cut an
officer's lip with a punch.

At Livingston SheriffCourt, Busby was found guilty of assault and given an extra
six months in jail. He was then moved to Shotts, where he carried out the new
assault.

Busby, whose dad Adam Snr founded the Scottish National Liberation Army, was
jailed for six years in June 2009 for a hoax bomb campaign targeted at
politicians.

He said he did it to highlight the ill health of his dad, who was jailed for
four years in Ireland last July for bomb hoaxes.

                                  Sunday Mail

                           February 13, 2011, Sunday

LEGEND LIZ HAS HEART ATTACK;
AILING TAYLOR, 78, IN TERROR HOSPITAL DASH

BYLINE: FIONA YOUNG

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 376 words


HOLLYWOOD icon Elizabeth Taylor has been rushed to hospital with congestive
heart failure.

The Oscar-winning actress was admitted to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los
Angeles within the past few days.

Her spokeswoman Sally Morrison said the 78-yearold - idolised as one of the
great screen beauties - was being treated for symptoms of the heart condition.

Taylor revealed in November 2004 that she was suffering from congestive heart
failure.

Her health has been deteriorating and she has been using a wheelchair for public
appearances in recent years.

Morrison said it is unknown how long the actress might be in the hospital.

She added that Taylor's family appreciated the support from fans but asked for
privacy to allow the medical team space to do their work.

Taylor had been scheduled to attend an amfAR benefit gala in New York last
Wednesday She was to receive an award alongside former president Bill Clinton
and designer Diane von Furstenberg, celebrating their dedication to Aids
research.

But she missed the event and Elton John accepted the honour on her behalf.

He passed on a message from her: "I am there in spirit and I join you in
saluting my fellow honourees and all these extraordinary leaders.

"I am inspired by their example, exhilarated by their vision, and encouraged by
their compassion and love. And I love them in return."

Taylor, who has appeared in more than 50 films, won Oscars for her performances
in Butterfield 8 (1960) and Who's Afraid Of Virginia Woolf? (1966).

But she has been just as famous for her marriages - eight of them, including two
to Richard Burton.

She has also had lifelong battles with substance abuse, her weight and physical
ailments.

She has endured more than 20 major operations and gone through countless
treatments.

The actress had nearfatal bouts with pneumonia in 1961 and 1990, and another
respiratory infection forced her to cancel all engagements for several weeks in
late 1992.

She had both hip joints replaced in 1994 and 1995.

Her 2004 diagnosis for congestive heart failure, compounded with spinal
fractures and the effects of scoliosis, left her nearly bedridden.

She has also battled ulcers, amoebic dysentery, bursitis, and had a benign brain
tumour removed in 1997.

SUNDAY EMAIL reporters@sundaymail.co.uk

LOAD-DATE: February 13, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Western Morning News (Plymouth, UK)

                           February 15, 2011 Tuesday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Dog walker tells of stab attack terror

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 387 words


The wife of a prominent businessman has told a court of her terror as she was
attacked by a man who repeatedly stabbed her in the back with a screwdriver.

Shirley Speare, wife of Plymouth carpets and beds retailer Larry Speare, was
giving evidence on the first day of the trial of Nicholas Killen.

He denies attempted murder and three other related offences.

The trial heard how Mrs Speare was brutally attacked with a screwdriver as she
walked her dog, Archie.

She kicked off her shoes and fled barefoot for her life before collapsing with
multiple stab wounds, a punctured and collapsed lung and a broken rib, the court
was told.

A neighbour, Michael Cosby, who came to her aid was also assaulted, suffering a
broken nose.

Mrs Speare said she initially thought her attacker was joking, as he began
chasing her dog and roaring, while making stabbing motions while holding a
screwdriver.

"But then he stood and stared at me and I realised I had to get away from him,"
she told the court. "I was terrified."

"I had just got past him when he started to stab me in the back.

"I could feel the instrument and the warmth of the blood.

"He stabbed me lots of times in my back and three or four times in my neck and
hair."

Prosecutor Nick Lewin told the jury the peace and quiet of the village of
Yealmpton near Plymouth was shattered on September 28, 2009, by "an unexpected
uproar and an apparently motiveless attack". He said the Speares had lived in
the village for 20 years and were due to fly to Portugal on holiday that day.

Mrs Speare decided to take Archie, their collie-Jack Russell cross, for a final
walk about 11.15am while her husband had a bath and she set off on their usual
route along the Erme Trail.

After about 20 minutes, she was suddenly confronted by a man the prosecution say
was Killen, said Mr Lewin.

Mr Lewin said Killen had a rolled-up cigarette in his hand which he discarded.
Police later found it with his DNA on it.

Killen, aged 35 and of Woodland Drive, Brixton, denies four offences: attempting
to murder Mrs Speare, an alternative count of assaulting Mrs Speare causing her
grievous bodily harm, possessing an offensive weapon in a public place and
assaulting Mr Cosby, causing actual bodily harm, all on the same date.

The trial continues.

'He stood and stared at me and I realised I had to get away' Shirley Speare

                       Evening Chronicle (Newcastle, UK)

                          February 16, 2011 Wednesday

I Didn't Plan A Terror Attack

BYLINE: Tom Mullen

SECTION: A; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 330 words


A TYNESIDE terror suspect accused of conspiring to blow up a plane said he
believed he was "living in sin" by taking his family to Britain.

But devout Muslim Rajib Karim told a court he "never" planned a terror attack
while working as a computer expert for British Airways in Newcastle.

The 31-year-old, from Gosforth, said he sent messages to his brother in code
because of fears over torture in Bangladesh, where he has relatives.

The prosecution alleges he was communicating with a terror cell in secret e-mail
exchanges and sharing details of his BA contacts from his home.

Giving evidence at Woolwich Crown Court in London, Karim said he sent encrypted
messages to his younger brother because of concerns for relatives' safety, and
helped to make a video about an organisation called Jamaat-Ul Mujahideen
Bangladesh because they were being "misrepresented".

James Wood QC, defending, asked him: "Did you ever intend to commit an act of
terrorism in the UK?" Karim replied: "Never."

He went on to say he believed he would be "living in sin" by moving to Britain.

"That's why I asked my wife to settle in Bangladesh," he said.

He was forced to move here with his wife and child in 2006 amid fears his
toddler son had bowel cancer.

Karim is accused of plotting to blow up a plane, sharing information of use to
hate groups such as al Qaeda, offering to help financial or disruptive attacks
on BA and gaining a UK job to "exploit terrorist purposes", which he denies.

He joined BA in September 2007 on its graduate training scheme.

The defendant told how he had become a devout Muslim in the years before,
leading him to "drift away" from some of his friends who were "drinking and
swearing".

He attended two mosques   Grange Park Mosque and University of Newcastle Mosque
and was not known to hold extreme views, the court heard.

Karim has already pleaded guilty to three charges of being involved in the
production of a terrorist group's video, fundraising and volunteering for terror
abroad.

GANG FEAR FOR FAMILY;
Dad tells of terror after attacks

BYLINE: Emma Smith

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1,2

LENGTH: 507 words


A DAD has spoken of his fears for his family's safety after a series of
vandalism attacks by a gang who are terrorising his street.

Thugs have repeatedly attacked cars and threatened residents and the worried dad
claims they even forced a family to move after an armed youth ordered them to
leave the area.

The 44-year-old moved to Clarkston three years ago as he thought it would be a
safe place to raise his daughter.

But he has since had to make numerous calls to the policeabout consistent
vandalism to his car in Monteith Drive.

Recently his car was stolen after thugs took keys from his home. The burned-out
vehicle was later found by police just 500 yards from his house.

A few days later the gang struck again - scratching the driver's side of the
hire car he was using as a replacement.

And within a week the thugs covered the car in scratches - causing at least
£1000 worth of damage.

The dad, who does not wish to be named because he's terrified of further
repercussions, has also been verbally threatened and had bottles thrown at him
in his own garden. He added: "I'm upset and angry - mostly due to the distress
this hadcausedtomypartnerandmyfive-yearold daughter - given what I knew about
previous incidents in the street.

"The police were called and at least this time they took my situation more
seriously. However, without evidence I was told they could do little.

"I'm out of pocket for more than £900 in insurance excess payments. I can barely
afford a new car and even if I could, I cannot park it outside my own home.

"Due to this extra cost I can barely feed my family or pay my bills this month."

Other residents on the street have also been targeted by the vandals.

Headded:"I'mawarethistypeofcrime happens from time to time but this is a
persistent ongoing problem that brings anxiety and misery to ordinary
hardworking families in the area.

"I'm sure many Glasgow residents would assume Clarkston is an affluent
middle-class area with low crime. I can assure you this is far removed from the
TURN TO PAGE 2

FROM PAGE 1 reality. I was brought up in Ruchazie, Tollcross and Castlemilk and
never experienced anything quite as bad."

The dad claims police were called to the street in August after 10 neighbours
had their cars vandalised.

He also alleges that a family ended up selling their house after a youth came to
their door with a knife and ordered them to leave the area.

The dad added: "My poor neighbours suffered months of intimidation, abuse and
verbal threats and vandalism."

East Renfrewshire Councillor Ralph Robertson said: "There is a group of youths
who seem to be causing havoc in the area. " Strathclyde Police said they had
received around 12 youth related calls in the past year about Monteith Drive.

However they said no report was made about a family being forced to move after
receivng threats from an armed youth .

A spokesman said: "We are constantly working to reduce crime and disorder. We
take this and all matters very seriously and will contact the gentleman to
address any concerns."

                             Paisley Daily Express

                           February 17, 2011 Thursday
                                 First Edition

MUM-TO-BE JAILED FOR A YEAR AFTER MUGGING TERROR;
Attacker could give birth behind bars

BYLINE: JOHN LEES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 364 words


A PREGNANT woman and her boyfriend have each been jailed for a year after they
threatened to stab an innocent stranger and then mugged her.

Paisley couple Cheryl Haggerty, 29, and Michael Corcoran, 25, pounced on their
victim as she was walking home at night.

Haggerty - who is now expecting a baby that will be born in prison - approached
Donna McFarlane and a friend in Well Street, Paisley, just before 10pm on
October 12, last year, and asked them: "Do you know me?" In the moments that
followed, both Haggerty and Corcoran walked behind their targets.

Haggerty then grabbed Ms McFarlane, spun her around and got hold of the shoulder
strap of her bag.

At this stage, Corcoran chillingly asked their victim: "Do you want stabbed with
a screwdriver?" and Haggerty added: "Gie's that."

Haggerty then snatched the handbag and both accused ran off towards nearby
Underwood Lane.

Paisley Sheriff Court heard that two police officers just happened to pass the
two accused and thought they were arguing, so turned back to talk to them.

Corcoran, who was drunk, was spoken to by the cops and was arrested, while
Haggerty was traced later.

In court, Corcoran, of Ferguslie Park Avenue, and Haggerty, of Sutherland
Street, admitted robbing Ms McFarlane after placing her in a state of fear and
alarm.

It was stated that the threats they issued had convinced their victim to let go
of her bag.

Defence agents for Corcoran and Haggerty stressed that, although threats were
issued, the couple had not been in possession of a weapon and Ms McFarlane had
not been injured.

The court was told that Corcoran had alcohol abuse problems which lay behind all
of his offending and that Haggerty, who was now three months' pregnant, had been
taking drugs at the time of the offence but was now clean.

It was stated they both accepted that what they had done was "inexcusable".

After studying reports and considering submissions, Sheriff David Pender said:
"The public have to be able to go about their business without the fear of
something like this happening to them.

"Although no weapon was used, the threats implied were sufficient to persuade
the complainer to part with her handbag."

Afghan paper says terror attacks cannot stop peace efforts

LENGTH: 286 words


Text of an editorial in Dari entitled: "Terrorist attacks cannot prevent
ensuring security in the country", published by state-owned Afghan newspaper
Anis on 19 February

We witnessed some terrorist attacks in different parts of the country last week.
The suicide attacks which took place in the west of Khost Province and outside a
market in Kabul and also the attack by armed men on a hotel in Kandahar city
have caused great concern. Many of our innocent people were killed in the recent
attacks.

The attacks come at a time when the peace process is stimulated in our country
and some Afghan provinces are freed from armed fighters. Moreover, dozens of
opponents of the government have welcomed a [peace] offer from the Afghan High
Peace Council and have been disarmed.

Undoubtedly, some insurgents cannot tolerate recent developments in the peace
process. They are trying to disrupt the process and spark war. However, they are
not aware that Afghans are faithful to their responsibility of ensuring peace in
Afghanistan. The answer of the Afghan people to these criminals is (We do not
lose) [as published]. The Afghan people have taken new steps and nothing can
prevent them. Therefore, those who still think about hatching plots against the
Afghan nation must understand this reality and stop killing our innocent people.

Afghan President Hamed Karzai has strongly condemned the recent terrorist
attacks in the country, saying the terrorists only cause civilian casualties
through their attacks. The continuation of such attacks proves that the
terrorists are the enemies of civilians and innocent people. In addition, they
want our people to always suffer misery and pain.

Source: Anis, Kabul, in Dari 19 Feb 11, p 1

Afghan paper says clergy should not keep mum about terrorist attacks

LENGTH: 433 words


Text of report headlined "Ministry of Islamic affairs and esteemed scholars
should not keep silent" by private Afghan newspaper Arman-e Melli on 20
February:

Armed opponents of the Afghan government launched attacks on a Kabul Bank branch
in Jalalabad city [the capital of eastern Nangarhar Province] yesterday, as
result of which large numbers of civilians were either killed or wounded. In the
past, the Taleban had organized such attacks on shopping malls in Kabul city and
establishments in [southern] Kandahar, Helmand and [eastern] Khost provinces, as
result of which large numbers of women and children were killed.

These unsavoury and horrific incidents show that armed groups opposing the
government are determined to attack public establishments in order to kill
civilians and innocent people as well. This crime has been committed at a time
when members of the Afghan High Peace Council [AHPC] are speaking about holding
peace talks with the armed group opposing the government and urging the
government and international forces to ensure the security of those Taleban
leaders who will reportedly arrive in the country to hold peace talks.

The Afghan people do not know on what Shari'ah instructions armed groups
opposing the government, especially the Taleban, shed blood of civilians and
innocent people or how they can explain un-Islamic acts are based on.

Afghan religious scholars have an obligation not to remain silent about crimes
which are committed by those people who do not fear God and they also have an
obligation to tell the truth. Taking this issue into consideration, the Afghan
Hajj and Islamic Affairs Ministry has always kept silence in such incidents and
has not yet taken any effective action in this regard. It is worth pointing out
that the ministry can discuss the issue with imams and mosque preachers. It
should advise them to denounce such barbaric acts because of respected Muslims
and the religion.

As a result, Afghans will not notice Islam in the faces of the brutal criminals
[the Taleban and terrorists] and should be accurately informed about the Islamic
instructions.

If the Hajj and Islamic Ministry knows its main responsibilities, terrorists
will not be able to have influence in mosques. If the ministry makes
considerable efforts to launch a programme for those suicide bombers who do not
have sufficient information about the Islamic instructions, it might be possible
that most of them will regret to carry out suicide attacks or kill civilians in
the country. But unfortunately...[ellipsis as published]

Source: Arman-e Melli, Kabul, in Dari 20 Feb 11

IRA THREATENS ROYAL WEDDING TERROR ATTACK;
Security fears as MP warns dissidents plan spectacular EXCLUSIVE Security fears
over wedding

BYLINE: Camilla Tominey

SECTION: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1,3

LENGTH: 385 words


THE Royal Wedding is at the centre of a terror threat amid fears dissident Irish
republicans plan to target Prince William, a senior MP warned last night.

Police have been told of growing concerns about the event on April 29 as William
marries Kate Middleton.

There are also fears about Westminster Abbey being targeted by anti-Government
anarchists, causing a major security nightmare around the Royals and their long
list of VIP guests.

Patrick Mercer, Conservative MP and ex-chairman of the Commons committee sc* on
anti-terrorism, said police and Army intelligence officers are worried about at
least three splinter groups, raising concerns of a repeat of the 1979 bombing
that killed Lord Louis Mountbatten.

The Queen's visit to Ireland could also be a target. Mr Mercer, a former Army
officer who has completed nine tours of Northern Ireland, said: "The timing of

Royal Wedding seems to me to be curiously close to Easter when Republicans will
be looking for an excuse to demonstrate.

"We should be under no illusions that, while the Queen's visit to Dublin is a
good thing, it also will attract Republican activity."

Last August, Mr Mercer warned that terrorists were planning to target the
Conservative Party Conference. On October 5, the day before David Cameron's
keynote speech to the conference in Birmingham, a car bomb went off outside the
Ulster Bank in Londonderry. The Real IRA claimed responsibility for the
explosion.

Last September, the Home Office raised the threat level from Irish-related
terrorism from moderate to substantial in the UK, a month after a car containing
200lb of explosives went off outside a Londonderry police station.

Improved relations between Westminster and Dublin have only recently made it
possible for Buckingham Palace to even entertain the idea of a visit to Ireland
by the Queen. She will become the first British monarch to visit the country
since her grandfather George V went in 1911 before the Republic had secured
independence.

Dai Davies, a former head of Royalty Protection, said the threat from
Irish-related terrorism is "real", but said police are more concerned about
anti-establishment groups.

"The IRA and its many factions continue to pose a real threat, but the bigger
threat to the Royal wedding is from anti-establishment protestors which is
escalating."

Afghan paper urges clerics not to remain "silent" on terror attacks

LENGTH: 318 words


Text of editorial headlined "Ministry of Islamic affairs and esteemed scholars
should not keep silent!" published by Afghan newspaper Arman-e Melli on 20
February

The government's armed opposition attacked Kabul Bank branch in Jalalabad City
yesterday. The attack killed and injured many innocent people. The Taleban also
attacked a supermarket in Kabul and some buildings in Kandahar, Khost and
Helmand provinces which have killed many women and children recently.

The recent events indicate that members of the armed opposition are attacking
public places intentionally to kill civilians. The crimes are taking place at a
time when members of Afghanistan's High Peace Council are working on opening
negotiations with the armed opposition. They urge the Afghan government and
international forces to ensure security of the Taleban leaders who may come to
Afghanistan. The Afghan people do not know with what type of Islamic
justification and permission the opposition, particularly the Taleban, justify
their non-Islamic acts?

We believe that Afghan religious scholars have the responsibility not to be
silent against crimes committed by those who are using the name of Islam. The
scholars must not avoid telling the truth. Moreover, the Ministry of Hajj and
Islamic Affairs has always remained silent when such events occur. However, the
ministry is able to at least address religious scholars in mosques to condemn
subversive and non-Islamic activities in the country.

Terrorists would not be able to enter the mosques if the Ministry of Islamic
Affairs fulfils its responsibility. Furthermore, if the ministry works
comprehensively, a number of Taleban fighters - who do not have the correct
understanding of Islam and religious laws - will be guided. Some of them may not
commit suicide attacks and will not kill innocent civilians.

But unfortunately. [As published]

                          February 24, 2011, Thursday

JEWEL GANG ROB OAP IN KNIFE TERROR RAID;
ATTACKER MAY HAVE BEEN JUST 14, POLICE SAY

BYLINE: Paul Drury

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 297 words


ROBBERS threatened an elderly couple at knifepoint and tied them up in a violent
jewellery robbery.

Two raiders, one of whom may have been as young as 14, smashed their way into
Jahan Ara Mobarak's home after tricking her into opening her door.

They tied 71-year-old Jahan up with telephone cable and demanded to know where
her valuables and safe were.

Twenty minutes into her ordeal, her businessman husband Riaz, 74, returned to
their pounds 750,000 detached villa and was also attacked and tied up.

Ransom The robbers, who were in the house for 90 minutes, finally escaped with
jewellery and valuables, leaving the couple tied up in separate rooms.

And they callously told terrified Jahan that they were taking her husband away
for ransom.

Yesterday, Jahan, from Giffnock, near Glasgow, relived her Tuesday lunchtime
ordeal.

She said: "He pushed me down and asked me where the safe was. He was shouting
that he knew I had jewellery and money.

"We were preparing to go to a wedding in Dundee, so I had laid out my diamonds
on the bed. He said he was going to cut off my finger and shoot my husband
unless we said where the safe was."

Cash-and-carry director Riaz said: "You see these things on the telly but you
never think they could happen to you."

The thieves took a Rolex watch, an expensive diamond solitaire ring, three other
rings, a gold pendant, some money and a Nokia mobile phone. The couple's car
keys were also taken.

Detective Inspector Craig Willison appealed for witnesses and said: "This was a
terrifying experience for the couple, who are extremely shocked and distressed."

The first suspect was white, 35-40 years, 6ft 3in-6ft 4in and of stocky build.
He was wearing dark clothing and working boots.

The second suspect is described as white, 14-17, 5ft 5in and of medium build.

                            Daily Post (North Wales)

                           February 24, 2011 Thursday
                              North Wales Edition

Pensioner's terror at arsonists' attack

BYLINE: KATE FORRESTER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 244 words


A PENSIONER says she has been left shaken and unable to sleep after arsonists
set light to her shed in the middle of the night.

Marion Williams, 74, of Wood Lane, Pen-y-Maes, Holywell, was woken by noises at
about midnight on Saturday.

"I heard two muffled bangs and then a massive bang," she said.

"I ran downstairs and looked out of the front window, but I couldn't see
anything. When I turned and looked through the back I just saw all this light -
it was like an inferno."

She rang 999 and ran to her neighbours' house to wake them up in case the fire
spread.

"I ran down the road to my son Alan's house and was hammering on his door to get
him up," said Mrs Williams.

"I was in such a state."

The fire burnt the shed to the ground and melted Mrs Williams's oil tank, which
left her without heating.

She said: "I don't feel safe in my own home since this has happened. On Sunday I
couldn't stop shaking. I can't sleep at night now.

"It's just sheer vandalism, it's senseless. Someone could have been killed.

"The fire was so close to my house and the neighbours and if the wind had been
blowing in a different direction it could have been a lot worse."

North Flintshire Sergeant John Williams said police have launched a joint
investigation into the incident with the fire service.

He added: "We are appealing for anyone who witnessed anything or might have
information to contact us."

Anyone with information should call police on 0845 607 1002.

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political

                            February 25, 2011 Friday

Afghan paper condemns targeting of civilians in terror attacks

LENGTH: 391 words


Text of an editorial in Pashto entitled: "Attack against civilians, ugliest
aspect of terrorism", published by state-owned Afghan newspaper Hewad on 22
February

A suicide attacker targeted a crowd of civilian people yesterday in Imam Saheb
District of Konduz Province when the people were trying to get identity cards of
their proud country. He killed or wounded many civilians. Many families in Imam
Saheb District were saddened. President Hamed Karzai and his cabinet strongly
condemned the attack and ordered the relevant agencies to arrest the
perpetrators of the attack and prosecute them. Over the past few days, many
bloody attacks have taken place in different parts of the country. The suicide
attacks in Kandahar, Khost and Nangarhar Provinces killed or wounded many
innocent civilians.

These attacks have created many concerns. It seems that the armed opposition has
changed its tactics. If we review the recent attacks, we will see that all the
attacks came in places where the ordinary people gathered for their daily
activities. For instance, the attack in Imam Saheb District of Konduz Province
had no military targets. There were no foreign or Afghan military forces. There
were only some ordinary civilian people from the villages of the district who
had come to get identity cards.

Such attacks against civilian people are the ugliest aspect of terrorism. We are
surprised by the conscience of those who target civilians, attack them and kill
them. Killing civilian people is not acceptable whatever the reason, whatever
the goals and whatever it is for. The people have cursed the perpetrators of
these attacks while strongly condemning them.

It is obvious that such attacks cannot create any strategic changes in favour of
the armed opposition in the current military situation. Also, the armed
opposition does not have the capability to fight the Afghan national army and
police and the international forces face-to-face. It tries to show its physical
presence as well as create an atmosphere of fear among the people by conducting
such attacks.

The country's security officials should review the security system of the cities
and districts taking into consideration the new tactics of the armed opposition,
and should take serious measures to prevent and defuse such bloody attacks.

Source: Hewad, Kabul, in Pashto 22 Feb 11, p 1

LOAD-DATE: February 25, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            February 25, 2011 Friday

Iraqi minister says "terrorist attacks" planned against 25 Feb protests; roundup

LENGTH: 810 words


Iraqi government-controlled Al-Iraqiyah TV, in its 1300 and 1700 gmt newscasts
on 24 February, reports on a statement by Major General Qasim Ata, spokesman for
the Baghdad Operations Command, that the security forces confiscated 500 fake
licences to carry weapons; a statement by acting Security Minister Adnan
al-Asadi that there are "terrorist" plans against the 25 February protestors; a
speech by National Alliance leader Ibrahim al-Ja'fari on the 25 February
protests; a statement by Aaron Snipe, spokesman for the US Embassy in Baghdad,
that the US supports the democratic process in Iraq and supports Prime Minister
Nuri al-Maliki's speech; the Ministry of Oil's decision to postpone signing a
contract to develop Ukaz gas field in Al-Anbar; and other political
developments.

Political Developments

Within its 1300 gmt newscast, the channel reports the following:

-  "Major General Qasim Ata, spokesman for the Baghdad Operations Command [BOC],
has denied that the office of the commander in chief of the Armed Forces or BOC
has published any statements that offend any political or religious figure. Ata,
in a press statement, said that the security forces, based on intelligence
information, were able to confiscate 500 fake licenses that allow infiltrators
to carry weapons in tomorrow's protests."

-  "Acting Security Minister Adnan al-Asadi has revealed the presence of 40
intelligence documents that reveal plans to carry out terrorist attacks, kill,
burn, and stab the protestors on Friday [25 February]. Al-Asadi, in a press
statement, highlighted that the ministry received information which confirm that
terrorist groups plan to booby-trap some mentally-handicapped people and push
them between the protestors or to burn them to claim later that journalists
burnt themselves during the protests. He added that other information confirmed
the intention of some infiltrators to wear a military uniform in the protests
and stab or shoot protestors."

Within its 1700 gmt newscast, the channel reports the following:

At 1705 gmt, the channel interrupts its newscast to carry live an 11-minute
speech by National Alliance leader Ibrahim al-Ja'fari.

Al-Ja'fari says that the "protests, for us, are a legitimate expression endorsed
by divine religions, human values, various social ethics, and was enshrined in
and adopted by the new Iraqi Constitution." Al-Ja'fari speaks about Saddam
Husayn's repression of protests in Iraq and about the "dictators" in the Arab
world and how people managed to protest against such "life-long tyrants." He
adds: "We [Iraqis] were born from the womb of peaceful and civil protests."
Al-Ja'fari says the demands of the people are legitimate but he warns against
the return of the "Ba'th regime" and calls on Iraqis to fight this.

-  "Some are trying to sabotage and distort the image of Iraq - the country that
became a model for democracy in the Middle East, which some Arab and regional
regimes fear - by staging protests that vandals take advantage of. Notables and
tribesmen in the holy Karbala Governorate have underlined the illegitimacy of
those protests because they are not staged against a totalitarian or a
repressive regime, and underlined that the parliament is the best evidence of a
democratic state."

-  "Aaron Snipe, spokesman for the US Embassy in Baghdad, has affirmed the US
support for a democratic process in Iraq and for Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki's
speech. Snipe, in an exclusive statement to Al-Iraqiyah TV, said that Iraq is a
democratic country and that the Iraqi citizens have the right to protest in a
peaceful manner."

-  "Justice Minister Hasan al-Shammari has underlined ongoing preparations to
set up proper and safe prisons and detention places to receive the prisoners and
detainees from the US side, according to the agreement of the US forces'
withdrawal from Iraq."

-  "Judge Midhat al-Mahmud, chairman of the Supreme Judicial Council,
highlighted that all legal measures will be taken in case of any violation
against any of the detainees. He underlined in a press statement that all
detainees are presented before medical committees and a file is opened for them
in the judiciary."

-  "The Ministry of Oil has postponed signing a contract with the winning
bidders in the third round of licenses to develop the Ukaz gas field. The
ministry was supposed to sign the contract, in its headquarters in Baghdad, with
South Korean Kogas and Kazakhstan's Cogas and Monai Gas companies to develop the
[gas] field in the Al-Anbar Governorate at a price of $5.5 per square foot and
reach a production average of 40 million square feet of gas on a daily basis. It
is noted that the local government in Al-Anbar demanded building an electricity
power plant near the gas field, which the ministry says is not included in the
contract."

Source: Al-Iraqiyah TV, Baghdad, in Arabic 1300-1700 gmt 24 Feb 11

                         Coulsdon and Purley Advertiser

                               February 25, 2011

Shoppers' terror as robbers attack cashpoint guard

BYLINE: Joanna Till and Richard O'Toole joanna.till@essnmedia.co.uk

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 356 words


A Gang of robbers attacked a  security guard in front of terrified shoppers at
Tesco in broad  daylight.

The incident took place on Monday  as a security guard from G4S filled up the
cash machine outside the store, in Brighton Road, Purley, at about 1pm.

Witnesses described seeing robbers grappling with the guard as they tried to
steal the cash.

A woman, who saw what happened as she parked her car, said: "The G4S man was
trying to explain to them that all the money was locked away and he could not
get to it.

"I have never been so terrified. I didn't know what to do."

Another eyewitness, who was waiting to withdraw money, said: "It all happened so
fast and no one could quite believe it."

According to witnesses, the robbers grabbed a cash box before piling into a
silver Renault Clio and speeding away.

A high-speed chase involving police cars and a helicopter ensued.

A police spokesman said the Clio collided with another car on the A236
Southbridge Road, but no one was hurt. The suspects then swung into Surrey
Street market in the heart of Croydon.

Trader Russell Smith, 49,  described seeing the car "screeching" around the
corner before colliding with another vehicle.

"They started bailing halfway down (the road) and then there was a loud bang,"
he added. "At that point they did bail out and scattered."

Abdul Rehman, 17, said he was at his stall when he heard sirens.

"It seemed like there were police and ambulances coming inside the market," he
added.

"Then I saw the car, and we were shocked because cars are not allowed in the
market."

A cash box was recovered in Surrey Street but police have not confirmed whether
or not the suspects escaped with any money.

Two suspects were arrested after the incident.

On Tuesday, a 24-year-old man, of no fixed abode, was charged with robbery. He
appeared at Tower Bridge Magistrates' Court on Wednesday and did not enter a
plea. He was remanded in custody until his next appearance at the Old Bailey. A
date has yet to be set.

A 17-year-old boy was also arrested after the incident and released on police
bail, pending further inquiries.

It is believed a third suspect may still be at large.

                                   The Mirror

                            February 28, 2011 Monday
                                 Ulster Edition

WHY DID GUNMEN TRY TO SHOOT A BOY OF 3?;
MUM TELLS HOW FAMILY FLED IN TERROR DURING ATTACK

BYLINE: MAURICE FITZMAURICE

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 293 words


A MUM last night called on gunmen who opened fire on her and her three-year-old
son to say why they tried to kill them.

Teresa Duffy and her little boy had to run for their lives as two thugs shot at
their home on Saturday.

They were in the kitchen of the bungalow in Strabane at around 7.15pm when the
attack happened in the Co Tyrone town's Ballycolman area.

Teresa told the Daily Mirror: "They came at the house last Saturday and tried to
kick in the door so we had a bin up against the back gate.

"We heard the bin moving and looked out and could see the arms moving up.

I grabbed the child and started to run but the shots were fired before I made it
out into the hall.

"They came through the back door and went into the ceiling. I was about three
feet away from the door they came through. They could have killed me or my
child.

"I want to know why they have done this, why they shot at me and a
three-year-old boy. The wee fella's in shock, he was having nightmares all last
night. A child shouldn't have to go through something like this, it's awful."

Two men were seen running away from the house. A man aged 35 along with Teresa's
partner and her 22-yearold sister were also in the property and were unhurt.
SDLP councillor Eugene McMenamin it was a reckless attack.

He added: "There is absolutely no justification for this attack. It is a very
worrying incident. I cannot understand why anyone would fire live rounds into a
house with a young woman and child inside.

"Thank God we are not looking at a fatality especially when you have armed men
shoot at a home this could easily have been the case. The trauma that this woman
and child have gone through is horrendous and totally unacceptable.

"I would urge anyone with any information to give it to the police."

                              473 of 500 DOCUMENTS


                                The Western Mail

                             March 1, 2011 Tuesday
                                 First Edition

BA computer expert plotted terror attack

BYLINE: TOM MORGAN

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 492 words


A BRITISH AIRWAYS computer expert was yesterday convicted of plotting to launch
a 9/11-style terror attack from the UK.

Rajib Karim, 31, wanted to use his position at the airline to plant a bomb on a
plane as part of a "chilling" conspiracy with Anwar al-Awlaki, a notorious
radical preacher associated with Al-Qaeda.

Among numerous plots to bring the airline to its knees, Karim hoped he could
exploit airline strikes to become cabin crew and cause an explosion on a
US-bound flight.

In encrypted emails with his brother and terror contacts in Iraq, Bangladesh,
Yemen, Afghanistan and Pakistan, he also discussed how he could attack BA
computer servers and ground its entire fleet.

The father-of-one was found guilty atWoolwich Crown Court of four counts of
planning terrorism after a jury heard he was "committed to an extreme jihadist
and religious cause" and was "determined to seek martyrdom".

Scotland Yard described the case as the most sophisticated decryption task it
had ever undertaken.

Speaking afterwards, Home Secretary Theresa May said the "heinous plot shows why
we will never be complacent".

Colin Gibbs, a counter-terrorism lawyer for the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS),
described Karim's deep determination to plan an attack as "frightening".

"The most chilling element of this case is probably the fact that Karim tried to
enrol as cabin crew and anyone can imagine how horrific the consequences of this
could have been, had he succeeded," Mr Gibbs said.

Bearded Karim stood emotionless in the dock as the jury concluded he plotted to
blow up an aircraft, shared information of use to al-Awlaki, offered to help
financial or disruptive attacks onBAand gained aUKjob to exploit terrorist
purposes.

The Bangladeshi national, who moved with his wife and son to Newcastle in 2006,
had already admitted being involved in the production of a terrorist group's
video, fundraising and volunteering for terror abroad.

Karim, a privately-educated IT expert from a middle-class family in Dhaka, was
lured into becoming an avid supporter of the extremist organisation Jammat-ul
Mujahideen Bangladesh (JMB) by his younger brother Tehzeeb.

But their plan to live in an Islamic state was put on hold when Karim moved to
England in December 2006.

Karim, described as "mild-mannered, well-educated and respectful", hid his
hatred for Western ways by joining a gym, playing football and never airing
extreme views.

But at the same time he was using his access to the airline's offices in
Newcastle and at Heathrow to spread confidential information.

After gaining a post-graduate job at BA in 2007, Karim held "John le
Carre"-style secret meetings with fellow Islamic extremists at Heathrow and, in
2009, began communicating with al-Awlaki from his home in Brunton Lane.

He also shared details of his BA contacts and communicated in code with JMB
supporters in Bangladesh.

Mr Justice Calvert-Smith set a sentencing date of March 18.

LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:  Rajib Karim

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: wm

                              All Rights Reserved

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            March 2, 2011 Wednesday

Pakistan police foil terror attack on parliament, arrest nine - sources

LENGTH: 466 words


Text of report by Munawer Azeem headlined "Terrorist gang planning attacks in
capital busted" published by Pakistani newspaper Dawn website on 2 March

Islamabad: A joint team of police and intelligence agencies has busted a
terrorist group comprising members of the banned Tehrik-i-Taleban Pakistan (TTP)
and some Afghan nationals, seizing 16kg of explosives, a rocket launcher and
pistols.

According to police sources, the group comprising 13 men from Parachinar, Bajaur
and Afghanistan includes the mastermind and facilitators and efforts were under
way to trace and their accomplices who were in the federal capital or likely to
arrive there.

The group had planned a terrorist attack on the Parliament House during a
session, the sources said.

Intelligence agencies and police got information in mid-February that the
group's members were coming to Islamabad and Rawalpindi and would scatter in
different localities.

In the third week of last month, the law-enforcement agencies intercepted their
phone calls and traced their location at Khana Bridge. A raid was conducted
immediately and nine people were held - Mohammad Zaka Kabli, Gul Shan, Humit
Jan, Ustand Zinda, Ziaullah, Raheem Jan, Murad Afghani, Gul Zammen and Ubaid
from Bajaur and Afghanistan.

During interrogation, they divulged that four more members of the group were due
in the capital.

The agencies and police mounted intelligence in and around the city, resulting
in the arrest in G-9 sector of Arshad, a key member of TTP's Parachinar chapter
and a close aide of the militants' area 'commander'.

The sources aid Arshad was the mastermind of the planned attack and the
explosives, rocket launcher and a pistol had been seized from him.

Later Zia, Gul Nabi and Hashim Khan were arrested. They were facilitators of the
group and responsible for providing vehicles and other supplies.

APP adds: Interior Minister Rehman Malik said on Tuesday [1 March] that the
law-enforcement agencies had arrested a high-profile terrorist who wanted to hit
Islamabad by rockets from the Margalla Hills.

He said the importance of the terrorist could be gauged from the fact that he
was operating in different areas of the country, including the capital.

He said that the arrested terrorist might be described as a handler or operator
because his record testified to his involvement in subversive activities.

The minister said that most members of the gang had been arrested while the
remaining one or two would be apprehended soon.

He said the investigation was likely to reveal more facts about the gang and its
activities. Mr Malik said there had been indications that some external powers
wanted to destabilize the country.

He said security in Islamabad had been tightened after the arrests.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 02 Mar 11

                                   Daily Star

                             March 3, 2011 Thursday
                                U.K. 1st Edition

'Terror attack' kills 2

BYLINE: by KEIR MUDIE

SECTION: NEWS; 04

LENGTH: 127 words


A GUNMAN who killed two US Airforce men on a bus in Germany yesterday could have
terrorist links.

Arif Uka, 21, from Kosovo, wounded another two servicemen in the shooting spree.

All four victims were based at RAF Lakenheath in Suffolk.

Uka was arrested after opening fire on a bus at Frankfurt airport yesterday
afternoon.

In Berlin, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said her sympathies were with the
victims and their families, and pledged to do everything in her power to
investigate the crime.

Ms Merkel added: "It is a terrible event."

A member of the US House Homeland Security Committee said the attack looked like
the work of terrorists.

Speaking in Washington DC, Patrick Meehan said he was still being briefed but
the early signs pointed to a terrorist attack.
